instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Operation Epic Manchago Maldocs Used for Infostealer Delivery
NVISO has detected malicious Excel documents delivering VBA-activated spreadsheets. In a blog post, researchers analyzed the campaign and the intricacies built into the maldocs discussed.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Operation Epic Manchago Maldocs Used for Infostealer Delivery
NVISO has detected malicious Excel documents delivering VBA-activated spreadsheets. In a blog post, researchers analyzed the campaign and the intricacies built into the maldocs discussed.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Infostealer




# Overview

NVISO detected malicious Excel documents in July 2020 that are able to deliver malware through VBA-activated spreadsheets. Unlike most malicious excel documents, these particular samples were created using EPPlus software. It is believed the campaign is being carried out by a single threat actor based on the number of samples provided to services such as VirusTotal. Additionally, delivery of payloads supports this theory. The lack of Office metadata led researchers to conclude the files were created in EPPlus as well as the uncompiled code contained within the spreadsheets. All of the sample maldocs contain a password protected VBA project. Efforts to recover the passwords were unsuccessful. A handful of samples were obtained and it was determined the VBA code will use either PowerShell or ActiveX to download the payload. These payloads are hosted on various websites. There is a common pattern to the second stage downloader. The stage 2 EXE loads a DLL. This DLL extracts and decodes steganography encoded images from the EXE. Finally, the DLL loads the stage 3 EXE. This is the final payload. These final stages included such malware as AgentTesla, Azorult, Formbook, Matiex, and njRAT. There does not appear to be a pattern in the targeting of victims. Further technical details can be found in the blog post contained within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.nviso.eu/2020/09/01/epic-manchego-atypical-maldoc-delivery-brings-flurry-of-infostealers/>

NVISO has detected malicious Excel documents delivering VBA-activated spreadsheets. In a blog post, researchers analyzed the campaign and the intricacies built into the maldocs discussed.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: DoJ Allows FBI Login to Exchange Server WebShells
In a ruling on April 13, 2021, the U.S. Department of Justice (DoJ) allowed the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) to log into exploited Microsoft Exchange Servers in order to disrupt and remove web shells providing backdoor access to the servers.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

According to multiple sources, including the DoJ, the FBI has been permitted to log into, copy, and remove malicious web shells from vulnerable Microsoft Exchange Servers. Throughout January and February 2021, threat actors have been exploiting a zero-day vulnerability in an effort to gain access to these servers. The vulnerability allowed for the installation of web shells for continued access. Although many owners of the vulnerable servers were able to remove the web shells, many more still appear to be vulnerable to this zero-day exploit. Some of the vulnerable server owners attempted to remove the web shells but were, ultimately, unsuccessful. The FBI then conducted the removal by issuing a command through the web shell to delete only the web shell itself as identified by its unique file path. This action did not include the patching of the servers in question but only the removal of the malicious web shells. Officials from the DoJ and FBI are urging owners to patch the affected systems immediately by reviewing Microsoft's remediation guide published in March in a Joint Advisory. Many security sources are urging owners to not only patch vulnerable systems but to remove any web shells left behind. Further details can be found in the links located within the Reference section below.

# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.justice.gov/usao-sdtx/pr/justice-department-announces-court-authorized-effort-disrupt-exploitation-microsoft>

  * <https://therecord.media/fbi-operation-removed-web-shells-from-hacked-exchange-servers-across-the-us/>
  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/nsa-discovers-critical-exchange-server-vulnerabilities-patch-now/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: NCAS Malware Analysis Report AR20-239B - VIVACIOUSGIFT
A Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) malware analysis report, AR20-239B, has been published through the National Cyber Awareness System. The report is a joint publication from Department of Homeland Security, the Federal Bureau of Investigation, and the Department of Defense. The report provides information on the North Korean network proxy tool, VIVACIOUSGIFT.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, APT




# Overview

 **From the Malware Analysis Report (AR20-239B)**  
 **MAR-10301706-2.v1 - North Korean Remote Access Tool: VIVACIOUSGIFT**

  


This Malware Analysis Report (MAR) is the result of analytic efforts between the Department of Homeland Security (DHS), the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), and the Department of Defense (DoD). Working with U.S. Government partners, DHS, FBI, and DoD identified Remote Access Tool (RAT) malware variants used by the North Korean government. This malware variant has been identified as VIVACIOUSGIFT. The U.S. Government refers to malicious cyber activity by the North Korean government as HIDDEN COBRA. For more information on HIDDEN COBRA activity, visit https://www.us-cert.gov/hiddencobra.

FBI has high confidence that HIDDEN COBRA actors are using malware variants in conjunction with proxy servers to maintain a presence on victim networks and to further network exploitation. DHS, FBI, and DoD are distributing this MAR to enable network defense and reduce exposure to North Korean government malicious cyber activity.

This MAR includes malware descriptions related to HIDDEN COBRA, suggested response actions and recommended mitigation techniques. Users or administrators should flag activity associated with the malware and report the activity to the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) or the FBI Cyber Watch (CyWatch), and give the activity the highest priority for enhanced mitigation.

This report looks at the malware samples known as VIVACIOUSGIFT that is used by advanced persistent threat (APT) cyber actors as a network proxy tool. The proxy requires an encrypted command line argument for its source and destination Internet Protocol (IP) addresses and has command and control (C2) functionality to retrieve and set the destination IP. The command line argument can also contain a source proxy IP, port, and password. The source proxy is used as an additional proxy when communicating with the source IP. The library libcurl version 7.94.1 is used when communicating with the source proxy.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. for Yara Rules.



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar20-239b>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: P.A.S. Fork v. 1.0
A blog from Sucuri has an analysis of the P.A.S. Fork V. 1.0, a PHP web shell that originally appeared in 2013.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: P.A.S. Fork v. 1.0
A blog from Sucuri has an analysis of the P.A.S. Fork V. 1.0, a PHP web shell that originally appeared in 2013.

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Sucuri has published a blog with information on P.A.S. Fork V 1.0. A version of the PHP web shell has been making the rounds since at least late 2016 when DHS and the FBI issued a joint report (linked below) on the malware with several IoCs for detection of the web shell. The initial version of the web shell was retired in 2013 due to accusations made against the authors of the shell. The latest variant was first seen in January 2020 in a new thread on a forum. Interest in the P.A.S. web shell was renewed after disclosure of new capabilities. These capabilities were mainly related to evasion tactics to avoid detection from web application firewalls and IDS systems. First verifiable usage of the new version came in March 2020 on a compromised website. Other changes included a different packer/obfuscator and the addition of random ASCII characters, which makes the PHP code difficult to read without proper editing tools. By removing the added strings, analysis could more easily be performed. Other modifications exist and can be seen by comparing older versions with the newest in a side-by-side editor. Backdoor commands are contained within the attacker's HTTP request as cookies. Hash values are set to facilitate obfuscation and are applied to a string containing the server IP and backdoor file. Hashed passwords can also be encoded. Further details can be found in the blog post located within the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * N/A




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://blog.sucuri.net/2020/10/p-a-s-fork-v-1-0-a-web-shell-revival.html>

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/sites/default/files/publications/JAR_16-20296A_GRIZZLY%20STEPPE-2016-1229.pdf>

A blog from Sucuri has an analysis of the P.A.S. Fork V. 1.0, a PHP web shell that originally appeared in 2013.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Adobe Document Cloud Phishing Campaign
Document sharing services are increasingly being impersonated in order to harvest credentials. In one such case analyzed by Cofense in a recent blog post, Adobe Document Cloud is the targeted service.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

Cofense has published a blog post analyzing a phishing email using an Adobe Document Cloud lure. The email originates from a Gmail account and claims to be from a government agency, providing legitimate contact details to support this. Attached, is what the body of the email states, is a purchase order that can be accessed via Adobe Document Cloud login or by downloading the latest version of Adobe Acrobat Reader, hoping they'll opt for the easier login choice. Opening the attachment results in an HTML page stored locally that gathers its resources from the legitimate Adobe website. After bypassing a popup stating that the document is electronically encrypted and requires the recipient to log in with their email to view, they are directed to a fake Adobe Document Cloud sign in page. Any submitted credentials are exfiltrated to a remote URL controlled by the attacker. Finally, the victim is redirected to the legitimate Adobe Acrobat webpage. For more information, see the Cofense blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://cofense.com/document-sharing-services-represent-a-vector-for-phishing-campaigns/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: K-Electric in Pakistan Suffers Netwalker Ransomware Attack
Breach / Leak Notification: An electricity provider in Pakistan, K-Electric, has suffered a Netwalker ransomware attack. According to a media report the, the attack has impacted online services, including billing.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: K-Electric in Pakistan Suffers Netwalker Ransomware Attack
Breach / Leak Notification: An electricity provider in Pakistan, K-Electric, has suffered a Netwalker ransomware attack. According to a media report the, the attack has impacted online services, including billing.

# Threat Type

  * Breach/Leak 




# Overview

  
K-Electric, the sole electricity provider for Karachi, Pakistan, has suffered a Netwalker ransomware attack that led to the disruption of billing and online services. K-Electric is Pakistan's largest power supplier, serving 2.5 million customers and employing over 10 thousand people. Starting yesterday, K-Electric customers have been unable to access the online services for their account.

# Reference

  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/netwalker-ransomware-hits-pakistans-largest-private-power-utility/>

K-Electric in Pakistan Suffers Netwalker Ransomware Attack

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Campaign Targeting Cryptocurrency Users
Intezer discovered a campaign targeting cryptocurrency users that they estimate began in early 2020. A new RAT associated with the campaign has been named ElectroRAT by Intezer. It is written in Golang and can run on Linux, MacOS, and Windows.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

A campaign that targets cryptocurrency users was discovered by Intezer in late 2020. Intezer estimates the campaign began around January 2020. Three Trojanized applications (DaoPoker, eTrade, and Jamm) built using the Electron framework are used in the campaign to deliver a RAT that has been named ElectroRAT by Intezer. The applications have been promoted through fake user accounts on social media and online forums that focus on cryptocurrency, and are hosted on websites created for the campaign. ElectroRAT uses raw Pastebin pages to determine its C&C address and Intezer estimates, from the number of pages views, that there may be several thousand victims. While ElectroRAT can log keystrokes, take screenshots, upload and download files, and execute commands, its primary goal is to obtain access to the victim's crypto wallets. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.intezer.com/blog/research/operation-electrorat-attacker-creates-fake-companies-to-drain-your-crypto-wallets/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: HabitsRAT Used to Target Linux and Windows Servers
HabitsRAT is a simple backdoor identified to be targeting Microsoft Exchange servers by exploiting the ProxyLogon vulnerability. Intezer has discovered newer Windows variants as well as a Linux variant.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, RAT




Overview

Intezer published a blog post analyzing the HabitsRAT backdoor, which was previously observed exploiting the ProxyLogon vulnerability. With their discovery, they also found a Linux variant of the malware, although the exploit leveraged to deliver this version is unknown. The malware is written in Go, allowing the same main code base to be shared between the variants with separate files to handle operating system-specific code. Once on the system, it attempts to establish persistence via a systemd unit file on Linux or a scheduled task on Windows. C2 communication is rather sophisticated as it uses public-key cryptography for encryption and authentication. The C2 server is polled every 10 seconds to check whether a command should be executed. Along with version 11 of the malware, a version 12 was found for Windows, with a different C2 public key in use and support for multiple C2 addresses. For more information, see the Intezer blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://www.intezer.com/blog/malware-analysis/habitsrat-used-to-target-linux-and-windows-servers/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: An Egregor Ransomware Profile
A report from Malwarebytes Labs provides a profile of the Egregor ransomware which was first observed in September 2020. Egregor is reportedly a variant of the Sekhmet ransomware.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Ransomware




# Overview

As the Egregor ransomware-as-a-service (RaaS) operation emerged, Maze affiliates began migrating to it. Some high profile attacks of large organizations have already been attributed to Egregor. Due to Egregor being ransomware-as-a-service with multiple affiliates the methods of Egregor distribution can vary. According to Malwarebytes Labs, the primary method is through comprising hosts by various means and installing Cobalt Strike which is ultimately used to deliver the Egregor payload. Other methods observed include phishing emails which deliver Qakbot and then Egregor installed manually by the attacker. Malwarebytes Labs also notes that there are reports of vulnerabilities in Microsoft's Exchange and VBScript Engine, and Adobe Flash Player, being used to compromise targets. Once a foothold inside a target is attained, the attackers will carry out a number of actions including, attempting to move laterally, identifying the high value systems, exfiltrating data, and finally executing the Egregor payload. While the ransom note provides details and a timeframe for paying the ransom (3 days) it also offers to provide information on the victim's security, such as how the initial breach occurred, etc. As is common in ransomware now, there is also the threat that if the ransom is not paid, the victim's sensitive data will be published. Further details are available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.malwarebytes.com/ransomware/2020/12/threat-profile-egregor-ransomware-is-making-a-name-for-itself/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Docker Images Used To Target Russian Websites With Denial Of Service
Crowdstrike has published a report describing how Docker Engine images are being used to stage a DoS attack on Russian websites. The target list implies that this is a pro-Ukrainian attack.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Denial Of Service
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Unknown
  *  **Targets:** Russia, Lithuania, Belarus
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Compromise of Exposed Docker API
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** DoS Attack



# Overview

Crowdstrike has been tracking a DoS threat being spread using Docker Engine images. This was originally discovered as the researcher's honeypot was compromised using the exposed Docker Engine API. The first malicious image deployed contained a Go-based HTTP benchmarking tool that can be used to stress-test a website. This was used to stage a DoS attack which starts automatically when a new container based on the image is created. The target is randomly picked from a hard-coded list. This image was updated in March to include a much wider target list across Russia, Belarus, and Lithuania. The second image works similarly, but uses a different DoS program named 'stoppropoganda' and is custom-made. Both images are hosted on Docker Hub and have over one hundred thousand downloads - although the number of downloads to compromised infrastructure is unknown. For more information, please see the link in the reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://www.crowdstrike.com/blog/compromised-docker-honeypots-used-for-pro-ukrainian-dos-attack/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1608.001 - Upload Malware  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1610 - Deploy Container  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1498 - Network Denial of Service  
  


#### Mitigations:

  
 **M1016:** Vulnerability Scanning - Vulnerability scanning is used to find potentially exploitable software vulnerabilities to remediate them.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1035:** Limit Access to Resource Over Network - Prevent access to file shares, remote access to systems, unnecessary services. Mechanisms to limit access may include use of network concentrators, RDP gateways, etc.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1048:** Application Isolation and Sandboxing - Restrict execution of code to a virtual environment on or in transit to an endpoint system.  
 **M1050:** Exploit Protection - Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
 **M1056:** Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Facefish Rootkit Analysis
Following on from a Juniper blog posting on a malware sample, 360 Netlab provides further technical details and names the malware Facefish.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Rootkit




# Overview

Facefish is described by 360 Netlab as a Linux rootkit that consists of a dropper and the rootkit module that runs at Ring 3. Facefish was previously reported by Juniper in April but the report did not provide a name for the malware. According to 360 Netlab, the dropper has over time been used to install a number of different rootkits. Facefish has been distributed through exploiting a vulnerability in the "Control Web Panel" application. The Juniper report provides some details on the vulnerabilities in Control Web Panel. The rootkit is loaded using LD_PRELOAD and hooks into the OpenSSH server process which allows the attacker to obtain user login credentials. Facefish also provides backdoor access to an infected system. The credentials and system information are uploaded to Facefish's C&C server using an encrypted communication protocol, which is detailed in both the Juniper and 360 Netlab articles. The links to both reports are contained in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.netlab.360.com/ssh_stealer_facefish_en/>

  * <https://blogs.juniper.net/en-us/threat-research/linux-servers-hijacked-to-implant-ssh-backdoor>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: The Gelsemium Cyberespionage Group
Gelsemium is believed to be a cyberespionage group that has been operating since 2014, and possibly earlier. An ESET report provides information on the TTPs associated with Gelsemium.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Cyberespionage




# Overview

A report from ESET provides information on the Gelsemium group, believed to be involved in cyberespionage. The group has been operating since at least 2014. The group's targets include electronics manufacturers, governments, religious organizations, and universities, located in East Asia and the Middle East, and in the past, Taiwan. The group has only attacked a small number of victims. Gelsemium's toolkit includes its own malware which ESET has named Gelsemine, Gelsenicine, and Gelsevirine. Other malware known to have been used by the group includes Chrommme and OwlProxy. Gelsemine is a first-stage dropper that contains multiple binaries used in further stages. Gelsenicine is a loader that retrieves and executes the next stage, Gelsevirine, which is the last stage of the chain. ESET notes that recently, Gelsemium exploited an Exchange server vulnerability to install the ChinaChopper webshell, which was later used to execute the first stage dropper, Gelsemine. It is unclear which Exchange server vulnerability was exploited but ESET believes it may be CVE-2020-0688. A notable tactic employed by Gelsemium is the use of Dynamic DNS (DDNS) domain names for its C&C servers. Further details are available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.welivesecurity.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/eset_gelsemium.pdf>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Necro Botnet Exploits Vulnerable Visual Tools DVR
The Necro Python botnet appeared on the threat landscape in January 2020, exploiting vulnerable services to run a polymorphic script on Windows and Linux hosts. Juniper published a blog post analyzing the most recent version of the payload.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Botnet
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Necro
  *  **Targets:** Visual Tools DVR
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Exploitation of vulnerable services
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Execute bot commands, install Monero miner



# Overview

Juniper published a blog post analyzing recent Necro botnet activity and changes to its payload. In terms of initial infection, Necro continues to exploit vulnerabilities in various devices, such as TerraMaster and Genexis products, as well as exploiting a new vulnerability in Visual Tools DVR. Once on a system, the bot connects to its C2 using a domain generation algorithm in combination with dynamic DNS services. Commands can be issued via IRC and provide capabilities such as port scanning, killing and executing processes, downloading additional payloads, and performing denial-of-service attacks. Juniper researchers also observed Monero miners being installed during the exploitation of Visual Tools DVR. For more information, see the Juniper blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [Necro Botnet Exploits Vulnerable VisualTools DVR IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64130286/Necro%20Botnet%20Exploits%20Vulnerable%20VisualTools%20DVR%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1634153745921&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).



# References

  * <https://blogs.juniper.net/en-us/threat-research/necro-python-botnet-goes-after-vulnerable-visualtools-dvr>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.006 - Python  
T1059.007 - JavaScript  
T1203 - Exploitation for Client Execution  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1014 - Rootkit  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1568 - Dynamic Resolution  
T1568.002 - Domain Generation Algorithms  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1498 - Network Denial of Service

Tell me about the following threat: Commodity .NET Packers use Embedded Images to Hide Payloads
Packers are used by attackers to evade antivirus detection and sandboxes while delivering malicious payloads. Proofpoint examines two examples of .NET packers that use embedded images in particular to hide payloads.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Commodity .NET Packers use Embedded Images to Hide Payloads
Packers are used by attackers to evade antivirus detection and sandboxes while delivering malicious payloads. Proofpoint examines two examples of .NET packers that use embedded images in particular to hide payloads.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Packer




# Overview

Proofpoint published their analysis of two commodity .NET packers that leverage steganography to distribute payloads. The first, dubbed "CyaX," is delivered as a .NET executable with a PNG image in its resources. When the image is decoded using Blue, Green, Red, and Alpha (BGRA) channels, a secondary executable is revealed. This secondary executable also contains a .NET resource, often packed with ConfuserEx or .NET Reactor, that can be decoded to reveal the final payload. Two additional variants are discussed: one which uses Red, Green, and Blue (RGB) channels instead of BGRA and compresses the immediate executable with gzip, and one that uses proper steganography against a secondary PNG image. The samples they analyzed were seen either dropping the Agent Tesla malware or Remcos RAT. The second packer analyzed, Hectobmp, contains several hundreds of images in the .NET resources, each of which contains part of the payload. Previously the images were stored in BMP file format, but more recent versions use PNG. Once decoded using RGB channels and reassembled in the correct order, a zlib Deflate compressed payload is dropped on the system. In this case, decoding the payload revealed an Agent Tesla sample. For more information, see the Proofpoint article in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.proofpoint.com/us/blog/threat-insight/commodity-net-packers-use-embedded-images-hide-payloads>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Dridex Affiliate Using COVID and Job Termination Lures
Researchers at Malwarebytes uncovered a Dridex affiliate leveraging job termination and COVID test result lures to deliver their payload.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Loader
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Dridex affiliate
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Dridex
  *  **Targets:** Unknown 
  * **Initial Infection Vector:** Malicious email attachment
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Install additional malware



# Overview

Malwarebytes published a blog post analyzing a recent Dridex campaign. The affiliate behind this activity had two different lures attempting to get victims to open a malicious attachment. The first version claims that the attached file is a termination letter, while the other uses fake COVID Omicron variant test results as a lure. In either case, users are enticed to open the attached Excel file using a provided password. The use of password protection on the file allows for sandbox evasion. If the user opens the file and enables macros, an RTF file is written and executed, ultimately leading to the Dridex payload being downloaded from a Discord server. When running on the system, Dridex allows its operator to install secondary malicious payloads, such as ransomware. For more information, see the Malwarebytes blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74056498/Dridex%20Affiliate%20Using%20COVID%20and%20Job%20Termination%20Lures%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1640893643480&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).



# References

  * <https://blog.malwarebytes.com/threat-intelligence/2021/12/dridex-affiliate-dresses-up-as-scrooge/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1588 - Obtain Capabilities  
T1588.001 - Malware  
T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
T1608.001 - Upload Malware  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.005 - Visual Basic  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1218 - Signed Binary Proxy Execution  
T1218.005 - Mshta  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Vulnerable WordPress Sites Used To DDoS Ukrainian Targets
BleepingComputer has reported on the discovery of several WordPress sites which contain a malicious script. When accessed by a user, the script is run and the browser is used to stage a DDoS attack. Details have been published in a report.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** DDoS
  *  **Targets:** Ukrainian Websites
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** WordPress Vulnerabilities
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** DDoS Attack



# Overview

Browsers are being used as part of an ongoing DDoS attack, BleepingComputer has reported. The attackers have compromised several WordPress sites using known vulnerabilities. With this, they have implanted a JavaScript file that runs when the site is loaded. The script forces the browser to make many connections to a hardcoded website, intending to degrade the service of the website. The sites targeted by the script include Ukrainian government agencies, think tanks, financial sites, and other pro-Ukrainian sites. Upon further analysis, the researchers found the same script being used by a pro-Ukrainian site to target Russian websites. The difference in this use of the script is that the website is transparent about the use of the script whereas on the compromised WordPress sites the user wouldn't know the script is running in the background. The script uses a random query string in the request to avoid anti-DDoS services and get to the actual target server. For more information please see the link in the reference section.

# Recommendations

For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

# References

  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/hacked-wordpress-sites-force-visitors-to-ddos-ukrainian-targets/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059.007 - JavaScript  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1489 - Service Stop  
T1498 - Network Denial of Service  
  


#### Mitigations:

  
 **M1016:** Vulnerability Scanning - Vulnerability scanning is used to find potentially exploitable software vulnerabilities to remediate them.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1024:** Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1048:** Application Isolation and Sandboxing - Restrict execution of code to a virtual environment on or in transit to an endpoint system.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1050:** Exploit Protection - Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: NCAS Malware Analysis Report AR21-055A
A Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency malware analysis report, AR21-055A, has been published through the National Cyber Awareness System. The report provides information on the webshell which is designed to be uploaded to an Accellion File Transfer Appliance (FTA) server.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: NCAS Malware Analysis Report AR21-055A
A Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency malware analysis report, AR21-055A, has been published through the National Cyber Awareness System. The report provides information on the webshell which is designed to be uploaded to an Accellion File Transfer Appliance (FTA) server.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Webshell




# Overview

This Malware Analysis Report (MAR) analyzes a malicious Hypertext Preprocessor (PHP) webshell file submitted to CISA for analysis. The webshell is designed to be uploaded to an Accellion File Transfer Appliance (FTA) server, a secure file transfer application used by customers to send large files. The webshell leverages a Structured Query Language (SQL) injection vulnerability to install itself onto the impacted FTA server. The webshell provides threat actors with the ability to locate files, obtain file metadata, and download files stored on the Accellion FTA server.

This webshell has been used in recent cyberattacks targeting users of Accellion FTA. For more information on these attacks, refer to Joint Cybersecurity Advisory AA21-055A.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 
  * IoCs can also be download in STIX format from CISA: <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/sites/default/files/publications/MAR-10325064.r1.v1.WHITE_stix.xml>



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-055a>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Zeoticus 2.0 Ransomware
Researchers recently discovered a new version of the Zeoticus ransomware. SentinelOne has published a blog post analyzing this ransomware family and the newest samples.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Ransomware




# Overview

SentinelOne published a blog post analyzing the Zeoticus ransomware, specifically focusing on the recently discovered version 2.0. The ransomware is sold on underground forums as a custom build for Windows Operating Systems. Unlike many modern ransomware families, Zeoticus does not contain any C2 mechanisms, allowing for it to run fully offline. Based on forum postings, the update to Zeoticus focuses on increasing speed and efficiency of the encryption processes. Additionally, the ability to target specific file extensions was added. Like most ransomware, the infection chain begins with processes that could interfere with encryption being killed. Zeoticus also covers its track by deleting its own binaries using the ping utility. As with previous versions, persistence continues to be established via a Registry Run key. While version 1.0 of the ransomware used a desktop wallpaper to provide the ransom note, this version mounts a new volume containing the note in an HTML file. Victims are requested to email the operators for further instructions. For more information, see the SentinelOne blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://labs.sentinelone.com/zeoticus-2-0-ransomware-with-no-c2-required/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: New FiveHands Ransomware Variant
During an incident investigation, NCC Group researchers discovered a new FiveHands ransomware variant. Their blog post provides an overview of the attack chain and payload.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Ransomware




# Overview

NCC Group published a blog post analyzing a new variant of the FiveHands ransomware, and its associated infection chain. Initial access is gained by exploiting a public-facing SonicWall VPN appliance to create a VPN profile. Once on the network, the attacker installs a series of publicly-available tools including port scanners for network reconnaissance. Additionally, the password recovery tool AllInOnePasswordRecoveryPro, was used to steal credentials. A remote desktop software, Remote Utilities, was leveraged for GUI-based C2 access, and for data exfiltration, the legitimate pCloud cloud storage service was used. To actor used PsExec to execute a Go-based program loader with command line options for skipping files of certain sizes. In addition, the loader can encrypt specific file paths using RSA or AES, and specify whether to perform full or partial encryption. For more information, see the NCC Group blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://research.nccgroup.com/2021/06/15/handy-guide-to-a-new-fivehands-ransomware-variant/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Gravity RAT Returns as Chat Application
Gravity is an Android RAT that can provide threat actors the ability to steal sensitive data from victim devices. Cyble reports on a recently discovered sample masquerading as a messaging application.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Gravity RAT Returns as Chat Application
Gravity is an Android RAT that can provide threat actors the ability to steal sensitive data from victim devices. Cyble reports on a recently discovered sample masquerading as a messaging application.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** RAT
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Gravity
  *  **Targets:** Android users 
  * **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data theft



# Overview

Cyble published a blog post analyzing a recent Gravity RAT sample masquerading as a secure chat application named "SoSafe Chat." At this time, the initial infection vector is unknown but the application is likely distributed via phishing links or a compromised site. Once on a device, the malware obtains various permissions that will ultimately allow the operator to steal sensitive data, such as SMS messages, call logs, audio, and system information. A hard-coded C2 address is used for communication and exfiltration of data. Within the source code, the researchers observed a domain name that led to a website advertising the messaging application. The download links on the site, however, were disabled so it is not currently the distribution source of the payload. For more information, see the Cyble blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/70222505/Gravity%20RAT%20Returns%20as%20Chat%20Application%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1636998301767&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Install security updates (M1001).
  * Users should be encouraged to only install apps from authorized app stores, which are less likely to contain malicious repackaged apps (M1011).
  * Implement an enterprise mobility management (EMM), also known as mobile device management (MDM) (M1012).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques (M1017).
  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.



# References

  * <https://blog.cyble.com/2021/11/11/gravity-rat-malware-returns-as-a-chat-application/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0027**

T1444 - Masquerade as Legitimate Application

 **Execution - TA0041**

T1575 - Native Code

 **Persistence - TA0028**

T1402 - Broadcast Receivers 

**Collection - TA0035**

T1412 - Capture SMS Messages

T1429 - Capture Audio

T1432 - Access Contact List

T1433 - Access Call Log

T1533 - Data from Local System  


 **Command and Control - TA0037**

T1436 - Commonly Used Port

T1437 - Standard Application Layer Protocol  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0036**

T1436 - Commonly Used Port

T1437 - Standard Application Layer Protocol

 **Impact - TA0034**

T1400 - Modify System Permissions

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Critical GitLab Vulnerability Exploited In The Wild
GitLab have published details on a critical vulnerability which would allow an attacker to execute arbitrary code. This is patched, but research shows a large number of unpatched instances accessible online.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Vulnerability
  *  **Targets:** GitLab Instances
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Exploitation of Public Facing Application
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Unknown 



# Overview

GitLab published a security release on April 14, 2021, to address a critical remote code execution vulnerability in the service's web interface. The vulnerability was originally identified by GitLab as an authenticated vulnerability caused by passing user-supplied photos to the service's embedded version of ExifTool. ExifTool's mishandling of the files could allow a remote attacker to run arbitrary commands as the git user. Since being published, the vulnerability has been upgraded to critical, as it has become clear that authentication is not required to exploit it. There have since been multiple exploits for CVE-2021-22205 published, and it is being actively exploited in the wild. Patches for the GitLab vulnerability have been available for over six months. However, an examination of GitLab instances that are accessible via the internet indicates that a significant proportion are still susceptible. GitLab users should update to the most recent version as soon as possible. Furthermore, GitLab should ideally not be an internet-facing service. Consider putting your GitLab behind a VPN if you need to access it from the internet. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/70221996/Critical%20GitLab%20Vulnerability%20Exploited%20In%20The%20Wild%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1636386402028&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Web Application Firewalls may be used to limit exposure of applications to prevent exploit traffic from reaching the application (M1050).



# References

  * <https://www.rapid7.com/blog/post/2021/11/01/gitlab-unauthenticated-remote-code-execution-cve-2021-22205-exploited-in-the-wild/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.004 - Exploits  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: SAP Security Patches – November 2020
On Tuesday November 10th, 2020, SAP issued 12 security notes for various products. Three of the notes were for previously released patches.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerabilities




# Overview

Tuesday, November 10th, 2020, brought a host of security notes to various SAP products. In all, twelve security notes were released with 3 of those being updates to previously released patch security notes. Of the twelve, 6 were rated as "Hot News" with CVSS ratings ranging from 9 to 10, 3 were rated as high with CVSS ratings from 7.5 to 8.6, the remainder were rated as medium with CVSS ratings from 4.3 to 6.5. Few other details were released in the security notes compilation. A list of the vulnerabilities is below. We recommend applying applicable patches as soon as possible.

## Affected Products and Corresponding Vulnerabilities

  * [Multiple CVE IDs] Missing Authentication Check in SAP Solution Manager (JAVA stack)  
CVE IDs - CVE-2020-26821, CVE-2020-26822, CVE-2020-26823, CVE-2020-26824  
Product - SAP Solution Manager (JAVA stack), Version - 7.2
  * Update to security note released on March 2020 Patch Day:  
[CVE-2020-6207] Missing Authentication Check in SAP Solution Manager  
Product - SAP Solution Manager (User Experience Monitoring), Version - 7.2
  * Multiple Vulnerabilities in SAP Data Services  
Related CVEs - CVE-2019-0230, CVE-2019-0233  
Product - SAP Data Services, Versions - 4.2 Hot News 9.8
  * [CVE-2020-26808] Code Injection in SAP AS ABAP and S/4 HANA (DMIS)  
Product - SAP AS ABAP(DMIS), Versions - 2011_1_620, 2011_1_640, 2011_1_700, 2011_1_710, 2011_1_730, 2011_1_731, 2011_1_752, 2020  
Product - SAP S4 HANA(DMIS), Versions - 101, 102, 103, 104, 105 Hot News 9.1
  * [CVE-2020-26820] Privilege escalation in SAP NetWeaver Application Server for Java (UDDI Server)  
Product - SAP NetWeaver AS JAVA, Versions - 7.20, 7.30, 7.31, 7.40, 7.50
  * Update to security note released on August 2020 Patch Day:  
[CVE-2020-6284] Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) in SAP NetWeaver (Knowledge Management)  
Product - SAP NetWeaver (Knowledge Management); Versions - 7.30, 7.31, 7.40, 7.50
  * [CVE-2020-26815] Security Vulnerabilities in SAP Fiori Launchpad (NewsTile Application)  
Additional CVE ID - CVE-2020-26825  
Product - SAP Fiori Launchpad (News Tile Application), Versions - 750,751,752,753,754,755
  * [CVE-2020-26809] Information Disclosure in SAP Commerce Cloud  
Product - SAP Commerce Cloud, Versions - 1808,1811,1905,2005
  * [CVE-2020-26810] Multiple Vulnerabilities in SAP Commerce Cloud (Accelerator Payment Mock)  
Additional CVE ID - CVE-2020-26811  
Product - SAP Commerce Cloud (Accelerator Payment Mock), Versions - 1808, 1811, 1905, 2005
  * [CVE-2020-26818] Multiple vulnerabilities in SAP NetWeaver AS ABAP (Web Dynpro)  
Additional CVE ID - CVE-2020-26819  
Product - SAP NetWeaver AS ABAP, Versions - 731, 740, 750, 751, 752, 753, 754, 755, 782
  * Update to security note released on September 2020 Patch Day:  
[CVE-2020-6311] Improper Authorization Checks in Banking services from SAP Bank Analyzer and SAP S/4HANA Financial Products  
Product - BANKING SERVICES FROM SAP 9.0(Bank Analyzer), Version - 500  
Product - S/4HANA FIN PROD SUBLDGR, Version - 100
  * [CVE-2020-26814] Information Disclosure in SAP Process Integration (PGP Module – Business-to-Business Add On)  
Product - SAP Process Integration (PGP Module – Business-to-Business Add On), Version - 1.0
  * [CVE-2020-26807] Incorrect Default Permissions in SAP ERP Client for E-Bilanz 1.0  
Product - SAP ERP Client for E-Bilanz 1.0, Version - 1.0
  * [CVE-2020-6316] Missing Authorization Check in SAP ERP and SAP S/4 HANA  
Product - SAP ERP, Versions - 600, 602, 603, 604, 605, 606, 616, 617, 618  
Product - SAP S/4 HANA, Versions - 100, 101, 102, 103, 104
  * [CVE-2020-26817] Improper input validation in Visual Enterprise Viewer  
Product - SAP 3D Visual Enterprise Viewer, Versions - 9



# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs is available here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/33982249/SAP%20Security%20Patches%20%E2%80%93%20November%202020%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1605125160323&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://wiki.scn.sap.com/wiki/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=562725571>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Pirate Bay Clones Serve Malicious Ads And Fake Torrents
CyberNews researchers have been monitoring sites impersonating the Pirate Bay. These sites use malicious advertising and false torrents to spread malicious javascript which can be used to spy on victims and steal data.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Pirate Bay Clones Serve Malicious Ads And Fake Torrents
CyberNews researchers have been monitoring sites impersonating the Pirate Bay. These sites use malicious advertising and false torrents to spread malicious javascript which can be used to spy on victims and steal data.

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malvertising
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malicious Ads
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Advertisement, Spying



# Overview

CyberNews security researchers have discovered a series of websites impersonating The Pirate Bay - a popular website for torrenting pirated media. These sites serve malicious adverts which are being used to distribute malicious files. The researchers discovered five of these impersonation domains, with one of these seeing more than six million monthly visitors. All of these sites have not been flagged in tools such as VirusTotal. All of these fake sites layer malicious adverts on the page meaning that if the user clicks anywhere on the page, they could trigger three or more. On top of these adverts, the torrent files being distributed were found to be potentially malicious JavaScript files. The site generates these files using the victim's query, automatically renaming them to fit whatever the user is searching for. The resulting download contains scripts that can spy on the user and serve them intrusive and potentially malicious adverts. For more information, please see the link in the reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74058542/Pirate%20Bay%20Clones%20Serve%20Malicious%20Ads%20And%20Fake%20Torrents%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1644598060018&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021)
  * Set PowerShell execution policy to execute only signed scripts (M1045).



# References

  * <https://cybernews.com/security/the-pirate-bay-clones-target-millions-of-users-with-malware-and-malicious-ads/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583.001 - Domains  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1189 - Drive-by Compromise  
T1566.002 - Spearphishing Link  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059.007 - JavaScript  
T1204.001 - Malicious Link

  * Set PowerShell execution policy to execute only signed scripts (M1045).



# References

  * <https://cybernews.com/security/the-pirate-bay-clones-target-millions-of-users-with-malware-and-malicious-ads/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583.001 - Domains  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1189 - Drive-by Compromise  
T1566.002 - Spearphishing Link  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059.007 - JavaScript  
T1204.001 - Malicious Link

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Introducing Ghimob Malware for Android
IBM's Security Intelligence has published a blog post detailing a new Android malware strain dubbed 'Ghimob'.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Introducing Ghimob Malware for Android
IBM's Security Intelligence has published a blog post detailing a new Android malware strain dubbed 'Ghimob'.

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

A new malware strain, dubbed 'Ghimob', has emerged as a third-party mobile app. The app, often banking-themed, can steal user data and act as spyware when downloaded and installed. As of the end of 2020, Ghimob is believed to have siphoned data from more than 153 apps by requesting accessibility permissions and debugger checks. The app has the ability to search for banking apps and, subsequently, steal money while another app covers the nefarious actions. The group behind the malware uses email or malicious site redirects to websites promoting Android apps. The emails contain a link which takes the user to an authentic-looking app. The malware messages the C2 server containing phone data and then steals sensitive information. Some of the apps mimicked include Google Defender, Google Docs, WhatsApp Updater, and Flash Update. Most of the finance apps are those of banks and cryptocurrency exchanges based in Brazil, Germany, Portugal, Peru, Paraguay, Angola, and Mozambique. Further information can be found in the blog post located within the Reference section below.

# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://securityintelligence.com/articles/what-is-ghimob-malware/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Android Trojans Stealing Facebook Logins
Researchers with Doctor Web uncovered several Android apps on the Google Play store that were Trojanized in order to steal Facebook login credentials.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Trojan




# Overview

Doctor Web published a blog post analyzing a series of Trojanized Android applications designed to steal Facebook login credentials. In total, ten apps were discovered with nine of those present in the Google Play store. The types of apps varied from photo editing tools to device performance utilities and more. All of the apps included legitimate code, allowing them to function as expected and thus decrease the chances of a user getting suspicious. Malicious code was injected into the app, however, to encourage the users to login to the app using Facebook in order to gain full functionality and remove ads. If a user opts to log in to Facebook, the legitimate Facebook login page is loaded, but JavaScript is used to capture and exfiltrate any submitted credentials and cookies. Doctor Web reported their findings to the Google Play store, but at the time of writing some of the apps remain active. For more information, see the Doctor Web blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://news.drweb.com/show/?i=14244>

Ukraine detected an attack against the system used for the circulation of documents in most public authorities. The threat actor, believed to be from the Russian Federation, attempted to spread malicious documents containing a macro that downloads and installs a remote access trojan.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, RAT, Data Theft, Backdoor




# Overview

The National Coordination Center for Cybersecurity under the National Security and Defense Council of Ukraine detected a cyberattack against the System of Electronic Interaction of Executive Bodies (SEI EB), a system used for the circulation of documents in most public authorities. The threat actor is believed to be a hacker spy group from the Russian Federation. instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: SharePoint as a Target
SenseCy's new article questions whether SharePoint is becoming the new "go-to" target of threat actors.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability



# Overview

SenseCy's article states that SharePoint servers are a ripe entry point for attackers. In a number of cases, these servers are part of the company's Active Directory service and are exposed to the Internet. According to the article, CVE-2019-0604 (Microsoft SharePoint code execution) was one of the ten most exploited vulnerabilities between 2016 and 2019. The article questions as to whether CVE-2020-1147 (Microsoft .NET Framework, SharePoint, and Visual Studio code execution) will have similar effects. The vulnerability is the result of not properly checking the source markup of XML file by the .NET components DataSet and DataTable. By uploading a specially crafted, malicious file to a vulnerable server, an attacker may be able to cause the SharePoint server to execute arbitrary code. The article indicates that both Chinese and Iranian state-sponsored groups have been known to attempt to exploit CVE-2019-0604 and theorize they may also attempt to use CVE-2020-1147 for the same purposes. For more details, please see the link in the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [SharePoint As A Target CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/30769201/SharePoint%20As%20A%20Target%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1600112782523&api=v2)



# Protection

  * CVE-2019-0604: HTTP_SharePoint_Deserialization_Exec
  * CVE-2020-1147: XML_DotNet_Framework_Exec



# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * https://blog.sensecy.com/2020/09/13/will-the-new-sharepoint-flaw-become-an-actors-favorite/

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Malicious Attack Campaign Targeting Jetpack Users Reusing Passwords
A malvertising campaign detected by Wordfence was determined to be the result of compromised WordPress login credentials on sites connected to Jetpack.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malvertising




# Overview

Wordfence published a blog post detailing a malvertising campaign abusing compromised WordPress login credentials on sites connected to Jetpack. Jetpack is a popular plugin for WordPress that requires administrators to connect their sites to a WordPress.com account. This WordPress.com account can then be used to perform administrative tasks on any WordPress site connected to Jetpack via that account. In the campaign observed by Wordfence, this administrative access was abused to install plugins that check to make sure a visitor to a website is not logged in and, if not, redirects the visitor to a malvertising website. Wordfence notes that this is not the first time Jetpack access has been used in combination with WordPress.com credentials to install malicious plugins. For more information, see the Wordfence blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://www.wordfence.com/blog/2021/06/malicious-attack-campaign-targeting-jetpack-users-reusing-passwords/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: RansomExx Improving and Expanding Capabilities
RansomExx is improving its capabilities and speed and has been responsible for several high-profile attacks in 2020, reports Trend Micro in a new report.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: RansomExx Improving and Expanding Capabilities
RansomExx is improving its capabilities and speed and has been responsible for several high-profile attacks in 2020, reports Trend Micro in a new report.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Ransomware, Trojan




# Overview

RansomExx has undergone some developmental improvements which allow for the infiltration of Linux servers in addition to Windows servers. Trend Micro researchers have found evidence of RansomExx compromising companies in the U.S., Canada, and Brazil. They were also able to observe Linux variant activity. The campaign is using IcedID as its infiltration vector. Vatet loader is the payload delivery method and Pyxie and Cobalt Strike as post-intrusion tools. The entire attack took about 5 hours to complete. Initially, a phishing email with an attached password-protected ZIP file is used as a lure. The ZIP file is actually a macro-infected Word document. The document downloads the IcedID Trojan from a malicious URL. IcedID uses steganography to deliver the payload by using a PNG file. Once decrypted, the payload is injected into memory and persistence is accomplished via a scheduled task that runs hourly by using regsvr32.exe to execute the malicious DLL. Once Cobalt Strike is deployed, it attempts to connect to the C2 server. This step then collects machine information and moves laterally. Vatet loader is used to deliver any payload that uses the correct XOR operation. At present, infection vectors to Linux servers is unknown with 3 separate RansomExx observed. Further information can be found in the report located in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/21/a/expanding-range-and-improving-speed-a-ransomexx-approach.html>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: ZShlayer Malware
A new variant of Shlayer, dubbed "ZShlayer" by SentinelOne researchers, has emerged and is leveraging a different shell language to distribute its payload.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

SentinelOne reports on ZShlayer, a Shlayer variant that leverages a different shell language in its infection chain. Specifically, the first-stage script, which previously was written in Bash, is now written in Zsh instead. This script arrives as part of an application bundle inside a DMG. It is heavily obfuscated but not notarized, unlike other recent versions of Shlayer. Zsh takes a base64-encoded file from the application bundle as its input. This file is a Bash script, specifically a Shlayer Bash script, which takes a secondary base64-encoded file from the application bundle and moves it to a newly-created application bundle. Further Bash scripts are executed in order to retrieve the final payload from a remote server. The specific payload delivered is based on OS version and other system information gathered by the script. In the end, the Shlayer payload is delivered to and installed on the victim host. SentinelOne references previous analyses of this malware family as the final payload is similar to those delivered in previous campaigns. For more information, see the SentinelOne blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://www.sentinelone.com/blog/coming-out-of-your-shell-from-shlayer-to-zshlayer/>
