instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: ICS-CERT Advisories February 25 2021
The ICS-CERT has published 4 advisories that affect PerFact OpenVPN-Client, Fatek FvDesigner, Rockwell Automation Logix Controllers, and ProSoft Technology ICX35.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

 Further information is available from the advisories which are summarized below.

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-056-01 - PerFact OpenVPN-Client**  
CVE-2021-27406 - An attacker can take leverage on this architecture and send the config command from any application running on the local host machine to force the back-end server into initializing a new open-VPN instance with arbitrary open-VPN configuration. This could result in the attacker achieving execution with privileges of a SYSTEM user.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 8.8 - assigned; the CVSS vector string is (AV:N/AC:L/PR:L/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-21-056-01>

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-056-02 - Fatek FvDesigner**  
CVE-2021-22662 - A use after free issue has been identified in the way the application processes project files, allowing an attacker to craft a special project file that may permit arbitrary code execution.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2021-22670 - An uninitialized pointer may be exploited while the application is processing project files, allowing an attacker to craft a special project file that may permit arbitrary code execution.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2021-22666 - The affected product is vulnerable to a stack-based buffer overflow while project files are being processed, allowing an attacker to craft a special project file that may permit arbitrary code execution.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2021-22683 - The affected product is vulnerable to an out-of-bounds write while processing project files, allowing an attacker to craft a special project file that may permit arbitrary code execution.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2021-22638 - The affected product is vulnerable to an out-of-bounds read while processing project files, allowing an attacker to craft a special project file that may permit arbitrary code execution.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-21-056-02>

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-056-03 - Rockwell Automation Logix Controllers**  
CVE-2021-22681 - Studio 5000 Logix Designer uses a key to verify Logix controllers are communicating with the affected Rockwell Automation products. The product is vulnerable because an unauthenticated attacker could bypass this verification mechanism and authenticate with Logix controllers.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 10.0 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:C/C:H/I:H/A:H).  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-21-056-03>

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-056-04 - ProSoft Technology ICX35**  
CVE-2021-22661 - Changing the password on the module webpage does not require the user to type in the current password first. Thus, the password could be changed by a user or external process without knowledge of the current password.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 8.2 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:H/A:L).  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-21-056-04>

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/42434657/ICS-CERT%20Advisories%20February%2025%202021%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1614317074274&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
ICS-CERT Advisories February 25 2021
The ICS-CERT has published 4 advisories that affect PerFact OpenVPN-Client, Fatek FvDesigner, Rockwell Automation Logix Controllers, and ProSoft Technology ICX35.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

 Further information is available from the advisories which are summarized below.

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-056-01 - PerFact OpenVPN-Client**  
CVE-2021-27406 - An attacker can take leverage on this architecture and send the config command from any application running on the local host machine to force the back-end server into initializing a new open-VPN instance with arbitrary open-VPN configuration. This could result in the attacker achieving execution with privileges of a SYSTEM user.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 8.8 - assigned; the CVSS vector string is (AV:N/AC:L/PR:L/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-21-056-01>

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-056-02 - Fatek FvDesigner**  
CVE-2021-22662 - A use after free issue has been identified in the way the application processes project files, allowing an attacker to craft a special project file that may permit arbitrary code execution.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2021-22670 - An uninitialized pointer may be exploited while the application is processing project files, allowing an attacker to craft a special project file that may permit arbitrary code execution.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2021-22666 - The affected product is vulnerable to a stack-based buffer overflow while project files are being processed, allowing an attacker to craft a special project file that may permit arbitrary code execution.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2021-22683 - The affected product is vulnerable to an out-of-bounds write while processing project files, allowing an attacker to craft a special project file that may permit arbitrary code execution.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2021-22638 - The affected product is vulnerable to an out-of-bounds read while processing project files, allowing an attacker to craft a special project file that may permit arbitrary code execution.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-21-056-02>

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-056-03 - Rockwell Automation Logix Controllers**  
CVE-2021-22681 - Studio 5000 Logix Designer uses a key to verify Logix controllers are communicating with the affected Rockwell Automation products. The product is vulnerable because an unauthenticated attacker could bypass this verification mechanism and authenticate with Logix controllers.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 10.0 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:C/C:H/I:H/A:H).  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-21-056-03>

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-056-04 - ProSoft Technology ICX35**  
CVE-2021-22661 - Changing the password on the module webpage does not require the user to type in the current password first. Thus, the password could be changed by a user or external process without knowledge of the current password.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 8.2 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:H/A:L).  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-21-056-04>

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/42434657/ICS-CERT%20Advisories%20February%2025%202021%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1614317074274&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Android Infostealer PJobRAT Targets Indian Military Personnel
A report from 360 Fiberhome Lab provides an analysis of the Android infostealer, PJobRAT. It is believed PJobRAT was in a campaign targeting Indian users with military backgrounds.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Android




# Overview

The first development versions of PJobRAT surfaced sometime in late 2019. A 360 Fiberhome Lab report speculates that a campaign using PJobRAT and targeting Indian users with military backgrounds began in January 2019. PJobRAT arrives in a fake app which pretends to be an Indian dating app named Trendbanter. The method of the app's distribution is unclear but 360 Fiberhome Lab speculates that it may be distributed through military-related forums. PJobRAT searches for a number of different document types including doc, docx, pdf, ppt, ppt, xlsx, and xls. Files that are located are uploaded to a remote server using Firebase Cloud Messaging and HTTP. Other fake applications disguised as Signal, HangOn Messenger, and others, are reported to use the same server. PJobRAT can also upload a device's address book, audio, video, and image files, lists of installed apps and files stored externally, the Whatsapp contact list and messages, as well as WiFi and location information. 360 Fiberhome Lab has been unable to attribute the malware and campaign to any specific actor. Further details are available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blogs.360.cn/post/analysis-of-PJobRAT.html>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Exposed Kubeflow Interfaces Used to Run Cryptomining Containers
A new campaign has been targeting exposed Kubeflow interfaces to install containers that carry out cryptocurrency mining according to a a report from a researcher at Cloud Security Research.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Cryptomining




# Overview

In late May, Cloud Security Research observed an increase in deployments of TensorFlow pods on a number Kubernetes clusters. The deployments were simultaneous, which according to Cloud Security Research, indicates the targets were scanned prior and the attacks staged to execute at the same time. To carry out the attack, the attackers targeted exposed instances of Kubeflow's centralized dashboard. Two cryptomining pods were installed on each cluster. One being the Ethminer which uses the GPU for mining, the other being XMRIG which uses the CPU. Prior to the commencement of cryptomining, a pod was installed which provided the attacker's information on the environment such as CPU and GPU information. Further details are available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/azure-security-center/new-large-scale-campaign-targets-kubeflow/ba-p/2425750>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: New Version of Apostle Ransomware
Agrius is a suspected Iranian threat actor operating in the Middle East known for deploying ransomware and wipers. SentinelOne has found a new version of their Apostle ransomware being deployed via a loader dubbed "Jennlog."
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Ransomware
  *  **Target:** Middle Eastern University
  *  **Ransomware Family:** Apostle
  *  **RaaS Operation:** No
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data encryption



# Overview

SentinelOne published a blog post detailing a new version of the Apostle ransomware found targeting a Middle Eastern university. The ransomware was installed via a loader dubbed "Jennlog." This .NET loader contains an embedded executable. The beginning of the file contains content masquerading as a legitimate log file, but the end of the file contains an obfuscated, compressed, and encrypted executable. The loader has the capability to check for the presence of sandboxes, virtual machines, and debuggers. The sample analyzed in the blog post drops a version of Apostle ransomware that operates the same as previous versions but leverages a new ransom note and wallpaper. The researchers noted that other versions of the Jennlog loader were identified but they instead dropped what appeared to be a test version of the OrcusRAT malware. For more information, see the SentinelOne blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64129226/New%20Version%20of%20Apostle%20Ransomware%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1633116432069&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).



# References

  * <https://www.sentinelone.com/labs/new-version-of-apostle-ransomware-reemerges-in-targeted-attack-on-higher-education/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1497 - Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion  
T1497.001 - System Checks

 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Hydra Variant Targeting Major German Bank
A new variant of Hydra has been detected in an ongoing phishing campaign by researchers at Cyble. This variant has more capabilities and is being targeted at users of the German bank Commerzbank.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Hydra Variant Targeting Major German Bank
A new variant of Hydra has been detected in an ongoing phishing campaign by researchers at Cyble. This variant has more capabilities and is being targeted at users of the German bank Commerzbank.

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware, Phishing
  *  **Targets:** Banking
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Hydra
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Phishing
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Propagation, Credential Theft



# Overview

A phishing campaign investigated by Cyble researchers has uncovered a new variant of the Android banking malware known as Hydra. This malware is being spread through websites that are pretending to be legitimate sites for Commerzbank, a major bank in Germany. A number of these false sites were registered to the same IP address, and where the user can download a false banking app. The application, titled 'Commerzbank Security', requests 21 different permissions. These include dangerous permissions, such as 'REQUEST_INSTALL_PACKAGES' which allows the threat actor to install applications without user interaction. With these permissions granted, Hydra can steal contact details, steal credentials, spy on user activities, and send bulk SMSs to the victim's contacts. The original variant of this malware behaved like a normal Banking bot by creating an overlay on targeted apps to capture input. The variant seen in this campaign has additional capabilities. One new piece of functionality is the ability to provide the attacker a TeamViewer style view of the screen by abusing the Accessibility feature to cast the screen and allow the attacker to interact with it. Another unique feature of this variant is that it uses TOR as a proxy, which hosts the C2 URL encoded in Base64. This campaign is one of an increasing number noted by the Cyble researchers, as the COVID19 pandemic has forced more users to interact with their banks solely online, opening them up to falling for the phishing domains and becoming infected. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64129474/Hydra%20Variant%20Targeting%20Major%20German%20Bank%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1633429100168&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.

  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.

  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.

  * Enterprises can vet applications for exploitable vulnerabilities or unwanted (privacy-invasive or malicious) behaviors. Enterprises can inspect applications themselves or use a third-party service (M1005). 

  * An enterprise mobility management (EMM), also known as mobile device management (MDM), system can be used to provision policies to mobile devices to control aspects of their allowed behavior (M1012) .
  * Warn device users not to accept requests to grant Device Administrator access to applications without good reason (M1007). 



# References

  * <https://blog.cyble.com/2021/09/30/a-new-variant-of-hydra-banking-trojan-targeting-european-banking-users/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1406 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1444 - Masquerade as Legitimate Application  
T1523 - Evade Analysis Environment

 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1412 - Capture SMS Messages  
T1409 - Access Stored Application Data  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1418 - Application Discovery  
T1016 - System Network Configuration Discovery  
T1421 - System Network Connections Discovery  
T1424 - Process Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1507 - Network Information Discovery  
T1412 - Capture SMS Messages  
T1432 - Access Contact List  
T1513 - Screen Capture  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1090 - Proxy  
T1090.003 - Multi-hop Proxy  
T1571 - Non-Standard Port  
T1573 - Encrypted Channel  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1447 - Delete Device Data  
T1448 - Carrier Billing Fraud

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Bit2Check BIN Code Checker
An investigation by RiskIQ led to the unmasking of the actor behind Bit2Check.
output:
# Threat Type

  * BIN Code Checker




# Overview

Bit2Check is advertised as a service to check the validity of credit cards and BIN (Bank Identification Number) codes. According to RiskIQ, the domains used by the service routinely swap between Google and Alibaba's IP spaces. Some of the domains used by Bit2Check utilize the same hosting pattern as Magecart domains, and in some cases, the IP addresses used to host Bit2Check had also been used to host Magecart domains. Investigated related websites, services, and social media accounts led RiskIQ to unmask the actor behind Bit2Check. It is believed that the actor is Kurdish and uses the name "Hama". Further details are available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://community.riskiq.com/article/f1e8399e>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: EwDoor Botnet Targets Edgewater Devices
Netlab 360 is reporting their discovery of a new botnet they have named EwDoor which has been observed targeting the EdgeMarc Enterprise Session Border Controller. All of the botnet infections have been located in the US and all on AT&T IP addresses.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Botnet client, Backdoor.
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unspecified
  *  **Associated Payloads:** EwDoor
  *  ** **Targets: Unpatched**** Edgewater Edgemarc devices.
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** CVE-2017-6079
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Persistence, Joining the botnet, Collection, and exfiltration of data.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

EwDoor is a new botnet malware that was first observed by Netlab 360 in late October. The EwDoor malware attempts to exploit a vulnerability (CVE-2017-6079) in Edgewater Edgemarc devices, specifically in this campaign, the EdgeMarc Enterprise Session Border Controller. The vulnerability, which was patched in 2017, could allow a remote attacker, using default credentials, to obtain root access to an affected device. According to Netlab's report, at one point there were just under 6K infections, all of which were on devices using AT&T IP addresses and located in the United States. Netlab notes the use of an unusual command in the EwDoor payload that is used to mount a filesystem. Once access has been gained to a device and the payload delivered, the victim's device info is sent to a C&C server and it joins the botnet. The infected devices can be used as botnet clients in DDoS attacks and the attackers can gather sensitive data from the infected devices. The addresses and port numbers for EwDoor C&C servers are obtained from BitTorrent trackers using one of two methods. Once the C&C details have been obtained EwDoor will then begin communicating with the C&C server. Aside from participating in DDoS attacks, the client is capable of downloading files, executing commands, and executing a reverse shell. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
EwDoor Botnet Targets Edgewater Devices
Netlab 360 is reporting their discovery of a new botnet they have named EwDoor which has been observed targeting the EdgeMarc Enterprise Session Border Controller. All of the botnet infections have been located in the US and all on AT&T IP addresses.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Botnet client, Backdoor.
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unspecified
  *  **Associated Payloads:** EwDoor
  *  ** **Targets: Unpatched**** Edgewater Edgemarc devices.
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** CVE-2017-6079
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Persistence, Joining the botnet, Collection, and exfiltration of data.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

EwDoor is a new botnet malware that was first observed by Netlab 360 in late October. The EwDoor malware attempts to exploit a vulnerability (CVE-2017-6079) in Edgewater Edgemarc devices, specifically in this campaign, the EdgeMarc Enterprise Session Border Controller. The vulnerability, which was patched in 2017, could allow a remote attacker, using default credentials, to obtain root access to an affected device. According to Netlab's report, at one point there were just under 6K infections, all of which were on devices using AT&T IP addresses and located in the United States. Netlab notes the use of an unusual command in the EwDoor payload that is used to mount a filesystem. Once access has been gained to a device and the payload delivered, the victim's device info is sent to a C&C server and it joins the botnet. The infected devices can be used as botnet clients in DDoS attacks and the attackers can gather sensitive data from the infected devices. The addresses and port numbers for EwDoor C&C servers are obtained from BitTorrent trackers using one of two methods. Once the C&C details have been obtained EwDoor will then begin communicating with the C&C server. Aside from participating in DDoS attacks, the client is capable of downloading files, executing commands, and executing a reverse shell. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Avos Ransomware Group Expands Capabilities
Cisco Talos has posted an advisory that details the recent activities of the Avos Ransomware group. This threat actor is utilizing several vulnerabilities to gain a foothold in targeted networks.
output:
Summary
=======



Threat Details
==============

* **Malware Type:** Ransomware
* **Associated Threat Actors:** Avos
* **Associated Payloads:** AvosLocker
* **Targets:** Unknown
* **Initial Infection Vector:** Spam Email
* **Additional TTPs:**See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below

Overview
========

The team at Talos was recently asked to assist a Cisco customer. When they responded to the request their analysis revealed that the customer was targeted by the Avos ransomware group. This threat group goes back to 2021 when they initially targeted Windows instances. Recently a new variant of their ransomware known as AvosLocker is targeting Linux environments. Avos ransomware is known as ransomware-as-a-service. In past campaigns, Avos used spam emails to compromise victims. During the investigation of this incident, Talos researchers found that the threat actor had utilized an ESXi server that was exposed as the initial vector. This particular server was exposed because of the VMWare Horizon Unified Gateways that were vulnerable to the Log4Shell. Further information is available from the link in the References section below.

Indicators of Compromise
========================

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

Recommendations
===============

* For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

References
==========

* [https://blog.talosintelligence.com/2022/06/avoslocker-new-arsenal.html](https://blog.talosintelligence.com/2022/06/avoslocker-new-arsenal.html "Follow link")

MITRE ATT&CK Framework
======================

#### Tactics and Techniques:

**Initial Access - TA0001**  
 T1566 - Phishing  
   T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  

**Execution - TA0002**  
 T1047 - Windows Management Instrumentation  
   T1059.001 - PowerShell  

**Persistence - TA0003**  
   T1546.003 - Windows Management Instrumentation Event Subscription  

#### Mitigations:

**M1017:**  User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
**M1018:**  User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
**M1021:**  Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
**M1022:**  Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
**M1026:**  Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
**M1028:**  Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
**M1031:**  Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
**M1033:**  Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
**M1035:**  Limit Access to Resource Over Network - Prevent access to file shares, remote access to systems, unnecessary services. Mechanisms to limit access may include use of network concentrators, RDP gateways, etc.  
**M1038:**  Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
**M1040:**  Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
**M1042:**  Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
**M1045:**  Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
**M1047:**  Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
**M1049:**  Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
**M1051:**  Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
**M1052:**  User Account Control - Configure Windows User Account Control to mitigate risk of adversaries obtaining elevated process access.  
**M1054:**  Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Exploiting COVID-19: Using Multiple Email Providers
The exploitation of the current COVID–19 health crisis continues across all sectors, according to the Cofense Phishing Defense Center team.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Exploiting COVID-19: Using Multiple Email Providers
The exploitation of the current COVID–19 health crisis continues across all sectors, according to the Cofense Phishing Defense Center team.

# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

According to the Cofense Phishing Defense Center (PDC) team, threat actors continue to exploit the current COVID-19 pandemic in order to initiate phishing attacks. Researchers assessed these key components, amongst others, allowing success for threat actors: the exploitation of the pandemic and cogent aesthetics to bait targets. A tactic often seen is the use of duplicate Dropbox landing pages that require victims to login in order to view crucial documentation relating to COVID–19. The threat actors provide fake login pages to the victim for a number of popular email services. The harvested credentials are stored in a database via HTTP POST to a PHP script, victims are redirected to a legitimate webpage unconnected to COVID-19. For more information, see the Cofense blog post in the Reference section.  


# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://cofense.com/exploiting-the-current-covid-19-health-crisis-through-multiple-email-providers/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: New Vulnerabilities in Billing System Exploited By Ransomware Group
The Huntress ThreatOps team have traced a detected ransomware attack back to a previously unknown vulnerability in the BQE Web Suite. They have published the process of uncovering this, and more vulnerabilities in a blog post.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Vulnerability
  *  **Targets:** Engineering Firm
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Exploitation of Public-Facing Server
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Lateral Movement, Ransomware Deployment



# Overview

The Huntress ThreatOps team has discovered several vulnerabilities after a number of their ransomware canary files were tripped within a customer's network. Upon investigation, alerts were discovered concerning a service account used for an SQL server. The server in question hosted BQE Web Suite 2020, and the logs indicated that a foreign IP was repeatedly sending POST requests leading up to the initial compromise. With this information, the ThreatOps team downloaded a version of the BillQuick server and managed to recreate the victim's environment. With this, the researchers used the tool 'sqlmap' to test for SQL injection vulnerabilities. With this tool, the researchers discovered many vulnerabilities, including the one that led to the infection of this engineering firm. The researchers were able to use this vulnerability to dump sensitive databases and more severely, execute code remotely. This was how the attackers were able to access the network and deploy ransomware. The Huntress ThreatOps team has been liaising with the developers of BillQuick and is in the process of patching the discovered vulnerability. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [New Vulnerabilities in Billing System Being Exploited CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/68616960/New%20Vulnerabilities%20in%20Billing%20System%20Being%20Exploited%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1635430309675&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Web Application Firewalls may be used to limit exposure of applications to prevent exploit traffic from reaching the application (M1050).



# References

  * <https://www.huntress.com/blog/threat-advisory-hackers-are-exploiting-a-vulnerability-in-popular-billing-software-to-deploy-ransomware>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.004 - Exploits  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Unsecured AWS Bucket Reveals 39 Million Records
Breach/Leak Notification: An online marketing company's database was left unsecured on an AWS server. CyberNews reveals the discovery of the records and the potential implications of the unsecured data.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Unsecured AWS Bucket Reveals 39 Million Records
Breach/Leak Notification: An online marketing company's database was left unsecured on an AWS server. CyberNews reveals the discovery of the records and the potential implications of the unsecured data.

# Threat Type

  * Leak




# Overview

The CyberNews research team uncovered an unsecured data bucket containing a database within an AWS server. The database belongs to a marketing firm, View Media. On July 29, Amazon closed the bucket and the data is no longer visible. Within the bucket were 700 statements of work for email and direct mail campaigns, along with 59 CSV and XLS files containing nearly 39 million records of U.S. citizens. About 2/3 of those records were unique. This information could later be used for targeting of potential victims in later scam attempts such as phishing, spam attacks, and identity fraud. "On August 24, we contacted View Media for an official comment regarding the leak. However, we received no response from the company." Further details can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * N/A




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://cybernews.com/security/online-marketing-company-exposes-data-of-millions-americans/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: APT27 Ransomware Attack Disrupted
An attack in progress was disrupted by researchers at eSentire, using many TTPs that suggest that this was meant to be a ransomware attack by the China-based group APT27. The target was a product safety testing organization, meaning that a lot of IP was at risk of being stolen or destroyed.
output:
Summary
=======



Attack Details
==============

* **Threat Type:** Ransomware
* **Targets:** Product safety testing organization
* **Malware Family/Families:** Hello, Mimikatz (S0002), Cobalt Strike (S0154)
* **Initial Infection Vector:** Vulnerable SharePoint server
* **Post-Compromise Actions:**Domain reconnaissance

Overview
========

Researchers at eSentire have disrupted a potential ransomware attack targeting a product safety testing company that they have attributed to the Chinese espionage group known as Emissary Panda or APT27. IBM X-Force tracks APT27 as Hive0006. It is speculated that this could be part of a false flag campaign as the attack uses many public tools and techniques that are of perceived low quality, but it could be the case that this attack was being used to mask the attacker's true activities in the network. In this attack, initial access was obtained by exploiting a vulnerable Sharepoint server. This has been observed in previous attacks by APT27, and so supports the theory that they may be the perpetrators of the attack. Once access had been gained, they used PowerShell to download and launch a Cobalt Strike beacon, disguising the execution as a Kaspersky service to bypass security controls via application allowlists. After this, the attackers attempted to escalate privileges before attempting to disable security monitoring using another PowerShell call. Finally, Mimikatz was used to configure the system to capture credentials from future logins. Once this was established, some post-compromise domain reconnaissance was observed before the attack was disrupted. Although no ransomware was deployed here, all of this behavior is consistent with previous Hello ransomware attacks that have been attributed to China-based actors. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

Indicators of Compromise
========================

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

CVEs
====

* A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/64128783/APT27%20Ransomware%20Attack%20Disrupted%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1632838433740&api=v2)

Recommendations
===============

* Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
* Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
* Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
* Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
* Set PowerShell execution policy to execute only signed scripts (M1045).
* It may be possible to remove PowerShell from systems when not needed, but a review should be performed to assess the impact to an environment, since it could be in use for many legitimate purposes and administrative functions (M1042).
* When PowerShell is necessary, restrict PowerShell execution policy to administrators. Be aware that there are methods of bypassing the PowerShell execution policy, depending on environment configuration (M1026).

References
==========

* <https://www.esentire.com/security-advisories/ransomware-hackers-attack-a-top-safety-testing-org-using-tactics-and-techniques-borrowed-from-chinese-espionage-groups>

MITRE ATT&CK Framework
======================

**Execution - TA0002**

parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
APT27 Ransomware Attack Disrupted
An attack in progress was disrupted by researchers at eSentire, using many TTPs that suggest that this was meant to be a ransomware attack by the China-based group APT27. The target was a product safety testing organization, meaning that a lot of IP was at risk of being stolen or destroyed.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
Summary
=======



Attack Details
==============

* **Threat Type:** Ransomware
* **Targets:** Product safety testing organization
* **Malware Family/Families:** Hello, Mimikatz (S0002), Cobalt Strike (S0154)
* **Initial Infection Vector:** Vulnerable SharePoint server
* **Post-Compromise Actions:**Domain reconnaissance

Overview
========

Researchers at eSentire have disrupted a potential ransomware attack targeting a product safety testing company that they have attributed to the Chinese espionage group known as Emissary Panda or APT27. IBM X-Force tracks APT27 as Hive0006. It is speculated that this could be part of a false flag campaign as the attack uses many public tools and techniques that are of perceived low quality, but it could be the case that this attack was being used to mask the attacker's true activities in the network. In this attack, initial access was obtained by exploiting a vulnerable Sharepoint server. This has been observed in previous attacks by APT27, and so supports the theory that they may be the perpetrators of the attack. Once access had been gained, they used PowerShell to download and launch a Cobalt Strike beacon, disguising the execution as a Kaspersky service to bypass security controls via application allowlists. After this, the attackers attempted to escalate privileges before attempting to disable security monitoring using another PowerShell call. Finally, Mimikatz was used to configure the system to capture credentials from future logins. Once this was established, some post-compromise domain reconnaissance was observed before the attack was disrupted. Although no ransomware was deployed here, all of this behavior is consistent with previous Hello ransomware attacks that have been attributed to China-based actors. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

Indicators of Compromise
========================

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

CVEs
====

* A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/64128783/APT27%20Ransomware%20Attack%20Disrupted%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1632838433740&api=v2)

Recommendations
===============

* Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
* Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
* Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
* Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
* Set PowerShell execution policy to execute only signed scripts (M1045).
* It may be possible to remove PowerShell from systems when not needed, but a review should be performed to assess the impact to an environment, since it could be in use for many legitimate purposes and administrative functions (M1042).
* When PowerShell is necessary, restrict PowerShell execution policy to administrators. Be aware that there are methods of bypassing the PowerShell execution policy, depending on environment configuration (M1026).

References
==========

* <https://www.esentire.com/security-advisories/ransomware-hackers-attack-a-top-safety-testing-org-using-tactics-and-techniques-borrowed-from-chinese-espionage-groups>

MITRE ATT&CK Framework
======================

**Initial Access - TA0001**  
 T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application  

**Execution - TA0002**  
 T1047 - Windows Management Instrumentation  
   T1059.001 - PowerShell  

**Persistence - TA0003**  
 T1078 - Valid Accounts  

**Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
   T1036.004 - Masquerade Task or Service  

**Discovery - TA0007**  
   T1069.002 - Domain Groups

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: MoDi RAT Spreading Via Email
Sophos has discovered an unusual reflective loader attack that starts with a malicious email containing VBS code and delivers a Trojan called MoDi RAT.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, RAT



# Overview

While searching through threat activity, two Sophos researchers discovered a unique reflective loader attack. The email, possibly part of a malspam campaign, is delivered to the potential victim's inbox with a malicious attachment. When the victim opens the attachment, the VBS code connects to a remote website to retrieve an archive file, encountering a number of 302 redirects along the way. The ZIP archive is hosted on OneDrive and contains another VBS file. This second VBS file is extracted by the original and saved to disk. It then creates three registry blobs as well as creating a scheduled task to run the downloaded code at some point in the future. When the scheduled task runs, the VBS file launches PowerShell, writes output to the system clipboard, then pastes that clipboard content as commands into the PowerShell window. This write and then paste using the clipboard may be an attempt to evade security products by not invoking PowerShell with a suspicious command line. The PowerShell window retrieves a .NET decoder executable from one of the registry blobs and injects it into a system process. This code then retrieves the other two blobs and injects them as well. One of the two blobs retrieved from the registry is the payload MoDi RAT. For more details, please refer to the link in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/30769931/MoDi%20RAT%20Spreading%20Via%20Email%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1600960801824&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://news.sophos.com/en-us/2020/09/24/email-delivered-modi-rat-attack-pastes-powershell-commands/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Ransomware Threat Actor - Karma
A ransomware threat actor named Karma that emerged in June 2021 is the subject of a report from SentinelLabs.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Ransomware
  *  **Targets:** Non-specific, possibly entities with significant revenue.
  *  ** **Ransomware Family:**** Karma Ransomware
  *  **RaaS Operation:** No
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** User execution of a malicious file.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data collection and exfiltration, File encryption.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.
  *  **Leak Site:**[http[:]//3nvzqyo6l4wkrzumzu5aod7zbosq4ipgf7ifgj3hsvbcr5vcasordvqd[.]onion/](http://3nvzqyo6l4wkrzumzu5aod7zbosq4ipgf7ifgj3hsvbcr5vcasordvqd.onion/) **  
**



# Overview

The ransomware threat actor named Karma was first observed in June 2021. The ransomware used by the group has since undergone many revisions, sometimes building multiple new variants in a single day. According to SentinelLabs Karma has targeted a number of organizations across multiple industry sectors. While no specific targeting information is provided, it would appear from the victim's information published on the Karma leak site, that Karma targets victims with significant revenue. According to revenue figures for victims listed on the leak site, all victims have revenue of at least $1 billion dollars. The Karma ransomware has similarities with other malware such as NEMTY, even more so with JSWorm. Over time, there have been significant changes to Karma's encryption process in some cases Chacha20 was used for file encryption, in others, Salsa20 was used. Ransom notes are base64-encoded in the binary and written to the victim system, originally with the name KARMA-AGREE.txt which in later samples changed to KARMA-ENCRYPTED.txt. The desktop background of an infected system is changed to an image that contains the information in the ransom note. In each ransom note, there are three email addresses that appear to be unique to each victim suggesting that the ransomware is compiled specifically for each victim. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64130591/Ransomware%20Threat%20Actor%20-%20Karma%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1634616026366&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).



# References

  * <https://www.sentinelone.com/labs/karma-ransomware-an-emerging-threat-with-a-hint-of-nemty-pedigree/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1012 - Query Registry  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
T1120 - Peripheral Device Discovery  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1485 - Data Destruction  
T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact

The Android Security Bulletin for May has been released and provides information on the forty-two vulnerabilities that are addressed in this bulletin.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

The April security bulletin for Android has been released. In it, forty-two vulnerabilities are addressed. Some of the potential impacts of successful exploitation of the vulnerabilities are information disclosure, privilege escalation, and remote code execution. Four of the vulnerabilities were rated as Critical, and thirty-seven as High, and one as Moderate. For details on the issues addressed in this bulletin, refer to the link in the Reference section.

# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://source.android.com/security/bulletin/2021-05-01>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Android  Credential Stealer - ERMAC
Cyble Research Labs has published a report on a new variant of the credential-stealing Android malware, ERMAC 2.0.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Android Malware
  *  **Targets:** Users of 467 various Android apps.
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** ERMAC
  *  **Initial Infection Vector: Fake app.**
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Credential stealing.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

ERMAC is credential-stealing malware for Android devices. Version 1.0 of ERMAC was discovered in August 2021 with the actor behind ERMAC renting it out for $3,000 per month with version 2.0 becoming available around March 2022, now being rented for $5,000 per month. Cyble Research Labs have published a report of their analysis of ERMAC 2.0 which has increased the number of applications it targets from 378 in version 1.0 to 467 in 2.0. ERMAC is installed through third-party sites. In Cyble's analysis, it was found on fake sites impersonating a Polish food delivery platform. A link to download what is purported to be the legitimate site's app is provided. It has also been observed masquerading as browser updates. The fake app seeks 43 different permissions when installed. Once installed, it sends a list of the applications installed on the infected device to its C&C servers. The C&C server responds with a list of targeted applications and an encrypted HTML phishing page ERMAC will use to carry out overlay injections. When the victim interacts with a targeted application, the overlay injection is used to obtain the victim's credentials which are then sent to the C&C server. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

# Recommendations

  * For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://blog.cyble.com/2022/05/25/ermac-back-in-action/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Tactics and Techniques:**

 **Initial Access - TA0027**  
T1444 - Masquerade as Legitimate Application  
T1476 - Deliver Malicious App via Other Means  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0030**  
T1406 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0031**  
T1412 - Capture SMS Messages  
  
 **Discovery - TA0032**  
T1421 - System Network Connections Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0035**  
T1432 - Access Contact List  
T1507 - Network Information Discovery  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0037**  
T1571 - Non-Standard Port  
T1573 - Encrypted Channel

 **Mitigations:**

 **M1001:** Security Updates -Install security updates in response to discovered vulnerabilities. Purchase devices with a vendor and/or mobile carrier commitment to provide security updates in a prompt manner for a set period of time. Decommission devices that will no longer receive security updates. Limit or block access to enterprise resources from devices that have not installed recent security updates. On Android devices, access can be controlled based on each device's security patch level. On iOS devices, access can be controlled based on the iOS version.  
 **M1005:** Application Vetting - Enterprises can vet applications for exploitable vulnerabilities or unwanted (privacy-invasive or malicious) behaviors. Enterprises can inspect applications themselves or use a third-party service. Enterprises may impose policies to only allow pre-approved applications to be installed on their devices or may impose policies to block use of specific applications known to have issues. In Bring Your Own Device (BYOD) environments, enterprises may only be able to impose these policies over an enterprise-managed portion of the device. Application Vetting is not a complete mitigation. Techniques such as Evade Analysis Environment exist that can enable adversaries to bypass vetting.  
 **M1006:** Use Recent OS Version - New mobile operating system versions bring not only patches against discovered vulnerabilities but also often bring security architecture improvements that provide resilience against potential vulnerabilities or weaknesses that have not yet been discovered. They may also bring improvements that block use of observed adversary techniques.  
 **M1011:** User Guidance - Describes any guidance or training given to users to set particular configuration settings or avoid specific potentially risky behaviors.  
 **M1012:** Enterprise Policy - An enterprise mobility management (EMM), also known as mobile device management (MDM), system can be used to provision policies to mobile devices to control aspects of their allowed behavior.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Lyceum APT Group Deploying Backdoor That Uses DNS for Command and Control
A report from Zscaler ThreatLabz provides an analysis of a .NET based backdoor that uses DNS Hijacking for C&C communications that has been used in attacks by the Iranian-sponsored APT group known as Lyceum.
output:
Summary
=======



Attack Details
==============

* **Threat Type:** Malware
* **Targets:** Organizations in the energy and telecommunication sectors located in the Middle East
* **Malware Family/Families:** DnsSystem backdoor
* **Initial Infection Vector:** Malicious Word document
* **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data collection and exfiltration
* **Additional TTPs:**See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.

Overview
========

Lyceum is reported by Zscaler ThreatLabz as being an Iranian-sponsored APT group that has been operating since sometime in 2017. This threat group is known to target organizations in the energy and telecommunication sectors located in the Middle East. The group has been using a .NET-based backdoor which is a modified version of the open-source tool, DIG.net. The modifications allow the backdoor to use DNS Hijacking to provide the backdoor's C&C communications. The backdoor uses DNS queries to a DNS server under the control of the attackers and the server's responses provide commands for the backdoor to carry out. In the campaign observed by Zscaler, the backdoor is delivered via a malicious Word document that uses the AutoOpen() and AutoClose() functions to drop the embedded backdoor onto the system. The backdoor, named "DnsSystem" is also copied to the system's startup folder to achieve persistence. Further information is available from the link in the References section below.

Indicators of Compromise
========================

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

Recommendations
===============

* For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

References
==========

* <https://www.zscaler.com/blogs/security-research/lyceum-net-dns-backdoor>

MITRE ATT&CK Framework
======================

**Tactics and Techniques:**

**Resource Development - TA0042**  
 T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
   T1583.001 - Domains  
   T1583.002 - DNS Server  
 T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
   T1587.001 - Malware  
 T1588 - Obtain Capabilities  
   T1588.002 - Tool  

**Initial Access - TA0001**  
 T1566 - Phishing  
   T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  

**Execution - TA0002**  
 T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
 T1204 - User Execution  
   T1204.002 - Malicious File  

**Persistence - TA0003**  
 T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
   T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  

**Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
 T1055 - Process Injection  

**Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
 T1562 - Impair Defenses  

**Discovery - TA0007**  
 T1010 - Application Window Discovery  
 T1018 - Remote System Discovery  
 T1057 - Process Discovery  
 T1518 - Software Discovery  

**Exfiltration - TA0010**  
 T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  

**Command and Control - TA0011**  
 T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
   T1071.004 - DNS  

**Mitigations:**

**M1013:**  Application Developer Guidance: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.  
**M1017:**  User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
**M1018:**  User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
**M1021:**  Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
**M1022:**  Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
**M1024:**  Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
**M1025:**  Privileged Process Integrity - Protect processes with high privileges that can be used to interact with critical system components through use of protected process light, anti-process injection defenses, or other process integrity enforcement measures.  
**M1026:**  Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
**M1028:**  Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
**M1031:**  Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
**M1033:**  Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
**M1037:**  Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
**M1038:**  Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
**M1039:**  Environment Variable Permissions - Prevent modification of environment variables by unauthorized users and groups.  
**M1040:**  Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
**M1042:**  Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
**M1043:**  Credential Access Protection - Use capabilities to prevent successful credential access by adversaries; including blocking forms of credential dumping.  
**M1044:**  Restrict Library Loading - Prevent abuse of library loading mechanisms in the operating system and software to load untrusted code by configuring appropriate library loading mechanisms and investigating potential vulnerable software.  
**M1045:**  Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
**M1047:**  Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
**M1049:**  Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
**M1054:**  Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
**M1056:**  Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.  
**M1057:**  Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
Lyceum APT Group Deploying Backdoor That Uses DNS for Command and Control
A report from Zscaler ThreatLabz provides an analysis of a .NET based backdoor that uses DNS Hijacking for C&C communications that has been used in attacks by the Iranian-sponsored APT group known as Lyceum.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
Summary
=======



Attack Details
==============

* **Threat Type:** Malware
* **Targets:** Organizations in the energy and telecommunication sectors located in the Middle East
* **Malware Family/Families:** DnsSystem backdoor
* **Initial Infection Vector:** Malicious Word document
* **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data collection and exfiltration
* **Additional TTPs:**See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.

Overview
========

Lyceum is reported by Zscaler ThreatLabz as being an Iranian-sponsored APT group that has been operating since sometime in 2017. This threat group is known to target organizations in the energy and telecommunication sectors located in the Middle East. The group has been using a .NET-based backdoor which is a modified version of the open-source tool, DIG.net. The modifications allow the backdoor to use DNS Hijacking to provide the backdoor's C&C communications. The backdoor uses DNS queries to a DNS server under the control of the attackers and the server's responses provide commands for the backdoor to carry out. In the campaign observed by Zscaler, the backdoor is delivered via a malicious Word document that uses the AutoOpen() and AutoClose() functions to drop the embedded backdoor onto the system. The backdoor, named "DnsSystem" is also copied to the system's startup folder to achieve persistence. Further information is available from the link in the References section below.

Indicators of Compromise
========================

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

Recommendations
===============

* For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: OneDrive Cloud Service Abused for Phishing
A phishing campaign discovered by Cofense is abusing legitimate OneDrive cloud hosting services to bypass detection.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

Cofense published a blog post analyzing a phishing campaign that is leveraging OneDrive to host their malicious content. The phishing email claims a file has been shared via OneDrive and provides a shortened OneDrive link to visit. Hosted on this OneDrive URL is a PDF containing hyperlinked text to a second-stage phishing page. If a user falls for this trick and visits the secondary page, they are presented with logon options for multiple email services combined with further OneDrive branding. Each login option provides a different fake login page; for example, one led to an Outlook login page while another presented a Box login. When a user provides credentials, the entered data is exfiltrated to the attacker while the victim is redirected to a benign research article. For more information, see the Cofense blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://cofense.com/blog/one-drive-malicious-links/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Russian Threat Group Attacking Russian Industry
A new Russian threat group, OldGremlin, is targeting Russian industries with ransomware, phishing attempts, and other malware. Group-IB details this group and its campaigns against those Russian industries.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Phishing, Ransomware




# Overview

A new Russian threat group is wreaking havoc on various Russian industries. Using a variety of techniques, the group seeks to phish credentials, implant malware, and deploy ransomware. The group is made up of Russian speakers who break the untold rule of not working within Russia and post-Soviet countries. Impersonating regulatory organizations, a metallurgical company, an industrial plant, a dental clinic, and media holdings company, the group uses a variety of techniques to infiltrate these and other industries within Russia. The first attack was against a large medical company using a phishing email claiming to be from the media holding company. Upon opening of the phishing email, a custom malware called TinyNode is installed. This malware is used as a backdoor and to load additional malware. The group performs reconnaissance, collection of data, and propagation. Additionally, the group uses Cobalt Strike to ensure post-exploitation is effective. The group moves laterally in an effort to obtain domain administrator credentials as well as creates a new account with privileges to perform administrative actions in case the original account is deleted or blocked. A backup of the data was unsuccessful as it was later revealed the attackers had deleted the organization's backups. Within hours, the ransomware TinyCryptor was spread throughout the network. A note of interest is each campaign uses a different email address. A demand of $50,000 worth of cryptocurrency was made in exchange for decrypting the encrypted files. The group was first observed between late-March and early-April. The group used a custom Trojan called TinyPosh. After a two week break, the group changed tactics and employed a fake email from a journalist to take part in research activities. The email used proper grammar as well as imitating the media's holding style. The fake journalist offered a 30-minute interview and uploaded questions to the cloud. Upon clicking the link, the TinyPosh Trojan was downloaded to a victim's computer. Persistence was set and the privileges of the account were obtained. Additionally, Cobalt Strike Beacon was launched and, in order to hide the actual C2 address, the group used a Cloudflare Workers server. The group took a hiatus until August 2020 when two large-scales campaigns were launched using the Russian media holding company as a front. Within days, the decoy email was edited to address protests in Belarus. Using several themes the group continued to launch TinyPosh backdoor attacks. These emails contained malicious emails with malicious ZIP files attached. Further details can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.group-ib.com/blog/oldgremlin>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: An Analysis of Malware Used by Turla in Recent Attack
Turla, a well known and believed to be state-sponsored APT group, has remained active for more than ten years. A report from Accenture analyzed malware that was used in an attack by Turla on a European government entity.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: An Analysis of Malware Used by Turla in Recent Attack
Turla, a well known and believed to be state-sponsored APT group, has remained active for more than ten years. A report from Accenture analyzed malware that was used in an attack by Turla on a European government entity.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, APT




# Overview

The APT, Turla, tracked by IBM X-Force as ITG12, is also known by a number of other names. These include, Belugasturgeon, Krypton, Makersmark, Snake, Uroburosk, Venomous Bear, Waterbug, and WhiteBear. Turla is believed to be state-sponsored and has been operating for at least ten years, Turla's typical targets include embassies and governments entities. Accenture published a report outlining the malware that was used in a recent attack by Turla on a European government entity. An RPC backdoor named HyperStack was used, and according to the report is probably a custom Turla backdoor. RATs such as Kazuar and Carbon were also used. An interesting thing in the attack was the use of multiple C&C servers, including some on running on hosts within the compromised network. More details are contained in the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.accenture.com/us-en/blogs/cyber-defense/turla-belugasturgeon-compromises-government-entity>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: BlackTech Employing Flagpro in Campaign
A campaign using a new malware dubbed Flagpro and employed by BlackTech is targeting some Japanese companies and has been observed by NTTSecurity.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: BlackTech Employing Flagpro in Campaign
A campaign using a new malware dubbed Flagpro and employed by BlackTech is targeting some Japanese companies and has been observed by NTTSecurity.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Downloader, Dropper/Loader, Exfiltration
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** BlackTech
  *  **Associated Payloads:**
  *  **Targets:** Japanese Defense, Media, Communications
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Spearphishing Email Attachment
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Download and execute tools, execute OS commands, collect authentication information



# Overview

Since at least October 2020, NTTSecurity has observed a campaign by threat actor BlackTech using a malware dubbed Flagpro targeting various Japanese businesses. Using a phishing email as the delivery mechanism, the malware is used during the initial stages of the attack. During this phase, a second stage malware is downloaded and executed. Attached to the email is a password-protected archive file containing an XLSM file. The password is in the phishing email. The XLSM file is tailored to each victim, lending plausibility to the attacker researching its victims. If macros are enabled in the XLSM file, malware is dropped and an EXE file is written to the Startup directory. This file is the Flagpro malware. Communication takes place with a C2 server and commands are sent from the C2 to Flagpro. Checks are made for furtherance of malicious activity based on the environment being attacked. Should the environment meet the standard for additional manipulation, more malware is downloaded and executed. The main functions of the malware are to download and execute a tool, execute OS commands and report results, and to collect and send Windows authentication information. Further technical details can be found in the analysis located within the Reference section below. 

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74056637/BlackTech%20Employing%20Flagpro%20in%20Campaign%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1641411311047&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction. (M1017)
  * Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc. (M1021)
  * Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts. (M1022)
  * Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries. (M1031)
  * Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking. (M1038)
  * Protect sensitive information with strong encryption. (M1041)
  * Use capabilities to prevent successful credential access by adversaries; including blocking forms of credential dumping. (M1043)
  * Use A/V and IDS/IPS signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software. (M1049)
  * Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data. (M1057)



# References
