instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Fullz House Group Grips Mobile Network
The cybercrime group Fullz House has infiltrated a wireless service provider to capture sensitive data. Malwarebytes provides the latest on this campaign.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Data Disclosure




# Overview

A wireless service provider was infiltrated by the cybercrime group, Fullz House. Boom! Mobile provides cellular plans that piggyback on major networks for a discounted cost to consumers. Malwarebytes reports on their discovery of an injection to the provider's website with a one-line code containing a Base64-encoded URL, which then loads a JavaScript library. The code loads a Google analytics script taken from another fake website mimicking PayPal. The code is a card skimmer checking for input fields from which to exfiltrate entered data. Unlike most skimmers, this particular skimmer is noisy since it uses an exfiltration connection each time input fields are filled. The skimmer uses a GET request that is noticeable in analyzed traffic. The domain used, as well as the code, were recognized from previous incidents also using decoy payment portals. The group quietly established a pattern last year and has since registered several lookalike domains. The infection vector was most likely from a vulnerable version of PHP. Boom! Mobile has since removed the skimmer. For further details, please see the report located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.malwarebytes.com/malwarebytes-news/2020/10/mobile-network-operator-falls-into-the-hands-of-fullz-house-criminal-group/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Mozilla Foundation Security Advisories January 26
The Mozilla Foundation has issued three security advisories covering vulnerabilities addressed in Firefox, Firefox ESR, and Thunderbird.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

The Mozilla Foundation has released Firefox 85, Firefox ESR 78.7, and Thunderbird 78.7 to cover multiple vulnerabilities. All three advisories have been rated as High. Issues resolved include user-after-poison, memory corruption, insecure framing, protocol command injection, leaking of cross-origin information, and type confusion. The most serious potential impact from successful exploitation of the vulnerabilities is the remote execution of arbitrary code. For further details, please refer to the appropriate advisory in the Reference section.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/38306087/Mozilla%20Foundation%20Security%20Advisories%20January%2026%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1611811538075&api=v2)

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: REvil Sideloading DLL
The REvil ransomware has been using a legitimate Microsoft binary that sideloads a malicious DLL to carry out file encryption according to a report from McAfee Labs.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Ransomware




# Overview

McAfee Labs has located samples of a REvil dropper that has two PE files embedded in the resource section. One of the files, MsMpEng.exe is a legitimate, signed Microsoft binary. The second file is a malicious DLL that is sideloaded using MsMpEng.exe. The ransomware config is encrypted using RC4. The language and keyboard layout are checked against a list of mostly eastern European countries and if a match is found, files are not encrypted. The config contains a list of services and processes, if found, the matching services are deleted and processes terminated. Files are then encrypted using the Salsa20 algorithm and the system's backdrop is set to display instructions to locate the ransom note left on the system. Further details are available from the report in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.mcafee.com/blogs/other-blogs/mcafee-labs/revil-ransomware-uses-dll-sideloading/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: An Analysis of the Nefilim Ransomware
Nefilim appeared on the threat landscape in 2020 providing operators with double extortion capabilities. Trend Micro published a brief analysis of this ransomware family.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Ransomware




# Overview

Trend Micro has published a blog post analyzing the Nefilim ransomware family. This ransomware, which is believed to have evolved from the Nemty ransomware, appeared in March 2020. Like many recent ransomware families, it provides a double extortion functionality. Initial access is obtained mainly through exposed RDP systems but also may be obtained through the exploitation of known vulnerabilities. With access to a victim system, various components are used to disable anti-virus, exfiltrate data, and drop the Nefilim payload to encrypt the system's files. Data exfiltration is done by archiving a folder of copied files using 7Zip and sending it back to the attackers using MEGASync. The threat actors will also move laterally across a network before carrying out their ransomware attack. They do this using legitimate tools, such as PsExec or WMI. For more information, see the Trend Micro blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/21/b/nefilim-ransomware.html>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Nigerian Bank Hack Denial
Breach/Leak Notification: A Nigerian bank suffered a data breach exposing a database. In a report from Techcabal, details and the bank's response are provided.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Breach




# Overview

A Nigerian bank's database is being sold on underground forums, according to a report from Techcabal. According to Bank Security, a Twitter handle reporting on bank security threats, three other forums have seen the database. When contacted, Unity Bank issued a statement: “Our attention has been drawn to social media reports purporting a data breach of our systems,” Unity Bank said. "For the avoidance of doubt, Unity Bank wishes to reassure all customers that we take the protection of their personal information very seriously in accordance with data protection legislation. The Bank hereby reassures its customers and the public at large, of the integrity of its systems, controls of which are continually enhanced in line with best practices, to forestall attempts at compromising confidential data.” The statement did not explicitly deny the hack nor did it deny the loss of data. According to Bank Security, PII of 53,000 customers is available in the database dump; however, the data in question is not actual customer data but a recruitment tool from enrollment exercises. More information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * N/A




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://techcabal.com/2020/09/01/two-nigerian-banks-have-been-hacked-they-deny-it-heres-a-bigger-problem/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Vulnerability in Welcart e-Commerce Plugin for WordPress
A report from Wordfence outlines a vulnerability its Threat Intelligence team discovered in an the Welcart e-Commerce plugin for WordPress.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Vulnerability in Welcart e-Commerce Plugin for WordPress
A report from Wordfence outlines a vulnerability its Threat Intelligence team discovered in an the Welcart e-Commerce plugin for WordPress.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability  





# Overview

  
A vulnerability was discovered in Collne Inc's Welcart e-Commerce plugin for WordPress by Wordfence's Threat Intelligence team. The vulnerability could allow an authenticated attacker to include a maliciously crafted string in the "usces_cookie" parameter, potentially resulting in the injection of a PHP object. In its report, Wordfence provides a CVSS 3.0 Base score of 7.5 for the vulnerability. Versions of Welcart e-Commerce plugin prior to 1.9.36 are reported as being vulnerable. The vendor has published an update which addresses the vulnerability. Further information is available from the links in the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * None provided.  





# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.wordfence.com/blog/2020/11/object-injection-vulnerability-in-welcart-e-commerce-plugin/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: NCAS Malware Analysis Report AR21-039B - TEARDROP
A Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency malware analysis report, AR21-039B, has been published through the National Cyber Awareness System. The report provides information on the TEARDROP malware, which is associated with the supply chain compromise of Solar Winds.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: NCAS Malware Analysis Report AR21-039B - TEARDROP
A Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency malware analysis report, AR21-039B, has been published through the National Cyber Awareness System. The report provides information on the TEARDROP malware, which is associated with the supply chain compromise of Solar Winds.

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

 **From the Malware Analysis Report (AR21-039B)**  
 **MAR-10320115-1.v1 - TEARDROP**

This report provides detailed analysis of malicious artifacts associated with a sophisticated supply chain compromise of Solar Winds Orion network management software, identified by the security company FireEye as TEARDROP.

TEARDROP is a loader designed to decrypt and execute an embedded payload on the target system. The payload has been identified as the Cobalt Strike Beacon Implant (Version 4) and provides a remote operator command and control capabilities over a victim system through an encrypted network tunnel. The capabilities include the ability to rapidly exfiltrate data, log keystrokes, take screenshots, and deploy additional payloads.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-039b>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Spammers Get Better at Impersonating Banking Services to Con Victims
Threat actors continue to exploit and leverage the current COVID-19 pandemic, as analysts witnessed a surge of phishing and malspam campaigns posing as online banking services, according to the Bitdefender Antispam Lab.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Phishing, Spam




# Overview

  
Threat actors took advantage of the current COVID-19 pandemic and online Black Friday sales to launch phishing and malspam campaigns, targeting prominent banks in the financial sector, according to the Bitdefender Antispam Lab. Researchers at the Bitdefender Antispam Lab noticed singular tactics integrating social engineering and phishing techniques. Furthermore, researchers uncovered several phishing attempts associated with the campaign from banks world-wide like Bank of America, Standard Bank, Wells Fargo, La Banque Postale, and HSBC Bank, as well as the money transaction services PayPal and Western Union. According to researchers, the most intriguing of all phishing attacks is the one involving the La Banque Postale, where 97.69% of incoming emails associated with the bank were marked as spam. Scammers attempted to dupe the end-user into accessing a malicious link, allowing them to listen in on communications received from the bank. In conclusion, the increase in digital transactions, online shopping, and the management of an individual’s finances online have created new avenues of approach for threat actors and cybercriminals alike. For more information, see the Hot For Security article in the Reference section.

# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://hotforsecurity.bitdefender.com/blog/spammers-get-better-at-impersonating-banking-services-use-lingo-and-legit-layouts-to-con-victims-24805.html>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: A Backdoor Named Crutch
ESET researchers disclose their report of a backdoor and document stealer called Crutch which is used by the APT group Turla.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, APT, Backdoor, Cyberespionage



# Overview

ESET researchers report on a backdoor and document stealer the APT group Turla calls Crutch. They indicate that Crutch is used for specific targets, such as the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in a European Union country. Turla (aka Krypton, Snake, VENOMOUS BEAR, and Waterbug) is a known cyber espionage group that has been active for more than ten years. ESET reveals, in their report, a strong link between Crutch and Gazer (also known as WhiteBear). Data stolen by Crutch was exfiltrated to Dropbox accounts under Turla operator control. The intent of the attack covered by the report was reconnaissance, lateral movement, and espionage. While searching for documentation, it was obvious, in some cases, that the attackers manually controlled which information would be exfiltrated rather than leaving it to an automated process. Based on the timestamps of exfiltrated files, ESET determined the attack had occurred between October 2018 through July 2019. ESET did not rule out phishing email attachments, used as a first-stage downloader, as the initial infection. This could have been something like Skipper or PowerShell Empire. Persistence is gained by using the technique called DLL hijacking. For full details, please review the link in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/35717482/A%20Backdoor%20Named%20Crutch%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1606931615876&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.welivesecurity.com/2020/12/02/turla-crutch-keeping-back-door-open/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Bom Skimmer is Newest Malware from Magecart Group 7
RiskIQ researchers have identified a new skimmer being used by Magecart Group 7. By analyzing this and other skimmers, the researchers were able to identify similarities in code which allows them to attribute this to the notorious group.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Targets:** eCommerce
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Bom Skimmer, MakeFrame Skimmer
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data Theft
  *  **Additional TTPs:** Dual Exfiltration Path



# Overview

RiskIQ researchers have discovered a new skimmer that they have named Bom Skimmer. This new skimmer has been active since 2019 and is currently running on a large number of fake and compromised online stores. The researchers have traced this skimmer back to the notorious Magecart Group 7, which was responsible for high-profile attacks, such as the attack on British Airways in 2018. This skimmer injects its payment form into compromised sites and then exfiltrates the captured data using both an actor-controlled server and a compromised server. Using dual exfiltration paths has been seen in other Magecart skimmers, and assists with attribution. Within this article, RiskIQ also identifies another skimmer in the same family as the Bom Skimmer, which they are calling the MakeFrame skimmer. This skimmer has a lot of the same functionalities as Bom Skimmer, but only uses one exfiltration path at a time, rather than using both compromised and actor-owned infrastructure. Another notable difference is that the MakeFrame skimmer can exfiltrate using either POST or GET requests, whereas Bom skimmer can only use GET requests. Despite this, the researchers assert that MakeFile and other skimmers were integrated into the version of the Bom skimmer that is in use today. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64129082/Bom%20Skimmer%20is%20Newest%20Malware%20from%20Magecart%20Group%207%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1632999773280&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.

  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.

  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.

  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.

  * Do not allow administrator accounts that have permissions to modify the Web content of organization login portals to be used for day-to-day operations that may expose them to potential adversaries on unprivileged systems (M1026).

  * Network intrusion detection and prevention systems that use network signatures to identify traffic for specific adversary malware can be used to mitigate activity at the network level. (M1031).



# References

  * <https://community.riskiq.com/article/743ea75b/description>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1056 - Input Capture  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1020 - Automated Exfiltration  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1565 - Data Manipulation

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Similarities Between the ShadowPad and PlugX Backdoors
Using samples from attacks on systems located in Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan, analysts from Doctor Web discovered relationships between the ShadowPad and PlugX backdoors.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Similarities Between the ShadowPad and PlugX Backdoors
Using samples from attacks on systems located in Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan, analysts from Doctor Web discovered relationships between the ShadowPad and PlugX backdoors.

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

According to a report from Doctor Web, the ShadowPad backdoor may be an evolution of the PlugX backdoor. The Winnti APT group are known to use modified versions of ShadowPad. Indicators from the malware involved in attacks on systems in Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan suggest that Chinese APT groups may have been involved in the attacks. Based on similarities found in the code of the ShadowPad and PlugX backdoors, Doctor Web analysts conclude that both backdoors may have been created by the same developers and is a more advanced backdoor than PlugX. Further details are available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * [https://news.drweb.com/show/?i=14048&lng=en&c=23](https://news.drweb.com/show/?i=14048&lng=en&c=23)

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: An Analysis of the Infostealing Malware - Saintstealer
A report from Cyble Research Labs provides an analysis of an information stealer named Saintstealer that has been developed by a group they refer to as the Saint gang.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Infostealer
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** The Saint gang.
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Saintstealer
  *  **Targets:** Unspecified
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unspecified
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Collection and exfiltration of information.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

Saintstealer is an information stealer that began life somewhere around November 2021 and was developed by a group that Cyble Research Labs refer to as the Saint gang in their report whwich provides an analysis of Saintstealer. No information is provided in the report on how Saintstealer is being distributed. The report does not that the C&C server used by the version of Saintstealer they analyzed is also used as the C&C server for a number of other information-stealing malware families including BloodyStealer, EchelonStealer, Nixscare stealer, Predator stealer, and QuasarRAT. Saintstealer is delivered in the form of a 32-bit C# .NET-based executable. Once executed it carries out a number of functions including environment checks so as to avoid running in a sandbox or virtual environment. If the environment checks are passed it then begins capturing information from the system such as cookies, information from various stores such as browsers and VPN clients, Discord tokens, Steam credentials, files from certain folders, and system information. The captured data is compressed and then sent as an attachment to a Telegram account. Additionally, some information is also sent to a URL. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below. 

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://blog.cyble.com/2022/04/27/dissecting-saintstealer/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Tactics and Techniques:**

 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1543 - Create or Modify System Process  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1528 - Steal Application Access Token  
T1539 - Steal Web Session Cookie  
T1552 - Unsecured Credentials  
T1555 - Credentials from Password Stores  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1007 - System Service Discovery  
T1046 - Network Service Scanning  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
T1124 - System Time Discovery  
T1518 - Software Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1113 - Screen Capture  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
  


 **Mitigations:**

 **M1015:** Active Directory Configuration - Configure Active Directory to prevent use of certain techniques; use SID Filtering, etc.  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1027:** Password Policies - Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1032:** Multi-factor Authentication - Use two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate to a system; such as username and password in addition to a token from a physical smart card or token generator.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1035:** Limit Access to Resource Over Network - Prevent access to file shares, remote access to systems, unnecessary services. Mechanisms to limit access may include use of network concentrators, RDP gateways, etc.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1041:** Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
 **M1054:** Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
 **M1057:** Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

An Analysis of the Infostealing Malware - Saintstealer
A report from Cyble Research Labs provides an analysis of an information stealer named Saintstealer that has been developed by a group they refer to as the Saint gang.

  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** The Saint gang.

  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Collection and exfiltration of information.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

Saintstealer is an information stealer that began life somewhere around November 2021 and was developed by a group that Cyble Research Labs refer to as the Saint gang in their report whwich provides an analysis of Saintstealer. No information is provided in the report on how Saintstealer is being distributed. The report does not that the C&C server used by the version of Saintstealer they analyzed is also used as the C&C server for a number of other information-stealing malware families including BloodyStealer, EchelonStealer, Nixscare stealer, Predator stealer, and QuasarRAT. Saintstealer is delivered in the form of a 32-bit C# .NET-based executable. Once executed it carries out a number of functions including environment checks so as to avoid running in a sandbox or virtual environment. If the environment checks are passed it then begins capturing information from the system such as cookies, information from various stores such as browsers and VPN clients, Discord tokens, Steam credentials, files from certain folders, and system information. The captured data is compressed and then sent as an attachment to a Telegram account. Additionally, some information is also sent to a URL. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below. 

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://blog.cyble.com/2022/04/27/dissecting-saintstealer/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Tactics and Techniques:**

 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1543 - Create or Modify System Process  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1528 - Steal Application Access Token  
T1539 - Steal Web Session Cookie  
T1552 - Unsecured Credentials  
T1555 - Credentials from Password Stores  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1007 - System Service Discovery  
T1046 - Network Service Scanning  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
T1124 - System Time Discovery  
T1518 - Software Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1113 - Screen Capture  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
  


 **Mitigations:**

 **M1015:** Active Directory Configuration - Configure Active Directory to prevent use of certain techniques; use SID Filtering, etc.  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1027:** Password Policies - Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1032:** Multi-factor Authentication - Use two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate to a system; such as username and password in addition to a token from a physical smart card or token generator.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1035:** Limit Access to Resource Over Network - Prevent access to file shares, remote access to systems, unnecessary services. Mechanisms to limit access may include use of network concentrators, RDP gateways, etc.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1041:** Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
 **M1054:** Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
 **M1057:** Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Zero-Day Sophos Firewall Exploitation
Volexity research reported on a customer who was targeted by multiple Chinese threat actors. These groups were all well-resourced, sophisticated, and assessed to be advanced persistent threats (APT). Specifically, Volexity detected the use of a recent zero-day exploit to target the customer’s firewall.
output:
Summary
=======



Threat Details
==============

* **Threat Type:** Vulnerability Exploitation, Malware
* **Associated Threat Actors:**DriftingCloud
* **Associated Payloads:** Weevely Webshell, PupyRAT, Pantegana, Sliver
* **Targets:** Vulnerable Sophos Firewalls
* **Initial Infection Vector:** Exploitation of External Sophos Firewalls via CVE-2022-1040
* **Post-Compromise Actions:** MITM Attack, Data Theft, Account Compromise, Session Hijacking
* **Additional TTPs:**See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below

Overview
========

Volexity researchers conducted an assessment of a Sophos firewall after detection of suspicious traffic from the device. The investigation suggested the firewall was compromised via the internet-exposed User Portal component.  Researchers identified suspicious and repeated access targeting a valid JSP file (login.JSP). Further analysis of the firewall revealed that the threat actor established a webshell backdoor through modification of a legitimate component file. The threat actor utilized this webshell in order to establish multiple VPN user accounts and associated certificate pairs for legitimate network access persistence. The attacker also modified specific DNS responses on the compromised device to conduct Man-in-the-Middle (MITM) attacks targeting hostnames, which belonged to the victim organization.

The MITM attacks allowed the attacker to conduct credential and session cookie theft from administrative access to the websites' content management systems (CMS). Veloxity's investigation identified multiple instances of successful access, via legitimate session cookies, to the client's CMS admin pages attributed to the attacker. These sessions were used to upload a variation of the Weevely webshell. These webshells then were used to upload additional malware. Further information is available from the link in the References section below.

Indicators of Compromise
========================

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

Recommendations
===============

* For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

References
==========

* [https://www.volexity.com/blog/2022/06/15/driftingcloud-zero-day-sophos-firewall-exploitation-and-an-insidious-breach/](https://www.volexity.com/blog/2022/06/15/driftingcloud-zero-day-sophos-firewall-exploitation-and-an-insidious-breach/ "Follow link")

**Defense Evasion - TA0005**

 T1055 - Process Injection  
   T1055.001 - Dynamic-link Library Injection

 T1070 - Indicator Removal on Host

**Credential Access - TA0006**  
 T1557 - Adversary-in-the-Middle

 T1539 - Steal Web Session Cookie

**Collection - TA0009**  
 T1557 - Adversary-in-the-Middle

**Command and Control - TA0011**

 T1071- Application Layer Protocol  
   T1071.001 - Web Protocols 

**Mitigations:**

**M1016:**  Vulnerability Scanning - Vulnerability scanning is used to find potentially exploitable software vulnerabilities to remediate them.  
**M1017:**  User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.

**M1024:**  Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
**M1026:**  Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
**M1030:**  Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
**M1031:**  Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
**M1032:**  Multi-factor Authentication - Use two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate to a system; such as username and password in addition to a token from a physical smart card or token generator.  
**M1035:**  Limit Access to Resource Over Network - Prevent access to file shares, remote access to systems, unnecessary services. Mechanisms to limit access may include use of network concentrators, RDP gateways, etc.  
**M1037:**  Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
**M1040:**  Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
**M1041:**  Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
**M1042:**  Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
**M1048:**  Application Isolation and Sandboxing - Restrict execution of code to a virtual environment on or in transit to an endpoint system.  
**M1050:**  Exploit Protection - Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.  
**M1051:**  Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
**M1056:**  Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: NVIDIA Security Bulletin - January 7th, 2021
NVIDIA published a security bulletin addressing vulnerabilities in their GPU Display Driver and vGPU software.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

 In total, sixteen vulnerabilities are highlighted. The GPU Display Driver for both Linux and Windows are affected. Potential impacts, if successfully exploited, include denial of service, escalation of privileges, data tampering, or information disclosure. NVIDIA has released patches fixing all of the issues addressed in the security bulletin. We recommend reviewing the advisories in the Reference section for patches and mitigation advice. 

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/35719964/NVIDIA%20Security%20Bulletin%20-%20January%207th%2C%202021%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1610555992225&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://nvidia.custhelp.com/app/answers/detail/a_id/5142/kw/Security%20Bulletin>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Chinese APT Group Cicada Conducting Sustained Espionage Campaign
Symantec researchers have been tracking the activity of the Chinese APT group Cicada. They have been attacking multiple organizations around the world, which is broadening the scope from the initial targets of Japanese-linked companies. Details have been published in a report.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Chinese APT Group Cicada Conducting Sustained Espionage Campaign
Symantec researchers have been tracking the activity of the Chinese APT group Cicada. They have been attacking multiple organizations around the world, which is broadening the scope from the initial targets of Japanese-linked companies. Details have been published in a report.

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Cyber-Espionage
  *  **Associated Threat Groups:** Cicada
  *  **Targets:** Governmental and NGOs across many countries
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Sodamaster (S0627), Mimikatz
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Exploitation of exchange server
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Unknown



# Overview

Cicada, also known as APT10, has been linked to espionage operations dating back to 2009. Symantec has discovered a new campaign starting in mid-2021 targeting a much broader scope than the initial activity which targeted Japanese-linked companies. The new campaign targets a wide range of Government and non-governmental organizations in multiple countries. In a number of instances, initial access was gained on Microsoft Exchange servers, hinting that there may have been a zero-day vulnerability used in the attacks on Exchange servers. Once access was gained, the group used a custom loader and a backdoor called Sodamaster. This malware is believed to be used exclusively by Cicada, which allows for attribution. It is a fileless malware that can evade detection and collect system information, as well as download more malware. It can also obfuscate and encrypt C2 traffic. For more information, please see the link in the reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.



# References

  * <https://symantec-enterprise-blogs.security.com/blogs/threat-intelligence/cicada-apt10-china-ngo-government-attacks>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Tactics and Techniques:**

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1106 - Native API  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1497 - Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion  
T1497.001 - System Checks  
T1497.003 - Time Based Evasion  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1012 - Query Registry  
T1033 - System Owner/User Discovery  
T1057 - Process Discovery  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1105 - Ingress Tool Transfer  
T1573 - Encrypted Channel  
T1573.001 - Symmetric Cryptography  
T1573.002 - Asymmetric Cryptography  
  


 **Mitigations:**

 **M1016:** Vulnerability Scanning - Vulnerability scanning is used to find potentially exploitable software vulnerabilities to remediate them.  
 **M1020:** SSL/TLS Inspection - Break and inspect SSL/TLS sessions to look at encrypted web traffic for adversary activity.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1048:** Application Isolation and Sandboxing - Restrict execution of code to a virtual environment on or in transit to an endpoint system.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1050:** Exploit Protection - Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Electric Company in Texas Being Used by Scammers
In an effort to intimidate customers of Austin Energy, scammers are using threatening phone calls to intimidate the customers into paying a non-existent bill with payment cards. Bleeping Computer and Austin Energy have both reported on these efforts.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

A Texas utility company's customers are being targeted by scammers in an effort to obtain money. The scammers telephone customers and warn them their utilities will be disconnected unless they make an immediate payment using reloadable debit cards or other non-traceable forms of payment. This type of request is common amongst scammers seeking quick financial gain. A large winter storm across the state seems to be the catalyst behind this scam. The Austin Energy company released a statement via Twitter advising customers on policy and protective measures. For more information, see the links located within the Reference section below. 

# CVEs

  * N/A




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.

  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.

  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.

  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.

  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.




# Reference

  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/texas-electric-company-warns-of-scammers-threatening-to-cut-power/>

  * [https://twitter.com/austinenergy/status/1363918887646019584](https://twitter\[.\]com/austinenergy/status/1363918887646019584)
  * <https://austinenergy.com/ae/residential/report-a-problem/report-telephone-scams>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: ISC BIND - Multiple Vulnerabilities Addressed
The ISC has published three Security Advisories pertaining to BIND. ISC has rated two of the advisories as High and one as Medium.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

Three Security Advisories for BIND have been published by the ISC. Two of the advisories have been rated as High and one as Medium by the ISC. All three of the vulnerabilities addressed by the advisories are exploitable remotely and have a potential impact of denial of service conditions. One of the vulnerabilities, CVE-2021-25216, if the named binaries have been compiled for 32-bit platforms could, under certain conditions, potentially allow for the remote execution of arbitrary code. Further information, including affected versions, workarounds, and available updates, is available from the advisories linked in the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * CVE-2021-25214, CVE-2021-25215, CVE-2021-25216




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://kb.isc.org/docs/cve-2021-25214>

  * <https://kb.isc.org/docs/cve-2021-25215>
  * <https://kb.isc.org/docs/cve-2021-25216>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: The Warzone RAT and Confucius Campaign
Quickheal has published a report on the infection chain and malware used in a campaign attributed to the South Asian APT group named Confucius.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

A campaign that Quickheal attributes to the South Asian APT group named Confucius has been distributing the Warzone RAT. A weaponized Word .docx file that uses template injection to download the next stage which attempts to exploit an older Office vulnerability, CVE-2017-11882. If exploitation is successful, the Warzone RAT is installed. Warzone RAT was discovered being distributed as a malware-as-a-service offering in 2018. Quickheal notes in its report that a 'cracked' version of Warzone is available from a GitHub repository. Warzone is advertised as being able to bypass UAC to elevate privileges, bypass Windows Defender, log keystrokes, execute a remote shell, achieve persistence, provide an RDP connection, access a device's webcam, and download and execute files. While the Quickheal report does not specifically state the weaponized .docx file is delivered via email, it does note that this is a typical delivery mechanism. Further details are available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blogs.quickheal.com/warzone-rat-beware-of-the-trojan-malware-stealing-data-triggering-from-various-office-documents/>

Quickheal has published a report on the infection chain and malware used in a campaign attributed to the South Asian APT group named Confucius.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: BlackCat Ransomware
A report from Kaspersky provides an analysis of the BlackCat ransomware and notes the use of an exfiltration tool that was previously associated with the BlackMatter ransomware group.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Ransomware
  *  **Targets:** Typically businesses.
  *  **Ransomware Family:** BlackCat
  *  **Additional Payloads:** Fendr (ExMatter), Mimikatz, PsExec.
  *  **RaaS Operation:** Yes
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unspecified in the report.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data collection and exfiltration, File encryption.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

BlackCat is a Ransomware-as-a-Service (RaaS) group that began advertising its services in December 2021 using the name ALPHV. According to a report from Kaspersky, one of the notable differences between BlackCat and other ransomware operators is that the BlackCat ransomware is written in the Rust language and provides variants for Linux and Windows. BlackCat uses the double extortion technique in their attacks and the tool used to exfiltrate data from a victim system is named Fendr, also known as ExMatter. This tool was previously associated with the BlackMatter ransomware group. Kaspersky notes that the modification and reuse of Fendr, and telemetry, suggests that some members of BlackCat are linked to the BlackMatter group. The version of the BlackCat ransomware analyzed by Kaspersky is a command-line application that accepts several arguments at runtime. Many of the operations it carries out, such as privilege escalation, deleting Windows shadow copies, and killing processes, are similar to other ransomware. For lateral movement, a compressed version of PsExec is used. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.



# References

  * <https://securelist.com/a-bad-luck-blackcat/106254/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Tactics and Techniques:**

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.001 - Malware  
T1588 - Obtain Capabilities  
T1588.002 - Tool  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1068 - Exploitation for Privilege Escalation  
T1134 - Access Token Manipulation  
T1134.003 - Make and Impersonate Token  
T1548 - Abuse Elevation Control Mechanism  
T1548.002 - Bypass User Account Control  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1003 - OS Credential Dumping  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
T1087 - Account Discovery  
T1087.001 - Local Account  
T1087.002 - Domain Account  
  
 **Lateral Movement - TA0008**  
T1570 - Lateral Tool Transfer  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1020 - Automated Exfiltration  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact  
T1489 - Service Stop  
T1490 - Inhibit System Recovery  
  


 **Mitigations:**

 **M1015:** Active Directory Configuration - Configure Active Directory to prevent use of certain techniques; use SID Filtering, etc.  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1019:** Threat Intelligence Program - A threat intelligence program helps an organization generate their own threat intelligence information and track trends to inform defensive priorities to mitigate risk.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1024:** Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
 **M1025:** Privileged Process Integrity - Protect processes with high privileges that can be used to interact with critical system components through use of protected process light, anti-process injection defenses, or other process integrity enforcement measures.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1027:** Password Policies - Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1041:** Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
 **M1043:** Credential Access Protection - Use capabilities to prevent successful credential access by adversaries; including blocking forms of credential dumping.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1048:** Application Isolation and Sandboxing - Restrict execution of code to a virtual environment on or in transit to an endpoint system.  
 **M1050:** Exploit Protection - Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
 **M1052:** User Account Control - Configure Windows User Account Control to mitigate risk of adversaries obtaining elevated process access.  
 **M1053:** Data Backup - Take and store data backups from end user systems and critical servers. Ensure backup and storage systems are hardened and kept separate from the corporate network to prevent compromise.  
 **M1056:** Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Silently Running Facebook Ads with Exploits
At this year's Virus Bulletin international conference, which was virtual, researchers from FaceBook presented the findings of their research into a malware family they’ve named "SilentFade". The name is short for "Silently running Facebook ADs with Exploits".
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Facebook researchers believe that malware named SilentFade, and the creators and operators of it, came onto the scene in early 2016. Since then, the SilentFade malware has been consistently improved with additional features and has been expanded to target other social networks and services. SilentFade is typically installed through a downloader that is bundled with pirated software. There are usually three or four components, including the downloader, that make up the SilentFade package. The downloader installs the payload as either a standalone component, or as a Windows service. Successfully installed, SilentFade will obtain the victim's Facebook credentials along with cookies from various browsers. As the name says, the objective of SilentFade is to run ads and pay for them using the stolen account credentials. Facebook attributes SilentFade to a Chinese company and filed a lawsuit against the company in December 2019. SilentFade has so far resulted in payment and ad fraud worth more than 4 million USD. See the report linked in the Reference section below for further details.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://vblocalhost.com/uploads/VB2020-Karve-Urgilez.pdf>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: New Version of CRAT Trojan
Cisco Talos are reporting their discovery of a new version of the CRAT Trojan. Prior versions of CRAT have been attributed to the Lazarus group, and Talos report that the TTPs associated with the new version are similar.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

The CRAT Trojan is known to have been used in past attacks by the Lazarus group. A new version of CRAT discovered by Cisco Talos exhibits similar TTPs. Lazarus is widely known as HIDDEN COBRA, and in addition are also known as APT38, the Guardians of Peace, Nickel Academy, and Zinc. IBM X-Force tracks the group as ITG03. CRAT is obfuscated, utilizes a number of techniques to avoid detection, and can function as a standalone RAT. It provides a modular framework and can download plugins from its C&C servers. The known plugins provide functions to log keystrokes, monitor the clipboard, take screenshots, and install the Hansom ransomware plugin. Previous versions of CRAT are known to have been delivered using malicious HWP documents that targeted the vulnerability CVE-2017-8291. Talos is not aware of the method of distribution for the new version of CRAT but considers it likely malicious documents are being used. Further details can be found in the Talos report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.talosintelligence.com/2020/11/crat-and-plugins.html>

Cisco Talos are reporting their discovery of a new version of the CRAT Trojan. Prior versions of CRAT have been attributed to the Lazarus group, and Talos report that the TTPs associated with the new version are similar.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Ryuk is Back and More Dangerous
According to an independent researcher, Ryuk has returned and is stronger than last seen. Publishing his findings on Twitter, the researcher (@th3_protoCOL) shares his discovery.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

By all appearances, it seems Ryuk is back and is stronger than ever before. According to an independent researcher, Chad (Twitter handle: th3_protoCOL), new activity has been observed featuring the infamous malware, Ryuk. In his tweet thread, the detection rate is extremely low with only 9 of 71 engines detecting this latest iteration of the malware. He details some of the processes to hunt:

  * vssadmin.exe Delete Shadows /all /quiet
  * bcdedit /set default (contains {} around default) recoverenabled No & bcdedit /set default (contains {} around default)
  * WMIC.exe shadowcopy delete



Two samples are provided in the IoCs section below. It appears the TTPs indicated include KEGTAP phishes and non-default Cobalt Strike. We will update this collection as more information becomes available. 

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://twitter.com/th3_protoCOL/status/1311283150774054914?s=20>

  * <https://www.virustotal.com/gui/file/cfe1678a7f2b949966d9a020faafb46662584f8a6ac4b72583a21fa858f2a2e8/detection>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Multiple Vulnerabilities Addressed in Citrix Hypervisor and XenServer
A Security Bulletin for Citrix Hypervisor and XenServer resolves ten vulnerabilities, the most serious of which could allow a guest system to compromise the host.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Multiple Vulnerabilities Addressed in Citrix Hypervisor and XenServer
A Security Bulletin for Citrix Hypervisor and XenServer resolves ten vulnerabilities, the most serious of which could allow a guest system to compromise the host.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

  
 The vulnerabilities could potentially allow a guest administrator to delete xenstore thereby causing a denial of service, or elevate their privileges to those of the host the guest is installed on. The vulnerabilities affect various versions of Hypervisor 8.1 and 8.2 LTSR, and XenServer 7.0 and 7.1 LTSR. Further details, including available updates are, can be found in the Citrix bulletin linked in the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/35718385/Multiple%20Vulnerabilities%20Addressed%20in%20Citrix%20Hypervisor%20and%20XenServer%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1608088909871&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://support.citrix.com/article/CTX286756>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: BladeHawk Targets Ethnic Kurds with Android RATs
ESET has published a report on a campaign conducted by the BladeHawk group that used Facebook postings to target ethnic Kurds with the Android RATs 888 and SpyNote.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Android Malware
  *  **Targets:** Ethnic Kurds and their supporters
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** 888 RAT, and SpyNote (S0305)
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Fake apps containing the malware.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions and** **Additional TTPs:** See MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

According to ESET, the BladeHawk group created Facebook profiles that posted links to fake Android apps. The profiles gave the appearance of being news feeds, news about Android in Kurdish, and news that would interest supporters of the Kurds. The postings contained links to apps that, while appearing legitimate, contained commercial malware, the 888 and SpyNote RATs. The same profiles were also used to post links to malicious apps to certain public Facebook groups which have a combined number of followers in excess of 11,000. In some cases, phishing activities were also observed. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64127353/BladeHawk%20Targets%20Ethnic%20Kurds%20with%20Android%20RATs%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1631158059643&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://www.welivesecurity.com/2021/09/07/bladehawk-android-espionage-kurdish/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **For 888 RAT**

 **Initial Access TA0027**  
T1444 Masquerade as Legitimate Application

 **Persistence TA0028**  
T1402 Broadcast Receivers   
  
**Defense Evasion TA0030**  
T1508 Suppress Application Icon   
T1447 Delete Device Data  
  
 **Credential Access TA0031**  
T1411 Input Prompt  
  
 **Discovery TA0032**  
T1418 Application Discovery  
T1420 File and Directory Discovery  
  
 **Collection TA0035**  
T1433 Access Call Log   
T1430 Location Tracking  
T1432 Access Contact List  
T1429 Capture Audio  
T1512 Capture Camera  
T1412 Capture SMS Messages  
T1533 Data from Local System  
T1513 Screen Capture  
  
 **Command And Control TA0037**  
T1509 Uncommonly Used Port  
  
 **Impact TA0034**  
T1582 SMS Control  
T1447 Delete Device Data

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Zoom Phish Sent Via Constant Contact Mailer
A recent Zoom phishing campaign caught the attention of Cofense researchers due to its use of a compromised Constant Contact account to send the emails.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Zoom Phish Sent Via Constant Contact Mailer
A recent Zoom phishing campaign caught the attention of Cofense researchers due to its use of a compromised Constant Contact account to send the emails.

# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

Cofense has published their analysis of a recent Zoom-themed phishing campaign. Zoom themes have been widely used in phishing campaign since the increased utilization of the software during the pandemic. The body of the phishing email claims the recipient's Zoom account has been suspended and requires verification. What is unique about this campaign as compared to other Zoom phishing campaigns is the use of the legitimate Constant Contact mailer to bypass email defenses. It appears a Constant Contact user's account was compromised and subsequently used by attackers to send the phishing emails. If a user clicks on the link in the email, they are redirected through a series of URLs beginning with a Constant Contact referrer URL. The final landing page is a copy of the Microsoft Outlook login page. Any entered credentials are exfiltrated to the attacker. For more information, see the Cofense blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://cofense.com/blog/zoom-phish-constant-contact>
