instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Cobalt Mirage Conducts Ransomware Operations in U.S.
Secureworks researchers released a report detailing their investigation into possible activity involving the Cobalt Mirage threat group. Reporting indicates that this threat actor is connected to Iran and has been active since June 2020.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Cobalt Mirage Conducts Ransomware Operations in U.S.
Secureworks researchers released a report detailing their investigation into possible activity involving the Cobalt Mirage threat group. Reporting indicates that this threat actor is connected to Iran and has been active since June 2020.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type: Ransomware**
  *  **Associated Threat Actors: Cobalt Mirage, Cobalt Illusion, Phosphorous, TunnerVision**
  *  **Associated Payloads: BitLocker, DiskCryptor**
  *  **Targets: U.S. philanthropic organization**



# Overview

Secureworks Counter Threat Unit (CTU) has recently collected intelligence based on incident response investigations and open-source reporting. The researchers have received reflections that indicate that Cobalt Mirage has been conducting offensive cyber operations in Israel, the U.S., Europe, and Australia. Cobalt Mirage has been linked to the Iranian threat group Cobalt Illusion and past activities have also been reported as Phosphorous and TunnelVison. IBM X-Force has connected activities between these groups and tracks them as ITG18.

Secureworks CTU is tracking separate clusters of activity involving Cobalt Mirage. Clusters A and B seem to have two separate goals for operational focus. Cluster A operations include BitLocker and DiskCryptor to conduct ransomware attacks for financial gain. Cluster B is assessed to be conducting targeted attacks to collect intelligence. Reporting indicates that this threat actor group scans internet-facing servers for unpatched flaws in Fortinet appliances and Microsoft Exchange Servers. Reporting also indicates that Cobalt Mirage targeted U.S. local government networks in March of this year and leveraged vulnerabilities in Log4shell. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

# Recommendations

  * For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://www.secureworks.com/blog/cobalt-mirage-conducts-ransomware-operations-in-us>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

####  **Tactics and Techniques:**

####  **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1595 - Active Scanning  
T1595.002 - Vulnerability Scanning  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1189 - Drive-by Compromise  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1098 - Account Manipulation  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1114 - Email Collection  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
T1571 - Non-Standard Port

 **Mitigations:**

 **M1016:** Vulnerability Scanning - Vulnerability scanning is used to find potentially exploitable software vulnerabilities to remediate them.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1032:** Multi-factor Authentication - Use two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate to a system; such as username and password in addition to a token from a physical smart card or token generator.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1041:** Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1048:** Application Isolation and Sandboxing - Restrict execution of code to a virtual environment on or in transit to an endpoint system.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1050:** Exploit Protection - Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
 **M1056:** Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.

 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1048:** Application Isolation and Sandboxing - Restrict execution of code to a virtual environment on or in transit to an endpoint system.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1050:** Exploit Protection - Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
 **M1056:** Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Cadbury Chocolate Lovers Fall Victim to Spoofing Attacks
The multinational confectionery company Cadbury fell victim to a spoofing campaign, targeting buyers and duping victims into sharing sensitive credentials.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Cadbury Chocolate Lovers Fall Victim to Spoofing Attacks
The multinational confectionery company Cadbury fell victim to a spoofing campaign, targeting buyers and duping victims into sharing sensitive credentials.

# Threat Type

  * Spoofing




# Overview

  
The Facebook group “Cadbury Rewards” began posting spurious advertisements on Facebook guaranteeing victims a free hamper of chocolate for liking and sharing the malicious post. Once victims click and access the link in the ad, they are redirected to a specially-branded portal and asked to provide their name, address, mobile phone number, and bank card details. By leveraging and exploiting Facebook, threat actors are able to manipulate end-users into sharing and reposting the malicious URL link in the ad. A tweet from the Cadbury UK Twitter account requests buyers of their brand be aware and take the necessary precautions to avoid falling victim to these attacks. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.infosecurity-magazine.com/news/cadbury-social-media-scammers/>

  * <https://twitter.com/CadburyUK/status/1325818442633580545>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: The Many Faces of Gozi
The Gozi malware family is ever emerging in new features, strains, and threat actors employing the malicious software. Check Point Research delves into the different flavors of Gozi in a new white paper.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: The Many Faces of Gozi
The Gozi malware family is ever emerging in new features, strains, and threat actors employing the malicious software. Check Point Research delves into the different flavors of Gozi in a new white paper.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, RAT




# Overview

Originally a small banking Trojan, Gozi has undergone massive changes in the number of variants available to threat actors. Operating continuously since 2007, Gozi has infected millions of machines and done untold damage to all types of industries and users. At its core, Gozi variants carry similar traits across the board. Some of the similarities between versions are strings contained within the binary's .bss section, man-in-the-browser attack, specific C2 check-in format, obfuscation of the C2 check-in, keylogging, email, FTP, IM accounts data and certificate grabbing, among others. Some of the specific strains carry differences that could easily be overlooked as most of the functionality of the RAT remains the same across the board. Goziat, an older variant, makes use of built-in Windows utilities and uses a different resource directory instead of the standard "images" directory. This can be configured during the build phase. Additionally, this variant typically targets .at top-level domains. Another variant, Gozi2RM3 or Gozi IAP2.0, has changes to the C2 structure. Communication is set in two stages. Stage 1 contains a hardcoded C2 in the initial infection binary. An ISP/geolocation deny list is also employed to pre-filter connections that could be researchers. Once the first stage is passed, the second stage pushes the main payload and true configuration. There appears to be a connection between Goziat and Gozi2RM3. Both variants use additional encryption steps by adding a serpent key in addition to the server's RSA key. Goziv3 RM3 targets mostly Australia, Italy, and the U.S. Some significant differences between this version include the use of a PX format, WD structure as opposed to Joined Resources (JJ), a word list is kept in one of the WD structs for generation of registry key names, the use of forfiles.exe for APC injection, and the communications method uses the request body instead of the URI for check-in. As with Gozi2RM3, a geofencing solution is in place. This particular variant has been bundled with a loader used by Emotet and Dridex. There are several variants of Gozi which have become unused. These include Dreambot, Saigon, and ISFB3/Ursnif-A. It's easy to mistake one strain of Gozi for another; however, with the differences pointed out, triage and analysis should help to identify which strain of malware is presented. More details can be found in the report located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://research.checkpoint.com/2020/gozi-the-malware-with-a-thousand-faces/>

The Gozi malware family is ever emerging in new features, strains, and threat actors employing the malicious software. Check Point Research delves into the different flavors of Gozi in a new white paper.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: An Analysis of Monero Miner Variants And Techniques
Trend Micro has published details of the various vulnerabilities being used to spread cryptomining malware, as well as the techniques used to perform the attacks. To evade some detections, the malware uses popular services such as GitHub to download malicious scripts.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: An Analysis of Monero Miner Variants And Techniques
Trend Micro has published details of the various vulnerabilities being used to spread cryptomining malware, as well as the techniques used to perform the attacks. To evade some detections, the malware uses popular services such as GitHub to download malicious scripts.

Summary
=======



Threat Details
==============

* **Malware Type:** Cryptojacker
* **Associated Threat Actors:**Unknown
* **Associated Payloads:** Multiple Monero Miners
* **Targets:** Unknown
* **Initial Infection Vector:**Pre-Authentication RCE
* **Post-Compromise Actions:**Crypto-Mining

Overview
========

Trend Micro has published details of the various vulnerabilities being used to spread cryptomining malware, as well as the techniques used to perform the attacks. In the vulnerabilities listed, it is noted that they are all well-documented and have several proofs of concept published. The samples investigated in this project worked on both Windows and Linux systems. This fact, coupled with the wide range of CVEs used, allows attackers to establish a presence on many hosts, making the campaigns very lucrative. One method of note was the use of valid content delivery mechanisms to bypass IP allowlists. In the Windows samples, a compromised service would download the miner scripts from commonly-used, legitimate sites, such as GitHub or Netlify. This traffic is encrypted, meaning it could be missed by IDS/IPS systems, and the domains are unlikely to be blocked in most environments. Analysis of the wallets associated with the miners shows that these samples are active in the wild and are continuing to spread and mine for cryptocurrency. For more information, see the Red Canary blog post and report in the References section.

Indicators of Compromise
========================

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

CVEs
====

* A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/74055971/An%20Analysis%20of%20Monero%20Miner%20Variants%20And%20Techniques%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1639153580962&api=v2)

Recommendations
===============

* Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
* Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
* Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
* Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior (M1040).

References
==========

* <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/21/l/vulnerabilities-exploited-for-monero-mining-malware-delivered-via-gitHub-netlify.html>

MITRE ATT&CK Framework
======================

**Initial Access - TA0001**  
 T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application  

**Execution - TA0002**  
 T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  

**Command and Control - TA0011**  
 T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  

**Impact - TA0040**  
 T1496 - Resource Hijacking

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: An Analysis of an Attack Against Iranian State Broadcaster
A report from Check Point provides an analysis of an attack occurring in January that targeted Iran's state broadcaster, the Islamic Republic of Iran Broadcasting.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: An Analysis of an Attack Against Iranian State Broadcaster
A report from Check Point provides an analysis of an attack occurring in January that targeted Iran's state broadcaster, the Islamic Republic of Iran Broadcasting.

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware, Destructive attack.
  *  **Targets:** The Islamic Republic of Iran Broadcasting (IRIB).
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** WinScreeny, HttpCallbackService, HttpService, ServerLaunch, and a disk wiper.
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unspecified.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Service disruption and destruction.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

An attack on Iran's state broadcaster, the Islamic Republic of Iran Broadcasting (IRIB), that began on January 27th resulted in multiple state-run television channels broadcasting videos of opposition leaders. A Check Point report which provides an analysis of the attacks notes that malicious executables were used to trigger the playing of the videos or audio files. In addition, wiper malware was used in the attacks in an effort to disrupt the state broadcasting networks. Other tools and malware used in the attack include multiple custom backdoors, malware that takes screenshots, and various configuration files and batch scripts that were used to deploy the malicious files. While the Iranian government attributes the attack to an organization opposed to it, Check Point notes that a claim of responsibility for the attack has been made in the name of Predatory Sparrow, though the claim should be treated with caution. Predatory Sparrow has claimed responsibility for several prior attacks against various Iranian government entities. 

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74059135/An%20Analysis%20of%20an%20Attack%20Against%20Iranian%20State%20Broadcaster%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1645494411463&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).



# References

  * <https://research.checkpoint.com/2022/evilplayout-attack-against-irans-state-broadcaster/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.001 - Malware  
T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
T1608.001 - Upload Malware  
T1608.002 - Upload Tool  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
T1059.003 - Windows Command Shell  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
T1571 - Non-Standard Port  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1485 - Data Destruction  
T1490 - Inhibit System Recovery  
T1496 - Resource Hijacking  
T1561 - Disk Wipe  
T1561.001 - Disk Content Wipe  
T1561.002 - Disk Structure Wipe  
T1565 - Data Manipulation

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: BluStealer Infostealing Malware
A report from Avast provides the results of their analysis of the BluStealer information-stealing malware and notes a spike in activity in early September.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Infostealer
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unspecified
  *  **Associated Payloads:** BluStealer
  *  **Targets:** Various
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malspam with an attached .ISO file.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Persistence, obtaining, and exfiltrating information.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

BluStealer, also referred to as a310logger, is information-stealing malware that is composed of a core written in Visual Basic a module written in .NET. The core reuses code from another piece of malware named SpyEx, with the BluStealer author adding additional features. The .NET module is known to incorporate code from a number of open-source tools including ChromeRecovery, firepwd, StormKitty, and ThunderFox, with the code being used in different variants. Many variants of BluStealer have been observed. The loaded used is written in .NET has been used by a number of other families of malware including Agent Tesla, Formbook, Oski Stealer, RedLine, and the Snake Keylogger. A spike in BluStealer activity, attributed to a single campaign was observed in early September. The primary distribution method is malspam and a large number of the samples obtained by Avast are sourced to a single campaign. Two sample emails are provided in Avast's report, one is in English and is a DHL-themed email, the other is in Spanish and themed as a Mexican metal company. Both emails request that the recipient fills in the form contained in the email attachment. The attachment is a .ISO file and contains the malware. Various techniques such as obfuscation are used to evade detection. If BluStealer detects it is executing in a VM, it will cease execution. Once installed, the malware will steal information such as certain documents, browser and crypto wallet credentials. The stolen data is staged and then exfiltrated using either SMTP or a Telegram bot. Further information is available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64128495/BluStealer%20Infostealing%20Malware%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1632458941081&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://decoded.avast.io/anhho/blustealer/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.001 - Malware  
T1588 - Obtain Capabilities  
T1588.001 - Malware  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.001 - Malicious Link  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1027.002 - Software Packing  
T1140 - Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information  
T1497 - Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion  
T1497.001 - System Checks  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1552 - Unsecured Credentials  
T1552.001 - Credentials In Files  
T1555 - Credentials from Password Stores  
T1555.003 - Credentials from Web Browsers  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
T1056 - Input Capture  
T1056.001 - Keylogging  
T1074 - Data Staged  
T1074.001 - Local Data Staging  
T1113 - Screen Capture  
T1115 - Clipboard Data  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1020 - Automated Exfiltration  
T1029 - Scheduled Transfer  
T1048 - Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64128495/BluStealer%20Infostealing%20Malware%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1632458941081&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Samba Security Advisories - March 24th, 2021
Samba published two security advisories addressing vulnerabilities in their software.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview



The first advisory addresses CVE-2020-27840, a heap corruption vulnerability in all Samba versions since Samba 4.0.0. If successfully exploited, an easily crafted DN could be sent to the Samba AD DC LDAP server to crash it. The second advisory addresses CVE-2021-20277, an out of bound read vulnerability in AD DC LDAP server. If successfully exploited, user-controlled LDAP filter strings may be used to crash the LDAP server.

Samba has released patches and mitigation advice alongside both advisories. We recommend reviewing the advisories and implementing their guidance as soon as possible.

# CVEs

  * CVE-2020-27840

  * CVE-2021-20277




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.samba.org/samba/security/CVE-2020-27840.html>

  * <https://www.samba.org/samba/security/CVE-2021-20277.html>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Buer and Bazar Malware Being Delivered in Phishing Campaign
Using fear tactics, threat actors have launched a phishing campaign at employees of companies. Using the guise of terminating employment, the actors are distributing Buer and Bazar malware, reports Zscaler.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Phishing




# Overview

Using intimidation tactics, threat actors are sending phishing emails containing information about termination of employment in order to implant malware into unsuspecting users' computer systems and networks. Initial infection is accomplished through said phishing email, which contains a Google document link, presumably, from the TrickBot gang. This link leads to the Bazar backdoor as well as the Buer loader. Trickbot has previously used different botnets, including Emotet, for the carrying out of its mission. Unlike most phishing emails, this contains no attachments, only a link to the aforementioned Google documents links. The body of the email states the recipient has been terminated and a link to the termination reasoning is included. In one such email, the reason for termination was positional redundancy. The link actually redirects to a URL used to download the malware payload. Most of the cases analyzed were instances where Bazar malware was downloaded; however, in some cases Buer loader was used. The packer for both is identical. The packed binaries contain an export function that is responsible for decryption and injection. First, a shell is deployed to decrypt a leaderless PE loader which contains the final payload. Using memory allocation, the payload is mapped into memory, given permissions, and transfers control. No self-injection is used. The Bazar backdoor is new malware and is part of TrickBot's toolkit. This is reserved for almost exclusively high profile targets. The Bazar loader is used to download and execute the backdoor, which, in turn, is used to execute binaries, scripts, modules, kill processes, and self removal. Control flow is obfuscated to hinder analysis. The Bazar loader is used to download the backdoor from a C2 using a URI format. This download was captured and analyzed. As with other Trickbot certificates, the certificates for Bazar were created in the same manner. It was also seen that the backdoor downloaded and executed the Cobalt Strike pentesting and post-exploit toolkit. It is hypothesized this is done so ransomware could be deployed, data stolen, or network access could be sold. Buer loader is sold on Russian underground forums. Most of its strings are encrypted and APIs are loaded by hash. Further information can be found in the links located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.zscaler.com/blogs/security-research/spear-phishing-campaign-delivers-buer-and-bazar-malware>

  * <https://www.vkremez.com/2020/04/lets-learn-trickbot-bazarbackdoor.html>
  * <https://krabsonsecurity.com/2019/12/05/buer-loader-new-russian-loader-on-the-market-with-interesting-persistence/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Ongoing Bank of America Phishing Campaigns
Two ongoing Bank of America phishing campaigns are targeting sensitive user and financial data. Bitdefender reports on the techniques implemented by the attackers.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Ongoing Bank of America Phishing Campaigns
Two ongoing Bank of America phishing campaigns are targeting sensitive user and financial data. Bitdefender reports on the techniques implemented by the attackers.

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type** : Phishing
  *  **Target** : Bank of America Users 



_Campaign 1_

  *  **Lure** : Bank of America security alert
  *  **Payload** : HTML attachment with fake verification form
  *  **TTPs** : Spoofed sender, HTML attachment ([T1566.001](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566/001/))
  *  **Compromised data** : Login, ATM pin, credit card details, account numbers, contact information, PII
  *  **Post-compromise actions** : Unknown



 _Campaign 2_

  *  **Lure** : Bank of America gift card giveaway
  *  **Payload** : Link to fake survey
  *  **TTPs** : Spoofed sender, phishing link ([T1566.002](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566/002/))
  *  **Compromised data** : Name, contact information, credit card details
  *  **Post-compromise actions** : Unknown



# Overview

Bitdefender published a blog post detailing two ongoing Bank of America phishing campaigns attempting to steal a variety of victim information. The first uses a security alert theme combined with an attached HTML form. The form attempts to gather as much information as possible, including account login details, credit card and account numbers, contact information, and personally identifiable information (PII), such as social security numbers and date of birth. The second campaign instead claims the user can get a gift card in exchange for participating in a survey. A link in the email takes users to the fake survey, which requests contact information and credit card details. For more information, see the Bitdefender blog post in the Reference section.

# Recommendations

  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.
  * Enable multi-factor authentication (MFA) where possible.



# Reference

  * <https://www.bitdefender.com/blog/hotforsecurity/watch-out-for-these-ongoing-bank-of-america-phishing-campaigns-targeting-customers-in-the-us>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Adrozek Malware
Adrozek is a new browser modifier malware discovered by Microsoft in widespread usage since as early as May 2020. Microsoft published their analysis of this malware family in a recent blog post.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Microsoft has published a blog analyzing a new browser modifier malware dubber "Adrozek." An interesting aspect of this malware is that is targets a variety of browsers (Microsoft Edge, Google Chrome, Yandex Browser, and Mozilla Firefox). It is distributed via drive-by-downloads hosted on an extensive distribution infrastructure. Once on a victim host, it uses a series of installer files to install the main payload. This main payload establishes persistence by registering itself as a service. It modifies browser DLLs and preferences in order to evade detection by disabling certain browser security capabilities. Additionally it modifies or installs browser extensions, which allows for the injection of code into search engines in order to inject ads into search engine results. When users visit these injected ad links, the operator of the malware will receive affiliate revenue. Another component of the malware that is download to the system allows the attacker to steal credentials from browsers. Microsoft notes that this malware is much more sophisticated than existing browser modifier threats. For more information, see the Microsoft blog post in the Reference section.

# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.microsoft.com/security/blog/2020/12/10/widespread-malware-campaign-seeks-to-silently-inject-ads-into-search-results-affects-multiple-browsers/>

Tell me about the following threat: EverythingIsLife is New Crypto Mining Campaign
The Awake Labs team has been tracking a new cryptocurrency mining campaign they have named EverythingIsLife. There does not seem to be an industry or location bias in the targeting, and the researchers are currently unaware of how the malware is spread. However, the malware has been analyzed and published in a report.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: EverythingIsLife is New Crypto Mining Campaign
The Awake Labs team has been tracking a new cryptocurrency mining campaign they have named EverythingIsLife. There does not seem to be an industry or location bias in the targeting, and the researchers are currently unaware of how the malware is spread. However, the malware has been analyzed and published in a report.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Cryptominer
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** EverythingIsLife
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Cryptomining



# Overview

The Awake Labs team has discovered a new type of crypto-miner. This has been named 'EverythingIsLife' due to the repetition of this string in the malware. The malware has been seen in many different locations and industries, and it is currently not known how the malware initially infects a victim. The C2 used by the malware contains '

# Recommendations

For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

# References

  * <https://awakesecurity.com/blog/everythingislife-a-masquerading-cryptocurrency-mining-campaign/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1036 - Masquerading  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1020 - Automated Exfiltration  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1496 - Resource Hijacking  
  


#### Mitigations:

  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1041:** Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1057:** Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: New AdLoad Campaign Undetected by XProtect
As Apple puts more protections in place, malware must adapt to evade detection. SentinelOne reports on the AdLoad malware's successful attempts to avoid Apple's XProtect detection system.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: New AdLoad Campaign Undetected by XProtect
As Apple puts more protections in place, malware must adapt to evade detection. SentinelOne reports on the AdLoad malware's successful attempts to avoid Apple's XProtect detection system.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Adware, Bundleware
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** AdLoad
  *  **Targets:** macOS systems
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malicious file download (T1204)
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Install adware/bundleware
  *  **Additional TTPs:** Installer masquerades as Flash Player, persistence via launchd job (T1053.004), persistence via launch agent (T1543.001), Zsh script (T1059.004)



# Overview

SentinelOne published a blog post analyzing the most recent AdLoad samples, which have been updated to evade Apple's defense systems. AdLoad is an adware loader targeting macOS system that has evolved since its appearance in late 2019. The dropper for AdLoad masquerades as an Adobe Flash Player update in the form of a .app file mounted as a DMG. Many of these files are signed with a valid signature or even notarized by Apple, assisting in its ability to evade detection. Once on the system, AdLoad establishes persistence via the user's LaunchAgents folder and, if privileges are obtained, via a launchd job. A Zsh script is used during the installation process to execute the final payload from the /tmp directory. As of right now, Apple's existing XProtect signatures do not detect this variant of AdLoad. For more information, see the SentinelOne blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/61374531/New%20AdLoad%20Campaign%20Undetected%20by%20XProtect%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1629139596227&api=v2)



# Protection

## Yara Rules
    
    
    private rule Macho  
    {  
        meta:  
            description = "private rule to match Mach-O binaries"  
        condition:  
            uint32(0) == 0xfeedface or uint32(0) == 0xcefaedfe or uint32(0) == 0xfeedfacf or uint32(0) == 0xcffaedfe or uint32(0) == 0xcafebabe or uint32(0) == 0xbebafeca  
    }  
      
    rule adload_2021_system_service  
    {  
        meta:  
            description = "rule to catch Adload .system .service variant"  
            author = "Phil Stokes, SentinelLabs"  
            version = "1.0"  
            last_modified = "2021-08-10"  
            reference = "https://s1.ai/adload"  
        strings:  
            $a = { 48 8D 35 ?? ?? 00 00 48 8D 5D B8 BA B8 00 00 00 48 89 DF E8 ?? ?? FB FF 48 8B 43 08 48 2B 03 66 48 0F 6E C0 66 0F 62 05 ?? ?? 00 00 66 0F 5C 05 ?? ?? 00 00 0F 57 C9 66 0F 7C C0 48 8D 7D A0 0F 29 0F F2 0F 59 05 }  
        condition:  
            Macho and all of them  
    }

# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://labs.sentinelone.com/massive-new-adload-campaign-goes-entirely-undetected-by-apples-xprotect/>

parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
New AdLoad Campaign Undetected by XProtect
As Apple puts more protections in place, malware must adapt to evade detection. SentinelOne reports on the AdLoad malware's successful attempts to avoid Apple's XProtect detection system.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Adware, Bundleware
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** AdLoad
  *  **Targets:** macOS systems
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malicious file download (T1204)
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Install adware/bundleware
  *  **Additional TTPs:** Installer masquerades as Flash Player, persistence via launchd job (T1053.004), persistence via launch agent (T1543.001), Zsh script (T1059.004)



# Overview

SentinelOne published a blog post analyzing the most recent AdLoad samples, which have been updated to evade Apple's defense systems. AdLoad is an adware loader targeting macOS system that has evolved since its appearance in late 2019. The dropper for AdLoad masquerades as an Adobe Flash Player update in the form of a .app file mounted as a DMG. Many of these files are signed with a valid signature or even notarized by Apple, assisting in its ability to evade detection. Once on the system, AdLoad establishes persistence via the user's LaunchAgents folder and, if privileges are obtained, via a launchd job. A Zsh script is used during the installation process to execute the final payload from the /tmp directory. As of right now, Apple's existing XProtect signatures do not detect this variant of AdLoad. For more information, see the SentinelOne blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/61374531/New%20AdLoad%20Campaign%20Undetected%20by%20XProtect%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1629139596227&api=v2)



# Protection

## Yara Rules
    
    
    private rule Macho  
    {  
        meta:  
            description = "private rule to match Mach-O binaries"  
        condition:  
            uint32(0) == 0xfeedface or uint32(0) == 0xcefaedfe or uint32(0) == 0xfeedfacf or uint32(0) == 0xcffaedfe or uint32(0) == 0xcafebabe or uint32(0) == 0xbebafeca  
    }  
      
    rule adload_2021_system_service  
    {  
        meta:  
            description = "rule to catch Adload .system .service variant"  
            author = "Phil Stokes, SentinelLabs"  
            version = "1.0"  
            last_modified = "2021-08-10"  
            reference = "https://s1.ai/adload"  
        strings:  
            $a = { 48 8D 35 ?? ?? 00 00 48 8D 5D B8 BA B8 00 00 00 48 89 DF E8 ?? ?? FB FF 48 8B 43 08 48 2B 03 66 48 0F 6E C0 66 0F 62 05 ?? ?? 00 00 66 0F 5C 05 ?? ?? 00 00 0F 57 C9 66 0F 7C C0 48 8D 7D A0 0F 29 0F F2 0F 59 05 }  
        condition:  
            Macho and all of them  
    }

# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://labs.sentinelone.com/massive-new-adload-campaign-goes-entirely-undetected-by-apples-xprotect/>

I have encountered the following information: Analysis of DecisiveArchitect's Custom Implant, JustForFun
Since 2019, Multiple CrowdStrike teams have been tracking a threat actor targeting global telecommunication companies in order to obtain sensitive data on particular users. Generally, information collected included call detail records (CDRs) and any other information related to targeted users/phone numbers. Crowdstrike is tracking this threat actor under the DecisiveArchitect activity cluster (publicly known as Red Menshen).

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

Summary
=======



Threat Details
==============

* **Threat Type:** Data theft
* **Associated Threat Actors:** DecisiveArchitect (AKA Red Menshen)
* **Associated Payloads:** JustForFun (AKA BPFDoor)
* **Targets:** Telecommunications industry
* **Initial Infection Vector:** CVE-2019-3010 (Privilege Escalation)
* **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data theft
* **Additional TTPs:**See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below

Overview
========

This particular threat actor has been observed primarily targeting Linux and Solaris systems using a custom implant (tracked by Crowdstrike as JustForFun, AKA BPFDoor.) While the threat actor has been observed compromising Windows systems during initial intrusion, they use publicly available tools and frameworks to pivot and maintain persistence while utilizing more sophisticated custom tools on Linux and Solaris systems.  DecisiveArchitect has demonstrated a high degree of sophistication and operational security. In addition to custom tools, they utilize multiple defense evasion techniques to avoid detection.  For more information, please see the link in the References section.

Indicators of Compromise
========================

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

Recommendations
===============

* For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

References
==========

* <https://www.crowdstrike.com/blog/how-to-hunt-for-decisivearchitect-and-justforfun-implant/>

MITRE ATT&CK Framework
======================

#### **Tactics and Techniques:**

**Initial Access - TA0001**  
 T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Applications

**Resource Development - TA0042**T1589 - Establish Accounts

**Persistence - TA0003**  
 T1037 - Boot or Logon Initialization Scripts

**Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
 T1036 - Masquerading

 T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information

**Mitigations:**

**M1016:**  Vulnerability Scanning: Continuous monitoring of vulnerability sources and the use of automatic and manual code review tools should also be implemented as well

**M1038:** Execution Prevention: Use tools that restrict program execution via application control by attributes other than file name for common operating system utilities that are needed.

**M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint: On Windows 10, enable Attack Surface Reduction (ASR) rules to prevent execution of potentially obfuscated scripts. EDR solutions may also be implemented. 

**M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware: Anti-virus can be used to automatically quarantine suspicious files.

**M1051:**  Update Software: A patch management process should be implemented to check unused dependencies, unmaintained and/or previously vulnerable dependencies, unnecessary features, components, files, and documentation.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Microsoft Patch Tuesday - April 2021
In its April 2021 security updates, Microsoft list 108 CVE numbered vulnerabilities in various Microsoft products. Of those, nineteen are rated as Critical, eighty-eight rated as Important, and one as Moderate. One of the vulnerabilities is reported to have been exploited in the wild. Six vulnerabilities in Microsoft's Chromium based browser, Edge, were addressed in a prior update. Microsoft rated these vulnerabilities as Unknown.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

In its April 2021 security updates, Microsoft list 108 CVE numbered vulnerabilities in various Microsoft products. Of those, nineteen are rated as Critical, eighty-eight rated as Important, and one as Moderate. The most severe vulnerabilities could, if exploited, allow for remote code execution. One of the vulnerabilities, CVE-2021-28310 - a Win32k privilege escalation vulnerability, is reported to have been exploited in the wild. Six vulnerabilities in Microsoft's Chromium based browser, Edge, were addressed in a prior update. Microsoft rated these vulnerabilities as Unknown. Further details are available from the links in the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/46072175/Microsoft%20Patch%20Tuesday%20-%20April%202021%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1618516599497&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://msrc.microsoft.com/update-guide>

  * <https://msrc.microsoft.com/update-guide/releaseNote/2021-Apr>
  * [https://securelist.com/zero-day-vulnerability-in-desktop-window-manager-cve-2021-28310-used-in-the-wild/101898/](https://securelist.com/zero-day-vulnerability-in-desktop-window-manager-cve-2021-28310-used-in-the-wild/101898/)

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: TA2552 Seeks Read-Only Access to Office 365 Accounts
TA2552 is a threat actor that has been tracked by Proofpoint. TA2552 uses Spanish language emails enticing victims to click a link in the email which, through an intermediary page, will lead them to a legitimate Microsoft URL that prompts the victim to allow a third-party app, read-only access to the victim's Office 365 account.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: TA2552 Seeks Read-Only Access to Office 365 Accounts
TA2552 is a threat actor that has been tracked by Proofpoint. TA2552 uses Spanish language emails enticing victims to click a link in the email which, through an intermediary page, will lead them to a legitimate Microsoft URL that prompts the victim to allow a third-party app, read-only access to the victim's Office 365 account.

# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

Using Spanish language emails, and imitating brands such as Netflix and Amazon or the Mexican government tax authority, a threat actor named TA2552 has been attempting to entice recipients to click a link in emails. The link in the email leads to a page typically hosted on a compromised website. A link on that page will lead to a genuine Microsoft third-party application consent page where the victim is asked to consent to a third-party app being given read only access to the victim's Office 365 account. If the victim does not provide consent, they will be redirected to a URL which may be benign, or a more traditional phishing page. If the victim consents to the third-party access, TA2552 will gain access to certain information in the user's account. TA2552 activity traces back to having begin as early as August 2019. Further details are available from the Proofpoint report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.proofpoint.com/us/blog/threat-insight/ta2552-uses-oauth-access-token-phishing-exploit-read-only-risks>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Mac Malware Bypassing Security Checks
Protective measures put into place by Apple have been circumvented by threat actors. In a blog post, researcher Patrick Wardle of Objective-See reports on the ability for threat actors to bypass notary functionality on the Mac OSX operating system.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Mac Malware Bypassing Security Checks
Protective measures put into place by Apple have been circumvented by threat actors. In a blog post, researcher Patrick Wardle of Objective-See reports on the ability for threat actors to bypass notary functionality on the Mac OSX operating system.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Adware




# Overview

What was formerly a problem not likely to rear its head in an Apple environment has become more and more common. Threats to macOS have begun an uptick in activity as threat actors look to expand their footprint into the Apple arena. Apple has responded, in kind, by introducing protective measures for its operating system. One such protective measure is the notarization of code by Apple after scanning software for malicious content. If software is not notarized by Apple, the OS will not allow the software to be installed on the system. The latest development in this "good vs. evil" cat and mouse game is the successful circumvention of the notarization process. Using an URL closely resembling the legitimate brew.sh, an active adware campaign is being employed. The website homebrew.sh is the culprit of this adware campaign and could easily be mistaken for the legitimate website due to the name "homebrew.sh" identifying the name of the brew service, thus making it likely to be mistakenly visited. Should a visitor connect to the "homebrew.sh" site, the user is redirected to an update for Adobe Flash Player. In this instance, the adware payloads were fully notarized. Containing the spctl command indicates the code has passed the notarization process. By submitting the application to Apple, they were scanned, approved, and notarized. These payloads are now able to run on macOS versions as recent as "Big Sur." The malware being employed in this campaign is the OSX.Shlayer malware. Although exceedingly common, the malware poses a significant risk to macOS users. This malware has the ability to download and install, with persistence, various macOS adware, including the Bundlore adware. Once the malicious payloads were identified and reported to Apple, the certificates were revoked and notarization status was rescinded. However, on August 28, 2020, the campaign was still live and serving new adware, which is still notarized. Further details can be found in the blog located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.

  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.

  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.

  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.

  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.




# Reference

  * <https://objective-see.com/blog/blog_0x4E.html>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: APT29 Abusing Legitimate Software for Targeted Operations in Europe
Cluster 25 recently released a report detailing the recent activities of APT29. Reporting indicates that this threat group is utilizing legitimate software and web services to obfuscate activities and target organizations in Europe.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** APT29, aka Nobelium, the Dukes, and Cozy Bear.
  *  **Targets:** European political and diplomatic organizations and think tanks. 
  * **Initial Infection Vector:** Spear-phishing.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

Researchers from Cluster 25 report that APT29 is actively targeting organizations in Europe. APT29, also known as Nobelium, the Dukes, and Cozy Bear, is one of the most active and sophisticated Russian threat actors. APT29 has been conducting operations since 2008 and past reporting indicates that APT29’s primary targets are western governments, political, diplomatic, and think tank organizations. The recent campaign conducted by APT29 involves spear-phishing and utilizing legitimate software to side-load a malicious DLL, and web services like Dropbox to act as C&C servers and to download further payloads. Additionally, the use of the side-loaded DLL may enable the threat actors to “unhook” the windows libraries in process memory to avoid EDR detection. The Cluster 25 report also mentions that reporting from other researchers indicates that APT29 is also utilizing Trello and its rest API to simulate a C2 server. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://cluster25.io/2022/05/13/cozy-smuggled-into-the-box/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Tactics and Techniques:**

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.007 - JavaScript  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.001 - Malicious Link  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1098 - Account Manipulation  
T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1055 - Process Injection  
T1055.003 - Thread Execution Hijacking  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1036 - Masquerading  
T1112 - Modify Registry  
T1140 - Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information  
T1202 - Indirect Command Execution  
T1497 - Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion  
T1553 - Subvert Trust Controls  
T1553.002 - Code Signing  
T1562 - Impair Defenses  
T1562.001 - Disable or Modify Tools  
T1620 - Reflective Code Loading  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1057 - Process Discovery  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
T1102 - Web Service  
T1105 - Ingress Tool Transfer  
  


 **Mitigations:**

 **M1013:** Application Developer Guidance: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1024:** Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
 **M1025:** Privileged Process Integrity - Protect processes with high privileges that can be used to interact with critical system components through use of protected process light, anti-process injection defenses, or other process integrity enforcement measures.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1032:** Multi-factor Authentication - Use two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate to a system; such as username and password in addition to a token from a physical smart card or token generator.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1039:** Environment Variable Permissions - Prevent modification of environment variables by unauthorized users and groups.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1043:** Credential Access Protection - Use capabilities to prevent successful credential access by adversaries; including blocking forms of credential dumping.  
 **M1044:** Restrict Library Loading - Prevent abuse of library loading mechanisms in the operating system and software to load untrusted code by configuring appropriate library loading mechanisms and investigating potential vulnerable software.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1046:** Boot Integrity - Use secure methods to boot a system and verify the integrity of the operating system and loading mechanisms.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1054:** Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.

parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
APT29 Abusing Legitimate Software for Targeted Operations in Europe
Cluster 25 recently released a report detailing the recent activities of APT29. Reporting indicates that this threat group is utilizing legitimate software and web services to obfuscate activities and target organizations in Europe.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Threat Details

  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** APT29, aka Nobelium, the Dukes, and Cozy Bear.
  *  **Targets:** European political and diplomatic organizations and think tanks. 
  * **Initial Infection Vector:** Spear-phishing.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

Researchers from Cluster 25 report that APT29 is actively targeting organizations in Europe. APT29, also known as Nobelium, the Dukes, and Cozy Bear, is one of the most active and sophisticated Russian threat actors. APT29 has been conducting operations since 2008 and past reporting indicates that APT29’s primary targets are western governments, political, diplomatic, and think tank organizations. The recent campaign conducted by APT29 involves spear-phishing and utilizing legitimate software to side-load a malicious DLL, and web services like Dropbox to act as C&C servers and to download further payloads. Additionally, the use of the side-loaded DLL may enable the threat actors to “unhook” the windows libraries in process memory to avoid EDR detection. The Cluster 25 report also mentions that reporting from other researchers indicates that APT29 is also utilizing Trello and its rest API to simulate a C2 server. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://cluster25.io/2022/05/13/cozy-smuggled-into-the-box/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Tactics and Techniques:**

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.007 - JavaScript  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.001 - Malicious Link  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1098 - Account Manipulation  
T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1055 - Process Injection  
T1055.003 - Thread Execution Hijacking  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1036 - Masquerading  
T1112 - Modify Registry  
T1140 - Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information  
T1202 - Indirect Command Execution  
T1497 - Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion  
T1553 - Subvert Trust Controls  
T1553.002 - Code Signing  
T1562 - Impair Defenses  
T1562.001 - Disable or Modify Tools  
T1620 - Reflective Code Loading  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1057 - Process Discovery  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
T1102 - Web Service  
T1105 - Ingress Tool Transfer  
  


 **Mitigations:**

 **M1013:** Application Developer Guidance: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1024:** Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
 **M1025:** Privileged Process Integrity - Protect processes with high privileges that can be used to interact with critical system components through use of protected process light, anti-process injection defenses, or other process integrity enforcement measures.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1032:** Multi-factor Authentication - Use two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate to a system; such as username and password in addition to a token from a physical smart card or token generator.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1039:** Environment Variable Permissions - Prevent modification of environment variables by unauthorized users and groups.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1043:** Credential Access Protection - Use capabilities to prevent successful credential access by adversaries; including blocking forms of credential dumping.  
 **M1044:** Restrict Library Loading - Prevent abuse of library loading mechanisms in the operating system and software to load untrusted code by configuring appropriate library loading mechanisms and investigating potential vulnerable software.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1046:** Boot Integrity - Use secure methods to boot a system and verify the integrity of the operating system and loading mechanisms.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.

 **M1054:** Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Digital-Only Banks Targeted In New Phishing Campaign
Digital-only banks are becoming more prevalent, and with this, they are becoming targets for scams and fraud. This blog post on Bushido Token Threat Intel explores one campaign targeting a bank in the UK.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Digital-Only Banks Targeted In New Phishing Campaign
Digital-only banks are becoming more prevalent, and with this, they are becoming targets for scams and fraud. This blog post on Bushido Token Threat Intel explores one campaign targeting a bank in the UK.

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Phishing
  *  **Target:** Monzo Customers
  *  **Lure:** Monzo Login Page
  *  **Compromised Data:** Banking Credentials
  *  **Post-compromise Actions:** Unknown



# Overview

Threat actors are targeting digital only banks as they are becoming more and more common. Bushido Token Threat Intel has published a blog post exploring one campaign targeting the online bank Monzo. The attack targets the mechanism by which a customer verifies their device for use with the bank - using a "golden link" which allows for the first login. The attack follows common phishing patterns, with the page copying Monzo's pages to get the users to enter their credentials and PIN. Along with the victim's name and phone number, the attacker will be able to access the compromised account. Upon exploration of the infrastructure behind the phishing site, the researcher discovered sites also targeting the bank Revolut. There was evidence that this attack was orchestrated by the threat actor "Cazanova", who offers phishing as a service. For more information, please see the link in the reference section

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74058973/Digital-Only%20Banks%20Targeted%20In%20New%20Phishing%20Campaign%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1645111572603&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Proactively reset accounts that are known to be part of breached credentials either immediately, or after detecting bruteforce attempts (M1018).



# References

  * <https://blog.bushidotoken.net/2022/02/mobile-banking-phishing-campaign.html>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
T1583.001 - Domains  
T1588 - Obtain Capabilities  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1056 - Input Capture  
T1056.002 - GUI Input Capture
