instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Cisco Security Advisories January 2021
Cisco has released four advisories that address vulnerabilities in several Cisco products for January 2021.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Cisco Security Advisories January 2021
Cisco has released four advisories that address vulnerabilities in several Cisco products for January 2021.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerabilities




# Overview

Cisco has released security advisories for several of its products. Listed below are the specific products affected and the subsequent patches addressing those vulnerabilities for each product. We recommend reviewing each of the advisories and implementing suggested patches as soon as possible.

## Cisco AnyConnect Secure Mobility Client for Windows DLL Injection Vulnerability

A vulnerability exists which could allow for an authenticated, local attacker to perform a DLL injection attack. Insufficient validation of resources is the source of the vulnerability. Affected versions of the software are Cisco AnyConnect Secure Mobility Client for Windows releases earlier than Release 4.9.04043. This vulnerability has a CVSS Score of 7.8.

 **CVEs**

  * CVE-2021-1237



 **Source**

<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-anyconnect-dll-injec-pQnryXLf>

## Cisco Small Business RV110W, RV130, RV130W, and RV215W Routers Management Interface Remote Command Execution and Denial of Service Vulnerabilities

Vulnerabilities in several Cisco Small Business routers could allow for an authenticated, remote attacker to execute arbitrary code or unexpected restart. Affected routers are listed below. This vulnerability has a CVSS Score of 7.2.

  * RV110W Wireless-N VPN Firewall
  * RV130 VPN Router
  * RV130W Wireless-N Multifunction VPN Router
  * RV215W Wireless-N VPN Router



 **CVEs**

  * CVE-2021-1159
  * CVE-2021-1160
  * CVE-2021-1161



 **Source**

<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-rv-overflow-WUnUgv4U>

## Cisco Small Business RV110W, RV130, RV130W, and RV215W Routers Management Interface Command Injection Vulnerabilities

Vulnerabilities in several Cisco Small Business routers could allow for an authenticated, remote attacker to inject arbitrary commands which are executed with root privileges. Affected routers are listed below. This vulnerability has a CVSS Score of 7.2.

  * RV110W Wireless-N VPN Firewall
  * RV130 VPN Router
  * RV130W Wireless-N Multifunction VPN Router
  * RV215W Wireless-N VPN Router



 **CVEs**

  * CVE-2021-1146
  * CVE-2021-1147
  * CVE-2021-1148



 **Source**

<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-rv-command-inject-LBdQ2KRN>

## Cisco Connected Mobile Experiences Privilege Escalation Vulnerability

A vulnerability exists in Cisco's Connected Mobile Experience (CMX), which, if successfully executed, could allow a remote, authenticated attacker without administrator privileges to change the password of any user on a vulnerable system. Affected versions of the software are Cisco CMX releases 10.6.0, 10.6.1, and 10.6.2. This vulnerability has a CVSS Score of 8.8.

 **CVEs**

  * CVE-2021-1144



 **Source**

<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-cmxpe-75Asy9k>

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/35719997/Cisco%20Security%20Advisories%20January%202021%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1610568305626&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-anyconnect-dll-injec-pQnryXLf>

  * <https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-rv-overflow-WUnUgv4U>
  * <https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-rv-command-inject-LBdQ2KRN>
  * <https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-cmxpe-75Asy9k>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Mirai Botnet Abusing Log4j Vulnerability
The Mirai botnet often implements new functionality as easily-exploitable vulnerabilities are discovered. In a report from Akamai, researchers detail Mirai's recent addition of Log4j exploits to their arsenal.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Exploit
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Mirai botnet
  *  **Targets:** Systems vulnerable to Log4Shell
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Exploitation of Log4j vulnerabilities
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Install additional payloads



# Overview

Akamai has published a blog post analyzing recent samples of Mirai that indicate the botnet is now exploiting the recent Log4j vulnerabilities. Using the unauthenticated remote code execution vulnerability, the Mirai scanner attempts to contact an LDAP server for the purpose of downloading a Java payload. At the time of research, the related Log4j exploit payloads and scripts were no longer available for download, limiting the analysis capabilities. Older samples contain remote code execution exploits for various applications, while most recent samples appear to focus on Log4j specifically. Each exploit target involves the use of two functions, one for establishing a network connection and one for executing the exploit payload. Patches have been released for the Log4j vulnerabilities and should be applied as soon as possible. For more information, see the Akamai blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74057177/Mirai%20Botnet%20Abusing%20Log4j%20Vulnerability%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1642622205893&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Update Apache Log4j to patch CVE-2021-44228 (see VMSA-2021-0028.8).
  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://www.akamai.com/blog/security/mirai-botnet-abusing-log4j-vulnerability>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1595 - Active Scanning  
T1595.002 - Vulnerability Scanning  
  
 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
T1608.001 - Upload Malware  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: SVCReady - A New Loader Malware
Hewlett Packard Threat Research discovered new spam campaigns that began in April of this year and delivered malware known as SVCReady. The campaigns have similarities to previous campaigns carried out by the financially-motivated threat group TA551.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

Summary
=======



Threat Details
==============

* **Malware Type:** Loader
* **Associated Threat Actors:** Similarities with prior campaigns conducted by TA551.
* **Associated Payloads:** RedLine Stealer
* **Targets:** Unknown
* **Initial Infection Vector:** Phishing
* **Additional TTPs:**See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.

Overview
========

HP Research provided an analysis of the SVCReady malware that has been distributed in phishing campaigns that began in April. The initial compromise is via a Microsoft Word document attached to the phishing emails. Once opened, this document uses VBA AutoOpen macros to execute shellcode stored in the document properties that downloads and then executes the SVCReady malware using rundll32.exe. Once SVCReady is executed it collects certain system information and sends it to the C&C server using HTTP.  Initially, the C&C communications were unencrypted but in May, SVCReady began using RC4 to encrypt them. The malware then sets a registry key used to provide persistence but due to an apparent coding error, the malware does not execute after a system reboot. SVCReady then collects the same system information again but this time also includes a screenshot and sends it to the C&C server. Lastly in the infection chain, SVCReady uses two WMI queries to check if it is running in a virtualized environment and communicates its finding to the C&C server. In the early stages of the campaign, the RedLine Stealer malware was delivered as an additional payload. The report goes on to note the similarities between the campaigns delivering SVCReady and prior campaigns conducted by the financially-motivated threat group known as TA551. Further information is available from the report which is linked in the References section below.

Indicators of Compromise
========================

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

Recommendations
===============

* For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

**Persistence - TA0003**

**Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
 T1218 - Signed Binary Proxy Execution

   T1497.001 - System Checks  

**Discovery - TA0007**  
 T1082 - System Information Discovery  

**Collection - TA0009**  
 T1005 - Data from Local System  
 T1113 - Screen Capture  

**Exfiltration - TA0010**  
 T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  

**Command and Control - TA0011**  
 T1001 - Data Obfuscation  
 T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
   T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
 T1573 - Encrypted Channel  
   T1573.001 - Symmetric Cryptography  

**Mitigations:**

**M1013:**  Application Developer Guidance: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.  
**M1017:**  User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
**M1018:**  User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
**M1020:**  SSL/TLS Inspection - Break and inspect SSL/TLS sessions to look at encrypted web traffic for adversary activity.  
**M1021:**  Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
**M1022:**  Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
**M1024:**  Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
**M1025:**  Privileged Process Integrity - Protect processes with high privileges that can be used to interact with critical system components through use of protected process light, anti-process injection defenses, or other process integrity enforcement measures.  
**M1026:**  Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
**M1031:**  Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
**M1033:**  Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
**M1037:**  Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
**M1038:**  Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
**M1040:**  Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
**M1042:**  Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
**M1043:**  Credential Access Protection - Use capabilities to prevent successful credential access by adversaries; including blocking forms of credential dumping.  
**M1044:**  Restrict Library Loading - Prevent abuse of library loading mechanisms in the operating system and software to load untrusted code by configuring appropriate library loading mechanisms and investigating potential vulnerable software.  
**M1045:**  Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
**M1047:**  Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
**M1049:**  Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
**M1050:**  Exploit Protection - Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.  
**M1054:**  Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
**M1056:**  Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.  
**M1057:**  Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Malicious Android Apps Targeting Users of JIO Telecom in India
Zscaler has identified a threat actor spreading malicious android apps via WhatsApp and SMS. The apps are specifically targeting JIO telecom users in India. Those targeted are tricked into thinking that TikTok is available again in India or that they are installing an app to register to receive a free Lenovo laptop, courtesy of the Government of India.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Malicious Android Apps Targeting Users of JIO Telecom in India
Zscaler has identified a threat actor spreading malicious android apps via WhatsApp and SMS. The apps are specifically targeting JIO telecom users in India. Those targeted are tricked into thinking that TikTok is available again in India or that they are installing an app to register to receive a free Lenovo laptop, courtesy of the Government of India.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Phishing




# Overview

An unnamed threat actor has been identified as actively operating since as early as March 20, 2020. Zscaler says the threat actor has been specifically targeting users of JIO, a telecom company operating in India. Victims may receive a message via WhatsApp or an SMS which contains a shortened URL that leads them to a web page on [weebly.com](http://weebly.com). From there, the user is tricked into downloading and installing a malicious Android APK file. The file is hosted on an attacker-controlled GitHub account. One of the tactics they use is to say that TikTok is available again in India and this is the new app. Another is that they need to install the app to register for a free Lenovo laptop being given out to students in India by the Government of India. The malicious app will display ads that provide revenue to the threat actor. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.zscaler.com/blogs/security-research/android-apps-targeting-jio-users-india>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: TigerRAT - New RAT on the Block
VMWare has published a blog detailing TigerRAT, a new malware that shares similarities with malware previously used by Andariel, a subset of Lazarus.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** RAT
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown though shares similarities with Andariel
  *  **Associated Payloads:** TigerRAT
  *  **Targets:** N/A
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Manipulate files, execute remote commands, log keystrokes, remote control over victim machine



# Overview

TigerRAT is a new RAT discovered by the Korean Internet & Security Agency (KISA). Analysis by VMWare unveils capabilities associated with the malware. TigerRAT has the ability to manipulate files, execute remote commands, log keystrokes, and remotely view and control the victim machine. The RAT originates from a loader app. Within the sample analyzed, configuration data for C2 communication is stored in encrypted form in the malware. This communication is disguised to appear as normal HTTP web traffic using port 443. The payload is structured in a 4-byte size, 16-byte key, and base64 encoded. Decryption of the payload executes the malware in memory. C2s are decrypted using CryptorDES. Various commands can be sent and received from the C2, such as those for gathering victim machine information as well as module updates. Further information can be found in the source article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74055861/TigerRAT%20-%20New%20RAT%20on%20the%20Block%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1639505009316&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction. (M1017)
  * Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts. (M1018)
  * Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc. (M1021)
  * Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root. (M1026)
  * Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries. (M1031)
  * Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking. (M1038)
  * Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior. (M1040)
  * Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing. (M1045)
  * Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses. (M1047)
  * Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software. (M1049)



# References

  * <https://blogs.vmware.com/security/2021/12/tigerrat-advanced-adversaries-on-the-prowl.html>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059.003 - Windows Command Shell  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1134.002 - Create Process with Token  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1056.001 - Keylogging  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1033 - System Owner/User Discovery  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
T1087.001 - Local Account  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
T1056.001 - Keylogging  
T1113 - Screen Capture  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1573.001 - Symmetric Cryptography

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: TunnelVision Exploiting VMware Horizon
TunnelVision is an Iranian-aligned threat actor operating in the Middle East and United States. SentinelOne has published a blog post analyzing the group's exploitation of VMware Horizon in recent campaigns.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: TunnelVision Exploiting VMware Horizon
TunnelVision is an Iranian-aligned threat actor operating in the Middle East and United States. SentinelOne has published a blog post analyzing the group's exploitation of VMware Horizon in recent campaigns.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Reverse shell
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** TunnelVision
  *  **Associated Payloads:** PowerShell reverse shell
  *  **Targets:** Middle East, United States
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Exploitation of VMware Horizon servers
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Remote command execution, credential harvesting, lateral movement



# Overview

SentinelOne published a blog post analyzing TunnelVision and their recent activity. TunnelVision, an Iranian-aligned threat actor operating in the Middle East and United States, is known for their use of 1-day vulnerability exploits and tunneling tools. In recent cases, they have used the Log4Shell exploit to target VMware Horizon servers. The exploit is used to execute PowerShell commands that will download files and return command outputs via a webhook. The group additionally uses PowerShell reverse shells to perform further post-compromise actions. Two different reverse shells were identified that ultimately provided backdoor access, allowing TunnelVision to execute recon commands, add a backdoor user, harvest credentials, tunnel RDP traffic, and deploy further reverse shells. The researchers noted an overlap between this group and those called Phosphorus by Microsoft and Charming Kitten or Nemesis Kitten by CrowdStrike. For more information, see the SentinelOne blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74059306/TunnelVision%20Exploiting%20VMware%20Horizon%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1645640136017&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Update VMware Horizon to patch the Log4j vulnerability.
  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).



# References

  * <https://www.sentinelone.com/labs/log4j2-in-the-wild-iranian-aligned-threat-actor-tunnelvision-actively-exploiting-vmware-horizon/>

parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
TunnelVision Exploiting VMware Horizon
TunnelVision is an Iranian-aligned threat actor operating in the Middle East and United States. SentinelOne has published a blog post analyzing the group's exploitation of VMware Horizon in recent campaigns.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Reverse shell
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** TunnelVision
  *  **Associated Payloads:** PowerShell reverse shell
  *  **Targets:** Middle East, United States
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Exploitation of VMware Horizon servers
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Remote command execution, credential harvesting, lateral movement



# Overview

SentinelOne published a blog post analyzing TunnelVision and their recent activity. TunnelVision, an Iranian-aligned threat actor operating in the Middle East and United States, is known for their use of 1-day vulnerability exploits and tunneling tools. In recent cases, they have used the Log4Shell exploit to target VMware Horizon servers. The exploit is used to execute PowerShell commands that will download files and return command outputs via a webhook. The group additionally uses PowerShell reverse shells to perform further post-compromise actions. Two different reverse shells were identified that ultimately provided backdoor access, allowing TunnelVision to execute recon commands, add a backdoor user, harvest credentials, tunnel RDP traffic, and deploy further reverse shells. The researchers noted an overlap between this group and those called Phosphorus by Microsoft and Charming Kitten or Nemesis Kitten by CrowdStrike. For more information, see the SentinelOne blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74059306/TunnelVision%20Exploiting%20VMware%20Horizon%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1645640136017&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Update VMware Horizon to patch the Log4j vulnerability.
  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).



# References

  * <https://www.sentinelone.com/labs/log4j2-in-the-wild-iranian-aligned-threat-actor-tunnelvision-actively-exploiting-vmware-horizon/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Fake WhatsApp Hacking Users
Vice reports on a fake WhatsApp application in the Apple App Store. The fake version has been used to steal phone, user, and other information.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Threat actors are targeting WhatsApp users in a scheme to steal information for the phone, users, and other important information. The fake app uses the MDM file to install the app containing the spyware. The actors use a phishing web page to direct victims to the fake app within the App Store. Researchers were unable to observe the second stage of the attack making it unclear what information was exfiltrated. The researchers were also unable to determine who the app was specifically targeting as it does not appear to be widespread targeting. Speculation is the application is associated with a "Cyber Electronic Warfare & Intelligence" company. Further details can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.vice.com/en/article/akdqwa/a-spyware-vendor-seemingly-made-a-fake-whatsapp-to-hack-targets>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: ACTINIUM Targeting Ukraine
Microsoft has published a report on the activities of a threat actor they have named ACTINIUM that has been targeting organizations located in Ukraine.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware, Espionage.
  *  **Targets:** Ukrainian government entities including the judiciary, law enforcement, and military as well as attacking non-profit organizations and NGOs.
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** DinoTrain, DesertDown, DilongTrash, ObfuBerry, ObfuMerry, PowerPunch, Pterodo (S0147), QuietSieve.
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Spearphishing emails with malicious documents attached.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Lateral movement, collection, and exfiltration of information.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

ACTINIUM is the name Microsoft has applied to a threat actor they previously tracked as DEV-0157 and is also known publicly as Gamaredon. ACTINIUM has been operating for close to 10 years. In the last 6 months, Microsoft has observed ACTINIUM targeting Ukrainian government entities including the judiciary, law enforcement, and military as well as attacking non-profit organizations and NGOs. The Ukrainian government has attributed ACTINIUM to the Russian Federal Security Service (FSB) and has been operating from Crimea. Microsoft reports that ACTINIUM's objectives are cyber espionage, maintaining and using their access to move laterally into related organizations. While a number of vectors may be used to compromise their targets. Microsoft notes one method in its report, that being the use of spearphishing emails with malicious documents attached that use remote template injection to begin the infection chain. The spearphishing emails and documents are typically themed to an organization that is familiar to the target. A number of payloads are deployed and these include DesertDown, DinoTrain, DilongTrash, ObfuBerry, ObfuMerry, PowerPunch, Pterodo, QuietSieve. In some cases, UltraVNC has been deployed to provide more interactive remote access. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74058528/ACTINIUM%20Targeting%20Ukraine%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1644546386402&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://www.microsoft.com/security/blog/2022/02/04/actinium-targets-ukrainian-organizations/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1589 - Gather Victim Identity Information  
T1591 - Gather Victim Org Information  
  
 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
T1583.001 - Domains  
T1583.004 - Server  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.001 - Malware  
T1588 - Obtain Capabilities  
T1588.002 - Tool  
T1608 - Stage Capabilities

T1608.002 - Upload Tool  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1199 - Trusted Relationship  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Execution - TA0002  
** T1053 - Scheduled Task/Job  
T1053.005 - Scheduled Task  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.005 - Visual Basic

T1204.002 - Malicious File

 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder

 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1070 - Indicator Removal on Host  
T1070.004 - File Deletion  
T1218 - Signed Binary Proxy Execution  
T1218.011 - Rundll32  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
T1074 - Data Staged  
T1074.001 - Local Data Staging  
T1113 - Screen Capture  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel

 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
T1105 - Ingress Tool Transfer

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: SpoofedScholars Phishing Scheme Imitates UK Scholars
An Iranian-state actor, TA453 (aka Charming Kitten), has been masquerading as UK scholars to target individuals of interest to the Iranian Government, according to a post from Proofpoint.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Phishing ([T1598](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1598/)) ([T1586](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1586/)) ([T1566](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566/))
  *  **Target:** Journalists, Senior Personnel, Professors
  *  **Lure:** Speaking engagement invitation 
  * **Payload:** Email with link 
  * **TTPs:** Spoofed sender, link in email ([T1566.002](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566/002/)) ([T1598.03](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1598/003/))
  *  **Compromised Data:** Login credentials to several services (Microsoft, iCloud, etc.) ([T1056](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1056/))
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Unknown



# Overview

Using spoofed but legitimate appearing email addresses, TA453 (Charming Kitten) has opened a phishing campaign by representing itself as scholars from U.K. higher education institutions. Using the actions detailed below, the actor attempted to harvest credentials belonging to its targeted individuals. At least three email addresses have been used in the campaign. Each of the addresses used are legitimate individuals' email addresses spoofed to appear as though they were sent from actual, known scholars. Proofpoint assesses with high confidence the actors are part of TA453 based on TTPs used in previous campaigns. Further information can be found in the post located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/57311898/SpoofedScholars%20Phishing%20Scheme%20Imitates%20UK%20Scholars%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1626375528718&api=v2)



# Protection

  * Educate all users on social engineering techniques. ([M1017](https://attack.mitre.org/mitigations/M1017/))
  * Employ Anti-virus and Anti-Malware on networks. ([M1049](https://attack.mitre.org/mitigations/M1049))
  * Use email filtering software. ([M1054](https://attack.mitre.org/mitigations/M1054))
  * Use Network Intrusion Devices to scan and remove attachments or block links. ([M1031](https://attack.mitre.org/mitigations/M1031))
  * Restrict web-based content. ([M1021](https://attack.mitre.org/mitigations/M1021))



# References

  * <https://www.proofpoint.com/us/blog/threat-insight/operation-spoofedscholars-conversation-ta453>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: 4 Types of Dropper Malware in Microsoft Office & How to Detect Them
Researchers at Deep Instinct have posted an assessment of dropper malware that is targeting Microsoft Office. This report is on VBA droppers that utilize different techniques to evade detections.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: 4 Types of Dropper Malware in Microsoft Office & How to Detect Them
Researchers at Deep Instinct have posted an assessment of dropper malware that is targeting Microsoft Office. This report is on VBA droppers that utilize different techniques to evade detections.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Dropper
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Aggah
  *  **Associated Payloads:** RevengeRAT, Emotet, Dridex
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malicious Office documents.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

Deep Instinct researched activity that involves the use of dropper malware utilizing Microsoft Office. A threat group known as Aggah is assessed to be conducting operations to deliver malware such as RevengeRAT. This threat actor utilizes Microsoft Office documents. One technique to evade detection used by Aggah in their VBA scripts is to include the string "MsgBox" in comments as this may lead AI-based detection tools to identify the code as "benign". The report also details how Dridex and Emotet droppers obfuscate their malicious VBA code in Microsoft documents. Further information can be found in the article linked within the Reference section below

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://www.deepinstinct.com/blog/types-of-dropper-malware-in-microsoft-office>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Tactics and Techniques:**

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
T1059.005 - Visual Basic  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1140 - Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information  
T1218 - Signed Binary Proxy Execution  
T1218.010 - Regsvr32  
  


 **Mitigations:**

 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1050:** Exploit Protection - Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.  
 **M1054:** Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.

I have encountered the following information: Chrome Browser Updates - February 16 2021
Google has released an update to its Chrome web browser for Windows, Mac, and Linux that provides fixes for ten vulnerabilities. Of the nine CVE-numbered vulnerabilities noted in the advisory, Google has rated eight as High, and one as Medium.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

Google has released an update, version 88.0.4324.182, to its Chrome web browser for Windows, Mac, and Linux that provides fixes for ten vulnerabilities. Of the nine CVE numbered vulnerabilities noted in the advisory, Google has rated eight as High, and one as Medium. instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Egregor Ransomware, Used in a String of High-Profile Attacks
Analysts at Recorded Future recently discovered a surge of attacks utilizing Egregor ransomware and targeting a range of high-profile targets across various industries, which researchers believe QakBot operators are behind.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Ransomware, Malware




# Overview

Recorded Future analyzed a surge of ransomware attacks associated with the ransomware variant Egregor, a part of the Sekhmet ransomware family. Egregor ransomware is an intricate piece of malware that employs obfuscation and anti-analysis, initiating both ransomware and double extortion attacks, according to analysts at Recorded Future. The security team at Recorded Future found the initial surge of attacks started in September and continued to increase in attack tempo, with their sights on high profile targets across multiple industries. According to Recorded Future, first, the threat actors exploit poorly-secured RDP services to initiate intrusion tactics. Once that is successful, threat actors begin to launch their payload with elements of SHA256 hashing and the lesser-known Rabbitcryptographic cipher combined to decrypt the payload. Further analysis revealed the ransomware having the capability to collect victim’s system information, including username, computer name, general system information, domain name, workgroup, and installed AV programs. In conclusion, analysts at Recorded Future address the severity behind recent developments in threat actors TTPs as it relates to the ransomware and the various tools they use and make several recommendations to help end-users stay protected. For more information, see the Recorded Future article in the Reference section.

# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.recordedfuture.com/egregor-ransomware-attacks/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: JSWorm Evolution
From 2019, the JSWorm ransomware was available through a public RaaS offering. According to a report from Kaspersky, midway through 2020 the operators closed the RaaS offering and began using JSWorm in highly targeted attacks, hunting the big game.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Ransomware




# Overview

JSWorm was discovered in 2019 and until mid-2020 was available through a public RaaS offering. It was propagated using a number of methods such as fake payment websites, spam campaigns, the RIG exploit kit, and the Trik botnet. A report from Kaspersky provides some insight on the evolution of JSWorm and its variants, including Nemty, Nefilim, Offwhite, Telegram, Fusion, Milihpen, and Gangbang. In mid-2020, the operators of the RaaS offering shuttered it and began using JSWorm in highly targeted big-game hunting operations. At the same time, the JSWorm operators also created a website where they published data stolen from their victims who would not pay the demanded ransom. The site remains active and, according to Kaspersky, contains information about more than a hundred organizations that were victims of attacks. Further information is available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://securelist.com/evolution-of-jsworm-ransomware/102428/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: New Versions of the Necro Botnet in the Wild
New versions of the Necro botnet have been reported by 360Netlab, A number of changes have been made to the new Necro versions, including the adoption of new propagation techniques, and a DGA for C2 domains.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: New Versions of the Necro Botnet in the Wild
New versions of the Necro botnet have been reported by 360Netlab, A number of changes have been made to the new Necro versions, including the adoption of new propagation techniques, and a DGA for C2 domains.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Botnet, Cryptomining




# Overview

Since the beginning of 2021, 360Netlab has detected three new versions of the Necro botnet. Necro is also known as Python.IRCBot, and N3Cr0m0rPh. The three new versions incorporate a host of new features including propagation using weak Telnet passwords and a 1-day vulnerability (CVE-2020-35665) in TerraMaster TOS, exploitation of some n-day vulnerabilities, increased use of code obfuscation, a domain generation algorithm (DGA) for C&C server domain names, and payloads distributed as both Python scripts and ELF binaries. The compiled ELF binary is used in situations where the infected host does not provide Python 2 due to its EOL status. The exploit for TerraMaster TOS was introduced into the Necro code eight days are the vulnerability was made public. Other payloads downloaded include the xmrig and xmrig1 cryptominers. The same actors are believed to be behind all three of the new versions, and the download servers used for Necro have also been observed hosting Mirai variants and malicious Windows executables. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.netlab.360.com/necro/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Undervolting Can Bypass Countermeasures
ZT-Chen has published a preview of an upcoming academic paper to be presented at Usenix Security 2021 on an undervolting process that could cause issues for Intel Software Guard Extensions (SGX).

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Undervolting Can Bypass Countermeasures
ZT-Chen has published a preview of an upcoming academic paper to be presented at Usenix Security 2021 on an undervolting process that could cause issues for Intel Software Guard Extensions (SGX).

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

Voltpillager is a hardware-based undervolting tool that has the ability to bypass countermeasures for SGX enclaves. The Voltpillager is used to connect to the Voltage Regulator, which generates and controls CPU voltage. This device can be built for about $30. The device requires physical access to the machine to be undervolted and cannot be deployed remotely, as the SGX has no access to any type of remote connection. SGX shields computations inside protected enclaves. Other research papers are built on the assumption that a cloud provider cannot look inside nor manipulate the enclave memory. Although a software patch based on CVE-2019-11157 has been issued, it provides no protection from any type of hardware-based attack model. At present, without physical access, the threat is not a feasible attack. The only type of software countermeasure that could be vulnerable is a fault injection. Technical details can be found within the links located in the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * CVE-2019-11157




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://zt-chen.github.io/voltpillager/>

  * <https://www.usenix.org/conference/usenixsecurity21/presentation/chen-zitai>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: IcedID Deployed Through Spearphishing
A report from FortiGuard Labs provides an analysis of a spearphishing email used to deploy IcedID that was sent to a Ukrainian company.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Targets:** A Ukrainian fuel company.
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** IcedID
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Spearphishing email with malicious attachment.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Collection and exfiltration of data, Persistence.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

FortiGuard Labs analyzed a spearphishing email that was sent to a Ukrainian fuel company. The email was a fake invoice that claimed to be from another fuel company and contained text in both Ukrainian and English. Attached to the email was an archive file that contained an ISO file. When the ISO file was mounted it showed an LNK file named "document". In addition, there was another file named "main.dll". When the LNK file was executed, it used Regsvr32 to register the DLL which was a loader used to deploy IcedID which then used a number of Windows command-line utilities to collect information about the infected system. It would then attempt to communicate with a C&C server chosen from a list and if successful, a copy of the payload was written to a temp directory and registry entries added to make it persistent. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

# Recommendations

  * For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.



# References

  * <https://www.fortinet.com/blog/threat-research/spoofed-invoice-drops-iced-id>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Tactics and Techniques:**

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1218 - Signed Binary Proxy Execution  
T1218.010 - Regsvr32  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
T1087 - Account Discovery  
T1087.002 - Domain Account  
T1482 - Domain Trust Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1185 - Browser Session Hijacking  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
  


 **Mitigations:**

 **M1013:** Application Developer Guidance: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1024:** Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
 **M1025:** Privileged Process Integrity - Protect processes with high privileges that can be used to interact with critical system components through use of protected process light, anti-process injection defenses, or other process integrity enforcement measures.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1043:** Credential Access Protection - Use capabilities to prevent successful credential access by adversaries; including blocking forms of credential dumping.  
 **M1044:** Restrict Library Loading - Prevent abuse of library loading mechanisms in the operating system and software to load untrusted code by configuring appropriate library loading mechanisms and investigating potential vulnerable software.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1050:** Exploit Protection - Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.  
 **M1054:** Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.

 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1043:** Credential Access Protection - Use capabilities to prevent successful credential access by adversaries; including blocking forms of credential dumping.  
 **M1044:** Restrict Library Loading - Prevent abuse of library loading mechanisms in the operating system and software to load untrusted code by configuring appropriate library loading mechanisms and investigating potential vulnerable software.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1050:** Exploit Protection - Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.  
 **M1054:** Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.

Oracle has released their quarterly Critical Patch Update (CPU) for October of 2020. Included are updates that fix 329 security vulnerabilities across the Oracle product line.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: XML Vulnerabilities in Go's Standard Library
Mattermost has responsibly disclosed three XML vulnerabilities in Go's standard library.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability



# Overview

Mattermost, working with Go's security team, has responsibly disclosed three XML vulnerabilities in Go's standard library. These include an XML attribute instability (CVE-2020-29509), an XML directive instability (CVE_2020-29510), and an XML element instability (CVE-2020-29511). In essence, if your application is processing information that has already gone through Go's decoder and encoder functions at least one time before, the application may be processing invalid data, since Go's decoder and encoder does not preserve the semantics of the data. The lack of integrity is a major issue in applications that require absolute semantic integrity in order to be secure, such as SAML (Security Assertion Markup Language). The notification indicates that the Go team cannot, at this time, reliably and reasonably address the issues. Only one of the issues is on the Go roadmap to be addressed in the foreseeable future. Mattermost is releasing an XML validation library that can be used as a workaround until a full patch can be released. For more details, please refer to the disclosure notification in the Reference section.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [XML Vulnerabilities in Gos Standard Library CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/35718356/XML%20Vulnerabilities%20in%20Gos%20Standard%20Library%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1608064748127&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * https://mattermost.com/blog/coordinated-disclosure-go-xml-vulnerabilities/

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Spoofed FBI Domains Pose Cyber and Disinformation Risks
The Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) has published an announcement regarding domains spoofing the agency being registered.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Spoofing




# Overview

 These domains attempt to look like the legitimate FBI website by slightly altering characteristics, such as changing spellings or using a different top-level domain. The registered domains then are leveraged by threat actors to carry out their objectives. This could be the dissemination of disinformation, phishing campaigns, or distribution of malware. By using a look-alike domain, victims are more likely to believe that the source of the content is legitimate. The registration of these domains has not be attributed to a specific threat actor and their exact usage is not yet known. The FBI urges the public to be wary of any information claiming to come from them as a source. For more information, see the FBI alert in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.ic3.gov/Media/Y2020/PSA201123>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Qakbot Malware Has Altered Tactics
In a SANS InfoSec Handlers Diary post, researcher Brad Duncan provides details of a recent Qakbot infection.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Banking Trojan
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unspecified
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Cobalt Strike
  *  **Targets:** Unspecified
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Spearphishing email with a malicious link.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Various depending on loaded modules.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

A SANS InfoSec Handlers Diary post detailing the distribution of Qakbot malware with a distribution tag of obama1600 has been published. The infection chain begins with a malspam email with a malicious link to a zip archive file. An Excel spreadsheet is extracted from the zip file and upon opening the Excel file and allowing macros to run, the macros will download Qakbot DLL files and execute them. Unlike previously known Qakbot infections, this particular version did not persist after logging out. The system was left running to be monitored and after a number of hours had passed, the infected host generated traffic for Cobalt Strike and VNC. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: ICS-CERT Advisories February 02 2021
The ICS-CERT has published two advisories that affect Rockwell Automation's MicroLogix 1400 and Siemens SIMATIC HMI Comfort Panels and SIMATIC HMI KTP Mobile Panels.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

 Further information is available from the advisories which are summarised below.

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-033-01 - Rockwell Automation MicroLogix 1400**  
CVE-2021-22659 - A remote unauthenticated attacker may be able to send a specially crafted Modbus packet allowing the attacker to retrieve or modify random values in the register. If successfully exploited, this may lead to a buffer overflow resulting in a denial-of-service condition. The FAULT LED will flash RED and communications may be lost. Recovery from denial-of-service condition requires the fault to be cleared by the user.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 8.1 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:H/PR:N/UI:N/S:C/C:L/I:L/A:H).  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-21-033-01>

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-033-02 - Siemens SIMATIC HMI Comfort Panels & SIMATIC HMI KTP Mobile Panels**  
CVE-2020-15798 - Affected devices with enabled Telnet service do not require authentication for this service. This could allow a remote attacker to gain full access to the device.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 8.1 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:H/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-21-033-02>

# CVEs

  * CVE-2021-22659, CVE-2020-15798




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories>

VMWare published a security advisory, VMSA-2021-0005, that addresses a vulnerability (CVE-2021-21982) in the VMware Carbon Black Cloud Workload appliance. The vulnerability is an authentication bypass issue which could potentially allow a remote attacker to obtain administrative access to an affected device. An update that addresses the vulnerability is available. We recommend reviewing the advisory linked in the Reference section below, for further details.

# CVEs

  * CVE-2021-21982 




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.vmware.com/security/advisories/VMSA-2021-0005.html>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Cobalt Strike Campaign Leveraging Domain Fronting to Target Myanmar
A new Cobalt Strike campaign is leveraging domain fronting to evade DNS filtering. Cisco observed the payloads abusing the Cloudflare Content Delivery Network (CDN) to redirect a Myanmar government owned-domain to an attacker-controlled server.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Cobalt Strike Campaign Leveraging Domain Fronting to Target Myanmar
A new Cobalt Strike campaign is leveraging domain fronting to evade DNS filtering. Cisco observed the payloads abusing the Cloudflare Content Delivery Network (CDN) to redirect a Myanmar government owned-domain to an attacker-controlled server.

# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Cobalt Strike
  *  **Targets:** Myanmar
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Remote command execution
  *  **Additional TTPs:** Domain fronting



# Overview

Cisco published a blog post analyzing a Cobalt Strike campaign implementing domain fronting techniques in combination with the Cloudflare Content Delivery Network (CDN) to evade DNS filtering. The threat actor, after compromising a network, used a Meterpreter stager to ultimately deploy the Cobalt Strike beacon. The earliest versions of this beacon did not leverage domain fronting and simply pointed to the attacker's C2 server. Later versions, however, had an updated configuration that used different HTTP headers that allows for the DNS traffic to occur with one host while the HTTP traffic will occur with another. The final version of the payload used a Myanmar government-owned domain for DNS resolution but ultimately directed traffic to the C2 domain. At the time of analysis, the C2 server was down so the follow-on activities are unknown. For more information, see the Cisco Talos blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/70222641/Cobalt%20Strike%20Campaign%20Leveraging%20Domain%20Fronting%20to%20Target%20Myanmar%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1637162410322&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021)



# References

  * <https://blog.talosintelligence.com/2021/11/attackers-use-domain-fronting-technique.html>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
T1583.001 - Domains  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1202 - Indirect Command Execution  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
T1105 - Ingress Tool Transfer

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Amnesty Report on FinSpy Activity
A report from Amnesty’s Security Lab provides an analysis of FinSpy samples that were located during investigations. The samples include FinSpy variants for Windows, Mac, Linux, and Android. The report also provides information on the capabilities of the NilePhish group who are known to distribute FinSpy.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Amnesty’s Security Lab has been tracking FinSpy usage due to its use in a number of operations to spy on what Amnesty describe as Human Rights Defenders. FinSpy is commercial spyware developed by the German company FinFisher Gmbh. Amnesty has observed variants of FinSpy for Windows, Mac, Linux, and Android. In its report, Amnesty looks at the NilePhish group who developed several droppers which include a fake Flash Player updater, macro enabled Word documents, and a .NET application. Early in 2020, NilePhish began testing Cobalt Strike, using an obfuscated VB script for installation. The versions of FinSpy for Mac and Linux share very similar modules which Amnesty notes could indicate a shared codebase, the launchers and infection chain are modified for Linux. All versions are configurable and employ various techniques to hinder detection and analysis. Further information is available from Amnesty's report which is linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.amnesty.org/en/latest/research/2020/09/german-made-finspy-spyware-found-in-egypt-and-mac-and-linux-versions-revealed/>

  * <https://www.sentinelone.com/blog/how-to-catch-a-spy-detecting-finfisher-spyware-on-macos/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: TA402 Campaigns
Proofpoint has published a report which provides an analysis of campaigns that began in late 2021 that they have attributed to TA402.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: TA402 Campaigns
Proofpoint has published a report which provides an analysis of campaigns that began in late 2021 that they have attributed to TA402.

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware, Espionage.
  *  **Targets:** Governments, foreign policy think tanks, and a state-affiliated airline, all located in the Middle East.
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** NimbleMamba, BrittleBush.
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Phishing emails with links leading to malicious files.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Collection and exfiltration of information.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below for TA402 TTPs.



# Overview

Proofpoint has published an analysis of campaigns that began in late 2021 and targeted governments, foreign policy think tanks, and a state-affiliated airline located in the Middle East. Proofpoint attributes the campaigns to a threat group they refer to as TA402 who is also known as Molerats and the Gaza Cybergang. IBM X-Force tracks the activities of the group using the identifier Hive0022. The threat group is believed to be Arabic-speaking, politically motivated, and acting in the interests of the Palestinian Territories. The campaigns typically began with phishing emails that contained links that, in two of the three analyzed cases, led to a host that used geolocation to redirect connections that did not originate from the target countries to a news site. Of the two examples that used the redirection based on geolocation, one used a website masquerading as Quora on an attacker-controlled domain, and the other involved an actor-controlled domain and WordPress site that carried out the redirections. In the third case, the group was using Dropbox to host the malicious files but were unable to conduct the geolocation redirection due to not having control of the domain. Dropbox was also used for C&C services in some cases. If a connection originated from one of the targeted countries, the victim was led to an RAR file that contained malicious executables. The payload was a new Trojan developed by TA402 that Proofpoint has named NimbleMamba and has features typical of malware used in intelligence gathering and initial access. In some cases, a second payload, the BrittleBush Trojan, was also deployed. Further information is available from Proofpoint's report which is linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74058570/TA402%20Campaigns%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1644815134743&api=v2)



# Detection

  * A Yara rule can be found here: [ Yara Rule.txt](/download/attachments/74058570/TA402%20Campaigns%20Yara%20Rule.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1644815148113&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://www.proofpoint.com/us/blog/threat-insight/ugg-boots-4-sale-tale-palestinian-aligned-espionage>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
T1566.002 - Spearphishing Link  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
T1059.005 - Visual Basic  
T1059.007 - JavaScript  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.001 - Malicious Link  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1036 - Masquerading  
T1140 - Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information  
T1218 - Signed Binary Proxy Execution  
T1218.007 - Msiexec  
T1480 - Execution Guardrails  
T1480.001 - Environmental Keying  
T1497 - Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion  
T1497.001 - System Checks  
T1553 - Subvert Trust Controls  
T1553.002 - Code Signing  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1555 - Credentials from Password Stores  
T1555.003 - Credentials from Web Browsers  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1057 - Process Discovery  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
T1102 - Web Service  
T1102.002 - Bidirectional Communication  
T1105 - Ingress Tool Transfer  
T1573 - Encrypted Channel  
T1573.001 - Symmetric Cryptography
