# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques (M1017).
  * Perform endpoint scans using the provided Yara rules.



# References

  * <https://www.mcafee.com/blogs/enterprise/mcafee-enterprise-atr/is-there-really-such-a-thing-as-a-low-paid-ransomware-operator/>

 **Discovery - TA0007**

T1057 - Process Discovery  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: FBI Flash Update MU-000139-MW
The Federal Bureau of Investigation has issued an update to a previous flash alert from October 14, 2020 regarding the targeting of misconfigured SonarQube instances.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: FBI Flash Update MU-000139-MW
The Federal Bureau of Investigation has issued an update to a previous flash alert from October 14, 2020 regarding the targeting of misconfigured SonarQube instances.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

A report from the FBI in October 2020, detailed the targeting of misconfigured SonarQube instances in an effort to "access source code repositories of US government agencies and private businesses." This follow-up provides some technical details on the attacks. According to the flash alert, SonarQube is a web-based, open-source platform used to measure and analyze source code quality. In April 2020, the FBI found source code leaks coming from insecure instances of the software. The nature of the leaks were US government and private companies within several industries to include: technology, finance, retail, food, eCommerce, and manufacturing. Using internal data, threat actors leaked the information through a lifecycle repository. The data was obtained through instances using default port setting and admin credentials. Similar activity was observed in July 2020, when source code proprietary to enterprises was published on a self-hosted repository. The initial phase involved the use of scanners seeking SonarQube instances with internet exposure. The attackers used default credentials in a effort to infiltrate these instances. The flash report contains mitigations listed in the Recommendations section below.

# CVEs

  * None Provided




# Recommendations

  * Change the SonarQube default setting, including changing the default administrator username, password, and port (9000).
  * Place SonarQube instances behind a login screen, and check if unauthorized users have accessed the instance.
  * Revoke access to any application programming interface keys or other credentials that were exposed in a SonarQube instance, if feasible.
  * Configure SonarQube instances to sit behind your organization's firewall and other perimeter defenses to prevent unauthenticated access.
  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * Not available at this time

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: WebNavigator Chromium Browser Published by Search Hijackers
A Chromium browser named WebNavigator claiming to provide an improved web experience, was discovered by Malwarebytes researchers and determined to be developed by search hijackers.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, PUP, Search Hijacking




# Overview

Malwarebytes published a blog post analyzing a Chromium browser, WebNavigator, developed by search hijackers. Search hijacking is a method of getting users to click on sponsored advertisements generated by custom search sites or browser extensions in order to generate referral revenue. While investigating a group of known search hijackers, a Malwarebytes researcher discovered a new method of distributing these ads. Instead of getting the user to install a malicious extension, the hijackers instead convince them to install a custom Chromium browser with the promise of faster speeds and simplified browsing. Users are led to the site hosting this application via advertisements and redirectors. Upon installation, WebNavigator is configured to run in the background and set itself as the default browser (unless otherwise specified by the user). Using the browser to perform searches results in the display of graphics-based "search recommendations" that are sponsored ads providing a source of revenue to the campaign operators. Similarities between the search recommendations view, advertising network, and the website offering the application led the researcher to conclude this was in fact the group behind previously investigated search hijacking campaigns. For more information, see the Malwarebytes blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.malwarebytes.com/pups/2020/11/webnavigator-chromium-browser-published-by-search-hijackers/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: New Rocke Group Malware Variant
Rocke Group has been active since 2018 distributing cryptomining software to Linux-based cloud server. Intezer reports on the group's most recent malware variant being leveraged for spreading their infection.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Cryptomining




# Overview

Intezer has published a blog post analyzing Rocke Group's most recent malware variant. A dropper script is used to download a UPX-packed payload to a victim server. This payload is comprised for multiple modules that are extracted and executed. For persistence, the malware creates a scheduled task in crontab and bashrc files. Additionally, a startup service is created to execute the malware. To spread laterally, the malware first attempts to brute force SSH, Redis, and Jenkins passwords. As a backup, it is able to exploit Jenkins and ActiveMQ vulnerabilities. Library hijacking is used in order to evade detection by hiding its presence from system commands. Following Rocke Group's cryptomining goals, the malware also includes an XMRig miner as a payload. Other processes using a significant amount of CPU are killed prior to the execution of the miner. For more information, see the Intezer blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://www.intezer.com/blog/cloud-security/rocke-group-actively-targeting-the-cloud-wants-your-ssh-keys/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: What You Must Know About a New Variant of Lorenz Ransomware
Tesorion, a Dutch cybersecurity company, has recently discovered a new variant of Lorenz ransomware.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Ransomware
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Lorenz Ransomware Gang
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Lorenz Ransomware
  *  **Targets:** Unspecified
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Spearphishing Email
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** File encryption
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

Lorenz ransomware has been active since April 2021. Tesorion published an article in July 2021 and made available a free decryptor for the original version via the NoMoreRansom initiative. Tesorion has discovered a new variant of the Lorenz ransomware and this one also has a serious bug. They explain in their latest blog that this latest version has a bug that makes it so the attacker is unable to recover any encrypted files. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.



# References

  * <https://www.tesorion.nl/en/posts/lorenz-ransomware-rebound-corruption-and-irrecoverable-files/>
  * <https://www.nomoreransom.org/en/index.html>
  * <https://www.tesorion.nl/en/posts/lorenz-ransomware-analysis-and-a-free-decryptor/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1590 - Gather Victim Network Information  
T1590.003 - Network Trust Dependencies  
T1591 - Gather Victim Org Information  
T1591.002 - Business Relationships  
  
 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1586 - Compromise Accounts  
T1586.002 - Email Accounts  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1078 - Valid Accounts  
T1199 - Trusted Relationship  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
T1566.002 - Spearphishing Link  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1047 - Windows Management Instrumentation  
T1053 - Scheduled Task/Job  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1555 - Credentials from Password Stores  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
T1087 - Account Discovery  
  
 **Lateral Movement - TA0008**  
T1021 - Remote Services  
T1021.002 - SMB/Windows Admin Shares  
T1080 - Taint Shared Content  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1102 - Web Service  
T1102.003 - One-Way Communication  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact  
T1490 - Inhibit System Recovery  
  


#### Mitigations:

  
 **M1013:** Application Developer Guidance: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1027:** Password Policies - Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1032:** Multi-factor Authentication - Use two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate to a system; such as username and password in addition to a token from a physical smart card or token generator.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1035:** Limit Access to Resource Over Network - Prevent access to file shares, remote access to systems, unnecessary services. Mechanisms to limit access may include use of network concentrators, RDP gateways, etc.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1048:** Application Isolation and Sandboxing - Restrict execution of code to a virtual environment on or in transit to an endpoint system.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1050:** Exploit Protection - Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
 **M1052:** User Account Control - Configure Windows User Account Control to mitigate risk of adversaries obtaining elevated process access.  
 **M1053:** Data Backup - Take and store data backups from end user systems and critical servers. Ensure backup and storage systems are hardened and kept separate from the corporate network to prevent compromise.  
 **M1054:** Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
 **M1056:** Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.  
 **M1057:** Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Satori Botnet Targeting Vantage Velocity Field Unit RCE Vulnerability
Palo Alto discovered a Mirai botnet variant, Satori, exploiting a Vantage Velocity field unit RCE vulnerability in order to spread itself.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Botnet




# Overview

Palo Alto published a blog post analyzing Satori, a Mirai botnet variant, and its exploitation of a Vantage Velocity field unit RCE vulnerability. This vulnerability, CVE-2020-9020, was discovered in 2020 and is rated as critical due to a low attack complexity resulting in remote code execution. The exploit attempt observed by Palo Alto researchers tries to call wget on the target host in order to download a file from a remote server and subsequently executes it. The same server hosting this malware is believed to be the C2 server for the Satori botnet. Once on the system, the malware spawns and detaches multiple child processes. A brute force attack is performed against port 23 on random hosts, and multiple hardcoded commands are executed to spread the botnet infection to new victim devices. A patch for this vulnerability has been released by Vantage Velocity and should be applied as soon as possible. For more information, see the Palo Alto blog post in the Reference section.  


# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/satori-mirai-botnet-variant-targeting-vantage-velocity-field-unit-rce-vulnerability/>

  *  **Malware Type:** Botnet
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Trickbot, Ryuk, Conti 
  * **Targets:** Asia-Pacific and EMEA Region
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Spam
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Botnet, Credentials Stolen



# Overview

Emotet is one of the most prolific malware types utilized by threat actors. Past reporting indicates that the Emotet botnet malware has been utilized by a number of threat actors to compromise endpoints and networks. Emotet has also been utilized to create a botnet that is marketed as malware as a service (MaaS). After the international law enforcement operation known as Ladybird, it was assessed that the botnet and the adjacent infrastructure had been taken down. TrendMicro now believes that the Emotet botnet malware returned and is once again operational. The newest version of Emotet now utilizes Excel 4.0 to execute downloads. Emotet malware has continued to change and uses several techniques to avoid detection. Two techniques employed by the latest version of Emotet include using .ocx on the file extension and deploying carets in URLs. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/22/e/bruised-but-not-broken--the-resurgence-of-the-emotet-botnet-malw.html>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Tactics and Techniques:**

 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1591.004 - Identify Roles  
T1595 - Active Scanning  
T1598 - Phishing for Information  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  


 **Mitigations:**

 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1054:** Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
 **M1056:** Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Anomalous Spyware Attacks Targeting ICS
A report published by Kaspersky looks at the growing number of what they consider anomalous spyware attacks that have been infecting ICS systems globally.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Targets:** ICS systems.
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Agent Tesla, Azorult, HawkEye, Noon/Formbook, Lokibot, Masslogger, Snake Keylogger, and others.
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Spearphishing.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data collection, and exfiltration.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

Kaspersky is reporting on their discovery of anomalous spyware attacks against ICS targets that have become a trend. The attacks are short-lived, have a limited scope, and have a small number of targets. The malware used in the campaigns investigated by Kaspersky is typically commodity spyware and includes well-known malware such as Agent Tesla, Azorult, HawkEye, Noon/Formbook, Lokibot, Masslogger, Snake Keylogger, and others. One of the main differentiators between these and other attacks is the use of SMTP for one-way C&C communications. Often, the C&C server is an SMTP server that was compromised in a prior attack. Spearphishing and internal spearphishing from a compromised server or email account are the usual infections vectors. One interesting aspect of these campaigns when using a compromised email account is the attacker's apparent reliance on C&C email traffic being detected as spam with the offending emails being automatically moved to a separate folder where the victim user may not notice them. Kaspersky's report also notes that the value of credentials for the corporate networks of industrial enterprises is 8-10 times higher than those which provide access to cloud hosting infrastructures. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74057370/Anomalous%20Spyware%20Attacks%20Targeting%20ICS%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1642987806694&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).



# References

  * <https://ics-cert.kaspersky.com/publications/reports/2022/1/19/campaigns-abusing-corporate-trusted-infrastructure-hunt-for-corporate-credentials-on-ics-networks/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1589 - Gather Victim Identity Information  
T1589.002 - Email Addresses  
T1589.003 - Employee Names  
  
 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1584 - Compromise Infrastructure  
T1584.004 - Server  
T1586 - Compromise Accounts  
T1586.002 - Email Accounts  
T1588 - Obtain Capabilities  
T1588.001 - Malware  
T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
T1566.002 - Spearphishing Link  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.001 - Malicious Link  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1087 - Account Discovery  
T1087.001 - Local Account  
  
 **Lateral Movement - TA0008**  
T1534 - Internal Spearphishing  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
T1056 - Input Capture  
T1056.001 - Keylogging  
T1114 - Email Collection  
T1114.001 - Local Email Collection  
T1119 - Automated Collection  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.003 - Mail Protocols

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Joomla! Update Addresses Multiple Vulnerabilities
An updated version of Joomla! has been released that addresses seven vulnerabilities in the Joomla! core.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

  
A new version of Joomla! has been released that provides mitigation for seven vulnerabilities in the Joomla! core. All seven of the vulnerabilities have been rated as Low by the Joomla! security team; CVE numbers for the vulnerabilities are yet to be provided. The vulnerabilities are due to a failure to properly validate user provided input, a missing token check, improper handling of usernames and blacklist configuration, a failure to remove sensitive data, and a failure to respect access levels. If successfully exploited, the vulnerabilities could allow an attacker to carry out CSRF and SQL injection attacks and obtain sensitive data. Updating to the new version, 3.9.23, addresses the vulnerabilities. Further details, including affected versions, are available from the link in the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * CVE numbers are not yet available.




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://developer.joomla.org/security-centre.html>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: IBM Security X-Force ShellBot Analysis
IBM Security X-Force researchers studied the botnet activity of a malware variant that is used by cybercrime groups to illegally mine cryptocurrency.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Cryptomining




# Overview

Examining two ShellBot botnets that were caught in attacks on honeypots, IBM Security X-Force researchers were able to infect its own devices and become part of the live botnets, thereby gaining insight into how these botnets were managed internally. While the ShellBots are rather simple Perl-based code, they enable attackers to mount IRC-controlled botnets that command mining on infected systems. ShellBot infections typically use brute-force attacks. In the botnets IBM X-Force examined, the most frequently used credential types helped identify the targets as misconfigured databases, FTP-servers, monitoring servers, and other Linux machines. By far the most frequent username for which the password was brute-forced was ‘root,’ followed by standard or default username strings such as ‘ubuntu’, ‘admin’, ‘user’, and ‘test’. There were also some standard database-type credentials such as ‘oracle’, ‘postgres’ or ‘mysql’. Immediately after a successful login, the infected system receives a list of commands to execute; these include sending back system information, downloading and executing a PERL script, removing logs, removing the command history, and deleting the payload itself. Reconnaissance commands were regularly issued to the bots to collect information that would allow the botnet’s operators to zero in on valuable assets. The information the attackers looked for was root access, CPU and GPU information, and system architecture. The ShellBot code also removed previous versions of the ShellBot malware and those of other cryptominers that might be resident on the system. Two IRC servers, named Blackcat and Pola, were discovered and were managed by Romanian-speaking botmasters. A Romanian threat group, identified in 2018 and tracked as Outlaw, has been observed using ShellBot to target different organizations. After comparing data from IBM’s own research with TTPs from previously reported Outlaw attacks, X-Force found similarities in the threat actors' TTPs to those in the Blackcat and Pola servers. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://securityintelligence.com/posts/shellbot-publicly-available-cryptocurrency-miner/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Weaponizing An Antivirus Driver
While conducting an incident response investigation involving the Cuba ransomware, researchers from Aon discovered a new technique in the Cuba toolset that is used to bypass security controls.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Weaponizing An Antivirus Driver
While conducting an incident response investigation involving the Cuba ransomware, researchers from Aon discovered a new technique in the Cuba toolset that is used to bypass security controls.

Summary
=======



Threat Details
==============

* **Malware Type:** Ransomware
* **Associated Threat Actors:** Operators of the Cuba ransomware
* **Associated Payloads:** Cuba ransomware and toolset
* **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
* **Post-Compromise Actions:** File encryption
* **Additional TTPs:**See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.

Overview
========

Researchers from Aon discovered a new technique in the Cuba ransomware toolset that is used to bypass security controls. The technique involves the use of a legitimate driver, in this case, Avast's Anti Rootkit kernel driver, to terminate a number of AV and EDR processes. Three variations of the technique were observed by Aon, all of which involve installing the driver and then using either an executable or PowerShell script that calls the DeviceIoControl API to terminate specific AV and EDR processes. The Aon report notes that the most recent version of the Cuba toolset contains a list of 110 processes to terminate if found. Further information is available from the link in the References section below.

Indicators of Compromise
========================

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

Recommendations
===============

* For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

References
==========

* [https://www.aon.com/cyber-solutions/aon\_cyber\_labs/yours-truly-signed-av-driver-weaponizing-an-antivirus-driver/](https://www.aon.com/cyber-solutions/aon_cyber_labs/yours-truly-signed-av-driver-weaponizing-an-antivirus-driver/ "Follow link")

MITRE ATT&CK Framework
======================

**Tactics and Techniques:**

**Execution - TA0002**  
 T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
   T1059.001 - PowerShell  
 T1106 - Native API  
 T1204 - User Execution  
   T1204.002 - Malicious File  
 T1569 - System Services  
   T1569.002 - Service Execution  

**Persistence - TA0003**  
 T1574 - Hijack Execution Flow  
   T1574.010 - Services File Permissions Weakness  

**Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
 T1055 - Process Injection  
   T1055.002 - Portable Executable Injection  

**Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
 T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
   T1027.001 - Binary Padding  
   T1027.002 - Software Packing  
 T1036 - Masquerading  
   T1036.005 - Match Legitimate Name or Location  
 T1140 - Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information  
 T1211 - Exploitation for Defense Evasion  
 T1218 - Signed Binary Proxy Execution  
 T1562 - Impair Defenses  
   T1562.001 - Disable or Modify Tools  

**Discovery - TA0007**  
 T1057 - Process Discovery  

**Mitigations:**

**M1013:**  Application Developer Guidance: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.  
**M1017:**  User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
**M1018:**  User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
**M1019:**  Threat Intelligence Program - A threat intelligence program helps an organization generate their own threat intelligence information and track trends to inform defensive priorities to mitigate risk.  
**M1021:**  Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
**M1022:**  Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
**M1024:**  Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
**M1026:**  Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
**M1028:**  Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
**M1031:**  Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
**M1033:**  Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
**M1037:**  Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
**M1038:**  Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
**M1039:**  Environment Variable Permissions - Prevent modification of environment variables by unauthorized users and groups.  
**M1040:**  Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
**M1042:**  Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
**M1044:**  Restrict Library Loading - Prevent abuse of library loading mechanisms in the operating system and software to load untrusted code by configuring appropriate library loading mechanisms and investigating potential vulnerable software.  
**M1045:**  Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
**M1047:**  Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
**M1048:**  Application Isolation and Sandboxing - Restrict execution of code to a virtual environment on or in transit to an endpoint system.  
**M1049:**  Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
**M1050:**  Exploit Protection - Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.  
**M1051:**  Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
**M1052:**  User Account Control - Configure Windows User Account Control to mitigate risk of adversaries obtaining elevated process access.  
**M1054:**  Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.

parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
Weaponizing An Antivirus Driver
While conducting an incident response investigation involving the Cuba ransomware, researchers from Aon discovered a new technique in the Cuba toolset that is used to bypass security controls.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
Summary
=======



Threat Details
==============

* **Malware Type:** Ransomware
* **Associated Threat Actors:** Operators of the Cuba ransomware
* **Associated Payloads:** Cuba ransomware and toolset
* **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
* **Post-Compromise Actions:** File encryption
* **Additional TTPs:**See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.

Overview
========

Researchers from Aon discovered a new technique in the Cuba ransomware toolset that is used to bypass security controls. The technique involves the use of a legitimate driver, in this case, Avast's Anti Rootkit kernel driver, to terminate a number of AV and EDR processes. Three variations of the technique were observed by Aon, all of which involve installing the driver and then using either an executable or PowerShell script that calls the DeviceIoControl API to terminate specific AV and EDR processes. The Aon report notes that the most recent version of the Cuba toolset contains a list of 110 processes to terminate if found. Further information is available from the link in the References section below.

Indicators of Compromise
========================

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

Recommendations
===============

* For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: New Mirai variant Named Mirai_ptea
A new Mirai variant that targets KGUARD DVR firmware was detected by Netlab 360 in the latter part of June. They named the new variant mirai_ptea.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Botnet, DDoS




# Overview

A new Mirai variant named mirai_ptea was detected by Netlab 360 in June. According to Netlab 360 who discovered and named the new variant, it targets a previously unknown vulnerability in KGUARD DVR firmware. Probing for this vulnerability began as early as March. A matter of days after the discovery of mirai_ptea, and another variant named mirai_aurora were detected exploiting the KGUARD vulnerability. Netlab 360's report notes that the vulnerability appears to have been addressed in versions of the KGUARD firmware. The vulnerability is due to the firmware listening on an unspecified port which will allows an attacker to execute system commands without any authentication. Command and control communications are handled by mirai_ptea connecting to a Tor server through a proxy node. The botnet is used to carry out DDoS attacks. Further information is available from the Netlab 360 report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.netlab.360.com/mirai_ptea-botnet-is-exploiting-undisclosed-kguard-dvr-vulnerability-en/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: More_eggs Backdoor Delivered via LinkedIn with Fake Job Offers
More_eggs is a malware-as-a-service backdoor sold by Golden Chickens to other cybercriminals. eSentire reports on its recent usage in a spear phishing campaign targeting LinkedIn professionals with fake job offers to distribute the payload.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Backdoor




# Overview

eSentire discovered the more_eggs backdoor being distributed as part of a LinkedIn spear phishing campaign. Targets receive a ZIP file name based on their LinkedIn job title, attempting to lure them into opening the ZIP file. Opening the file leads to the execution of VenomLNK, the initial stage of a more_eggs infection. VenomLNK, in turn, displays a decoy job application document to distract the user while executing TerraLoader, more_eggs' plugin loader. Finally, Terraloader loads the TerraPreter payload via an ActiveX control file downloaded from AWS. The more_eggs operator is then able to interact with the victim host in order to carry out further activities, such as installing additional malware or exfiltrating data. Notably, this entire infection chain is performed by abusing legitimate Windows processes, decreasing the chances of detection. eSentire was unable to attribute this activity to a specific threat actor, but based on known more_eggs customers and previous threat activity, potential groups include FIN6, Evilnum, and Cobalt Group. For more information, see the eSentire blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.esentire.com/security-advisories/hackers-spearphish-professionals-on-linkedin-with-fake-job-offers-infecting-them-with-malware-warns-esentire>

Tell me about the following threat: Chrome Browser Update - March 2 2021 - Exploit in the Wild
Google has released an update to its Chrome web browser for Windows, Mac, and Linux that provides fixes for forty-eight vulnerabilities. An exploit for one of the vulnerabilities exists in the wild.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Chrome Browser Update - March 2 2021 - Exploit in the Wild
Google has released an update to its Chrome web browser for Windows, Mac, and Linux that provides fixes for forty-eight vulnerabilities. An exploit for one of the vulnerabilities exists in the wild.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

Google has released an update, version 89.0.4389.72, to its Chrome web browser for Windows, Mac, and Linux that provides fixes for forty-eight vulnerabilities. An exploit for the one of the vulnerabilities (CVE-2021-21166) exists in the wild. Google has rated this vulnerability as High. The most serious potential impact from successful exploitation of the vulnerabilities is the remote execution of arbitrary code. Further information is available from the release notes which are linked in the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/42434953/Chrome%20Browser%20Update%20-%20March%202%202021%20-%20Exploit%20in%20the%20Wild%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1614734328165&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://chromereleases.googleblog.com/2021/03/stable-channel-update-for-desktop.html>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Phishing Campaign Utilizes DocuSign to Evade Detection
Phishing campaigns often abuse legitimate services to evade detection by hiding behind well-known senders and domains. Cofense reports on one such case of an actor using DocuSign to distribute phsihing links.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Phishing
  *  **Target:** Non-specific
  *  **Lure:** Shared document via Docusign
  *  **Payload:** Phishing link via DocuSign file
  *  **Compromised Data:** Email credentials



# Overview

Cofense published a blog post analyzing a phishing campaign using DocuSign to evade security email gateways. By sending the lure as a shared document via DocuSign, security controls will recognize the sender and link within the body as legitimate. The messaging used alongside the share link spoofs a legitimate person and company and references a proposed document. Visiting the link leads to a DocuSign file with an embedded link to supposedly view the document via Adobe Document Cloud. The link uses a shortened URL to redirect users to the final landing page. From here, email credentials are requested and any entered data is exfiltrated to the attacker. For more information, see the Cofense blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/70222776/Phishing%20Campaign%20Utilizes%20DocuSign%20to%20Evade%20Detection%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1637336394949&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).



# References

  * <https://cofense.com/blog/phishing-campaign-docusign/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1598 - Phishing for Information  
T1598.003 - Spearphishing Link  
  
 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
T1608.005 - Link Target

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: The Return of Lotus Panda
According to a report from Cluster25, the APT group known as Naikon, also commonly known as Lotus Panda and APT30 has resurfaced after reportedly having been dormant.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: The Return of Lotus Panda
According to a report from Cluster25, the APT group known as Naikon, also commonly known as Lotus Panda and APT30 has resurfaced after reportedly having been dormant.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Loader, Beacon.
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Naikon
  *  **Associated Payloads:** HexINI, Beacon derived from the Viper RedTeam framework. 
  * **Targets:** Unspecified
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Spearphishing email with a malicious document attached.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** C&C Communications.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

A report from Cluster25 attributes an attack they analyzed as being connected to the APT group they refer to as Naikon. The group is also commonly known as Lotus Panda, and APT30, and is tracked by IBM X-Force as ITG06. The attack began with a spearphishing email that had a malicious document attached. Two payloads, a loader named HexINI, and a shellcode that is a beacon derived from the RedTeam framework named Viper, are hidden in the properties of the document. HexINI is used to load the shellcode into memory and then execute it. The shellcode creates a suspended svchost.exe process and injects the final beacon into it. The process then beacons for commands from its C&C server using an HTTPS URL. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://cluster25.io/2022/04/29/lotus-panda-awake-last-strike/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Tactics and Techniques:**

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1055 - Process Injection  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1105 - Ingress Tool Transfer  
T1571 - Non-Standard Port  
T1573 - Encrypted Channel  
  


 **Mitigations:**

 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1020:** SSL/TLS Inspection - Break and inspect SSL/TLS sessions to look at encrypted web traffic for adversary activity.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1054:** Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.

According to a report from Cluster25, the APT group known as Naikon, also commonly known as Lotus Panda and APT30 has resurfaced after reportedly having been dormant.

# References

# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Tactics and Techniques:**

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1055 - Process Injection  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1105 - Ingress Tool Transfer  
T1571 - Non-Standard Port  
T1573 - Encrypted Channel  
  


 **Mitigations:**

 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1020:** SSL/TLS Inspection - Break and inspect SSL/TLS sessions to look at encrypted web traffic for adversary activity.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1054:** Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Prynt Stealer Is New Malware Being Advertised On Cybercrime Forums
Cyble research labs have discovered a new infostealer named Prynt Stealer which is being sold on cybercrime forums. The stealer can steal credentials and financial information from several browsers and claims to be fully undetectable.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Stealer
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Prynt Stealer
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown **  
**
  * **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data Theft



# Overview

Cyble research labs have written an analysis on a new stealer malware called Prynt Stealer. The stealer is able to steal from many different browsers, as well as VPN, FTP, Messaging and Gaming apps. In addition to this, it can perform financial theft using keylogger functionality. The developer of the malware claims it is undetectable by security software. The malware is encoded using a rot13 cipher and executes in memory rather than dropping a payload. Upon execution, the malware first searches for files and steals them before stealing data from browsers. It can steal from almost all Chromium-based browsers, as well as MS Edge and Firefox-based browsers. It then moves onto other applications such as Telegram and Steam. All of this data is collated, along with system information and screenshots and is compressed into a folder. The stealer uses Telegram to retrieve the remote server IP and sends the compressed folder. The malware also contained unused functionality, such as a keylogger. This could be controlled using a builder which was provided by the TA, and allows customization of the malware. For more details, please see the link in the reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

# References

  * <https://blog.cyble.com/2022/04/21/prynt-stealer-a-new-info-stealer-performing-clipper-and-keylogger-activities/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1497.001 - System Checks  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1528 - Steal Application Access Token  
T1539 - Steal Web Session Cookie  
T1552 - Unsecured Credentials  
T1555 - Credentials from Password Stores  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1007 - System Service Discovery  
T1057 - Process Discovery  
T1087 - Account Discovery  
T1124 - System Time Discovery  
T1518 - Software Discovery  
T1614 - System Location Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1056 - Input Capture  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
T1567 - Exfiltration Over Web Service  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
  


#### Mitigations:

  
 **M1015:** Active Directory Configuration - Configure Active Directory to prevent use of certain techniques; use SID Filtering, etc.  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1027:** Password Policies - Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1032:** Multi-factor Authentication - Use two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate to a system; such as username and password in addition to a token from a physical smart card or token generator.  
 **M1035:** Limit Access to Resource Over Network - Prevent access to file shares, remote access to systems, unnecessary services. Mechanisms to limit access may include use of network concentrators, RDP gateways, etc.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1041:** Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
 **M1054:** Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
 **M1057:** Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Apple Security Updates May 3 2021 - Exploitation in the Wild Reported
Apple has published security updates for macOS Big Sur, iOS, iPadOS and watchOS. In total, four vulnerabilities are addressed in the updates, all of which are reported as being actively exploited in the wild.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

Apple has published security updates which take macOS Big Sur to 11.3.1, iOS (for older devices) to 12.5.3, iOS and iPadOS to 14.5.1, and watchOS to 7.4.1. In total, four vulnerabilities are addressed in the updates, one of which is common to all updates. All four vulnerabilities are WebKit issues and are all reported as being actively exploited in the wild. All four vulnerabilities, if successfully exploited, could potentially allow a remote attacker to execute arbitrary code. We recommend updating to the latest versions as soon as possible. Further details are available from the links in the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * CVE-2021-30661, CVE-2021-30663, CVE-2021-30665, CVE-2021-30666




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://support.apple.com/kb/HT201222>

  * <https://support.apple.com/en-us/HT212335>
  * <https://support.apple.com/en-us/HT212336>
  * <https://support.apple.com/en-us/HT212339>
  * <https://support.apple.com/en-us/HT212341>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Cybercriminals Distribute Backdoor With VPN Installer
With an increased usage in VPN programs during the transition to work from home, it's not surprising cybercriminals are looking to take advantage. Trend Micro reports on one such case of a fake Windscribe VPN installer bundle being used to distribute a backdoor.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Backdoor




# Overview

Trend Micro has published their analysis of a fake VPN installer distributing a backdoor. Victims are initially convinced to download what they believe is the Windscribe VPN installer but are instead downloading a malicious bundled application. The bundle drops three files: the legitimate VPN installer, a malicious downloader, and a VBS script. The VBS script is responsible for executing both the legitimate installer and the downloader. While the installer is distracting the user from any malicious activity, the downloader obtains the backdoor payload from a remote website. The downloaded file is an encrypted JPG file. After decryption, a backdoor executable is revealed. This backdoor contains basic functionality including downloading, executing, and updating files, taking screenshots, and gathering system information. For more information, see the Trend Micro blog post in the Reference section. 

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/20/i/wind-up-windscribe-vpn-bundled-with-backdoor.html>

I have encountered the following information: ICS Medical Advisory - December 8th, 2020
ICS-CERT has released a medical security advisory addressing two vulnerabilities in GE Healthcare Imaging and Ultrasound products.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview



CVE-2020-25175 is an unprotected transport of credentials vulnerability and CVE-2020-25179 is an exposure of sensitive information to an unauthorized control sphere vulnerability. Potential impacts of successful exploitation of these vulnerabilities are unauthorized access, exposure of sensitive information, such as patient health information (PHI), and arbitrary code execution. No patches have been released to address these issues but GE has provided mitigation advice to prevent these vulnerabilities from being exploited.

We recommend reviewing the advisories in the Reference section for mitigation advice.

# CVEs

  * CVE-2020-25175

  * CVE-2020-25179




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsma-20-343-01>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Indian Power Grid Targeted By Chinese State-Sponsored Group
Recorded Future has produced a report on the threat actor they call TAG-38. In the report, they describe activities targeting the Indian power grid and go into detail on their tools and techniques.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Backdoor
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** TAG-38 **  
**
  * **Associated Payloads:** ShadowPad
  *  **Targets:** Indian Power Companies
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Espionage



# Overview

Recorded Future has been tracking the Chinese state-sponsored threat actor they call TAG-38. This group has compromised at least 7 organizations related to the power sector in Northern India, close to a contested border. The actors used ShadowPad implants controlled by compromised infrastructure to target the victim networks. The activity used compromised IOT devices as C2 servers which were situated primarily in Taiwan or South Korea. A large number of these servers had been used previously in other Chinese state-sponsored campaigns. Attribution is further encouraged by the use of a unique SSL certificate that has links to wider espionage activity. At this moment, it is unclear how the devices were originally compromised. For more information, please see the link in the reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

# References

  * <https://go.recordedfuture.com/hubfs/reports/ta-2022-0406.pdf>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1584 - Compromise Infrastructure  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
T1090.003 - Multi-hop Proxy  
  


#### Mitigations:

  
 **M1020:** SSL/TLS Inspection - Break and inspect SSL/TLS sessions to look at encrypted web traffic for adversary activity.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1056:** Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.  
 **M1057:** Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: More SolarWinds Vulnerabilities Disclosed
Trustwave has reported on new SolarWinds Orion and Serv-U FTP vulnerabilities.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: More SolarWinds Vulnerabilities Disclosed
Trustwave has reported on new SolarWinds Orion and Serv-U FTP vulnerabilities.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerabilities




# Overview

Three new security issues have been disclosed by Trustwave security researchers, the most critical of which is classified as critical that could allow for remote code execution with escalated privileges. Encouragingly, none of these vulnerabilities were executed during the recent SolarWinds attacks or other "in-the-wild" attacks. The researchers have a Proof-of-Concept code they are not yet releasing in an effort to give SolarWinds opportunity to create a patch for the vulnerabilities. During installation of the SolarWinds products, the researcher observed the installation of a technology that hasn't been installed by default in many years. The technology, Microsoft Message Queue (MSMQ), is used extensively in SolarWinds' Orion Collector. Within the queues is the lack of security configuration. Message processing code runs as a service which uses LocalSystem account to control the OS. The second vulnerability allows for the harvesting of database credentials for everyone within the database. These users are granted read/write privileges by default. Any unprivileged user who can log in to the box either locally or via RDP will be able to get a cleartext password by using a simple one line decryption code. Lastly, the researcher was able to add an admin user for himself to the SolarWinds Serv-U FTP for Windows by dropping a simple file that is picked up by Serv-U FTP. Full technical details can be found in the report located within the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * CVE-2021-25274, CVE-2021-25275, CVE-2021-25276




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.trustwave.com/en-us/resources/blogs/spiderlabs-blog/full-system-control-with-new-solarwinds-orion-based-and-serv-u-ftp-vulnerabilities/>

  * [ServU-FTP 15.2.2 Hotfix 1](https://downloads.solarwinds.com/solarwinds/Release/HotFix/Serv-U-15.2.2-Hotfix-1.zip)
  * <https://documentation.solarwinds.com/en/Success_Center/orionplatform/content/release_notes/orion_platform_2020-2-4_release_notes.htm>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Cobalt Strike Deployment in Microsoft Teams Updates
A blog post from Bleeping Computer details how updates in Microsoft Teams are leading to Cobalt Strike deployments. The COVID-19 restrictions have made this infiltration more easily accessible.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Ransomware




# Overview

Attacks on Microsoft Teams updates have risen since the advent of the COVID-19 pandemic. The latest attacks on this platform focus mostly on the education sector. A non-public security advisory seen by Bleeping Computer showed Microsoft is aware of the issue and has issued warnings to its customers about the fake update campaigns. Using the ZeroLogon (CVE-2020-1472) vulnerability, actors are able to gain administrative access to victim machines and networks. Fake ads are placed in order to facilitate the victim into clicking a fake Teams update. It is believed these ads are being done through poisoned search results or malvertisements. In one instance, Microsoft found the actors bought a search engine ad in order to place their malware at the top of search results. To further the ruse, the actors installed a legitimate copy of the update. The initial payload was Predator the Thief Infostealer for the purposes of harvesting credentials, browser, and payment data. Additional malware installed included Bladabindi (NJRat) and ZLoader stealer. This also allowed for the download of Cobalt Strike beacons. By implanting these beacons, the actor is able to move laterally within the network. There are other campaigns using the same modus operandi, leading researchers to conclude the same actor is behind these attacks as well. Further details can be found in the blog post located within the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * CVE-2020-1472




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/fake-microsoft-teams-updates-lead-to-cobalt-strike-deployment/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: North Korea Distributing BLINDINGCAN RAT
SentinelOne has published a paper regarding malicious North Korean activity and the distribution of a RAT labeled BLINDINGCAN.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, RAT, Campaign



# Overview

Job offers are the subject of this particular phishing campaign and they carry BLINDINGCAN RAT as a payload, a SentinelOne paper states. The defense and aerospace industries in Europe and the United States are the primary targets of this campaign. An infected system in a key location can provide the attackers with valuable intelligence and key technologies, the article indicated. The attachment attempts to exploit CVE-2017-0199, a vulnerability in the processing of RTF files, which can result in the execution of arbitrary code if successful. Once infected, the malware contacts its command and control servers for additional components, such as a keylogger and clipboard monitor. Information about the system is sent back to the command and control servers. For more details, please refer to the links in the Reference section.

# CVEs

  * CVE-2017-0199
