instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: New Multi-Platform Skimmer
A new multi-platform skimmer targeting Shopify, BigCommerce, Zencart, and Woocommerce stores was discovered and reported on by Sansec.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: New Multi-Platform Skimmer
A new multi-platform skimmer targeting Shopify, BigCommerce, Zencart, and Woocommerce stores was discovered and reported on by Sansec.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Skimmer




# Overview

Sansec published a blog post analyzing a skimming campaign targeting a variety of shopping platforms. While skimming campaigns typically target one e-commerce platform, this campaign leverages a skimmer that targets multiple platforms including Shopify, BigCommerce, Zencart, and Woocommerce. Given these hosted platforms don't allow custom JavaScript, the attackers inject the skimmer into the victim website before users are taken to the legitimate checkout page. The skimmer presents a fake PayPal form that gathers and exfiltrates entered details. An error is then displayed indicating processing failed, and users are redirected to the legitimate checkout page. Interestingly, this skimmer uses a domain generation algorithm to produce the exfiltration domains. For more information, see the Sansec blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://sansec.io/research/skimmer-dynamic-exfiltration-shopify-bigcommerce>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: TeamTNT Updates Scripts After Tool Leak
Talos Intelligence has written a report detailing TeamTNTs actions after their tools were leaked by security researchers. They are actively modifying their scripts which target AWS instances, but can also run in on-premise, container, or other forms of Linux instances.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: TeamTNT Updates Scripts After Tool Leak
Talos Intelligence has written a report detailing TeamTNTs actions after their tools were leaked by security researchers. They are actively modifying their scripts which target AWS instances, but can also run in on-premise, container, or other forms of Linux instances.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Cryptominer
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** TeamTNT
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Various Scripts
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Cryptomining



# Overview

Cisco Talos has been provided with recently modified versions of TeamTNT's malicious scripts. These have been modified because of a recent leak where security researchers published their tools and made their scripts public. These scripts include scripts that steal credentials, cryptocurrency mining scripts, and scripts for lateral movement and persistence. The majority of these scripts were targetting AWS instances, but there are scripts to affect on-premise, container, and other Linux instances. One factor which has not been reported on in the past was the ability of these scripts to disable cloud security tools. The majority of this functionality is targeting Alibaba Cloud Security's various agents. The scripts can hunt for the process and attempt to kill it by running Alibaba tools, as well as trying to unmount the default Alibaba aegis directory. For full details of each script and its functionality, please see the link in the reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

# References

  * <https://blog.talosintelligence.com/2022/04/teamtnt-targeting-aws-alibaba.html>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1592.002 - Software  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1098.004 - SSH Authorized Keys  
T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1480 - Execution Guardrails  
T1562 - Impair Defenses  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1496 - Resource Hijacking  
  


#### Mitigations:

  
 **M1013:** Application Developer Guidance: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1024:** Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
 **M1025:** Privileged Process Integrity - Protect processes with high privileges that can be used to interact with critical system components through use of protected process light, anti-process injection defenses, or other process integrity enforcement measures.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1032:** Multi-factor Authentication - Use two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate to a system; such as username and password in addition to a token from a physical smart card or token generator.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1039:** Environment Variable Permissions - Prevent modification of environment variables by unauthorized users and groups.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1043:** Credential Access Protection - Use capabilities to prevent successful credential access by adversaries; including blocking forms of credential dumping.  
 **M1044:** Restrict Library Loading - Prevent abuse of library loading mechanisms in the operating system and software to load untrusted code by configuring appropriate library loading mechanisms and investigating potential vulnerable software.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1054:** Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
 **M1055:** Do Not Mitigate - This category is to associate techniques that mitigation might increase risk of compromise and therefore mitigation is not recommended.  
 **M1056:** Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: GhostEmperor - A New Sophisticated Chinese Threat Group
Researchers at Securelist have identified repeated behaviors when investigating attacks on Exchange servers. This activity is sophisticated and has been going on for at least a year, with many high profile targets being breached. The activity is not thought to be associated with any known threat groups, and so the group is being tracked under the name GhostEmperor.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: GhostEmperor - A New Sophisticated Chinese Threat Group
Researchers at Securelist have identified repeated behaviors when investigating attacks on Exchange servers. This activity is sophisticated and has been going on for at least a year, with many high profile targets being breached. The activity is not thought to be associated with any known threat groups, and so the group is being tracked under the name GhostEmperor.

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Targets:** Government Entities, Telecommunication Companies
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Demodex
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Exploitation of Public-Facing Servers
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data Collection, Internal Reconnaissance **  
**



# Overview

Whilst investigating attacks on Exchange servers, researchers at Securelist discovered a repeated cluster of behavior. This behavior involved highly sophisticated methods and hitherto unseen malware, suggesting that this is a very capable threat group. The researchers have traced this activity back to July 2020. As this is a long-standing operation, with advanced capabilities and no known affinity to existing threat groups, the researchers have named this group GhostEmperor. This group has been observed using several initial infection vectors, but most commonly, they exploit public-facing servers to gain initial access. They have recently been observed exploiting the ProxyLogon vulnerability. Once initial access is gained, the group deploys a series of malware starting with a PowerShell dropper, which installs the second stage as a service and executes it. This second stage then initiates a third stage payload as an in-memory implant. The third stage is in charge of facilitating a communication channel with a C2 server, where traffic can be masqueraded under the guise of legitimate communications with a benign service. The final stage is injected into the winlogon.exe process by the previous stage, which provides the attacker remote control over the system. In addition to the final stage, the implant also deploys a Windows kernel-mode driver which serves as a rootkit with the sole purpose of concealing malware artifacts. Analysts have named this rootkit Demodex, as it has not been seen before. Once this malware has been established, the attackers perform internal reconnaissance using public tools such as NBTscan, as well as tools from the Sysinternals suite such as PsExec and ProcDump. GhostEmperor mainly targets government entities and telecommunication companies in southeast Asia, with multiple high-profile entities targeted in Malaysia, Thailand, Vietnam, and Indonesia. Researchers have characterized the group as a Chinese-speaking group, thanks to some evidence found in the custom malware. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64129608/GhostEmperor%20-%20A%20New%20Sophisticated%20Chinese%20Threat%20Group%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1633523506641&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.

  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.

  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.

  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.

  * Some endpoint security solutions can be configured to block some types of process injection based on common sequences of behavior that occur during the injection process (M1040). 
  * Set PowerShell execution policy to execute only signed scripts (M1045).
  * When PowerShell is necessary, restrict PowerShell execution policy to administrators. Be aware that there are methods of bypassing the PowerShell execution policy, depending on environment configuration (M1026).



# References

  * <https://securelist.com/ghostemperor-from-proxylogon-to-kernel-mode/104407/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1587.001 - Malware  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1053 - Scheduled Task/Job  
T1543 - Create or Modify System Process  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1055 - Process Injection  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1014 - Rootkit  
T1036 - Masquerading  
T1055 - Process Injection  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1007 - System Service Discovery  
T1046 - Network Service Scanning  
T1057 - Process Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
T1056 - Input Capture  
T1113 - Screen Capture  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1565 - Data Manipulation

The activity is not thought to be associated with any known threat groups, and so the group is being tracked under the name GhostEmperor.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: South Korean and Australian Users Targeted with Malicious Emails Disguised as Accounting Ledgers
A malspam campaign spotted by Bitdefender is leveraging tax season in South Korea as a phishing lure.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, RAT




# Overview

Bitdefender published a brief blog post detailing a malspam campaign targeting users in South Korea and Australia. The body of the email simply claims an "account ledger" is attached for review, enticing the recipient to open the malicious file. This theme aligns with upcoming filing deadlines for income tax returns in South Korea, increasing the chances a user may believe these claims. Opening the attached file leads to the execution of malware on the victim system. Specifically, a remote access Trojan (RAT) is installed, allowing the attackers capabilities such as accessing sensitive information, taking screenshots, monitoring user activity, and downloading additional payloads. For more information, see the Bitdefender blog post in the Reference section.

# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://hotforsecurity.bitdefender.com/blog/threat-actors-target-south-korean-and-aussie-users-with-malicious-emails-disguised-as-accounting-ledgers-25835.html>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Matanbuchus: Malware-as-a Service
Palo Alto networks posted an assessment of a threat actor who has been advertising malware-as-a-service (MaaS)on underground marketplaces. The threat actor known as BelialDemon is currently selling a downloader known as Matanbuchus.
output:
Summary
=======



Threat Details
==============

* **Malware Type:** Loader
* **Associated Threat Actors:** BelialDemon
* **Associated Payloads:** Malicious Excel Document
* **Targets:** Unknown
* **Initial Infection Vector:** Phishing
* **Additional TTPs:**See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below

Overview
========

Unit 42 has been monitoring underground forums and tracking the activities of a threat actor known as BelialDemon. This threat actor began selling Matanbuchus malware in February of 2021. Matanbuchus is MaaS that has the capability of loading a second-stage malware from C&C servers. Unit 42 has observed the threat actor BelialDemon and they are involved in the development of malware loaders. Past operations have shown that they developed a loader known as TriumphLoader. Matabuchus uses Excel documents to lure victims and the loader has the capability to execute a .exe or .dll file in memory, utilize schtasks.exe to modify scheduled tasks, and launch custom PowerShell commands. Further information is available from the link in the References section below.

Indicators of Compromise
========================

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

Recommendations
===============

* For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

References
==========

* [https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/matanbuchus-malware-as-a-service/](https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/matanbuchus-malware-as-a-service/ "Follow link")

MITRE ATT&CK Framework
======================

#### Tactics and Techniques:

**Initial Access - TA0001**  
 T1566 - Phishing  
   T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  

**Execution - TA0002**  
   T1053.005 - Scheduled Task  
   T1059.001 - PowerShell  
 T1204 - User Execution  
   T1204.002 - Malicious File  

**Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
   T1574.001 - DLL Search Order Hijacking  

#### Mitigations:

**M1013:**  Application Developer Guidance: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.  
**M1017:**  User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
**M1018:**  User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
**M1021:**  Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
**M1022:**  Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
**M1024:**  Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
**M1026:**  Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
**M1028:**  Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
**M1031:**  Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
**M1033:**  Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
**M1038:**  Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
**M1040:**  Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
**M1042:**  Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
**M1044:**  Restrict Library Loading - Prevent abuse of library loading mechanisms in the operating system and software to load untrusted code by configuring appropriate library loading mechanisms and investigating potential vulnerable software.  
**M1045:**  Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
**M1047:**  Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
**M1049:**  Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
**M1051:**  Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
**M1052:**  User Account Control - Configure Windows User Account Control to mitigate risk of adversaries obtaining elevated process access.  
**M1054:**  Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.

Palo Alto networks posted an assessment of a threat actor who has been advertising malware-as-a-service (MaaS)on underground marketplaces. The threat actor known as BelialDemon is currently selling a downloader known as Matanbuchus.

Summary
=======



Threat Details
==============

* **Malware Type:** Loader
* **Associated Threat Actors:** BelialDemon
* **Associated Payloads:** Malicious Excel Document
* **Targets:** Unknown
* **Initial Infection Vector:** Phishing
* **Additional TTPs:**See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below

Overview
========

Unit 42 has been monitoring underground forums and tracking the activities of a threat actor known as BelialDemon. This threat actor began selling Matanbuchus malware in February of 2021. Matanbuchus is MaaS that has the capability of loading a second-stage malware from C&C servers. Unit 42 has observed the threat actor BelialDemon and they are involved in the development of malware loaders. Past operations have shown that they developed a loader known as TriumphLoader. Matabuchus uses Excel documents to lure victims and the loader has the capability to execute a .exe or .dll file in memory, utilize schtasks.exe to modify scheduled tasks, and launch custom PowerShell commands. Further information is available from the link in the References section below.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Phishing Campaign Targeting Predominantly Government Entities
A phishing campaign, active since late 2019, and targeting the education, energy, finance, government, and heath sectors in a number of geographies, has been reported by Recorded Future’s Insikt Group. The campaign has leveraged the open source phishing framework, FiercePhish.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Phishing Campaign Targeting Predominantly Government Entities
A phishing campaign, active since late 2019, and targeting the education, energy, finance, government, and heath sectors in a number of geographies, has been reported by Recorded Future’s Insikt Group. The campaign has leveraged the open source phishing framework, FiercePhish.

# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

Primarily targeting governmental entities, as well as the education, energy, finance, and heath sectors, Recorded Future’s Insikt Group has identified a phishing campaign that has been active since late 2019. The most targeted countries have been Canada, India, the United States, and Turkey. Other countries targeted include, Australia, India, Qatar, the Republic of Korea, Turkey, the United Arab Emirates, and the United Kingdom. The campaign has largely been using Russian domains (.ru) and Insikt believes the campaign has been coordinated through the site asherintartrading.com. The site has hosted the management portal for the the open source phishing framework, FiercePhish. A number of IP addresses, including more than thirty belonging to DigitalOcean, have also been used in the campaign, along with more than two hundred domains and URLs. The URLs follow a similar naming convention in most cases. In the email noted in the report, the victim was presented with a fake Gmail login page. In addition, if the victim clicked the unsubscribe link in the email, they were presented with a different phishing page, on a different domain. Further details are available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://go.recordedfuture.com/hubfs/reports/cta-2020-1027.pdf>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Malware in Minecraft Mods
Riding on the success of Minecraft, Kaspersky has observed threat actors distributing malware via modpacks in the Google Play store.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Malware in Minecraft Mods
Riding on the success of Minecraft, Kaspersky has observed threat actors distributing malware via modpacks in the Google Play store.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Adware




# Overview

Kaspersky has published a report detailing the discovery of fake Minecraft modpacks distributing malware. The supposed modpacks are hosted on the official Google Play store, some of which have been downloaded more than a million times. Despite having different publishers, Kaspersky suspects the same threat actor is behind the applications. They also observed the use of bots to boost ratings through fake reviews. Once downloaded by a victim, the modpack is able to be opened once; however, it contains no functionality relating to its advertised use. After closing the application, the icon is deleted from the device, making it harder to find by the user. At this point, the malware begins displaying ads on the device regularly via the browser, essentially rendering the device unusable. It also contains C2 commands allowing for Google Play, Facebook, or YouTube to be launched. For more information, see the Kaspersky blog post in the Reference section.

# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.




# Reference

  * <https://www.kaspersky.com/blog/minecraft-mod-adware-google-play/37717/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Verblecon - A New Loader
A report from Symantec looks at a new loader they describe as sophisticated being used in low-level attacks to install cryptominers and potentially steal Discord tokens.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Targets:** Unspecified
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Verblecon
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unspecified
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data collection and exfiltration, Cryptomining.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

Symantec has reported a new loader named Verblecon they describe as complex and powerful and being used in low-level attacks. The attacks are described as unsophisticated and low-reward. No information is provided on how the malware is being distributed to victims which Symantec described as mostly non-enterprise systems. Verblecon itself is loaded as a server-side JAR file and is polymorphic making it appear different each time it is downloaded. When executed, Verblecon checks that it is not being debugged or run in a virtual machine or sandbox. It then collects information about the system and communicates it to a C&C server. A payload is then downloaded in the form of binary blobs which are decrypted, executed, and injected into dllhost.exe using com.sun.jna. The objective of that attacks appears to be cryptomining but may also involve attempts to steal Discord tokens. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.



# References

  * <https://symantec-enterprise-blogs.security.com/blogs/threat-intelligence/verblecon-sophisticated-malware-cryptocurrency-mining-discord>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Tactics and Techniques:**

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
T1583.001 - Domains  
T1583.004 - Server  
T1588 - Obtain Capabilities  
T1588.001 - Malware  
T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
T1608.001 - Upload Malware  
T1608.002 - Upload Tool  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.001 - Malicious Link  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1055 - Process Injection  
T1055.001 - Dynamic-link Library Injection  
T1112 - Modify Registry  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1033 - System Owner/User Discovery  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
T1573 - Encrypted Channel  
T1573.001 - Symmetric Cryptography  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1496 - Resource Hijacking  
  


 **Mitigations:**

 **M1013:** Application Developer Guidance: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1020:** SSL/TLS Inspection - Break and inspect SSL/TLS sessions to look at encrypted web traffic for adversary activity.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1024:** Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
 **M1025:** Privileged Process Integrity - Protect processes with high privileges that can be used to interact with critical system components through use of protected process light, anti-process injection defenses, or other process integrity enforcement measures.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1043:** Credential Access Protection - Use capabilities to prevent successful credential access by adversaries; including blocking forms of credential dumping.  
 **M1044:** Restrict Library Loading - Prevent abuse of library loading mechanisms in the operating system and software to load untrusted code by configuring appropriate library loading mechanisms and investigating potential vulnerable software.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1056:** Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.  
 **M1057:** Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

The Mozilla Foundation has issued a Moderate-rated security advisory that addresses multiple vulnerabilities in Thunderbird.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

The Mozilla Foundation has released Thunderbird 78.9.1 to cover multiple vulnerabilities related to OpenPGP functions. The advisory has been rated as Moderate. The vulnerabilities could potentially result in a failure to send encrypted emails or allow a remote attacker to conduct a spoofing attack. For further details, please refer to the appropriate advisory in the Reference section.

# CVEs

  * CVE-2021-23991, CVE-2021-23993 




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.mozilla.org/en-US/security/advisories/mfsa2021-13/>

The Mozilla Foundation has issued three High-rated security advisories that address multiple vulnerabilities in Firefox, Firefox ESR, and Thunderbird.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

The Mozilla Foundation has released Firefox 86, Firefox ESR 78.8, and Thunderbird 78.8 to cover multiple vulnerabilities. All three advisories have been rated as High. The Mozilla Foundation has released Firefox 86, Firefox ESR 78.8, and Thunderbird 78.8 to cover multiple vulnerabilities. All three advisories have been rated as High. The potential impact from successful exploitation of the most serious vulnerability is the remote execution of arbitrary code. For further details, please refer to the appropriate advisory in the Reference section.

# CVEs

# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: A Compromise, BazarLoader, and an Apparent Conti Affiliate
The DFIR Report has published an article that follows the activities of an apparently Conti affiliate during an intrusion.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: A Compromise, BazarLoader, and an Apparent Conti Affiliate
The DFIR Report has published an article that follows the activities of an apparently Conti affiliate during an intrusion.

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Ransomware
  *  **Targets:** Unspecified
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** BazarLoader (S0534), Conti (S0575)
  *  **Other Payloads:** AdFind (S0552), Advanced IP Scanner, Cobalt Strike (S0154), PowerSploit (S0194), Rclone, Seatbelt
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malicious document attached to a spearphishing email.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Privilege escalation, Persistence, Discovery, Collection, Exfiltration
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

An article from the DFIR Report follows the activities of a threat actor from the initial compromise until their eviction from the system some three days later. While it is not absolutely certain, it is believed that the initial compromise was gained through a malicious document attached to a spearphishing email. A short time after the initial compromise, the actor was observed using standard Microsoft utilities for discovery and a Cobalt Strike beacon was installed shortly thereafter. While attempting to enumerate the network, the actor mistyped a lot of commands. In addition, they were seen to be following the instructions, in order, from some documents that are provided to Conti affiliates. In some cases, even using the same passwords from the documents for accounts they created. Adfind, native Windows utilities, and the Cobalt Strike beacon were used for further discovery. Credentials used for privilege escalation were obtained by dumping LSASS. When satisfied with their discovery phase the actor, using a reverse proxy, connected to the compromised host using RDP. Next, they moved laterally to the domain controller using RDP, downloaded and executed AdFind, executed two separate Cobalt Strike beacons, created two local administrator accounts, and installed a copy of the AnyDesk remote access software. They continued enumerating the network using PowerSploit and began searching for documents of interest on hosts connected to the domain. Another tool, the Advanced IP Scanner was used to scan for other subnets on the LAN. Later, they again enumerated the domain controller, this time using Seatbelt and then pivoted to another domain controller and carried out the same steps as they had done on the previous domain controller. After a period of inactivity, the actor returned to the system and used Rclone to exfiltrate the data they had collected to the public file-sharing service, Mega. Their access to the system was terminated not long after this. Amongst the data the actor collected, was an active directory backup they created, made in “IFM” media mode. All these steps and the apparent use of Conti affiliate instructions suggest the intended outcome of the attack was the deployment of the Conti ransomware, prevented in the case when the actor was evicted from the systems prior to Conti deployment. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64129600/A%20Compromise%2C%20BazarLoader%2C%20and%20an%20Apparent%20Conti%20Affiliate%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1633493852280&api=v2)



# Detection

  * A list of Yara rules can be found here: [ Yara Rules.txt](/download/attachments/64129600/A%20Compromise%2C%20BazarLoader%2C%20and%20an%20Apparent%20Conti%20Affiliate%20Yara%20Rules.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1633494020747&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://thedfirreport.com/2021/10/04/bazarloader-and-the-conti-leaks/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1204 - User Execution  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1078 - Valid Accounts  
T1078.002 - Domain Accounts  
T1078.003 - Local Accounts  
T1136 - Create Account  
T1136.001 - Local Account  
T1136.002 - Domain Account  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1078 - Valid Accounts  
T1078.002 - Domain Accounts  
T1078.003 - Local Accounts  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1036 - Masquerading  
T1036.004 - Masquerade Task or Service  
T1055 - Process Injection  
T1055.001 - Dynamic-link Library Injection  
T1055.012 - Process Hollowing  
T1218 - Signed Binary Proxy Execution  
T1218.011 - Rundll32  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1003 - OS Credential Dumping  
T1003.001 - LSASS Memory  
T1003.005 - Cached Domain Credentials  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1016 - System Network Configuration Discovery  
T1016.001 - Internet Connection Discovery  
T1018 - Remote System Discovery  
T1033 - System Owner/User Discovery  
T1046 - Network Service Scanning  
T1057 - Process Discovery  
T1069 - Permission Groups Discovery  
T1069.001 - Local Groups  
T1069.002 - Domain Groups  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
T1087 - Account Discovery  
T1124 - System Time Discovery  
T1135 - Network Share Discovery  
T1482 - Domain Trust Discovery  
T1518 - Software Discovery  
  
 **Lateral Movement - TA0008**  
T1021 - Remote Services  
T1021.001 - Remote Desktop Protocol  
T1021.002 - SMB/Windows Admin Shares  
T1021.006 - Windows Remote Management  
T1570 - Lateral Tool Transfer  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
T1039 - Data from Network Shared Drive  
T1074 - Data Staged  
T1074.001 - Local Data Staging  
T1074.002 - Remote Data Staging

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Threat Actor Group Cloud Atlas Tracked by DomainTools Researchers
Researchers from DomainTools continue to see an APT group known as Cloud Atlas (also known as Inception) run campaigns which primarily focus on targeting countries formerly part of the Soviet Union with an emphasis on energy and political themes.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Phishing, Data Theft, Trojan




# Overview

Researchers from DomainTools were able to identify new infrastructure used by Cloud Atlas, an APT, also known as Inception. A pattern of infrastructure creation used by Cloud Atlas shows that they have a reliance on European hosting providers such as Hostkey and OVH. The domains use consistent naming themes that include terms such as "office," update," or "ms," which are likely designed to spoof Microsoft-related items. When researchers discovered documents associated with the discovered infrastructure, they were further convinced of linking it to Cloud Atlas by the appearance of the same long numerical template string across the documents as they have previously used. The documents are Microsoft word documents, likely deployed as attachments in emails, and execute code that attempt to download additional payload files that are later called upon by powershell or vbscript. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.domaintools.com/resources/blog/the-continuous-conundrum-of-cloud-atlas>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: 8220 Gang's Recent Use of Custom Miner and Botnet
A cluster of malicious activity led Lacework Labs to uncover loader scripts delivering a custom cryptocurrency miner and IRC botnet, which they believe are attributed to the 8220 Gang.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Cryptomining, Botnet




# Overview

Lacework Labs uncovered a series of malicious loader scripts delivering a custom cryptocurrency miner and IRC botnet, which they attribute to the 8220 Gang. The loaders are shell scripts likely dropped on systems via n-day exploits for public-facing services. Once on the system, the script is responsible for downloading and executing the malware, gaining persistence via cron jobs, moving laterally via SSH, and cleaning up its tracks. The first payload delivered to the system is a custom XMRig miner dubbed "PwnRig." Notably, it leverages mining proxies in order to prevent researchers from analyzing the wallets. The second payload is the Tsunami IRC bot, which allows its operator to issue a variety of commands via an IRC server. Capabilities include file operations, DDoS attacks, and command execution. The report goes into detail about the network infrastructure used by the group and some potential confusion around attribution. For more information, see the Lacework blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://www.lacework.com/8220-gangs-recent-use-of-custom-miner-and-botnet/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Ryuk Flips the Script in Five Hours
The threat actors behind Ryuk have updated tactics from phishing emails to a domain wide ransomware attack inside 5 hours. The DFIR Report posted an analysis and case summary regarding the sudden change in tactics.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Ransomware, Phishing




# Overview

Using tools such as Cobalt Strike, AdFind, WMI, and PowerShell, the actors behind Ryuk took their actions from a phishing email to a full-blown, domain-wide ransomware attack in just 5 hours. Using Bazar as an entry point via phishing email, the actors were able to accomplish their mission faster than previously observed. As with previous attacks, once Bazar was downloaded, it began injecting into explorer.exe or svchost.exe and spawning command shells. The domain was then mapped using a lower-level privileged user with a slow and methodical approach. It was from this point the Zerologon vulnerability (CVE-2020-1472) was used to reset the password of the primary domain controller. Lateral movement was done via SMB file transfers and WMI executions of Cobalt Strike beaconing. More domain discovery was accomplished and privilege escalation was completed. Additional Cobalt Strike beacons were deployed, and further domain recon was performed using AdFind. At just 4 hours into the attack, the actors were able to pivot from the primary domain controller to RDP into the backup server. This was the target for the deployment of ransomware, followed by servers and, finally, workstations. Execution of the ransomware occurred on the primary domain controller and completed their attack at the 5 hour mark. Further details can be found within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://thedfirreport.com/2020/10/18/ryuk-in-5-hours/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: A Novel Web Skimmer
A report from BleepingComputer looks into a recently discovered web skimmer that has some interesting features.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: A Novel Web Skimmer
A report from BleepingComputer looks into a recently discovered web skimmer that has some interesting features.

# Threat Type

  * Skimmer




# Overview

A recently discovered web skimmer that has some interesting features is the subject of a report from BleepingComputer. It was initially discovered and analyzed by a researcher who uses the Twitter handle @AffableKraut. Firstly, the skimmer's code is contained within an image file. The image file was stored on the store's server and the code is retrieved from the image using steganography. The skimmer grabs a victim's order data from the checkout page, checks the validity of the data, and if the data fails validation, will even return a message to the checkout page. In addition, when the data verification fails, the skimmer removes the malicious iframes it uses from the checkout page. If verification of the data succeeds, the data is then used to prefill a fake PayPal payment iframe that overlays the legitimate checkout page. Once the victim data has been obtained, the victim is returned to legitimate checkout process. Further details are available from the article linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/credit-card-skimmer-fills-fake-paypal-forms-with-stolen-order-info/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: WordPress Redirect Kit Malware
Analysts with Sucuri observed semi-randomized malware injections in WordPress environments. The injections make use of redirects to obtain malware from infected websites.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

Summary
=======



Threat Details
==============

* **Malware Type:** Unknown
* **Associated Threat Actors:**Unknown
* **Associated Payloads:**Multi-part payload assembled using function calls
* **Targets:**WordPress users
* **Initial Infection Vector:**Google search result redirects
* **Post-Compromise Actions:**Add malicious user to ensure continued access
* **Additional TTPs:**Unknown

Overview
========

Utilizing random function calls, a series of WordPress redirects allows for malware to be installed in WordPress environments. Analysts from Sucuri observed the activity and conducted analysis on the actions and redirects. The redirects were noticed during the accessing of a website through Google search results. The browser used was caught in a redirect loop that eventually led to a bogus site. The analysts saw three separate redirects before landing on a scam website. The domain to which the user was redirected has been taken offline and blocklisted by Google. This led the threat actors to open a new domain from which the same actions can be performed. Using randomly named variables and arguments (get\_option()), malware is stored in various places within the database and loads it into memory. The calls use JavaScript to perform the nefarious actions; combined with the randomization of the locations of the calls, detection is more difficult. According to the analysts, the multiple parts of malware downloaded during different parts of the intrusion make analysis a more in-depth endeavor. When compared to legitimate WordPress installations, the versions in which the malware was loaded beared little resemblance to the legitimate installation. Further details can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

Indicators of Compromise
========================

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

Recommendations
===============

* Use direct calls to websites if known.
* Use caution when opening sites from Google search results.
* Block URLs located in the IoCs section.

References
==========

* <https://blog.sucuri.net/2021/09/multistage-wordpress-redirect-kit.html>

MITRE ATT&CK Framework
======================

**Initial Access - TA0001**  
 T1133 - External Remote Services  
 T1189 - Drive-by Compromise  

**Execution - TA0002**  
  T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
  T1059.007 - JavaScript  
  T1129 - Shared Modules  

**Persistence - TA0003**  
 T1136 - Create Account  
 T1136.001 - Local Account

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Proxylogon Allows for New Malware Family Capabilities
The Proxylogon zero-day exploit has allowed for three new malware families to take advantage of the vulnerability. Trend Micro has published a blog post regarding these new capabilities and their usage.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Ransomware, Botnet




# Overview

The Proxylogon zero-day exploits have allowed for several malware families to take advantage of the vulnerability. Included in these malware families are LemonDuck, BlackKingdon, and Prometei botnet. The vulnerability allows the malwares to execute Chopper web shells that allow for the usage of the final payloads of the families. Activities deployable include dropping ExchDefender seen in both BlackKingdom and Prometei, and a WMI modifier allowing for LemonDuck infections. As seen in previous campaigns involving ExchDefender, a service made to impersonate a security measure for Exchange is created. This leads to the execution of a binary in a created folder which uses the command line "Dcomsvc." The directory is searched for web shells used in other attacks and deletes them. In the LemonDuck family, WMI is used to modify the OAB. A PowerShell process executes a Base64-encoded command. Once deobfuscated, it is revealed that it is capable of modifying the ExernalURL of an ASPX file. This, then, allows for remote command execution. Further information can be found in the blog located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/21/e/proxylogon-a-coinminer--a-ransomware--and-a-botnet-join-the-part.html>

I have encountered the following information: WarzoneRAT Using New Detection Evasion Tactics
The Uptycs Threat Research Team has been researching new techniques being used by WarzoneRAT. In this article, they discuss a detection evasion technique using process hollowing.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Remote Access Trojan
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** WarzoneRAT (S0670)
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malicious Excel Document
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Unknown
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

The Uptycs Threat Research team has been analyzing the techniques used by the WarzoneRAT malware. The malware tends to be delivered via a malicious Excel document, which uses javascript embedded in a macro to start the kill chain. This script downloads the payload from a remote server and sets up persistence using scheduled tasks. In this article, the researchers describe a defense evasion technique that is a recent development for Warzone RAT. The launching script downloads various payloads, which are injected into legitimate processes such as MSBuild.exe using process hollowing. The script also injects a payload, which performs UAC bypass via ComputerDefaults.exe, allowing the malware to run at a higher privilege level. For more information, please see the link in the reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

# Recommendations

  * For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://www.uptycs.com/blog/warzonerat-can-now-evade-with-process-hollowing>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1053.005 - Scheduled Task  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1055.012 - Process Hollowing  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1055 - Process Injection  
  


#### Mitigations:

  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1054:** Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.

Tell me about the following threat: New Targeting of National Oil Company’s Ongoing Development and Exploration Projects
IBM X-Force Threat Intelligence has identified phishing emails targeting companies with an interest in the pipeline offshore Sarawak, Malaysia project led by Petroleum Authority of Thailand (PTT) Exploration and Production Public Co. Ltd’s (PTTEP). This activity has been connected to a previous credential harvesting campaign identified by X-Force in July 2020.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: New Targeting of National Oil Company’s Ongoing Development and Exploration Projects
IBM X-Force Threat Intelligence has identified phishing emails targeting companies with an interest in the pipeline offshore Sarawak, Malaysia project led by Petroleum Authority of Thailand (PTT) Exploration and Production Public Co. Ltd’s (PTTEP). This activity has been connected to a previous credential harvesting campaign identified by X-Force in July 2020.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Credential Harvesting




# Overview

In mid-September 2020, IBM X-Force Threat Intelligence observed a wave of phishing emails targeting companies likely having an interest in the pipeline offshore Sarawak, Malaysia project led by Petroleum Authority of Thailand (PTT) Exploration and Production Public Co. Ltd’s (PTTEP). X-Force uncovered Domain Name System (DNS) Start of Authority (SOA) records associated with this activity that directly overlap with the DNS SOA record reported by X-Force in July 2020 “Years of Phishing Campaigns Deliver Credential Harvesting Malware to Exploit Worldwide Expansion of Major Saudi Arabian Energy Company”. The emails involved in this campaign deliver the AgentTesla credential harvesting malware. The full story, including indicators of compromise, is available to IBM X-Force Premier Threat Intelligence clients at the link below.

# Indicators of Compromise

Indicators of compromise are available to IBM X-Force Premier Threat Intelligence clients at the link below.

# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * Premier Threat Intelligence clients can read more and see the indicators at: <https://station.trustar.co/constellation/reports/9c339d47-8b17-4c7c-a4e1-5eb9770c3ca0>

  * To learn more about X-Force Premier Threat Intelligence, visit: <https://www.ibm.com/security/services/threat-intelligence>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Apache Struts 2 RCE Vulnerability
The Apache Software Foundation has published an advisory that addresses a vulnerability in Struts 2, which, in some cases, could allow for the remote execution of arbitrary code.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

An advisory from the Apache Software Foundation addresses a vulnerability in Struts 2 that could allow a remote attacker to execute arbitrary code. The vulnerability is caused by a failure to properly sanitize user-provided input in certain tags. The vulnerability can be exploited if forced Object-Graph Navigation Language (OGNL) evaluation using the %{...} syntax has been applied. A remote attacker could exploit the vulnerability by sending a maliciously crafted request to the application, potentially leading to arbitrary code execution. Versions of Strut 2 2.0.0 through 2.5.25 are affected. A workaround, and an update (version 2.5.26), have been published to address the vulnerability. Further details are available from the link in the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * CVE-2020-17530




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/WW/S2-061#space-menu-link-content>

I have encountered the following information: South Eastern Asian Government Institutions Targeted By Chinese APT Group
Bitdefender has published a whitepaper on their monitoring of a Chinese APT group that has been targeting South Eastern Asian government institutions since late 2018.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, APT, Backdoor



# Overview

In a recently published whitepaper, Bitdefender dissects the antics of a Chinese APT group's attacks on South Eastern Asian Government institutions. The paper indicates that these attacks have been going on since at least late 2018. Although proof was not found, Bitdefender suspects that social engineering via spam may be the source of infection. Chinoxy backdoor is first loaded and gains persistence on the infected system. Chinoxy then deploys additional modules, including in some cases, an open source Chinese RAT called PcShare. Lateral movement was also observed to some extent through the uses of credentials. How the credentials were obtained is unknown. System information is gathered through the use of a number of Windows command line tools such as tasklist.exe, ipconfig.exe, among others. Data gathered is sent back to the command and control servers on a daily basis. For a detailed timeline and tool description, please refer to the link in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.bitdefender.com/files/News/CaseStudies/study/379/Bitdefender-Whitepaper-Chinese-APT.pdf>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Matryosh Botnet
The Moobot appears to have created a new botnet malware dubbed "Matryosh" by Netlab 360 researchers.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Matryosh Botnet
The Moobot appears to have created a new botnet malware dubbed "Matryosh" by Netlab 360 researchers.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Botnet, DDoS




# Overview

Netlab 360 published a blog post analyzing a new botnet malware named Matryosh. This malware does not have any embedded propagation capabilities and has the primary goal of carrying out DDoS attacks. Android-like devices are infected via the ADB interface using an initial payload that downloads and executes a shell script. This shell script, in turn, retrieves several versions of Matryosh payload designed for different architectures from the same remote server hosting the shell script. Upon execution, resources and functions are decrypted, revealing various attack methods and remote domains. To obtain its TOR proxy and C2 information, hardcoded remote domains are queried to identify data in their DNS TXT records. The first DNS TXT record provides a string used to obtain the subdomains used for generating the next domain list. The second DNS TXT record is from one of the domains in the aforementioned list and returns the TOR proxy addresses. Finally, the last TXT record provides the TOR C2 address. At this point C2 communication is fully established and the bot can receive instructions for getting group information, performing a heartbeat, or carrying out a DDos attack. Similarities in the C2 model, commands, and communication indicate an overlap with the Moobot group. For more information, see the Netlab blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.netlab.360.com/matryosh-botnet-is-spreading-en/>

Upon execution, resources and functions are decrypted, revealing various attack methods and remote domains. To obtain its TOR proxy and C2 information, hardcoded remote domains are queried to identify data in their DNS TXT records. The first DNS TXT record provides a string used to obtain the subdomains used for generating the next domain list. The second DNS TXT record is from one of the domains in the aforementioned list and returns the TOR proxy addresses. Finally, the last TXT record provides the TOR C2 address. At this point C2 communication is fully established and the bot can receive instructions for getting group information, performing a heartbeat, or carrying out a DDos attack. Similarities in the C2 model, commands, and communication indicate an overlap with the Moobot group. For more information, see the Netlab blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.netlab.360.com/matryosh-botnet-is-spreading-en/>

X-Force Threat Intelligence researchers have published a report on Internet of Things (IoT) attack activity observed over the course of 2020, specifically focusing on IoT botnets.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Internet of Threats: IoT Botnets Drive Surge in Attacks
X-Force Threat Intelligence researchers have published a report on Internet of Things (IoT) attack activity observed over the course of 2020, specifically focusing on IoT botnets.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Vulnerability, Botnet




# Overview

X-Force Threat Intelligence released their analysis of 2020 IoT attack activity, which heavily revolved around IoT botnets. The report details significant trends observed, including the botnet families leveraged, devices exploited, and industries targeted. An overview of the most active botnet malware families is provided. This includes the Mozi botnet, Gafgyt, Echobot, Loli, and ZeroShell. Alongside the report, the researchers provide detailed recommendations on how users can protect their networks and devices from falling victim to such an attack. The full story, analysis, and mitigation advice is available to IBM X-Force Premier Threat Intelligence clients at the link below.

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: IronNetInjector
A new loader in Turla's arsenal, dubbed IronNetInject, was analyzed by Palo Alto in a recent blog post.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Injector




# Overview

Palo Alto published a blog post analyzing , a new malware loading tool attributed to Turla.  is composed of IronPython scripts and an injector used to load a final payload. IronPython is an open-source project that allows Python code to use .NET framework APIs without compiling a .NET assembly. The IronPython script in this case executes the .NET injector. The injector and the malicious payloads are both Base64-encoded and Rijndael-encrypted. The injector is able to load either PE files or .NET assemblies into either its own process or a remote process. The main malware family being loaded by  samples identified by Palo Alto was ComRAT, however an RPC backdoor and unknown malware were also identified. The researchers were unable to determine the initial infection vector used to deliver this tool. For more information, see the Palo Alto blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/ironnetinjector/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Lazarus Using BMP Files With Malicious HTA Objects
A report from Malwarebytes Labs provides details of an attack that occurred in early April that they attribute to the Lazarus APT group. In the attack, a BMP image that contained embedded HTA objects was used to drop a loader.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Lazarus Using BMP Files With Malicious HTA Objects
A report from Malwarebytes Labs provides details of an attack that occurred in early April that they attribute to the Lazarus APT group. In the attack, a BMP image that contained embedded HTA objects was used to drop a loader.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Phishing




# Overview

The first stage of an attack, attributed to the Lazarus APT group by Malwarebytes Labs, probably began with phishing emails. Lazarus is known by many names including Guardians of Peace, Hidden Cobra, Nickel Academy, and Zinc. A malicious document attached to the emails contained macros that would kick off the infection process by dropping a loader. The loader was contained in a PNG file present in the document, which was then converted to a BMP file. During the conversion from PNG into the uncompressed BMP format, the malicious HTA objects are also decompressed. The HTA objects provide a JavaScript file that creates an executable file, in this case, "AppStore.exe". In turn, AppStore.exe loads a base64-encrypted payload into memory. The second stage payload initiates communication with the C&C servers. Further details are available from the Malwarebytes Labs report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.malwarebytes.com/malwarebytes-news/2021/04/lazarus-apt-conceals-malicious-code-within-bmp-file-to-drop-its-rat/>
