instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Signed XLL File Email Attachment Delivers Buer Loader
A malicious spam campaign was discovered by FortiGuard Labs that tricks their targets into opening an attached malicious, but signed, Microsoft Excel document with an .XLL file extension. The use of an .XLL file for malicious use is not new, but it is rare. After the file is opened it downloads the payload, which is malware known as Buer Loader.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Phishing
  *  **Target:** Anyone, Anywhere
  *  **Lure:** Shipment Courier Status Email
  *  **Payload:** Downloads and runs **** Buer Loader
  *  **TTPs:** Spearphishing Attachment ([T1566.001](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566/001/)) Malicious File ([T1204.002](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1204/002/)) Persistence ([T1547.001](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1547/001/)) Evasion/Code Signing ([T1553.002](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1547/001/)) Data Collection ([T1005](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1005/)) C2 via Web Protocol ([T1071.001](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1071/001/)) Exfiltration Over C2 ([T1041](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1041/)) System Information Discovery ([T1082](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1082/))
  *  **Compromised Data:** System Information Discovery ([T1082](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1082/))
  *  **Post-compromise Actions:** Exfiltration Over C2 ([T1041](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1041/))



# Overview

FortiGuard Labs discovered a spam campaign that was sending out an attached malicious Microsoft Excel document with an .XLL file extension. The file is also signed which will often allow it to evade endpoint security products. The spam campaign is not targeting any particular set of organizations or users from particular countries. After the file is opened, it will download a loader named Buer Loader. Buer Loader is a popular Malware-as-a-Service (MaaS) used by various threat actors and can be used to deliver any number of other malware software. This is a newer variant of Buer Loader that has been completely rewritten. For more information, see the Fortinet blog post in the References section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [SignedXLLFileEmailAttachmentDeliversBuerLoader-IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/57312483/SignedXLLFileEmailAttachmentDeliversBuerLoader-IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1627070585697&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.
  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.



# References

  * <https://www.fortinet.com/blog/threat-research/signed-sealed-and-delivered-signed-xll-file-delivers-buer-loader>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Analysis of Xloader’s C2 Network Encryption
Xloader is the successor to Formbook and operates a malware-as-a-service (MaaS) business model in which it rents and supports C2 infrastructure. A blog post from Zscaler provides a detailed analysis of Xloader's C2 network encryption and communication protocol.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Analysis of Xloader’s C2 Network Encryption
Xloader is the successor to Formbook and operates a malware-as-a-service (MaaS) business model in which it rents and supports C2 infrastructure. A blog post from Zscaler provides a detailed analysis of Xloader's C2 network encryption and communication protocol.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Infostealer
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Xloader
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data theft, remote command execution



# Overview

Zscaler published a blog post analyzing Xloader's C2 network encryption and communication protocol. Xloader, the successor to Formbook, operates a malware-as-a-service (MaaS) business model in which it rents and supports C2 infrastructure. C2 communication occurs over HTTP, using a GET request to register itself with the C2 server and POST requests to exfiltrate stolen information. The payload communicates with a series of decoy C2 servers to hinder analysis. The encryption process involves @c4 encryption, base64 encoding, and character substitution. It is similar to Formbook's encryption process but includes an additional layer of RC4 encryption with a complex algorithm involved in deriving the key. For more information, see the Zscaler blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74057447/Analysis%20of%20Xloader%E2%80%99s%20C2%20Network%20Encryption%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1643049081413&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://www.zscaler.com/blogs/security-research/analysis-xloaders-c2-network-encryption>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1140 - Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1555 - Credentials from Password Stores  
T1555.003 - Credentials from Web Browsers  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
T1056 - Input Capture  
T1056.001 - Keylogging  
T1113 - Screen Capture  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1001 - Data Obfuscation  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
T1132 - Data Encoding  
T1573 - Encrypted Channel

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: PrivateLoader Pay-Per-Install Campaign Distributing Wide Range of Malware
Researchers at Intel471 have been tracking the malware being distributed by Pay-per-install services. In this article, they detail the malware being distributed by the PrivateLoader Malware.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Loader
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** PrivateLoader
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Trojanized Cracked Software
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Malware Installation



# Overview

Pay-per-install malware services allow attackers to outsource the delivery and distribution of their payload to a third party that will already have the infrastructure and techniques to do so. Researchers at Intel471 have been tracking PrivateLoader, which is being used to distribute many types of malware and appears to operate on a PPI model. This malware is delivered through several sites offering cracked software. The sites are often SEO optimized so they appear at the top of search pages to act as lures for potential victims. The final payload is served as a password-protected zip archive and downloaded onto the victim machine. The majority of the malware loaded by PrivateLoader was Smokeloader and Redline stealer, and didn't seem to target any specific geographical region. It has also been seen delivering Trickbot and Dridex, and in a small number of cases, Lockbit ransomware. The researchers were able to identify that over 20,000 users were infected with this malware, showing that it is an effective delivery mechanism. For more information, please access the link in the references section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74058841/PrivateLoader%20Pay-Per-Install%20Campaign%20Distributing%20Wide%20Range%20of%20Malware%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1645010891751&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Application control may be able to prevent the running of executables masquerading as other files (M1038).



# References

  * <https://intel471.com/blog/privateloader-malware>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
T1608.001 - Upload Malware  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1053 - Scheduled Task/Job  
T1053.005 - Scheduled Task  
T1176 - Browser Extensions  
T1543 - Create or Modify System Process  
T1543.003 - Windows Service  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1548 - Abuse Elevation Control Mechanism  
T1548.002 - Bypass User Account Control

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Ukrainian Organizations Targeted by Destructive Malware
A report from Microsoft outlines an attack that is targeting Ukrainian organizations with destructive malware that overwrites the MBR of an infected system.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Ukrainian Organizations Targeted by Destructive Malware
A report from Microsoft outlines an attack that is targeting Ukrainian organizations with destructive malware that overwrites the MBR of an infected system.

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware, overwrites MBR and files.
  *  **Targets:** Government, information technology, and non-profit organizations located in Ukraine.
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** WhisperGate.
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unspecified.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Overwriting the system MBR and files.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

Ukrainian organizations are being targeted with destructive malware that overwrites the MBR of an infected system according to a report from Microsoft. No notable associations between these attacks which began on January 13th and attacks by known threat groups have been located by Microsoft and they are tracking the actor behind this activity as DEV-0586. Microsoft has named the malware WhisperGate. There is no information in the Microsoft report as to the vector used to deploy the malware onto systems. The malware itself pretends to be ransomware and is executed in two stages, the first of which is executed when the system is powered down and overwrites the system's MBR with a fake ransom note. In all cases, the ransom notes ask for $10,000 and contain the same Bitcoin wallet address and Tox chat ID. WhisperGate's second stage is a downloader that is used to download a file corrupter which searches the system for files that match a hard-coded list of specific extensions and when found overwrites the file's content with a fixed number of 0xCC bytes and changes the file's extension to what appears to be a random four-byte extension. At the time the Microsoft report was written, Microsoft noted that the malware has been located in dozens of systems belonging to government, and information technology and non-profit organizations located in Ukraine. Further information is available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74056999/Ukrainian%20Organizations%20Targeted%20by%20Destructive%20Malware%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1642391468316&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Users should be encouraged to only install apps from authorized app stores, which are less likely to contain malicious repackaged apps (M1011).

  * Implement an enterprise mobility management (EMM), also known as mobile device management (MDM) (M1012).

  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques (M1017).

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://www.microsoft.com/security/blog/2022/01/15/destructive-malware-targeting-ukrainian-organizations/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.001 - Malware  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1485 - Data Destruction  
T1490 - Inhibit System Recovery  
T1561 - Disk Wipe  
T1561.001 - Disk Content Wipe  
T1561.002 - Disk Structure Wipe

Tell me about the following threat: Exposed BrandBQ Database Leaked Data
Breach / Leak Notification: An exposed database belonging to a Polish online fashion retail company, BrandBQ, was discovered by researchers from vpnMentor. The database reportedly contained over one terabyte of data, including users' personal information.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Exposed BrandBQ Database Leaked Data
Breach / Leak Notification: An exposed database belonging to a Polish online fashion retail company, BrandBQ, was discovered by researchers from vpnMentor. The database reportedly contained over one terabyte of data, including users' personal information.

# Threat Type

  * Breach/Leak 




# Overview

  


"BrandBQ owns several retail and fashion brands operating in Eastern Europe. It appears the exposed database belonged to at least one of these brands’ websites, Answear. The database also included entries from another BrandBQ website, WearMedicine.com. The database contained an enormous amount of data, over 1 terabyte, and was leaking incredibly sensitive personal and financial data belonging to online shoppers visiting the websites. By leaking this data, BrandBQ compromised the safety and security of millions of people across Eastern Europe, exposing them to fraud, financial scams, and wholesale identity theft."

# Reference

  * <https://www.vpnmentor.com/blog/report-answear-leak/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: TurboTax Files Targeted by Mount Locker Ransomware
Bleeping Computer reports on Vitali Kremez's Twitter post about Mount Locker Ransomware targeting TurboTax .tax files.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Ransomware




# Overview

Advanced Intel's Vitali Kremez has published a Twitter post on Mount Locker ransomware targeting TurboTax files in preparation ahead of tax season. Threat actors are targeting .tax, .tax2009, .tax2013, and .tax2014 files. These extensions are specific to TurboTax. The latest version only targets these files, as far as researchers can ascertain at this point. Kremez states that it seems odd that only specific year returns are being targeted; however, the .tax string would match any other extensions containing that string. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * N/A




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary.

  * Backup any sensitive tax documents to detachable media and remove the media from computers to ensure the recovery of information. 



# Reference

  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/mount-locker-ransomware-now-targets-your-turbotax-tax-returns/>

  * [https://twitter.com/VK_Intel/status/1329472284889919490](https://twitter\[.\]com/VK_Intel/status/1329472284889919490)

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: New Variant of Buer Loader Written in Rust
A new variant of the Buer malware loader, dubbed "RustyBuer" by Proofpoint, has been completely rewritten in the Rust programming language.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Loader




# Overview

Proofpoint published a blog post analyzing a new variant of the Buer malware loader. The significant difference of this new variant, dubbed "RustyBuer," is that it has been completely rewritten to use the Rust programming language instead of C. Additionally, the threat actors are becoming more sophisticated by using more convincing lures. The new payload is being distributed via DHL shipping-themed phishing emails with either links to download a documents or a document directly attached to the email. The documents leverage malicious macros to extract an embedded payload and drop it on the system. Persistence is established via a LNK file that executes at startup. Base64 encoding, hex encoding, and RC4 encryption are used in order to encrypt C2 communications. The initial POST request to the C2 server provides system information. The response contains instructions related to downloading and executing a second-stage payload. In some cases, RustyBuer was used to distribute Cobalt Strike Beacon as a second-stage. In other cases, no second-stage payload was identified, potentially indicating access-as-a-service operations. The purpose of the rewrite is likely due to more efficient nature and broader feature set of Rust along with the ability to bypass existing detections of Buer that rely on C code detection. For more information, see the Proofpoint blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.proofpoint.com/us/blog/threat-insight/new-variant-buer-loader-written-rust>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Malvertising Making a Comeback
According to a new report from MalwareBytes, malvertising is on the rise again. New delivery methods have taken the place of the classic drive-by download.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malvertising




# Overview

New statistics observed by MalwareBytes indicates malvertising is, once again, on the rise. Researchers have seen Raccoon Stealer and RIG exploit kit in their observations. The adult website, xhamster.com, has seen the largest malvertising campaign in more than a year. One malvertising actor was offering bids for ads on adult websites with the majority of victims located within the U.S. with 56% of the observed traffic. A popular ad network, ExoClick, was abused with redirection pages. The first domain used in the campaign was disguised as a web design agency; however the page was simply a decoy page. The actor used server-side cloaking to redirect victims to a Fallout exploit kit landing page. This page attempted to exploit CVE-2019-0752 and CVE-2018-15982. These CVEs attack Internet Explorer and Adobe's Flash Player respectively. Nearly two weeks later, a new domain was used and employed a 302 redirect. This instance used the RIG exploit kit to disseminate Raccoon Stealer. A second malvertiser (malsmoke) has been tracked for months and uses Smoke Loader malware. The actor placed their malicious ad on the xhamster.com website. This campaign used a different and more sophisticated redirection technique with client-side fingerprinting and connectivity checks in an effort to target only legitimate IP addresses. For this attack, both Raccoon Stealer and ZLoader were downloaded and deployed. This group has a propensity to switch ad networks with rapid pace to continually perform its malvertising campaigns. Due to the continued use of Internet Explorer, it is suspected that these attacks and campaigns will continue using the aforementioned CVEs. Further information can be found in the report located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.malwarebytes.com/social-engineering/2020/09/malvertising-campaigns-come-back-in-full-swing/>

Adobe has released seven security bulletins covering seven of their products.

Adobe has released updates for Photoshop for Windows and macOS. These updates resolve a critical vulnerability. Successful exploitation could lead to arbitrary code execution in the context of the current user.   
<https://helpx.adobe.com/security/products/photoshop/apsb21-01.html>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: New Android Surveillanceware, Hornbill and SunBird Released by Pro-India APT Named Confucius
New Android surveillanceware has been discovered by the Lookout Threat Intelligence team. It is targeting Pakistani users in an effort to ex-filtrate data and audio communications recordings. Domains used in the campaign point to the campaign being carried out by APT group, Confucius.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Data Theft, RAT, APT




# Overview

The Lookout Threat Intelligence team has discovered two new android malware packages they named Hornbill and SunBird. Both have the purpose of ex-filtrating data, which includes data and audio recordings of communications, from the android device. The Lookout team analyzed over 18GB of ex-filtrated data which revealed locations of the infected devices. Notable targets included individuals in the Pakistani military and government. It is believed the advanced persistent threat group (APT) Confucius is behind the campaign. Confucius has been known to to be pro-India actor pursuing Pakistani and other South Asian targets since 2013. The group has been known to name their malicious apps similar to legitimate phone chat apps. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.
  * Do not install phone applications from unofficial app stores.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.lookout.com/lookout-discovers-novel-confucius-apt-android-spyware-linked-to-india-pakistan-conflict>

  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.
  * Do not install phone applications from unofficial app stores.

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Ryuk Ransomware Infection Chain
Focusing on the infection chain of the main payload, Cybereason published a blog post analyzing the Ryuk ransomware.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Ransomware




# Overview

Cybereason published a blog post analyzing the Ryuk ransomware, its history, and its infection chain. They first discuss the groups evolving TTPs, specifically the variety of malware involved in their infection chains, from Trickbot to EMPIRE, to Emotet. Additionally, they mention their findings indicate that the same threat actor is using Ryuk, Conti, and BazarLoader. Regardless of the malware involved, Ryuk is typically delivered as the final payload. With regard to the infection chain, recently Trickbot or BazarLoader have acted as the main initial infection vectors. Once on the system, the Ryuk payload copies itself and uses process injection for execution. It then uses the device's ARP table to discover target hosts and uses Wake-on-LAN packets in an attempt to mount the C$ to the initial victim machine. Specific services are killed using net.exe, shadow copies are deleted, and persistence is established. The last step before encryption is to use icacls.exe to change the permissions of files and folders on the host. Finally, encryption is carried out on both the local host and the mounted remote drives. The signature .RYK extension is appended to encrypted files. The ransom note, interestingly, contains nothing except the name of the malware and an email address; no instructions are provided. For more information, see the Cybereason blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://www.cybereason.com/blog/cybereason-vs.-ryuk-ransomware>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: New Zeppelin Ransomware Attacks
The Zeppelin ransomware is known to have been used in attacks against healthcare and IT services providers in 2019. In late August 2020, Juniper Threat Labs observed a new campaign distributing Zeppelin and using a new Trojan downloader.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Ransomware




# Overview

Juniper Threat Labs observed a new campaign distributing Zeppelin in late August, 2020. A new Trojan downloader has been implemented which, according to Juniper, is "largely undetected by antivirus applications". Malicious Word documents, which are presented as invoices, are used as the initial infection vector. A victim would need to enable macros for the document's malicious VBA code to begin executing. The initial macro writes a .vbs file to the local system, which is then executed when the document is closed. When executed, the .vbs script downloads the Zeppelin ransomware which is in turn executed after a pause. The pause is an attempt to evade automated sandbox analysis. Zeppelin does not infect systems which are located in Belarus, Kazakhstan, Russia, or Ukraine. Further details are available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blogs.juniper.net/en-us/threat-research/zeppelin-ransomware-returns-with-a-fresh-wave-of-attacks>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Elephant Beetle Targets Latin America
A report from Sygnia's Incident Response team provides information on a financially motivated threat group they have named Elephant Beetle.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware, Fraud.
  *  **Targets:** Organizations in Latin America involved in the commerce and finance sectors.
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Unnamed.
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Compromise of public-facing applications.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Persistence, discovery, lateral movement, carrying out fraudulent transactions.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

For at least two years, the financially motivated threat group Elephant Beetle has been targeting organizations in Latin America that are involved in the commerce and finance sectors. According to a report from Sygnia's Incident Response Team, the group is highly proficient with Java-based attacks and typically exploits Java-based applications, such as webservers that have well-known, possibly unpatched vulnerabilities. The CVE numbered vulnerabilities cited in the Sygnia report as having been used to compromise systems are CVE-2017-1000486, CVE-2015-7450, and CVE-2010-5326. The initial payload deployed during the initial compromise is typically a webshell. Using the initial foothold, the group may spend up to three months conducting reconnaissance and moving laterally through the environment before carrying out any fraudulent transactions. If a transaction is discovered or blocked, the group will go silent for up to a few months before attempting another transaction using a different system. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74056648/Elephant%20Beetle%20Targets%20Latin%20America%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1641439822145&api=v2)



# Detection

  * A list of Yara rules can be found here: [ Yara Rules.txt](/download/attachments/74056648/Elephant%20Beetle%20Targets%20Latin%20America%20Yara%20Rules.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1641439835791&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Vulnerable Plugin Exploited in Spam Redirect Campaign
Researchers at Sucuri observed a threat actor exploiting an unauthenticated privilege escalation vulnerability in the wp-user-avatar plugin to carry out a spam redirect campaign.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Vulnerable Plugin Exploited in Spam Redirect Campaign
Researchers at Sucuri observed a threat actor exploiting an unauthenticated privilege escalation vulnerability in the wp-user-avatar plugin to carry out a spam redirect campaign.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Spam redirector
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Trojanized Plugin
  *  **Targets:** WordPress
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Exploit vulnerable WP plugin ([T1190](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1190/))
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Spam redirection 
  * **Additional TTPs:** Hide malicious plugin ([T1564](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1564/)), create WP admin account ([T1136](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1136/)), Base64-encoded payload ([T1027](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1027/))



# Overview

Sucuri published a blog post analyzing a spam redirect campaign exploiting a vulnerable plugin for its initial infection vector. Specifically, the threat actor is abusing an unauthenticated privilege escalation vulnerability in unpatched versions of the wp-user-avatar plugin. The upload functionality of this plugin allows the attacker to upload a backdoor to the victim website. Additionally, the vulnerability allows for the creation of an admin account, providing further access. The backdoor includes functionality to delete the vulnerable plugin after the infection is complete, preventing further exploitation. The researchers observed the backdoor being used to install a fake "Zend Fonts" plugin. The malicious code in this plugin is responsible for redirecting non-admin visitors to a spam site. These spam sites can then be used by the attacker for distributing malicious payloads or performing phishing. For more information, see the Sucuri blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/57312819/Vulnerable%20Plugin%20Exploited%20in%20Spam%20Redirect%20Campaign%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1627491705310&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Install available updates to systems and software ([M1051](https://attack.mitre.org/mitigations/M1051/))
  * Restrict web-based content to include Javascript and attachment download ([M1021](https://attack.mitre.org/mitigations/M1021/))



# References

  * <https://blog.sucuri.net/2021/07/vulnerable-plugin-exploited-in-spam-redirect-campaign.html>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: COVID-Themed Destructive Malware
Threat actors continue to exploit the COVID-19 pandemic, even two years after it started. Fortinet observed a recent campaign using a "COVID-22" theme to distribute joke malware and a wiper.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Wiper
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** WipeMBR.exe
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data destruction



# Overview

Fortinet published a blog post analyzing a "COVID-22" themed payload. The method of distribution is unknown, but the infection chain eventually involves a victim opening a malicious executable. Upon execution, the payload drops a series of VBS scripts and additional executables onto the system. Joke malware activities then occur, such as intrusive pop ups and images being displayed and audio being played on a loop. Additionally, and more significantly, one of the executables run alongside the joke malware is a wiper. It is responsible for overwriting part of the Master Boot Record (MBR) with zeros, preventing the system from successfully loading the OS after a forced reboot. Notably, no files are encrypted or destroyed, allowing for data recovery. For more information, see the Fortinet blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/70222461/COVID-Themed%20Destructive%20Malware%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1636734530845&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021)



# References

  * <https://www.fortinet.com/blog/threat-research/to-joke-or-not-to-joke-covid-22-brings-disaster-to-mbr>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.005 - Visual Basic  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1561 - Disk Wipe  
T1561.002 - Disk Structure Wipe

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Juniper Security Advisories - January 2021
Juniper has published fifteen Security Bulletins that apply to Junos OS and in some instances to Junos OS Evolved. The vulnerabilities addressed in the bulletins affect various Juniper products.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Juniper Security Advisories - January 2021
Juniper has published fifteen Security Bulletins that apply to Junos OS and in some instances to Junos OS Evolved. The vulnerabilities addressed in the bulletins affect various Juniper products.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

  
 The most common impact of successful exploitation of the vulnerabilities are denial of service conditions. Some of the vulnerabilities could allow local privilege escalation or unauthenticated access to affected devices. Further details are available from the link in the Reference section below. All of the January advisories are prefixed with "2021-01".

# CVEs

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: TeamTNT Targets AWS Instances
TeamTNT is known to attack cloud services with intent to steal credentials, perform cryptojacking, or install backdoors. Trend Micro reports on a specific script used by the group to steal AWS credentials.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Trend Micro has published an analysis of a shell script used by TeamTNT to steal AWS credentials. This script was found hardcoded in a malicious binary dropped onto compromised systems. It was likely dropped onto systems after the threat actor exploited a misconfiguration or vulnerabilities to gain remote access. The script runs on any Linux system, whether it is running an AWS instance or not. The file that stores the stolen credentials is also created and ex-filtrated regardless of whether any data was actually found. The remote server to which the files were uploaded was an open directory, allowing the researchers to see all of the ex-filtrated data. They also discovered cryptocurrency mining tools being hosted on the same server. In the small percentage of cases where the script ran successfully on an AWS instance, it was able to steal AWS related secrets, providing information that can be used to carry out further attacks. For more information, see the Trend Micro blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/21/c/teamtnt-continues-attack-on-the-cloud--focuses-on-aws-instances.html>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Chimera's Abuse of Cloud Services
Chimera is a threat actor focused on stealing sensitive data from victim networks, often maintaining a presence for extended period of time. Fox-IT reports on the group's abuse of cloud services in recent campaigns.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, APT




# Overview

Fox-IT has published a report focusing on Chimera's use of cloud services in recent campaigns against semiconductor and aviation organizations. There are consistent tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) used by the threat actor across all their intrusions, including their method of initial access. The actor begins by using compromised usernames and passwords in a password spraying attack against remote services, such as webmail. Once valid credentials are identified, they are used to access a remote access service, such as a VPN to obtain a foothold in the victim network. Password spraying attacks continue against administrator accounts identified on the victim host. Finally, with an administrator account compromised, a Cobalt Strike beacon is installed to be used for remote access instead of the initial remote access service that was abused. Scans are performed for network discovery, such as identifying proxy settings, hosts, services, and shares. Lateral movement occurs to compromise other hosts of interest, such as domain controllers, and obtain domain administrator credentials. On each victim host another Cobalt Strike beacon is installed; however, no persistence mechanism exists, so if the system is rebooted, the Cobalt Strike beacon will quit. Once lateral movement is complete, data of interest, such as intellectual property, emails, and personally identifiable information, on each host is identified and prepared for exfiltration. In some cases exfiltration occurs via the Cobalt Strike beacon, but in most cases the data is compressed with WinRAR and uploaded to an attacker-controlled cloud storage account, such as OneDrive. After the initial exfiltration, the attacker will periodically return to identify new files and accounts of interest and perform the same process. For more information, see the Fox-IT blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.fox-it.com/2021/01/12/abusing-cloud-services-to-fly-under-the-radar/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Ransomware Ads Being Banned at a Rapid Pace
Hot on the heels of the Colonial Pipeline ransomware attack, cybercrime forums, threat groups, and others are reevaluating their business model. According to several reports of varying sources, even Darkside has claimed to have taken itself offline.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Ransomware Ads Being Banned at a Rapid Pace
Hot on the heels of the Colonial Pipeline ransomware attack, cybercrime forums, threat groups, and others are reevaluating their business model. According to several reports of varying sources, even Darkside has claimed to have taken itself offline.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Ransomware




# Overview

Due to what is being described as indiscriminate targeting, many forums, repos, and even some threat groups are taking steps to ensure a "proper vetting" of targets occurs prior to attack. The forums and repos have gone so far as to ban any ransomware ads placed on the sites. Any type of ad touting ransomware is removed. Leading the way in this effort is the XSS Russian-speaking forum. RaaS gangs such as REvil, LockBit, DarkSide, Netwalker, Nefilim, Babuk, and others have been using these forums to recruit new members, partners, and affiliates. The owner of XSS feels that ransomware is bringing "unwanted attention to the site and has become dangerous and toxic," according to a quote obtained by Bleeping Computer. Many of the RaaS gangs are purportedly leaving the forums for others that are more welcoming of their type of activity, such as exploit.in. This move will, most likely, be a temporary one as more and more forums are banning these gangs/actors. Forum admins have also stated they will remove all ransomware-related topics as well as affiliate programs. 

In a surprise move, DarkSide has claimed to have ceased operations. This closure is a result of the attack on the Colonial Pipeline that caused major interruptions in the flow of petroleum to large sections of the eastern United States. DarkSide has released a "press release" stating they are apolitical and will vet targets before any future attacks. Colonial Pipeline reportedly paid nearly $5M in cryptocurrency to obtain a decryption key from the actors. One well-known threat actor, UNKN, stated the operations ceased due to the loss of access to the public data leak site, payment servers, and CDN servers "at the request of law enforcement agencies," and cryptocurrency being moved to an unknown wallet. DarkSide has confirmed UNKN's claims. DarkSide also announced the requirement of providing decryption keys to each target that have been attacked and would compensate all financial obligations by May 23, 2021. 

REvil has imposed new restrictions on the targeting of entities. Affiliates are now required to obtain permission in order to target an organization. According to the representative of REvil, health care, education, etc. are all prohibited targets as are government sectors of any country. Further information can be found in the links located within the Reference section below. 

# Reference

  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/ransomware-ads-now-also-banned-on-exploit-cybercrime-forum/>

  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/darkside-ransomware-servers-reportedly-seized-operation-shuts-down/>
  * <https://www.intel471.com/blog/darkside-ransomware-shut-down-revil-avaddon-cybercrime>
  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/popular-russian-hacking-forum-xss-bans-all-ransomware-topics/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Retail Sector: 2020 Top Threats
IBM X-Force Threat Intelligence has published a report highlighting the top threats facing the retail industry in 2020.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Automated Account Takeover, Business Email Compromise




# Overview

  
IBM X-Force Threat Intelligence has reported on their observations of threats facing the retail industry as the sector grows. With so many opportunities to siphon off transactions, retail remains a lucrative target for cybercriminals. According to the 2020 IBM X-Force Threat Intelligence Index, the retail services industry is the second most-attacked of all industries. Cybersecurity professionals focused on this sector have pointed to two particular security threats that top the list of attacks types: automated account takeover and business email compromise. Additionally, some firms are advocating the use of active defense deception—the use of decoy data— to protect their most sensitive data. In their report, the researchers also highlight the key threat actors targeting this industry. The full story is available to IBM X-Force Premier Threat Intelligence clients at the link below.

# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.




# Reference

  * Premier Threat Intelligence clients can read at: <https://station.trustar.co/constellation/reports/742dd034-48b2-4c1f-b11e-3a148bb7005d>

  * To learn more about X-Force Premier Threat Intelligence, visit: <https://www.ibm.com/security/services/threat-intelligence>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Face Mask Manufacturer Lure Delivers Agent Tesla Malware
Another email campaign preying off of the COVID-19 situation was discovered by researchers at Area 1 Security. Analysis revealed the final payload delivered in this campaign was Agent Tesla.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, RAT




# Overview

Area 1 Security has published their analysis of a COVID-19 themed email campaign. The email subject and body are related to the sale of face masks and thermometers, which were in short supply earlier this year. The body includes the company logo and details for a legitimate chemical manufacturer or import/export business. Along with changing the spoofed company, the attackers also rotated the sender IP address and attachment hash to avoid systems detecting known malicious indicators. Attached to these emails was a GZ archive masquerading as a PDF that supposedly contains details on ordering face masks. Contained within the archive is an executable file that, upon execution, installs the Agent Tesla RAT. After initial check in with the C2 server, it waits to receive commands to be executed on the victim host. One of the main functionalities of Agent Tesla is the ability to steal passwords from various applications. Gathered credentials and other sensitive information are then exfiltrated to the C2 server via SMTP. For more information, see the Area 1 Security blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.area1security.com/blog/facemask-phishing-agent-tesla-malware/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Malicious KMSPico Installer Distributing Cryptbot
KMSPico is a tool used to activate Windows without a valid license key. Red Canary recently found installers for the program being abused to distribute the Cryptbot stealer.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Stealer
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Cryptbot
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malicious KMSPico installer
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data theft



# Overview

Red Canary published a blog post analyzing a fake KMSPico installer being used to distribute the Cryptbot stealer. The installer is being distributed via lookalike domains and installs the functioning KMSPico tool alongside the malware in order to evade detection. Contained within the 7Zip archive distributed as part of the installer is a Batch script, the AutoIT executable, an AutoIT script, and the encrypted Cryptbot binary. The Batch script kicks off the execution flow to ultimately use the AutoIT executable and script to install the Cryptbot payload. Once running on the system, Cryptbot is capable of stealing browser credentials and cryptocurrency wallets, which are exfiltrated to a C2 server over HTTP. For more information, see the Red Canary blog post and report in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74055968/Malicious%20KMSPico%20Installer%20Distributing%20Cryptbot%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1639152180180&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://redcanary.com/blog/kmspico-cryptbot/>
  * <https://redcanary.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/12/KMSPico-V5.pdf>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.003 - Windows Command Shell  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1036 - Masquerading  
T1055 - Process Injection  
T1055.012 - Process Hollowing  
T1497 - Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion  
T1497.001 - System Checks  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1555 - Credentials from Password Stores  
T1555.003 - Credentials from Web Browsers  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols

KMSPico is a tool used to activate Windows without a valid license key. Red Canary recently found installers for the program being abused to distribute the Cryptbot stealer.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: LuminousMoth APT Group Targeting South Asia
LuminousMoth is a Chinese-speaking actor that Kaspersky observed using large-scale campaigns, but likely targeting a much smaller subset of victims, across South East Asia.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Campaign




# Overview

A Chinese-speaking actor using large-scale campaigns across South East Asia since October 2020, has been named LuminousMoth by Kaspersky. The great majority of victims are in the Philippines with Myanmar being the second most affected country. The actual targets of the campaign are likely government entities. In its report, Kaspersky notes two infection vectors. An email sent to victims contains a Dropbox link which leads to an RAR archive. To disguise the archive as a Word document, the “file_subpath” parameter is set to that of a file with a DOCX extension. Inside the archive were two malicious DLLs along with two legitimate executables files which were used to sideload the DLLs. If the first stage is successful, the second stage consists of installing a Cobalt Strike beacon and achieving persistence using a registry entry. The report notes that in the Philippines, there may have been another infection vector involved. The malware attempts to spread itself by copying malicious files to removable storage devices. In some cases, on systems located in Myanmar, an information stealer impersonated the Zoom video-conferencing application. It scanned the infected systems for files with specific extensions and exfiltrated those found to its C&C server. On some other systems, a tool to steal cookies from the Chrome web browser was deployed. Kaspersky notes a number of similarities in LuminousMoth's TTPs and targeting with another group named HoneyMyte (aka Mustang Panda), and finds with medium to high confidence that the LuminousMoth activity is connected to HoneyMyte.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://securelist.com/apt-luminousmoth/103332/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Mozilla Foundation Security Advisory 2020-53
The Mozilla Foundation has published security advisory 2020-53 detailing a vulnerability (CVE-2020-26970) in Thunderbird.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability



# Overview

In security advisory 2020-53, the Mozilla Foundation describes a stack overflow vulnerability (CVE-2020-26970) patched in Thunderbird 78.5.1. The issue was caused by writing an SMTP server status integer value on the stack designed to only hold one byte. This could potentially corrupt the stack which might be exploitable. Thunderbird 78.5.1 corrects this issue and previous versions should be upgraded to this new version as soon as possible.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/35717466/Mozilla%20Foundation%20Security%20Advisory%202020-53%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1606922038291&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.mozilla.org/en-US/security/advisories/mfsa2020-53/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Magnitude Exploit Kit Distributing Magniber Ransomware
Avast has published a report on current activity involving the Magnitude exploit kit that targets Internet Explorer users in South Korea and results in the deployment of the Magniber ransomware.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Magnitude Exploit Kit Distributing Magniber Ransomware
Avast has published a report on current activity involving the Magnitude exploit kit that targets Internet Explorer users in South Korea and results in the deployment of the Magniber ransomware.

# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Ransomware
  *  **Targets:** Internet Explorer Users
  *  **Ransomware Family:** Magniber
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** CVE-2021-26411 **,** Initial Access (TA0001, T1189), Execution(TA0002, T1059.007, T1203, T1204, T1204.001)
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Privilege Escalation (TA0004, T1068, T1055), Defense Evasion (T1140, T1574, T1027, T1027.002, T1055), Impact (TA0040, T1486)
  *  **Additional TTPs:** Resource Development (TA0042, T1583.001, T1583, T1587, T1587.001, T1588, T1588.005, T1608, T1608.005)



# Overview

Due to past laws in South Korea which mandated the use of ActiveX controls for government and e-commerce sites, there remains a significant number of Internet Explorer users. The Magnitude exploit kit used to target Internet Explorer has been around for many years. To take advantage of the significant number of Internet Explorer users in South Korea, its operators are buying popunder ads on adult sites and pay only for those displayed to South Korean visitors to the sites. If a visitor to the site clicks on one of the ads, they are first redirected to a page that provides a legitimate-looking ad. The next redirection takes the victim to a second domain that is hosting an obfuscated JavaScript exploit for CVE-2021-26411. The second domain is short-lived, being rotated every thirty minutes, and domains are not reused. The JavaScript exploit used is one that is publicly available but includes custom shellcode, three versions of shellcode are used depending on the version of Windows the victim is using. If the exploit is successful, another vulnerability, CVE-2020-0986, is exploited to elevate privileges, and if successful, the Magniber ransomware is then injected into another process. Unlike the high profile big game hunting ransomware, Magniber does not employ the double extortion model of exfiltrating data to publish if the ransom is not paid. A ransom note is left in each directory in which files were encrypted. The ransom note contains a .onion URL that includes a subdomain that is generated dynamically, for each victim. Further information is available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/59540312/Magnitude%20Exploit%20Kit%20Distributing%20Magniber%20Ransomware%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1628222547230&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date ([M1049](https://attack.mitre.org/mitigations/M1049/)).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs ([M1031](https://attack.mitre.org/mitigations/M1031/), [M1035](https://attack.mitre.org/mitigations/M1035/), [M1037](https://attack.mitre.org/mitigations/M1037/)).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level ([M1051](https://attack.mitre.org/mitigations/M1051/)).



# References

  * <https://decoded.avast.io/janvojtesek/magnitude-exploit-kit-still-alive-and-kicking/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: ICS-CERT Advisories - September 22, 2020
ICS-CERT has published two security advisories addressing vulnerabilities in ICS-related systems.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

ICS-CERT has published two security advisories, ICSA-20-266-01 and ICSA-20-266-02, addressing vulnerabilities in ICS-related systems. ICSA-20-266-01 addresses two vulnerabilities in the GE Digital APM Classic tool. The first vulnerability, CVE-2020-16240, is an insecure direct object reference (IDOR) vulnerability that could allow an attacker to download sensitive data related to user accounts without having the proper privileges. The second vulnerability, CVE-2020-16244, is the result of unsalted passwords that could allow an authenticated user to obtain and decrypt password hashes. Both vulnerabilities are patched in recent versions of the software. ICSA-20-266-02 details two vulnerabilities in GE Reason S20 Ethernet Switches. CVE-2020-16242 and CVE-2020-16246 are both cross site scripting vulnerabilities, one of which could allow an attacker to perform critical application actions while the other could allow malicious JavaScript to be rendered. Both vulnerabilities have been patched by GE in recent firmware updates. We recommend reviewing the advisories, linked to in the References section, and applying any relevant updates as soon as possible.

# CVEs

A complete list of associated CVEs can be found here: 

# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-20-266-01>

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-20-266-02>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Patchwork APT Infects Self With Own RAT
A report from Malwarebytes Labs looks at a recent campaign carried out by the Indian APT group known as Patchwork who also infected themselves with their own RAT.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware, Espionage.
  *  **Targets:** Researchers involved in molecular medicine and biological science.
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Ragnatela RAT.
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malicious documents attached to spear-phishing emails.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data collection and exfiltration.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below for the TTPs typically used by Patchwork.



# Overview

The Indian APT group known as Patchwork has been active for many years, typically attacking Pakistani targets. According to Malwarebytes Labs, Patchwork typically uses spear-phishing as their infection vector, and their most recent campaign was carried out between late November and early December 2021 using malicious documents themed to appear to be from Pakistani authorities. The targets of the attack were researchers involved in molecular medicine and biological science, this campaign was the first time Patchwork has been observed targeting personnel in these fields. The document analyzed by Malwarebytes exploited a vulnerability in the Microsoft Equation Editor. The payload was the Ragnatela RAT which is a variant of the BadNews RAT. The objective of the campaign was cyberespionage. However, the actors also managed to infect themselves with their own RAT which allowed Malwarebytes to obtain screenshots and keystrokes from Patchwork's own systems. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74056704/Patchwork%20APT%20Infects%20Self%20With%20Own%20RAT%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1641787700177&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017)



# References

  * <https://blog.malwarebytes.com/threat-intelligence/2022/01/patchwork-apt-caught-in-its-own-web/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.002 - Code Signing Certificates  
T1588 - Obtain Capabilities  
T1588.002 - Tool  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1189 - Drive-by Compromise  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
T1566.002 - Spearphishing Link  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter

 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**

T1548.002 - Bypass User Account Control  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**

 **Discovery - TA0007**

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: ICS-CERT Security Advisories - December 17th, 2020
ICS-CERT has released three security advisories addressing vulnerabilities in ICS-related devices and software.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: ICS-CERT Security Advisories - December 17th, 2020
ICS-CERT has released three security advisories addressing vulnerabilities in ICS-related devices and software.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview



ICSA-20-352-01 addresses an improper authentication vulnerability in Emerson's Rosemount X-STREAM that, if successfully exploited, could allow an attacker to download files and obtain sensitive information.

ICSA-20-352-02 addresses three vulnerabilities in PTC's Kepware KEPServerEX. These include a stack-based buffer overflow, heap-based buffer overflow, and use after free vulnerability. Potential impacts, if successfully exploited, include a denial-of-service condition, data leakage, or remote code execution.

ICSA-20-352-03 addresses an incorrect default permissions issue with PTC's Kepware LinkMaster that, if successfully exploited, could allow a local attacker to globally overwrite the service configuration to execute arbitrary code with NT SYSTEM privileges.

We recommend reviewing the advisories in the Reference section for patches and mitigation advice.

# Recommendations

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Lemon_Duck Cryptominer Targets Cloud Apps and Linux
Lemon_Duck is an advanced cryptominer that spreads across networks and leverages victim resources to turn a profit. Sophos reports on the most recent updates to the malware, which is been constantly evolving.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Cryptomining




# Overview

Sophos has published their analysis of the most recent version of Lemon_Duck. The first change the researchers noticed was the use of COVID-19-themed emails to social engineer users. Attached to these emails is an Office document that leverages an RTF exploit for CVE-2017-8570 to install the malware. Once an initial foothold is gained, the malware contains code necessary to construct new emails and attachments on-the-fly that are then sent to recipients in the victim's contact list in order to compromise additional networks. For infection of and lateral movement to Windows hosts, Lemon_Duck contains exploit code for SMBGhost and EternalBlue, as well as Mimikatz. Alternatively, when infecting Linux hosts either SSH brute-force attacks are performed or Redis or Hadoop weaknesses are exploited. Cron jobs are used for persistence on Linux hosts. Lemon_Duck identifies and kills any other mining processes to maximize the resources available to its own cryptominer. Once running on the system, Lemon_Duck can perform its ultimate goal of mining cryptocurrency to turn a profit for its operators. For more information, see the Sophos blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://news.sophos.com/en-us/2020/08/25/lemon_duck-cryptominer-targets-cloud-apps-linux/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: TrickBot Takedown Operation
A joint effort between ESET, Black Lotus Labs, Microsoft, FS-ISAC, and other led to the takedown of TrickBot botnet. A court action led to the interruption of the notorious bot.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: TrickBot Takedown Operation
A joint effort between ESET, Black Lotus Labs, Microsoft, FS-ISAC, and other led to the takedown of TrickBot botnet. A court action led to the interruption of the notorious bot.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Botnet, Ransomware, Credential Theft




# Overview

A joint effort by several major cybersecurity companies and firms was responsible for the takedown, albeit temporarily, of the TrickBot botnet. Trickbot has been around since at least 2016 and is one of the most prolific and dangerous botnets seen. This effort was not the first attempt in taking down TrickBot. Weeks prior to this effort, bots were receiving configurations to replace C2s with reserved IPs. In doing so, the bots were unable to connect to the actual C2s; however, new infections were still occurring. This takedown attempt was allegedly operated by U.S. Cyber Command. The latest attempt involved the efforts of several agencies sharing technical information about the botnet with law enforcement. Unfortunately, the actors behind the botnet had options to allow them to maintain the botnet as well as recover lost, infected computers. One such fallback is the ability to contact a C2 and download a list of secondary C2 servers. Additionally, the C2 servers were able to control plugins and exfiltrate stolen data. It is hypothesized by the U.S. government that the botnet could pose a significant threat to the 2020 election cycle. These attacks could lead to the holding of voter information, stealing sensitive data, election results, and impact the election system at large. For more information, please see the links located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.lumen.com/a-look-inside-the-trickbot-botnet/>

  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/trickbot-botnet-targeted-in-takedown-operations-little-impact-seen/>
  * <https://www.welivesecurity.com/2020/10/12/eset-takes-part-global-operation-disrupt-trickbot/>
  * <https://blogs.microsoft.com/on-the-issues/2020/10/12/trickbot-ransomware-cyberthreat-us-elections/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Nokoyawa Ransomware Updates and Reuses Code
Researchers at Fortinet Labs posted a report detailing the activities and capabilities of a new Windows ransomware known as Nokoyawa. This malware has code similarities with ransomware named Karma which has been connected to the well-known ransomware called Nemty.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Ransomware ****
  * **Targets:** Windows systems
  *  **Ransomware Family:** Nemty ****
  * **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** File encryption
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below



# Overview

Fortinet Labs conducted an assessment of the new Nokoyawa Ransomware that they first observed in February of this year. Nokoyawa is assessed to have code similarities with a well-known ransomware called Nemty. Fortigard Labs found that although there are code similarities with Nemty, Nokoyawa has an increased capability to encrypt files. Unlike Nemty that runs on 32 and 64-bit, Nokoyawa also appears to run on only 64-bit Windows instances. The authors of Nokoyawa are reusing publicly available code to build and quickly add capabilities to this ransomware. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://www.fortinet.com/blog/threat-research/nokoyawa-variant-catching-up>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Tactics and Techniques:**

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.001 - Malware  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1562 - Impair Defenses  
T1562.001 - Disable or Modify Tools  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
T1135 - Network Share Discovery  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact  
T1489 - Service Stop  
  


 **Mitigations:**

 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1024:** Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1039:** Environment Variable Permissions - Prevent modification of environment variables by unauthorized users and groups.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1053:** Data Backup - Take and store data backups from end user systems and critical servers. Ensure backup and storage systems are hardened and kept separate from the corporate network to prevent compromise.  
 **M1054:** Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
 **M1056:** Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: VMware Security Advisory - VMSA-2020-0027
VMware has published security advisory, VMSA-2020-0027, which addresses a single command injection vulnerability, rated as Critical, in VMware Workspace One Access, Access Connector, Identity Manager, and Identity Manager Connector.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

  
VMware has published security advisory VMSA-2020-0027 that deals with a single vulnerability in VMware Workspace One Access, Access Connector, Identity Manager, and Identity Manager Connector. The vulnerability (CVE-2020-4006) could allow an attacker who can authenticate to the admin account on port 8443, to potentially execute commands on the underlying operating system. The commands could be executed with unrestricted privileges. Updates to mitigate the vulnerability are yet to be provided. Workarounds are provided in the advisory. Further details, including affected versions, are available from the advisory linked in the Reference section below. We recommend implementing the workarounds at the earliest opportunity.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/33983115/VMware%20Security%20Advisory%20-%20VMSA-2020-0027%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1606194567570&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.vmware.com/security/advisories/VMSA-2020-0027.html>

  * <https://kb.cert.org/vuls/id/724367>
