instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: X-Force Executive Update – Oldsmar Water Treatment Facility Hack
X-Force Threat Intelligence has published an executive update providing insights into a recent hack of a water treatment facility and the lessons it provides.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Hacking




# Overview

On Friday, February 5, 2021, an unknown hacker used TeamViewer remote management software to gain access to the computer network of a water treatment plant in Oldsmar, Florida. The hacker then increased the amount of sodium hydroxide, or lye, to be released into the water by a factor of 111. A supervisor that was working remotely observed the change being made in the system and immediately reversed it, so the hacking operation ultimately had no effect on the water supply. X-Force analysts consider this event to provide some valuable lessons for organizations with operational technology networks, including risks posed by remote access programs and weak authentication policies. The full story and analysis is available to IBM X-Force Premier Threat Intelligence clients at the link below.

# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.




# Reference

  * Premier Threat Intelligence clients can read more at: <https://station.trustar.co/constellation/reports/5ffa489f-fc94-4376-ba51-6cbb7d631662>

  * To learn more about X-Force Premier Threat Intelligence, visit: <https://www.ibm.com/security/services/threat-intelligence>

Tell me about the following threat: Adobe Security Updates April 2021
Adobe has released four security updates. The updates are for Photoshop, Digital Editions, Bridge, and RoboHelp. Three of the updates address at least one vulnerability rated by Adobe as Critical and one is rated Important.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Adobe Security Updates April 2021
Adobe has released four security updates. The updates are for Photoshop, Digital Editions, Bridge, and RoboHelp. Three of the updates address at least one vulnerability rated by Adobe as Critical and one is rated Important.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

 The potential impact of successful exploitation of the most serious vulnerabilities is the remote execution of arbitrary code. Further details are available from the links below.

 **APSB21-28 Security updates available for Adobe Photoshop**  
Adobe has released updates for Photoshop for Windows and macOS. These updates resolve multiple critical [vulnerabilities. Successful exploitation could lead to arbitrary code execution in the context of the current user.](https://helpx.adobe.com/security/products/framemaker/apsb21-14.html)  
<https://helpx.adobe.com/security/products/photoshop/apsb21-28.html>

 **APSB21-26 Security Updates Available for Adobe Digital Editions**  
Adobe has released a security update for Adobe Digital Editions. This update resolves a critical vulnerability that could result in arbitrary file system write.  
<https://helpx.adobe.com/security/products/Digital-Editions/apsb21-26.html>

 **APSB21-23 Security Updates Available for Adobe Bridge**  
Adobe has released a security update for Adobe Bridge. This update addresses critical and important vulnerabilities that could lead to arbitrary code execution in the context of the current user.   
<https://helpx.adobe.com/security/products/bridge/apsb21-23.html>

**APSB21-20 Security update available for RoboHelp  
** Adobe has released a security update for RoboHelp. This update resolves a vulnerability rated important. Successful exploitaton could lead to privilege escalation in the context of current user.  
<https://helpx.adobe.com/security/products/robohelp/apsb21-20.html> **  
**

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/46072181/Adobe%20Security%20Updates%20April%202021%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1618520349798&api=v2)

<https://helpx.adobe.com/security/products/photoshop/apsb21-28.html>

 **APSB21-26 Security Updates Available for Adobe Digital Editions**  
Adobe has released a security update for Adobe Digital Editions. This update resolves a critical vulnerability that could result in arbitrary file system write.  
<https://helpx.adobe.com/security/products/Digital-Editions/apsb21-26.html>

 **APSB21-23 Security Updates Available for Adobe Bridge**  
Adobe has released a security update for Adobe Bridge. This update addresses critical and important vulnerabilities that could lead to arbitrary code execution in the context of the current user.   
<https://helpx.adobe.com/security/products/bridge/apsb21-23.html>

**APSB21-20 Security update available for RoboHelp  
** Adobe has released a security update for RoboHelp. This update resolves a vulnerability rated important. Successful exploitaton could lead to privilege escalation in the context of current user.  
<https://helpx.adobe.com/security/products/robohelp/apsb21-20.html> **  
**

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/46072181/Adobe%20Security%20Updates%20April%202021%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1618520349798&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  *     * <https://helpx.adobe.com/security.html>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: SPM55 - An Indonesian Phishing As A Service Operator
DomainTools has published a report that provides information on the activities of an Indonesian Phishing-as-a-Service operator they refer to as SPM55.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Phishing
  *  **Target:** Users with accounts at financial institutions, services companies, and technology companies.
  *  **Lure:** Account disabled messages.
  *  **Payload:** Phishing page. ****
  * **Compromised Data:** Account credentials and other personal information.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

According to a report from DomainTools, SPM55 is an Indonesian Phishing-as-a-Service operator that has been increasing its customer base and activity. The report notes that the SPM55 offerings have a high rate of success in comparison to other phishing kits. Financial institutions, services companies, and technology companies are the typical targets. The operator also offer add-ons for credit card checkers, account validators, and what is described as an "antibot." The antibot is used to help evade detection by redirecting sessions to benign sites if they do not appear to be from a valid phishing target. SPM55 prefers Indonesian-speaking customers and payments from OVO and DANA, which are Indonesian payment services. Payments can also be made using Bitcoin and Ethereum. The typical lures used in target emails claim a recipient's account has been disabled. Aside from seeking a victim's credentials the phishing pages can also include fields to capture other personal information. The kit is written in PHP, some parts of which have been copied from other phishing kits. Interestingly, harvested credentials are sent not only to the SPM55 customer but also to the operators. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.



# References

  * <https://www.domaintools.com/resources/blog/spm55-ascending-the-ranks-of-indonesian-phishing-as-a-service-offerings>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Tactics and Techniques:**

 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1589 - Gather Victim Identity Information  
T1589.002 - Email Addresses  
T1598 - Phishing for Information  
T1598.001 - Spearphishing Service  
  
 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
T1583.001 - Domains  
T1583.004 - Server  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1588 - Obtain Capabilities  
T1588.002 - Tool  
T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.002 - Spearphishing Link  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.001 - Malicious Link  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1056 - Input Capture  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1020 - Automated Exfiltration  
  


 **Mitigations:**

 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1041:** Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1054:** Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
 **M1056:** Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: APT34 Campaign IoCs
A tweet from the 360 Threat Intelligence Center provides IoCs believed to be associated with a campaign being conducted by APT34, aka OilRig. APT34 is tracked by IBM X-Force as ITG13.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Campaign, APT




# Overview

APT34 (aka Cobalt Gypsy, Helix Kitten, IRN2, and OilRig) is a threat group suspected to originate from Iran. APT34 is tracked by IBM X-Force as ITG13. APT34 has been operating since at least 2014 and targeted a variety of industries, including energy, chemical, financial, government, and telecommunications. Geographically, the group primarily targets the Middle East. The IoCs relate to malicious Excel files. While no information was provided on the delivery mechanism for the files, it is likely to be via spearphishing emails with the Excel files attached. It is mentioned in the tweet that an attack associated with the IoCs used DNS tunneling.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://twitter.com/360CoreSec/status/1408348476660797440>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: In-the-Wild Exploits Seen Targeting MS Exchange
New reports from Volexity and Microsoft detail an in-the-wild exploit being seen across multiple industries. Microsoft has released out of band updates to address the vulnerabilities.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: In-the-Wild Exploits Seen Targeting MS Exchange
New reports from Volexity and Microsoft detail an in-the-wild exploit being seen across multiple industries. Microsoft has released out of band updates to address the vulnerabilities.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

## ***UPDATE April 12, 2021***

CISA has provided an analysis of further samples of the China Chopper Webshell, which may be in use against Microsoft Exchange servers. Further information can be found in the Reference section below or [here](https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-102a).

## ***UPDATE March 25, 2021***

  
US-CISA and DHS have issued additional information about China Chopper Webshells which may be in use against Microsoft Offline Address books. These latest samples are inline with other samples previously examined. There are subtle differences in the code used for the creation of the shells. We recommend you read the reports and apply any and all patches available as well as examining your environment for any evidence of these or any other potentially nefarious webshells. Further information can be found in the Reference section below or [here](https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-084a) and [here](https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-084b). 

## ***UPDATE March 16, 2021***

  
Yesterday, Microsoft released a one-click Exchange On-Premises Mitigation tool. This tool is not designed to replace patching of vulnerable servers, it is merely meant to help those who've not yet had opportunity to patch these systems. This tool includes the latest Microsoft Safety Scanner and will mitigate CVE-2021-26855. The tool performs three operations: mitigate against current known attacks using CVE-2021-26855 using a URL Rewrite configuration, scan the Exchange Server using the Microsoft Safety Scanner, and attempt to reverse any changes made by identified threats. Further detailed guidance can be found in the Reference section below or [here](https://msrc-blog.microsoft.com/2021/03/15/one-click-microsoft-exchange-on-premises-mitigation-tool-march-2021/).

## ***UPDATE March 15, 2021***

  
The Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency released 7 malware analysis reports on webshells seen throughout its investigation. The findings indicate that each webshell observed also contains some form of backdoor as well as the webshells themselves. These webshells could, if implanted, allow attackers to execute JavaScript code on compromised servers. The reports are linked in the Reference section or just below this update.

  * [https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-072a](https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-072a)

  * [https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-072b](https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-072b)

  * [https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-072c](https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-072c)

  * [https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-072d](https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-072d)

  * [https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-072e](https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-072e)

  * [https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-072f](https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-072f)

  * [https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-072g](https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-072g)




## ***UPDATE March 12, 2021***

The Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) and Cybersecurity Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) have published a joint advisory detailing further information on the Microsoft Exchange Server attacks. According to the FBI and CISA, multiple nation-state actors and cybercriminals are likely exploiting the previously mentioned vulnerabilities. Should these attackers successfully exploit these vulnerabilities, they have the ability to gain persistence and control of the affected network. The possibility exists of the sale of compromised network access on the dark web. These networks can contain valuable research, technology, PII, and sensitive information from multiple sectors. The agencies assess the attackers will continue to exploit these vulnerabilities in order to steal information, encrypt data for ransom, or, in a worst case scenario, execute a destructive attack against compromised networks. The report also notes the types of industries currently or previously having seen attacks as "local governments, academic institutions, non-governmental organizations, and business entities in multiple industry sectors, including agriculture, biotechnology, aerospace, defense, legal services, power utilities, and pharmaceutical". Additionally, this targeting is consistent with targeting activity by Chinese cyber actors. Further details can be found in the link located within the reference section below or [here](https://www.ic3.gov/Media/News/2021/210310.pdf). 

## ***UPDATE #3 March 10, 2021***

WeLiveSecurity is reporting that at least 10 APT groups are attacking the vulnerabilities in Exchange. Among the APTs and malware listed are: LuckyMouse, Tick, Winnti Group, Calypso, Websiic, Tonto Team (CactusPete), Mikroceen (Vicious Panda), ShadowPad (unconfirmed), "Opera" Cobalt Strike, and DLTMiner. There is also speculation that some of the ATPs and threat actors may be piggybacking off webshells left by other APTs who may have already successfully exploited the vulnerable servers, though this is unconfirmed. Further information can be found in the link located within the Reference section below or [here](https://www.welivesecurity.com/2021/03/10/exchange-servers-under-siege-10-apt-groups/). 

## ***UPDATE #2 March 10, 2021***

Recorded Future reports on the evolution of the exploitation of the Microsoft Exchange Server vulnerabilities. Indications are that the exploitation attempts are coming from multiple groups simultaneously. Some of the groups mentioned in the article are state-sponsored APTs while others are simply cybercrime groups. One such group has been using the flaws to insert webshells to install DLTminer malware for the purposes of cryptomining. According to the article, "the ever-increasing number of attackers had moved into indiscriminate mass-exploitation against any Exchange server left connected to the internet without a patch, with the number of hacked servers being estimated in the realm of “astronomical” and tens of thousands, per US government sources. Security agencies have observed intrusions in the Netherlands, Czech Republic, and Norway in addition to the U.S. Other, larger countries have issued national security alerts to patch on-premises servers as soon as possible in order to avoid exploitation. There is speculation these countries may already be seeing attempts to exploit the vulnerabilities. At present, at least 1,500 infected systems have been seen by at least one security firm. Further details can be found in the article located within the Reference section or [here](https://therecord.media/attacks-on-exchange-servers-expand-from-nation-states-to-cryptominers/). 

## ***UPDATE #1 March 10, 2021***

Palo Alto's Unit 42 has released additional details on the China Chopper webshells and changes made to the shell during the exploitation of these vulnerabilities. Additionally, a Yara rule was released which helps to identify templates used for the China Chopper webshell as they exist in OAB configurations. This webshell is injected into a pre-existing OAB ASPX page. Researchers warn that any on-premises Exchange servers exposed to the internet should assume scanning is/has been accomplished numerous times. Indications from analysis show several clusters of threat actors are continuously attempting to exploit vulnerable servers. Further details can be found in the link located within the Reference section below or [here](https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/china-chopper-webshell/).

## ***UPDATE March 9, 2021***

Microsoft has released emergency updates for unsupported versions of Microsoft Exchange. Though unsupported, the company released these updates to address only the newest vulnerabilities as stated in this document. Further information can be found in the link below or [here](https://www.zdnet.com/article/microsoft-exchange-attacks-now-microsoft-rushes-out-a-patch-for-these-unsupported-exchange-servers-too/).

  


***UPDATE March 8, 2021***

FireEye has [published](https://www.fireeye.com/blog/threat-research/2021/03/detection-response-to-exploitation-of-microsoft-exchange-zero-day-vulnerabilities.html) analysis of the processes and inner workings of the vulnerabilities and related malware. Researchers have identified a web shell named help.aspx which contained code to help identify endpoint security products such as FireEye xAgent, CarbonBlack, and CrowdStrike Falcon. A second web shell named iisstart.aspx was seen approximately twenty days after the first web shell. This web shell, partially obfuscated, has more capabilities, functions, and is generally more advanced than the previous shell. This particular version allowed for the execution of arbitrary commands and the upload, deletion, and viewing of files. The analysis confirmed the files indicate the signature match for China Chopper. One particular command seen was the attempt to delete the administrator user from Exchange Organizations administrators group. The team verified Microsoft's information regarding the post-exploitation activity such as credential theft by dumping LSASS, the use of 7-zip compression for exfiltration, the use of Exchange PowerShell Snap-ins for the exfiltration of mailbox data, and the use of offensive tools such as Covenant, Nishang, and PowerCat for remote access. Finally, analysis revealed the ever changing naming of the web shell on each intrusion. We will provide further details as they are presented.

  


***UPDATE March 6, 2021***

According to CISA, Microsoft has released (CISA and Microsoft links below) an updated [script](https://github.com/microsoft/CSS-Exchange/tree/main/Security) for scanning the Exchange log files for IoCs for the vulnerabilities. We recommend running the script against any Exchange servers within your organization as soon as possible.

## ***UPDATE March 5, 2021***

IBM Security family PAM Content Update [4103.03231](https://exchange.xforce.ibmcloud.com/xpu/XPU%204103.03231) contains 4 new events, 0 new moderate event responses, and 0 new aggressive event responses. The new signatures, HTTP_Exchange_Cookie_Auth_Bypass, HTTP_Exchange_VirtualDirectory_Cmd_Injection, HTTP_Exchange_Cookie_SSFR, and HTTP_Exchange_VirtualDirectory_Upload, apply to the Microsoft Exchange vulnerabilities, CVE-2021-26855, CVE-2021-26858, and CVE-2021-27065.

## ***UPDATE #3 March 3, 2021***

CISA has published an alert, AA21-062A, regarding the Exchange vulnerabilities. The URL is located in the Reference section below.

## ***UPDATE #2 March 3, 2021***

An URL has been added to the Reference section for the Dubex report on the exploit.

## ***UPDATE March 3, 2021***

A blog from Rapid7 contains more details on this zero-day attack and how to address the issues allowing the zero-day to proliferate. In the blog, researchers reveal the tools employed in the attacks to be China Chopper Webshell and ProcDump being used against LSASS. Additionally, the team provided a link for the proof-of-concept code that allows for the exposure to the public internet. 

## ***Original Post - Update March 2, 2021***

Multiple zero-day exploits targeting vulnerabilities in on-premises versions Microsoft Exchange servers have been used in attacks in the wild. Microsoft describe the attacks as limited and targeted. According to a report from Volexity, the attacks appear to have started as early as January 6, 2021. The report notes that the attackers are using a remotely exploitable server-side request forgery (SSRF) vulnerability (CVE-2021-26855) to steal the contents of a victim's mailbox. The vulnerability does not require authentication. If the Exchange server is a single machine, the attacker must know the targeted user's domain SID in order to access the mailbox. In multiple server configurations, the attacker only needs the email address of the intended victim. In both cases, the attacker must know the FQDN of the internal Exchange servers. The vulnerability can be exploited by sending a specially crafted HTTP POST request to the server with an XML SOAP payload. Volexity has also observed this attack being conducted on OWA. In addition, Volexity reports that the attackers chained the SSRF vulnerability with a remote code execution vulnerability in the Exchange servers and installed webshells on the compromised servers.

Microsoft, Volexity, and Dubex have collaborated on this research and attribute the activity to HAFNIUM, a Chinese state-sponsored group. Victimology and TTPs as the basis for attribution. According to Microsoft, HAFNIUM has primarily targeted entities in the United States. The targeted industry sectors include defense contractors, higher education institutions, infectious disease researchers, law firms, NGOs, and policy think tanks. HAFNIUM typically uses leased virtual private servers (VPS) located in the United States to conduct operations.

Microsoft has issued emergency out of band updates to address these critical vulnerabilities in Exchange. Microsoft is urging customers to update on-premises systems immediately. In keeping with Microsoft's recommendation, IBM also urges customers to immediately patch affected systems.

  * [CVE-2021-26855](https://msrc.microsoft.com/update-guide/vulnerability/CVE-2021-26855) is a server-side request forgery (SSRF) vulnerability in Exchange which allowed the attacker to send arbitrary HTTP requests and authenticate as the Exchange server.
  * [CVE-2021-26857](https://msrc.microsoft.com/update-guide/vulnerability/CVE-2021-26857) is an insecure deserialization vulnerability in the Unified Messaging service. Insecure deserialization is where untrusted user-controllable data is deserialized by a program. Exploiting this vulnerability gave HAFNIUM the ability to run code as SYSTEM on the Exchange server. This requires administrator permission or another vulnerability to exploit.
  * [CVE-2021-26858](https://msrc.microsoft.com/update-guide/vulnerability/CVE-2021-26858) is a post-authentication arbitrary file write vulnerability in Exchange. If HAFNIUM could authenticate with the Exchange server then they could use this vulnerability to write a file to any path on the server. They could authenticate by exploiting the CVE-2021-26855 SSRF vulnerability or by compromising a legitimate admin’s credentials.
  * [CVE-2021-27065](https://msrc.microsoft.com/update-guide/vulnerability/CVE-2021-27065) is a post-authentication arbitrary file write vulnerability in Exchange. If HAFNIUM could authenticate with the Exchange server then they could use this vulnerability to write a file to any path on the server. They could authenticate by exploiting the CVE-2021-26855 SSRF vulnerability or by compromising a legitimate admin’s credentials.



# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/42434924/In-the-Wild%20Exploits%20Seen%20Targeting%20MS%20Exchange%20CVEs.txt?version=2&modificationDate=1614724559932&api=v2)

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/42434924/In-the-Wild%20Exploits%20Seen%20Targeting%20MS%20Exchange%20IoCs.txt?version=3&modificationDate=1619489999367&api=v2)



# Protection

  * A complete list of Yara Rules can be found here: [ Yara Rules.txt](/download/attachments/42434924/In-the-Wild%20Exploits%20Seen%20Targeting%20MS%20Exchange%20Yara%20Rules.txt?version=2&modificationDate=1619489938221&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * [https://www.volexity.com/blog/2021/03/02/active-exploitation-of-microsoft-exchange-zero-day-vulnerabilities](https://www.volexity.com/blog/2021/03/02/active-exploitation-of-microsoft-exchange-zero-day-vulnerabilities)/

In-the-Wild Exploits Seen Targeting MS Exchange
New reports from Volexity and Microsoft detail an in-the-wild exploit being seen across multiple industries. Microsoft has released out of band updates to address the vulnerabilities.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

## ***UPDATE April 12, 2021***

CISA has provided an analysis of further samples of the China Chopper Webshell, which may be in use against Microsoft Exchange servers. Further information can be found in the Reference section below or [here](https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-102a).

## ***UPDATE March 25, 2021***

  
US-CISA and DHS have issued additional information about China Chopper Webshells which may be in use against Microsoft Offline Address books. These latest samples are inline with other samples previously examined. There are subtle differences in the code used for the creation of the shells. We recommend you read the reports and apply any and all patches available as well as examining your environment for any evidence of these or any other potentially nefarious webshells. Further information can be found in the Reference section below or [here](https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-084a) and [here](https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-084b). 

## ***UPDATE March 16, 2021***

  
Yesterday, Microsoft released a one-click Exchange On-Premises Mitigation tool. This tool is not designed to replace patching of vulnerable servers, it is merely meant to help those who've not yet had opportunity to patch these systems. This tool includes the latest Microsoft Safety Scanner and will mitigate CVE-2021-26855. The tool performs three operations: mitigate against current known attacks using CVE-2021-26855 using a URL Rewrite configuration, scan the Exchange Server using the Microsoft Safety Scanner, and attempt to reverse any changes made by identified threats. Further detailed guidance can be found in the Reference section below or [here](https://msrc-blog.microsoft.com/2021/03/15/one-click-microsoft-exchange-on-premises-mitigation-tool-march-2021/).

## ***UPDATE March 15, 2021***

  
The Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency released 7 malware analysis reports on webshells seen throughout its investigation. The findings indicate that each webshell observed also contains some form of backdoor as well as the webshells themselves. These webshells could, if implanted, allow attackers to execute JavaScript code on compromised servers. The reports are linked in the Reference section or just below this update.

  * [https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-072a](https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-072a)

  * [https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-072b](https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-072b)

  * [https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-072c](https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-072c)

  * [https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-072d](https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-072d)

  * [https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-072e](https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-072e)

  * [https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-072f](https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-072f)

  * [https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-072g](https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-072g)




## ***UPDATE March 12, 2021***

The Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) and Cybersecurity Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) have published a joint advisory detailing further information on the Microsoft Exchange Server attacks. According to the FBI and CISA, multiple nation-state actors and cybercriminals are likely exploiting the previously mentioned vulnerabilities. Should these attackers successfully exploit these vulnerabilities, they have the ability to gain persistence and control of the affected network. The possibility exists of the sale of compromised network access on the dark web. These networks can contain valuable research, technology, PII, and sensitive information from multiple sectors. The agencies assess the attackers will continue to exploit these vulnerabilities in order to steal information, encrypt data for ransom, or, in a worst case scenario, execute a destructive attack against compromised networks. The report also notes the types of industries currently or previously having seen attacks as "local governments, academic institutions, non-governmental organizations, and business entities in multiple industry sectors, including agriculture, biotechnology, aerospace, defense, legal services, power utilities, and pharmaceutical". Additionally, this targeting is consistent with targeting activity by Chinese cyber actors. Further details can be found in the link located within the reference section below or [here](https://www.ic3.gov/Media/News/2021/210310.pdf). 

## ***UPDATE #3 March 10, 2021***

WeLiveSecurity is reporting that at least 10 APT groups are attacking the vulnerabilities in Exchange. Among the APTs and malware listed are: LuckyMouse, Tick, Winnti Group, Calypso, Websiic, Tonto Team (CactusPete), Mikroceen (Vicious Panda), ShadowPad (unconfirmed), "Opera" Cobalt Strike, and DLTMiner. There is also speculation that some of the ATPs and threat actors may be piggybacking off webshells left by other APTs who may have already successfully exploited the vulnerable servers, though this is unconfirmed. Further information can be found in the link located within the Reference section below or [here](https://www.welivesecurity.com/2021/03/10/exchange-servers-under-siege-10-apt-groups/). 

## ***UPDATE #2 March 10, 2021***

Recorded Future reports on the evolution of the exploitation of the Microsoft Exchange Server vulnerabilities. Indications are that the exploitation attempts are coming from multiple groups simultaneously. Some of the groups mentioned in the article are state-sponsored APTs while others are simply cybercrime groups. One such group has been using the flaws to insert webshells to install DLTminer malware for the purposes of cryptomining. According to the article, "the ever-increasing number of attackers had moved into indiscriminate mass-exploitation against any Exchange server left connected to the internet without a patch, with the number of hacked servers being estimated in the realm of “astronomical” and tens of thousands, per US government sources. Security agencies have observed intrusions in the Netherlands, Czech Republic, and Norway in addition to the U.S. Other, larger countries have issued national security alerts to patch on-premises servers as soon as possible in order to avoid exploitation. There is speculation these countries may already be seeing attempts to exploit the vulnerabilities. At present, at least 1,500 infected systems have been seen by at least one security firm. Further details can be found in the article located within the Reference section or [here](https://therecord.media/attacks-on-exchange-servers-expand-from-nation-states-to-cryptominers/). 

## ***UPDATE #1 March 10, 2021***

Palo Alto's Unit 42 has released additional details on the China Chopper webshells and changes made to the shell during the exploitation of these vulnerabilities. Additionally, a Yara rule was released which helps to identify templates used for the China Chopper webshell as they exist in OAB configurations. This webshell is injected into a pre-existing OAB ASPX page. Researchers warn that any on-premises Exchange servers exposed to the internet should assume scanning is/has been accomplished numerous times. Indications from analysis show several clusters of threat actors are continuously attempting to exploit vulnerable servers. Further details can be found in the link located within the Reference section below or [here](https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/china-chopper-webshell/).

## ***UPDATE March 9, 2021***

Microsoft has released emergency updates for unsupported versions of Microsoft Exchange. Though unsupported, the company released these updates to address only the newest vulnerabilities as stated in this document. Further information can be found in the link below or [here](https://www.zdnet.com/article/microsoft-exchange-attacks-now-microsoft-rushes-out-a-patch-for-these-unsupported-exchange-servers-too/).

  


***UPDATE March 8, 2021***

FireEye has [published](https://www.fireeye.com/blog/threat-research/2021/03/detection-response-to-exploitation-of-microsoft-exchange-zero-day-vulnerabilities.html) analysis of the processes and inner workings of the vulnerabilities and related malware. Researchers have identified a web shell named help.aspx which contained code to help identify endpoint security products such as FireEye xAgent, CarbonBlack, and CrowdStrike Falcon. A second web shell named iisstart.aspx was seen approximately twenty days after the first web shell. This web shell, partially obfuscated, has more capabilities, functions, and is generally more advanced than the previous shell. This particular version allowed for the execution of arbitrary commands and the upload, deletion, and viewing of files. The analysis confirmed the files indicate the signature match for China Chopper. One particular command seen was the attempt to delete the administrator user from Exchange Organizations administrators group. The team verified Microsoft's information regarding the post-exploitation activity such as credential theft by dumping LSASS, the use of 7-zip compression for exfiltration, the use of Exchange PowerShell Snap-ins for the exfiltration of mailbox data, and the use of offensive tools such as Covenant, Nishang, and PowerCat for remote access. Finally, analysis revealed the ever changing naming of the web shell on each intrusion. We will provide further details as they are presented.

  


***UPDATE March 6, 2021***

According to CISA, Microsoft has released (CISA and Microsoft links below) an updated [script](https://github.com/microsoft/CSS-Exchange/tree/main/Security) for scanning the Exchange log files for IoCs for the vulnerabilities. We recommend running the script against any Exchange servers within your organization as soon as possible.

## ***UPDATE March 5, 2021***

IBM Security family PAM Content Update [4103.03231](https://exchange.xforce.ibmcloud.com/xpu/XPU%204103.03231) contains 4 new events, 0 new moderate event responses, and 0 new aggressive event responses. The new signatures, HTTP_Exchange_Cookie_Auth_Bypass, HTTP_Exchange_VirtualDirectory_Cmd_Injection, HTTP_Exchange_Cookie_SSFR, and HTTP_Exchange_VirtualDirectory_Upload, apply to the Microsoft Exchange vulnerabilities, CVE-2021-26855, CVE-2021-26858, and CVE-2021-27065.

## ***UPDATE #3 March 3, 2021***

CISA has published an alert, AA21-062A, regarding the Exchange vulnerabilities. The URL is located in the Reference section below.

## ***UPDATE #2 March 3, 2021***

An URL has been added to the Reference section for the Dubex report on the exploit.

## ***UPDATE March 3, 2021***

A blog from Rapid7 contains more details on this zero-day attack and how to address the issues allowing the zero-day to proliferate. In the blog, researchers reveal the tools employed in the attacks to be China Chopper Webshell and ProcDump being used against LSASS. Additionally, the team provided a link for the proof-of-concept code that allows for the exposure to the public internet. 

## ***Original Post - Update March 2, 2021***

Multiple zero-day exploits targeting vulnerabilities in on-premises versions Microsoft Exchange servers have been used in attacks in the wild. Microsoft describe the attacks as limited and targeted. According to a report from Volexity, the attacks appear to have started as early as January 6, 2021. The report notes that the attackers are using a remotely exploitable server-side request forgery (SSRF) vulnerability (CVE-2021-26855) to steal the contents of a victim's mailbox. The vulnerability does not require authentication. If the Exchange server is a single machine, the attacker must know the targeted user's domain SID in order to access the mailbox. In multiple server configurations, the attacker only needs the email address of the intended victim. In both cases, the attacker must know the FQDN of the internal Exchange servers. The vulnerability can be exploited by sending a specially crafted HTTP POST request to the server with an XML SOAP payload. Volexity has also observed this attack being conducted on OWA. In addition, Volexity reports that the attackers chained the SSRF vulnerability with a remote code execution vulnerability in the Exchange servers and installed webshells on the compromised servers.

Microsoft, Volexity, and Dubex have collaborated on this research and attribute the activity to HAFNIUM, a Chinese state-sponsored group. Victimology and TTPs as the basis for attribution. According to Microsoft, HAFNIUM has primarily targeted entities in the United States. The targeted industry sectors include defense contractors, higher education institutions, infectious disease researchers, law firms, NGOs, and policy think tanks. HAFNIUM typically uses leased virtual private servers (VPS) located in the United States to conduct operations.

Microsoft has issued emergency out of band updates to address these critical vulnerabilities in Exchange. Microsoft is urging customers to update on-premises systems immediately. In keeping with Microsoft's recommendation, IBM also urges customers to immediately patch affected systems.

  * [CVE-2021-26855](https://msrc.microsoft.com/update-guide/vulnerability/CVE-2021-26855) is a server-side request forgery (SSRF) vulnerability in Exchange which allowed the attacker to send arbitrary HTTP requests and authenticate as the Exchange server.
  * [CVE-2021-26857](https://msrc.microsoft.com/update-guide/vulnerability/CVE-2021-26857) is an insecure deserialization vulnerability in the Unified Messaging service. Insecure deserialization is where untrusted user-controllable data is deserialized by a program. Exploiting this vulnerability gave HAFNIUM the ability to run code as SYSTEM on the Exchange server. This requires administrator permission or another vulnerability to exploit.
  * [CVE-2021-26858](https://msrc.microsoft.com/update-guide/vulnerability/CVE-2021-26858) is a post-authentication arbitrary file write vulnerability in Exchange. If HAFNIUM could authenticate with the Exchange server then they could use this vulnerability to write a file to any path on the server. They could authenticate by exploiting the CVE-2021-26855 SSRF vulnerability or by compromising a legitimate admin’s credentials.
  * [CVE-2021-27065](https://msrc.microsoft.com/update-guide/vulnerability/CVE-2021-27065) is a post-authentication arbitrary file write vulnerability in Exchange. If HAFNIUM could authenticate with the Exchange server then they could use this vulnerability to write a file to any path on the server. They could authenticate by exploiting the CVE-2021-26855 SSRF vulnerability or by compromising a legitimate admin’s credentials.



# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/42434924/In-the-Wild%20Exploits%20Seen%20Targeting%20MS%20Exchange%20CVEs.txt?version=2&modificationDate=1614724559932&api=v2)

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/42434924/In-the-Wild%20Exploits%20Seen%20Targeting%20MS%20Exchange%20IoCs.txt?version=3&modificationDate=1619489999367&api=v2)



# Protection

  * A complete list of Yara Rules can be found here: [ Yara Rules.txt](/download/attachments/42434924/In-the-Wild%20Exploits%20Seen%20Targeting%20MS%20Exchange%20Yara%20Rules.txt?version=2&modificationDate=1619489938221&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Supply Chain Compromise by a Darkside Affiliate
A report from Mandiant provides information on a supply chain compromise carried out by a Darkside affiliate Mandiant refers to as UNC2465.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Supply Chain Compromise by a Darkside Affiliate
A report from Mandiant provides information on a supply chain compromise carried out by a Darkside affiliate Mandiant refers to as UNC2465.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Ransomware, Supply Chain Compromise




# Overview

While Darkside has reportedly ceased operations, at least some of its affiliates have not. During an investigation of an intrusion, Mandiant found that that the initial infection vector was a Trojanized application installer. The installer was downloaded from the legitimate site of a security camera PVR vendor. While Mandiant reported the compromised installers to the vendor, the attackers may also have been able to replace the Trojanized installers. The installer was downloaded in a .zip file and, when extracted and executed, created two files. One was a clean copy of the installer, which functioned normally. The other file launched a URL using the command line. The URL resulted in two more files that leveraged VBScript and PowerShell and attempted to download the SMOKEDHAM dropper. The dropper is used to install the SMOKEDHAM backdoor. Aside from providing the attackers the ability to execute commands on the victim system, it also logs keystrokes and uploads the captured data to a C&C server every five minutes. SMOKEDHAM was also observed downloading UltraVNC and an NGROK utility. UltraVNC was used to download and install a dropper for Cobalt Strike. Data was dumped from the LSASS process and the attackers were observed using RDP to move laterally to other systems. In this case, the attackers were prevented from installing the ransomware payload. Mandiant suspects that few victims were compromised via the Trojanized installers and attributes the attack to the Darkside affiliate UNC2465. Further details are available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.fireeye.com/blog/threat-research/2021/06/darkside-affiliate-supply-chain-software-compromise.html>

While Darkside has reportedly ceased operations, at least some of its affiliates have not. During an investigation of an intrusion, Mandiant found that that the initial infection vector was a Trojanized application installer. The installer was downloaded from the legitimate site of a security camera PVR vendor. While Mandiant reported the compromised installers to the vendor, the attackers may also have been able to replace the Trojanized installers. The installer was downloaded in a .zip file and, when extracted and executed, created two files. One was a clean copy of the installer, which functioned normally. The other file launched a URL using the command line. The URL resulted in two more files that leveraged VBScript and PowerShell and attempted to download the SMOKEDHAM dropper. The dropper is used to install the SMOKEDHAM backdoor. Aside from providing the attackers the ability to execute commands on the victim system, it also logs keystrokes and uploads the captured data to a C&C server every five minutes. SMOKEDHAM was also observed downloading UltraVNC and an NGROK utility. UltraVNC was used to download and install a dropper for Cobalt Strike. Data was dumped from the LSASS process and the attackers were observed using RDP to move laterally to other systems. In this case, the attackers were prevented from installing the ransomware payload. Mandiant suspects that few victims were compromised via the Trojanized installers and attributes the attack to the Darkside affiliate UNC2465. Further details are available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.fireeye.com/blog/threat-research/2021/06/darkside-affiliate-supply-chain-software-compromise.html>

I have encountered the following information: New Threat Group - UNC3524
Mandiant has published a report that examines the TTPs of a newly discovered threat group they refer to as UNC3524.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware, Espionage.
  *  **Targets:** Employees involved in acquisitions, corporate development, mergers, IT security staff, or that deal with large corporate transactions.
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** QUIETEXIT
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Collection of emails.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

UNC3524 is a newly discovered threat group that focuses on collecting the emails of its targets. According to a report from Mandiant, the group targets employees working in the fields of acquisitions, corporate development, mergers, IT security staff, or that deal with large corporate transactions. Mandiant notes that UNC3524's targeting suggests a financial motivation, the level of tradecraft displayed by the group is more suggestive of an espionage actor. How UNC3524 gain their initial access to an organization is, at the time Mandiant's report was published, unknown. Once the group has gained access, they typically install a backdoor named QUIETEXIT on devices such as load balancers, SAN arrays, and wireless access point controllers. QUIETEXIT establishes an SSH connection to a C&C server, and once connected QUIETEXIT provides the functionality of an SSH server. It is also capable of setting up a SOCKS tunnel that allows the attackers to execute their tools on their local system thus leaving no traces of tools on the compromised systems. The C&C servers used by the group are a botnet of compromised IoT devices. The IoT devices are typically legacy conference room camera systems from a specific vendor. The IP addresses of the C&C servers are typically obtained using Dynamic DNS providers though an IP address and port can be specified in the command-line arguments used when executing QUIETEXIT. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://www.mandiant.com/resources/unc3524-eye-spy-email>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Tactics and Techniques:**

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
T1583.003 - Virtual Private Server  
T1584 - Compromise Infrastructure  
T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
T1608.003 - Install Digital Certificate  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
T1059.003 - Windows Command Shell  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1037 - Boot or Logon Initialization Scripts  
T1037.004 - RC Scripts  
T1098 - Account Manipulation  
T1098.001 - Additional Cloud Credentials  
T1505 - Server Software Component  
T1505.003 - Web Shell  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1003 - OS Credential Dumping  
T1003.004 - LSA Secrets  
T1003.006 - DCSync  
T1111 - Two-Factor Authentication Interception  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1012 - Query Registry  
T1016 - System Network Configuration Discovery  
T1049 - System Network Connections Discovery  
T1057 - Process Discovery  
T1518 - Software Discovery  
  
 **Lateral Movement - TA0008**  
T1021 - Remote Services  
T1021.004 - SSH  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1114 - Email Collection  
T1114.002 - Remote Email Collection  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1090 - Proxy  
T1090.003 - Multi-hop Proxy  
T1095 - Non-Application Layer Protocol  
T1572 - Protocol Tunneling  
T1573 - Encrypted Channel  
T1573.002 - Asymmetric Cryptography  
  


 **Mitigations:**

 **M1015:** Active Directory Configuration - Configure Active Directory to prevent use of certain techniques; use SID Filtering, etc.  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1020:** SSL/TLS Inspection - Break and inspect SSL/TLS sessions to look at encrypted web traffic for adversary activity.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1024:** Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
 **M1025:** Privileged Process Integrity - Protect processes with high privileges that can be used to interact with critical system components through use of protected process light, anti-process injection defenses, or other process integrity enforcement measures.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1027:** Password Policies - Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1032:** Multi-factor Authentication - Use two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate to a system; such as username and password in addition to a token from a physical smart card or token generator.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1035:** Limit Access to Resource Over Network - Prevent access to file shares, remote access to systems, unnecessary services. Mechanisms to limit access may include use of network concentrators, RDP gateways, etc.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1041:** Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1043:** Credential Access Protection - Use capabilities to prevent successful credential access by adversaries; including blocking forms of credential dumping.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1048:** Application Isolation and Sandboxing - Restrict execution of code to a virtual environment on or in transit to an endpoint system.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1056:** Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Silver Sparrow - macOS Malware With No Current Payload
An unusual piece of macOS malware has been reported by Red Canary. The malware is named Silver Sparrow, has infected almost 30,000 systems but, as of yet, has no actual payload.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Silver Sparrow is macOS malware, two versions of which have been analysed by Red Canary. The first version surfaced in August 2020, the second version appearing a month later. Both versions contained Mach-O binaries. However, the Mach-O binary in the second version is compiled for the Intel x86_64 and M1 ARM64 architectures. Silver Sparrow has been distributed using malvertising with links that lead to malicious DMG or PKG installers. Between them, the two versions of Silver Sparrow are reported to have infected almost 30,000 systems. Once installed, Silver Sparrow contacts its C&C every hour. As of yet, no actual payload is known to have been delivered to the infected systems. Silver Sparrow can completely remove itself from infected systems. While the actual purpose of Silver Sparrow is unknown, and there is no current payload, the operators of Silver Sparrow could issue instructions to the malware at a time of their choosing. Further details are available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://redcanary.com/blog/clipping-silver-sparrows-wings/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Phorpiex Botnet Now Running Without C2 Server
Phorpiex malware was briefly down this summer, but has since returned in a more sophisticated form, according to a report by Check Point Research. The new variant is able to run as a Peer-to-Peer network in the event of its C2 servers being shut down, increasing the botnet resiliency.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Cryptomining
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Phorpiex/Twizt
  *  **Targets:** Cryptocurrency Owners
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Crpyto-clipping, Malware Dropping



# Overview

Check Point Researchers have reported on a new variant of the old cryptominer known as Phorpiex. Earlier this year, the owners of this malware commented that they were shutting down operations and putting the source code up for sale. Less than two weeks after this statement, Phorpiex reappeared with some new functionality. It is unclear whether it was sold and redeveloped or if the original threat actors decided to continue development. The main difference was that this new variant was able to function without any C2 servers, operating in a peer-to-peer mode to communicate with other infected machines. The malware also appears to be more successful at using the crypto-stealing technique known as crypto-clipping. This technique replaces any copied cryptocurrency address with the attacker's wallet when pasted. Since the addresses are long and random, the victim doesn't notice the replacement and authorizes the payment to the victim's wallet. The total value of currency stolen this way is almost half a million dollars, with the largest single transaction totaling 26 Etherium. The malware also has a new method for communicating with the C2 server. It uses a custom, encrypted protocol which uses a hash value to guarantee message integrity, which is more sophisticated than the original malware used. This new variant is called 'Twizt' and is steadily increasing in prevalence with most infections occurring in African countries. There is some evidence the operators of this malware are Ukrainian, as the malware will not run on machines in Ukraine. Further information is available from the links in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74056390/Phorpiex%20Botnet%20Now%20Running%20Without%20C2%20Server%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1640254355709&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking (M1038). 
  * Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior (M1040). 



# References

  * <https://research.checkpoint.com/2021/phorpiex-botnet-is-back-with-a-new-twizt-hijacking-hundreds-of-crypto-transactions/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1053 - Scheduled Task/Job  
T1129 - Shared Modules  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1056 - Input Capture  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
T1056 - Input Capture  
T1115 - Clipboard Data  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1008 - Fallback Channels  
T1571 - Non-Standard Port  
T1573 - Encrypted Channel  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1496 - Resource Hijacking

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Chrome Browser Updates - April 20 2021 - Exploit in the Wild
Google has released updates to its Chrome web browser for Windows, Mac, and Linux that provides fixes for five vulnerabilities. An exploit for one of the vulnerabilities is reported to exist in the wild.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Chrome Browser Updates - April 20 2021 - Exploit in the Wild
Google has released updates to its Chrome web browser for Windows, Mac, and Linux that provides fixes for five vulnerabilities. An exploit for one of the vulnerabilities is reported to exist in the wild.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

Google has released an update, version 90.0.4430.85, to its Chrome web browser for Windows, Mac, and Linux that provides fixes for five vulnerabilities. An exploit for one of the vulnerabilities (CVE-2021-21224) is reported to exist in the wild. Google has rated the vulnerabilities as High. The potential impact from successful exploitation of the most serious of the vulnerabilities is the remote execution of arbitrary code. Further information is available from the release notes which are linked in the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * CVE-2021-21222, CVE-2021-21223, CVE-2021-21224, CVE-2021-21225, CVE-2021-21226 




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://chromereleases.googleblog.com/2021/04/stable-channel-update-for-desktop_20.html>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: New RAT malware gets commands via Discord, has ransomware feature
Threat actors have exploited Discord by utilizing it as a C2 server for the remote access Trojan known as “Abaddon." What worries analysts and researchers alike is a ransomware feature is being developed for the malware.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: New RAT malware gets commands via Discord, has ransomware feature
Threat actors have exploited Discord by utilizing it as a C2 server for the remote access Trojan known as “Abaddon." What worries analysts and researchers alike is a ransomware feature is being developed for the malware.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Ransomware




# Overview

It was discovered by the MalwareHunterTeam that Discord, a multi-platform communication app designed specifically for gamers, was being exploited by threat actors leveraging it as a C2 server for an enhanced RAT. According to the analyst, when activated, the RAT automatically compromises the following: saved credit card information, credentials, and system information, such as country, IP address, and hardware information. Threat actors then initiate the Discord command and control server to command the malware to exhaust utilization, steal data, and frequently monitor their collection of infected PCs for new data and executable functions involving the malware. While assessing the current developments of this new malware, researchers discovered additional functionality, like the ability to encrypt and decrypt files, further emphasizing on the success and potential of this new malware. For more information, see the blog post in the Reference section.

# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/new-rat-malware-gets-commands-via-discord-has-ransomware-feature/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: APT-C-59 Targets East and Southeast Asian Organizations
APT-C-59 is a threat group operating out of China and carrying out attacks against government, research, media, and medical organizations in East and Southeast Asia. 360 Threat Intelligence Center has published a blog post detailing the group's tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs).
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** APT, Backdoor
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** APT-C-59
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Unnamed backdoor
  *  **Targets:** East and Southeast Asian government, research, media, and medical organizations
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Phishing emails, exploitation of browser vulnerabilities, malicious packages
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Remote command execution



# Overview

360 Threat Intelligence Center has published a blog post detailing the tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) associated with APT-C-59, a Chinese APT targeting organizations in East and Southeast Asia. The group has used various methods of initial access, starting with phishing links that exploit browser vulnerabilities, but since moving to Trojanized installation packages. Regardless of the initial infection vector, a malicious backdoor is eventually installed on the victim host. It first collections system information, which is sent to a C2 server that, in return, provides commands to be executed. Possible commands include those to create persistence via a scheduled task, perform a screenshot, or execute files. A reverse shell capable of executing commands via cmd.exe was also discovered being used by the group. For more information, see the blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/68617450/APT-C-59%20Targets%20East%20and%20Southeast%20Asian%20Organizations%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1635881160930&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques (M1017).



# References

  * <https://mp.weixin.qq.com/s/WBpML3BTxFPHmBgyunmEEA>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1189 - Drive-by Compromise  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
T1566.002 - Spearphishing Link  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.003 - Windows Command Shell  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.001 - Malicious Link  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1053 - Scheduled Task/Job  
T1053.005 - Scheduled Task  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1574 - Hijack Execution Flow  
T1574.002 - DLL Side-Loading  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1113 - Screen Capture  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
T1573 - Encrypted Channel  
T1573.001 - Symmetric Cryptography
