instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Latest Attack Techniques From Qbot
Check Point published their latest findings on a ten year old banking Trojan called Qbot. They indicated that, despite its age, Qbot is still being improved and is still a threat.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Trojan, Campaigns



# Overview

Check Point examines the new techniques that a decade old banking Trojan called Qbot (aka Qakbot and Pinkslipbot) is exhibiting. The malware is capable of stealing information such as passwords, emails, credit card information, and more. It can also be used as a downloader for other malware, including ransomware packages. Commands from the bot controller can cause Qbot, on the infected system, to connect and make financial transactions with the victim's credentials. Additionally, Qbot can use stolen emails to send replies to other potential victims, making such replies appear legitimate. In July, Check Point observed an Emotet campaign that dropped a newer copy of Qbot on victims' systems. August saw a new malspam campaign distributing Qbot. The majority of the victims in this campaign resided in the US and Europe, with government, military, and manufacturing industries being the most targeted. The infection vector is an email, possibly an email thread stolen from a previous victim, with a malicious attachment or URL. A Visual Basic Script (VBS) stored in a malicious archive is used to start the infection process. Using VBS as a standalone script is relatively new (since April 2020) for malware. Normally, VBS is used as the macro in a weaponized Word document for installation. The VBS file is padded with NULL bytes to make it larger than 35 megabytes, a figure most sandboxes ignore. Once activated, the script sleeps for a period of time, also in an attempt to bypass sandbox environments. Obfuscation is used, as well as a number of anti-virtual machine and anti-debugging techniques, to avoid detection. Persistence is gained through registry keys and a scheduled task. For full technical details, please visit the link in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/28379390/Latest%20Attack%20Techniques%20From%20Qbot%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1598562243434&api=v2)



# Protection

  * Yara Rules can be found here: [ Yara.txt](/download/attachments/28379390/Latest%20Attack%20Techniques%20From%20Qbot%20Yara.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1598562282998&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://research.checkpoint.com/2020/exploring-qbots-latest-attack-methods/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: German Users Targeted with Gootkit Banker or REvil Ransomware
A Gootkit campaign in Germany led Malwarebytes researchers to discover a complex malware loader being used to deliver both Gootkit and REvil.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Ransomware




Overview

Malwarebytes published a blog post analyzing a malware loader targeting German users with Gootkit and REvil payloads. The loader script was hosted on compromised sites such that if visitors matched certain criteria, a download link would be injected into the page in the form of a fake forum post. Clicking this link would download a ZIP containing a malicious script. This malicious script is responsible for connecting to a C2 from which it downloads a second-stage JavaScript. The second-stage then executes an embedded payload. At this point, one of two techniques is implemented. With the first method, a hexadecimal-encoded PE is stored in the Registry and executed to eventually load the REvil ransomware. Alternatively, a base64-encoded payload stored in the Registry executes a series of PowerShell scripts that eventually lead to the installation of the Gootkit banking Trojan. For more information, see the Malwarebytes blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.malwarebytes.com/threat-analysis/2020/11/german-users-targeted-with-gootkit-banker-or-revil-ransomware/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: HMRC Phishing Scam Abuses Mail Service
A security researcher named TheAnalyst discovered and shared information about a continuous HMRC phishing campaign leveraging SendGrid’s features to support malicious attacks, according to BleepingComputer.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: HMRC Phishing Scam Abuses Mail Service
A security researcher named TheAnalyst discovered and shared information about a continuous HMRC phishing campaign leveraging SendGrid’s features to support malicious attacks, according to BleepingComputer.

# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

Threat actors continue to abuse and exploit the legitimate email delivery service SendGrid to collect sensitive credentials. By utilizing some of SendGrid’s features, threat actors are able to bypass spam filters and email security products. The malicious webpages in a specific campaign analyzed by BleepingComputer mimic the HMRC and GOV.UK appearance, requesting information such as: UTR number, NINo number, passport number and expiry dates, driving license number, name, DOB and, address information. According to the information BleepingComputer received, what made this campaign so successful was the spoofed “From email” field with an outgoing address likely designed to trick the victim. For more information, see the BleepingComputer article in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/hmrc-phishing-scam-abuses-mail-service-to-bypass-spam-filters/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Preventive Security Service and Arid Viper Activity
After taking action against hackers in Palestine, Facebook has released their findings on the two threat groups behind the malicious activity.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Preventive Security Service and Arid Viper Activity
After taking action against hackers in Palestine, Facebook has released their findings on the two threat groups behind the malicious activity.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Cyber Espionage, Influence Operations




# Overview

Facebook published a blog post detailing their findings on two distinct threat groups operating in Palestine. The first is the Preventive Security Service (PSS), the Palestinian Authority’s internal intelligence organization. The group leveraged social engineering to convince victims to download malware to their devices. The malware used by the group included low-sophistication custom malware and open-source malware tools. Their Android malware masquerades as a chat application and collects device metadata that will be exfiltrated to Firebase. SpyNote was also used for remote device access and call monitoring. On Windows, the NJRat and HWorm malware families were used. Lastly, fictitious personas on social media were used for social engineering. Arid Viper is an APT in Palestine. Infrastructure leveraged by the group is tied to iOS and Android malware, phishing campaigns, and C2 servers. The group has built a sophisticated iOS surveillanceware that can be installed on non-jailbroken devices and uses a public jailbreak for escalating privileges. It was distributed as part of a fully functional chat application. Micropasia was used on Windows, while malware families similar to FrozenCell and VAMP were used on Android devices. Facebook released a full report detailing Arid Viper's campaign and the malware used. For more information, see the blog post and report linked to in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://about.fb.com/news/2021/04/taking-action-against-hackers-in-palestine/>

  * <https://about.fb.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Technical-threat-report-Arid-Viper-April-2021.pdf>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Compromised Docker Hub Accounts Abused for TeamTNT Cryptomining
TeamTNT is known for targeting exposed Docker REST APIs in order to carry out cryptomining campaigns. Trend Micro published a blog post detailing a recent TeamTNT campaign using compromised Docker Hub accounts to spread host their malicious containers.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Compromised Docker Hub Accounts Abused for TeamTNT Cryptomining
TeamTNT is known for targeting exposed Docker REST APIs in order to carry out cryptomining campaigns. Trend Micro published a blog post detailing a recent TeamTNT campaign using compromised Docker Hub accounts to spread host their malicious containers.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Cryptominer
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** TeamTNT
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Malicious scripts, cryptominer
  *  **Targets:** Docker servers
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Exposed Docker REST API
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Cryptomining, lateral movement



# Overview

Trend Micro published a blog post analyzing a recent TeamTNT campaign abusing Docker Hub for their malicious activities. They begin by creating a container on a remote host via exposed Docker REST APIs. This container is retrieved from Docker Hub, via accounts either compromised or owned by TeamTNT. Upon deployment these Docker images execute a malicious script that installs various tools to be used for post-compromise activities. These include tools for lateral movement, such as masscan and zmap. Ultimately, TeamTNT will carry out their goal of installing a cryptocurrency miner in order to turn a profit. During these attacks, the threat actors carry out container escapes to gain access to the host system. Persistence is established by adding new SSH key pairs to the authorized_keys file. Trend Micro reported the abused accounts to Docker, who have since disabled them. For more information, see the Trend Micro blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/70222380/Compromised%20Docker%20Hub%20Accounts%20Abused%20for%20TeamTNT%20Cryptomining%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1636572784047&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Use multi-factor authentication wherever possible. (M1032)
  * Limit communications with the container service to local Unix sockets or remote access via SSH. Require secure port access to communicate with the APIs over TLS by disabling unauthenticated access to the Docker API and Kubernetes API Server (M1035).



# References

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/21/k/compromised-docker-hub-accounts-abused-for-cryptomining-linked-t.html>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
T1583.001 - Domains  
T1586 - Compromise Accounts  
T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
T1608.001 - Upload Malware  
T1608.002 - Upload Tool  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.004 - Unix Shell  
T1610 - Deploy Container  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1098 - Account Manipulation  
T1098.004 - SSH Authorized Keys  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1611 - Escape to Host  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1018 - Remote System Discovery  
T1613 - Container and Resource Discovery  
  
 **Lateral Movement - TA0008**  
T1021 - Remote Services  
T1021.004 - SSH  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1496 - Resource Hijacking

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: APT10 Uses Sophisticated Multi-Layered Loader in A41APT Campaign
The Kaspersky Global Research and Analysis Team (GReAT) has discovered the use of a sophisticated multi-layered loader within what's known as the A41APT campaign. They've named the loader malware, Ecipekac, based on the unique string found in the second layer of the loader. Kaspersky has high confidence that the APT10 group is behind the A41APT campaign.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, APT, RAT




# Overview

Since March 2019, Kaspersky observed an APT campaign targeting multiple industries, including the Japanese manufacturing industry and its overseas operations, that was designed to steal information. This campaign was named the A41APT campaign which is derived from the host name “DESKTOP-A41UVJV” from the attacker’s system used in the initial infection. APT10, which is also known as Red Apollo, POTASSIUM, MenuPass, CVNX, ChessMaster, Hogfish, Cicada, Snake Wine, and Stone Panda. IBM X-Force tracks the group as ITG01. The group has traditionally targeted organizations linked to Japan, and MSPs. In January 2021, Kaspersky discovered new activity from A41APT that utilized modified and updated payloads. These include a sophisticated multi-layered loader they have named "Ecipekac". There are four layers of loaders, and they observed three types of final payload. The payloads seen have been FYAnti loader for QuasarRAT, SodaMaster, and P8RAT. Further details are available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://securelist.com/apt10-sophisticated-multi-layered-loader-ecipekac-discovered-in-a41apt-campaign/101519/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: TokyoX - Previously Unknown Malware Uses DLL Side-Loading
Lab52 researchers discovered a new payload they have named "TokyoX", which is decrypted by a side-loaded DLL and executed in memory. Although this may be unrelated to other malware families, it does appear to have some similarities with PlugX in the way it is loaded.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Backdoor
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** TokyoX
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Side-loading DLL using Legitimate Executable
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Unknown 



# Overview

Lab52 has been analyzing a new sample of malware that loads what seems to be a previously unseen artifact. The researchers are unable to confirm for certain if this is a new malware family, but it doesn't appear to be related to any other malware at this stage. The initial DLL was found in a zipped folder along with a legitimate executable and an encrypted Data file. The DLL file implements the loader function for the Data file. On execution, the malware replicates to another file path and executes from there, where it creates a child process and decrypts the final payload, which the researchers are calling "TokyoX". This name comes from the fact that the decrypted payload does not start with the traditional MZ header, but instead with the string "tokyo". The DLL is executed by the legitimate executable found in the archive file. Once the payload is running, it checks for a mutex to make sure it isn't infecting a compromised system, before collecting system data and sending this to the C2. An analysis of the payload shows that it can receive six commands. These commands include local reconnaissance instructions, uploading files to the C2 server, and even a command that deletes all artifacts from the malware on the system and stops execution. At the time of writing, there is no attribution for this malware, but there are similarities to APT groups that use PlugX. Further information is available from the reports linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74056903/TokyoX%20-%20Previously%20Unknown%20Malware%20Uses%20DLL%20Side-Loading%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1642087518858&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Application control may be able to prevent the running of executables masquerading as other files (M1038).
  * Avoid encrypted archives. These are often used to bypass anti-virus protection.
  * Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior (M1040). 



# References

  * <https://lab52.io/blog/tokyox-dll-side-loading-an-unknown-artifact/>
  * <https://lab52.io/blog/tokyox-dll-side-loading-an-unknown-artifact-part-2/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1574 - Hijack Execution Flow  
T1574.002 - DLL Side-Loading  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1574 - Hijack Execution Flow  
T1574.002 - DLL Side-Loading  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1036 - Masquerading  
T1564 - Hide Artifacts  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1007 - System Service Discovery  
T1016 - System Network Configuration Discovery  
T1016.001 - Internet Connection Discovery  
T1057 - Process Discovery  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Moobot Targets Hikvision Vulnerability
Analysis of malware exploiting a Hikvision vulnerability (CVE-2021-36260) led Fortinet researchers to uncover a Moobot campaign abusing the vulnerability to distribute its payload.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Moobot Targets Hikvision Vulnerability
Analysis of malware exploiting a Hikvision vulnerability (CVE-2021-36260) led Fortinet researchers to uncover a Moobot campaign abusing the vulnerability to distribute its payload.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Botnet
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Moobot
  *  **Targets:** Hikvision devices
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Exploitation of vulnerable Hikvision devices (CVE-2021-36260)
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** DDoS



# Overview

Fortinet published a blog post analyzing a Moobot campaign exploiting a Hikvision vulnerability (CVE-2021-36260) for propagation. The vulnerability is due to insufficient input validation and allows an unauthenticated attacker to inject commands into requests to Hikvision products. In the case of the Moobot campaign, the exploit first removes any existing infections, then echos a payload onto the system, and finally changes commonly used administrator commands for defense evasion. The dropped payload acts as a downloader, retrieving a secondary payload from a remote server based on the identified system architecture. The researchers identified this secondary payload as the Moobot botnet malware. Once installed on a system, the malware waits for a command from its C2 server, and will ultimately carry out DDoS attacks based on the received commands. For more information, see the Fortinet blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74055955/Moobot%20Targets%20Hikvision%20Vulnerability%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1639146966181&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).



# References

  * <https://www.fortinet.com/blog/threat-research/mirai-based-botnet-moobot-targets-hikvision-vulnerability>

 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1595 - Active Scanning  
T1595.002 - Vulnerability Scanning  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.004 - Unix Shell  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1036 - Masquerading  
T1036.005 - Match Legitimate Name or Location  
T1070 - Indicator Removal on Host  
T1070.004 - File Deletion  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1498 - Network Denial of Service  
T1498.001 - Direct Network Flood

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Blackrota - A Backdoor Written in Go
Netlab 360 reports on a backdoor written in Go that is been dubbed "Blackrota". It exploits an unauthorized access vulnerability in the Docker Remote API.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Blackrota - A Backdoor Written in Go
Netlab 360 reports on a backdoor written in Go that is been dubbed "Blackrota". It exploits an unauthorized access vulnerability in the Docker Remote API.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Backdoor, Vulnerability



# Overview

Blackrota is a backdoor that exploits the Docker Remote API and its unauthorized access vulnerability according to a report by Netlab 360. At this time, Blackrota only works on Linux. Blackrota is compiled based on geacon. Geacon is a CobaltStrike Beacon written in Go. Using the CobalStrike Beacon, Blackrota can employ CobaltStrike to access and control infected hosts. The obfuscated code of BlackRota is compiled statically, meaning that all of the libraries and functions it uses are included in the final executable. This can potentially result in a very large binary file, which can be hard to reverse engineer. For more details review the link in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/33983242/Blackrota%20-%20A%20Backdoor%20Written%20in%20Go%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1606255041532&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: ITG14 Shift To Ransomware With New TTPs
IBM X-Force Threat Intelligence has published a report on ITG14 and their shift from Point-of-Sale (POS) systems to ransomware and the emergence of new TTPs for the group.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Ransomware, Phishing, VBS, PowerShell, Backdoor




# Overview

IBM X-Force Threat Intelligence has published a report on ITG14, which shares overlap with FIN7 and CARBON SPIDER, and its latest shift from Point-of-Sale (POS) systems to ransomware with new TTPs. X-Force analysts have concluded ITG14 has worked as an affiliate of the Sodinokibi (aka REvil) ransomware-as-a-service (RaaS) group as well as possibly Ryuk. Additionally, ITG14 is reportedly behind the DarkSide RaaS operation. In this change of focus, the group has shifted from highly targeted, to more indiscriminate targeting of victims. Since March 2020, the group has been using VBS loaders to download the GRIFFON JScript backdoor, the JSSLoader .NET backdoor, and PowerShell loaders called TAKEOUT, SCRAMBLELOADER, and CLEARLOADER. The change in TTPs indicates the probable use of a new underground infrastructure, malware suppliers, and cooperation with other threat groups. The switch from POS attacks to ransomware indicates a decrease in revenue from POS attacks and the opportunity for more revenue through ransomware. The full story and analysis is available to IBM X-Force Premier Threat Intelligence clients at the link below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Indicators of compromise are available to IBM X-Force Premier Threat Intelligence clients at the link below.




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * Premier Threat Intelligence clients can read more at: <https://station.trustar.co/constellation/reports/e9dc890b-33ee-47eb-b1c4-3f30a16a5918>

  * To learn more about X-Force Premier Threat Intelligence, visit: <https://www.ibm.com/security/services/threat-intelligence>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Cyrat Ransomware
Discovered by G DATA researchers, Cyrat is a new Python-based ransomware family using an abnormal encryption method.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Ransomware




# Overview

G DATA has published a blog post analyzing a new ransomware family dubbed Cyrat. The payload is combined with Python and converted to a Windows PE file with PyInstaller. Due to some dependencies related to Python, in its current state the payload will crash when run on a victim system. For the purpose of analysis, the researcher installed the required dependencies. Upon doing so, it is revealed the ransomware masquerades as a tool to fix corrupted DLLs, displaying a window with fake messages related to the discovery and repair of broken DLLs. In the background it is using the Fernet encryption scheme to encrypt user files on the system. The use of Fernet in ransomware is unusual and could cause problems in some cases as it is designed to handle small files and, thus, may exhaust a system if large files are encountered. A public RSA key downloaded from Mediafire is used to encrypt the Fernet key. A ransom note requests the victim emails the operators to obtain a Bitcoin wallet address to be used for payment. During the infection process, the ransomware performs common functionality, such as deleting volume shadow copies, disabling admin tools, and disabling recovery capabilities. Furthermore, persistence is established via the autostart folder. The researchers note the presence of checks for Linux and Darwin environments, but no code that would function properly on such systems. Based on the fact it crashes upon execution, it appears the discovered sample is an early version of the ransomware. It is likely the attackers will create new versions that fix the bugs found in this sample. For more information, see the G DATA blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.gdatasoftware.com/blog/cyrat-ransomware>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Additional Dark Caracal Indicators
Following Checkpoint's recent report on the Dark Caracal threat group, the Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) has published previously unreported indicators of compromise (IoCs) associated with the actor.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, RAT, APT




# Overview

The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) has published various indicators of compromise associated with the Dark Caracal threat group, which was recently reported on by Checkpoint. They provide a brief overview of the group, which is believed to be state-sponsored, supporting Kazakhstan and Lebanon government interests in particular. Although they were inactive for a period of time, they re-emerged in November of 2019 with new, signed versions of the Bandook malware. Checkpoint's report specifies a much broader list of target industries and countries than previously discussed. The Bandook malware used by the group is a commercially available, full-featured RAT that has been around since 2007. While monitoring the group, the EFF identified Bandook samples, command and control infrastructure, and other indicators of compromise associated with the group that were not provided in Checkpoint's reporting. For more information, see the Checkpoint blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2020/12/dark-caracal-you-missed-spot>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Children's Smartwatches Under Attack
Mnemonic reports on hidden snapshot and wiretapping capabilities they found in children's smartwatches.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Children's Smartwatches Under Attack
Mnemonic reports on hidden snapshot and wiretapping capabilities they found in children's smartwatches.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Espionage, Backdoor



# Overview

A Mnemonic report provides information about smartwatches from a Chinese manufacturer that have hidden snapshot and wiretapping capabilities installed. The backdoor provides remote and covert surveillance through wiretapping, picture taking, and location tracking. The manufacturer in question is a technology company named Qihoo 360. The Norwegian company Xplora has re-branded the device and is selling it to European and US markets. According to the article, over 350,000 of the devices have been sold globally. The backdoor is not the result of an exploitation of a vulnerability. Rather, it is part of the software initially installed on the device. Commands are sent to the device via SMS packets. For full technical details and history of past run-ins with Qihoo 360, refer to the link in the Reference section.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: CetaRAT Targeting Indian Government Agencies
While tracking the CetaRAT, Quick Heal observed an increase in targeting of Indian government agencies. Their blog post provides an anaysis of the payload.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: CetaRAT Targeting Indian Government Agencies
While tracking the CetaRAT, Quick Heal observed an increase in targeting of Indian government agencies. Their blog post provides an anaysis of the payload.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** RAT
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** SideCopy APT
  *  **Associated Payloads:** CetaRAT
  *  **Targets:** Indian government
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malicious email attachment
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data theft



# Overview

Quick Heal published a blog post analyzing the CetaRAT payload. This RAT family was first seen in use by the SideCopy APT and has recently been used increasingly in targeting of Indian government agencies. The infection chain begins with a malicious ZIP archive attached to a spear phishing email. The ZIP file downloads a remotely-hosted HTA file that results in the creation and execution of either a JavaScript or Batch file. The JavaScript file was observed creating persistence via the Startup folder, while the Batch script established persistence via a Registry Run key. In both cases Indian government-themed decoy documents were displayed to trick the user. The dropped CetaRAT payload proceeds to gather system information, which is subsequently encrypted and exfiltrated to a C2 server. The RAT is capable of executing commands to upload and download data, execute additional payloads, perform process operations, and more. For more information, see the Quick Heal blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64130338/CetaRAT%20Targeting%20Indian%20Government%20Agencies%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1634217982384&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).



# References

  * <https://blogs.quickheal.com/cetarat-apt-group-targeting-the-government-agencies/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.003 - Windows Command Shell  
T1059.007 - JavaScript  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1218 - Signed Binary Proxy Execution  
T1218.005 - Mshta  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
T1518 - Software Discovery  
T1518.001 - Security Software Discovery  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1001 - Data Obfuscation  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols

The infection chain begins with a malicious ZIP archive attached to a spear phishing email. The ZIP file downloads a remotely-hosted HTA file that results in the creation and execution of either a JavaScript or Batch file. The JavaScript file was observed creating persistence via the Startup folder, while the Batch script established persistence via a Registry Run key. In both cases Indian government-themed decoy documents were displayed to trick the user. The dropped CetaRAT payload proceeds to gather system information, which is subsequently encrypted and exfiltrated to a C2 server. The RAT is capable of executing commands to upload and download data, execute additional payloads, perform process operations, and more. For more information, see the Quick Heal blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64130338/CetaRAT%20Targeting%20Indian%20Government%20Agencies%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1634217982384&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).



# References

  * <https://blogs.quickheal.com/cetarat-apt-group-targeting-the-government-agencies/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Donot Team Campaigns and Malware
ESET has published an analysis of variants of malware used in Donot Team campaigns that ESET has named DarkMusical and Gedit.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware, Espionage.
  *  **Targets:** Government and military organizations, and individuals, located in South Asian countries.
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Various
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Spearphishing emails with weaponized documents attached.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Persistence, Lateral movement, Data collection, and exfiltration.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

Two campaigns that are attributed to the Donot Team have been analyzed by ESET. Their report notes that Donot is known for attacking government and military organizations, and individuals, located in a small number of South Asian countries, primarily Bangladesh, Nepal, Pakistan, and Sri Lanka. However, Donot may also attack the embassies of the countries they target in any location. The group, also identified as APT-C-35 and SectorE02, has been active since 2016, and its objective is espionage. Donot typically use spearphishing as the infection vector with one of three functionally different documents attached to the emails. One variant is macros is Excel, PowerPoint, and Word files which use macros to deliver the payload. Another variant is RTF documents with a .doc extension that exploit the Equation Editor vulnerability, CVE‑2017‑11882. The last variant uses RTF template injection to download another document that exploits the Equation Editor vulnerability. Of the malware analyzed in the report, the malware used in the Gedit campaign was first observed used in attacks in September 2020 with DarkMusical malware being first used in June 2021. Both are variants of the yty malware framework. In some cases, another malware framework named Jaca was used. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74057297/Donot%20Team%20Campaigns%20and%20Malware%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1642740969674&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).



# References

  * <https://www.welivesecurity.com/2022/01/18/donot-go-do-not-respawn/>

 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System

T1113 - Screen Capture  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: IBM Security Guardium Security Bulletins - October 13th, 2020
IBM has published two security bulletins addressing vulnerabilities in Apache Kafka and FasterXML jackson-databind, which are used by IBM Security Guardium.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview



Security Bulletin 6347588 addresses thirty-seven vulnerabilities in Apache Kafka which is used by IBM Security Guardium. If successfully exploited, the vulnerabilities could allow an attacker to cause denial of service conditions, carry out cross-site scripting and phishing attacks, obtain sensitive information, escalate privileges, or remotely execute arbitrary code.

Security Bulletin 6347600 addresses three vulnerabilities in FasterXML jackson-databind which is used by IBM Security Guardium. The most serious impact from successful exploitation of the vulnerabilities is the remote execution of arbitrary code.

Further details, including affected versions and available updates which address the vulnerabilities, are available from the advisories linked below.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/32145929/IBM%20Security%20Guardium%20Security%20Bulletins%20-%20October%2013th%2C%202020%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1602657269548&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.ibm.com/support/pages/node/6347588>

  * <https://www.ibm.com/support/pages/node/6347600>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Shathak Group Distributing Conti Ransomware with Trickbot
Cybereason have published the timeline of an attack beginning with a phishing email and resulting with a Conti ransomware infection.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Phishing, Ransomware
  *  **Associated Threat Actor:** Shathak (G0127), ITG23 (G0102)
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Conti (S0575), Trickbot (S0266), Cobalt Strike (S0154)
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Phishing
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Encryption, Exfiltration



# Overview

Cybereason researchers have published a profile of an attack carried out by the threat group Shathak. The threat group Shathak, also known as TA551, is an email-based malware distributor that uses phishing emails to spread malware. Shathak has spread a wide range of malware, primarily information-stealing malware, such as Ursniff and Valak, and more recently IcedID. IBM X-Force reported in October 2021 that the threat group ITG23, also known as the TrickBot Gang, had partnered with Shathak in July 2021 to distribute the TrickBot and the BazarLoader malware. The malware is distributed by the Shathak group via malicious documents such as Microsoft Word documents. These documents are stored in password-protected archive files and contain malicious macros that run when the user opens the file and enables macros. This macro then drops and executes the malware that allows the attacker to continue the attack. Other activities, such as reconnaissance, credential theft, and data exfiltration, are first carried out by the actors. The attackers then deploy a Cobalt Strike beacon before deploying Conti ransomware. This whole process takes around two days from the initial compromise. Further details are available from the links in the Reference section below.

# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking (M1038). 



# References

  * <https://www.cybereason.com/blog/threat-analysis-report-from-shatak-emails-to-the-conti-ransomware>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1598 - Phishing for Information  
T1598.002 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1047 - Windows Management Instrumentation  
T1053.005 - Scheduled Task  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1053.005 - Scheduled Task  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1112 - Modify Registry  
T1218.005 - Mshta  
T1218.010 - Regsvr32  
T1218.011 - Rundll32  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1003.001 - LSASS Memory  
T1003.003 - NTDS  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1018 - Remote System Discovery  
T1046 - Network Service Scanning  
T1087 - Account Discovery  
T1482 - Domain Trust Discovery  
  
 **Lateral Movement - TA0008**  
T1021.001 - Remote Desktop Protocol  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1048 - Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Gallium Expands Targeting With New PingPull Tool
Palo Alto's Unit 42 has analyzed a new remote access Trojan named PingPull that is being utilized by a possibly state-sponsored APT group named Gallium.
output:
Summary
=======



Threat Details
==============

* **Malware Type:** Malware, Espionage
* **Associated Threat Actors:** Gallium, aka Softcell
* **Associated Payloads:** PingPull RAT
* **Targets:** Organizations in the government, finance, and telecommunications sectors located in Africa, Europe, and Southeast Asia.
* **Initial Infection Vector:** Unspecified
* **Post-Compromise Actions:** Collection and exfiltration of information
* **Additional TTPs:**See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.

Overview
========

Gallium is a threat group that has been targeting organizations in Africa, Europe, and Southeast Asia. Gallium has historically targeted the telecommunications sector but has expanded its targeting to include the finance and government sectors. According to a report from Palo Alto's Unit42, Gallium is likely to be a Chinese state-sponsored group. The new PingPull RAT used by Gallium comes in three main variants, each of which uses one of three protocols, HTTP(S), ICMP, or raw TCP, for C&C communications. The use of ICMP helps PingPull helps hide its connections to C2 servers as few organizations monitor ICMP traffic. PingPull malware is coded in C++ and gives the threat actor the ability to execute commands and access a reverse shell on compromised hosts. Further information is available from the link in the References section below.

Indicators of Compromise
========================

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

Recommendations
===============

* For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

References
==========

* [https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/pingpull-gallium/](https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/pingpull-gallium/ "Follow link")

MITRE ATT&CK Framework
======================

**Tactics and Techniques:**

**Resource Development - TA0042**  
 T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
   T1583.004 - Server  
 T1588 - Obtain Capabilities  
   T1588.002 - Tool  

**Initial Access - TA0001**  
 T1078 - Valid Accounts  
 T1133 - External Remote Services  
 T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application  

**Execution - TA0002**  
 T1047 - Windows Management Instrumentation  
 T1053 - Scheduled Task/Job  
   T1053.005 - Scheduled Task  
 T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
   T1059.001 - PowerShell  
   T1059.003 - Windows Command Shell  

**Persistence - TA0003**  
 T1078 - Valid Accounts  
 T1136 - Create Account  
   T1136.002 - Domain Account  
 T1505 - Server Software Component  
   T1505.003 - Web Shell  
 T1574 - Hijack Execution Flow  
   T1574.002 - DLL Side-Loading  

**Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
 T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
   T1027.002 - Software Packing  
   T1027.005 - Indicator Removal from Tools  
 T1036 - Masquerading  
   T1036.003 - Rename System Utilities  
 T1550 - Use Alternate Authentication Material  
   T1550.002 - Pass the Hash  
 T1553 - Subvert Trust Controls  
   T1553.002 - Code Signing  

**Credential Access - TA0006**  
 T1003 - OS Credential Dumping  
   T1003.001 - LSASS Memory  
   T1003.002 - Security Account Manager  

**Discovery - TA0007**  
 T1016 - System Network Configuration Discovery  
 T1018 - Remote System Discovery  
 T1033 - System Owner/User Discovery  
 T1049 - System Network Connections Discovery  

**Lateral Movement - TA0008**  
 T1570 - Lateral Tool Transfer  

**Collection - TA0009**  
 T1005 - Data from Local System  
 T1074 - Data Staged  
   T1074.001 - Local Data Staging  
 T1560 - Archive Collected Data  
   T1560.001 - Archive via Utility  

**Exfiltration - TA0010**  
 T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  

**Command and Control - TA0011**  
 T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
   T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
 T1090 - Proxy  
   T1090.002 - External Proxy  
 T1105 - Ingress Tool Transfer  
 T1573 - Encrypted Channel  
   T1573.002 - Asymmetric Cryptography  

**Mitigations:**

**M1013:**  Application Developer Guidance: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.  
**M1015:**  Active Directory Configuration - Configure Active Directory to prevent use of certain techniques; use SID Filtering, etc.  
**M1016:**  Vulnerability Scanning - Vulnerability scanning is used to find potentially exploitable software vulnerabilities to remediate them.  
**M1017:**  User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
**M1018:**  User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
**M1020:**  SSL/TLS Inspection - Break and inspect SSL/TLS sessions to look at encrypted web traffic for adversary activity.  
**M1021:**  Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
**M1022:**  Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
**M1024:**  Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
**M1025:**  Privileged Process Integrity - Protect processes with high privileges that can be used to interact with critical system components through use of protected process light, anti-process injection defenses, or other process integrity enforcement measures.  
**M1026:**  Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
**M1027:**  Password Policies - Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.  
**M1028:**  Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
**M1030:**  Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
**M1031:**  Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
**M1032:**  Multi-factor Authentication - Use two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate to a system; such as username and password in addition to a token from a physical smart card or token generator.  
**M1033:**  Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
**M1035:**  Limit Access to Resource Over Network - Prevent access to file shares, remote access to systems, unnecessary services. Mechanisms to limit access may include use of network concentrators, RDP gateways, etc.  
**M1037:**  Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
**M1038:**  Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
**M1040:**  Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
**M1041:**  Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
**M1042:**  Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
**M1043:**  Credential Access Protection - Use capabilities to prevent successful credential access by adversaries; including blocking forms of credential dumping.  
**M1044:**  Restrict Library Loading - Prevent abuse of library loading mechanisms in the operating system and software to load untrusted code by configuring appropriate library loading mechanisms and investigating potential vulnerable software.  
**M1045:**  Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
**M1046:**  Boot Integrity - Use secure methods to boot a system and verify the integrity of the operating system and loading mechanisms.  
**M1047:**  Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
**M1048:**  Application Isolation and Sandboxing - Restrict execution of code to a virtual environment on or in transit to an endpoint system.  
**M1049:**  Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
**M1050:**  Exploit Protection - Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.  
**M1051:**  Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
**M1052:**  User Account Control - Configure Windows User Account Control to mitigate risk of adversaries obtaining elevated process access.  
**M1054:**  Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
**M1056:**  Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.  
**M1057:**  Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
Gallium Expands Targeting With New PingPull Tool
Palo Alto's Unit 42 has analyzed a new remote access Trojan named PingPull that is being utilized by a possibly state-sponsored APT group named Gallium.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
Summary
=======



Threat Details
==============

* **Malware Type:** Malware, Espionage
* **Associated Threat Actors:** Gallium, aka Softcell
* **Associated Payloads:** PingPull RAT
* **Targets:** Organizations in the government, finance, and telecommunications sectors located in Africa, Europe, and Southeast Asia.
* **Initial Infection Vector:** Unspecified
* **Post-Compromise Actions:** Collection and exfiltration of information
* **Additional TTPs:**See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.

Overview
========

Gallium is a threat group that has been targeting organizations in Africa, Europe, and Southeast Asia. Gallium has historically targeted the telecommunications sector but has expanded its targeting to include the finance and government sectors. According to a report from Palo Alto's Unit42, Gallium is likely to be a Chinese state-sponsored group. The new PingPull RAT used by Gallium comes in three main variants, each of which uses one of three protocols, HTTP(S), ICMP, or raw TCP, for C&C communications. The use of ICMP helps PingPull helps hide its connections to C2 servers as few organizations monitor ICMP traffic. PingPull malware is coded in C++ and gives the threat actor the ability to execute commands and access a reverse shell on compromised hosts. Further information is available from the link in the References section below.

Indicators of Compromise
========================

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

Recommendations
===============

* For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

References
==========

* [https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/pingpull-gallium/](https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/pingpull-gallium/ "Follow link")

======================

**Tactics and Techniques:**

**Resource Development - TA0042**

**Execution - TA0002**

**Persistence - TA0003**

**Defense Evasion - TA0005**

**Credential Access - TA0006**

**Discovery - TA0007**

**Lateral Movement - TA0008**

**Collection - TA0009**

**Exfiltration - TA0010**

**Command and Control - TA0011**

   T1090.002 - External Proxy  
 T1105 - Ingress Tool Transfer  
 T1573 - Encrypted Channel  
   T1573.002 - Asymmetric Cryptography  

**Mitigations:**

**M1013:**  Application Developer Guidance: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.  
**M1015:**  Active Directory Configuration - Configure Active Directory to prevent use of certain techniques; use SID Filtering, etc.  
**M1016:**  Vulnerability Scanning - Vulnerability scanning is used to find potentially exploitable software vulnerabilities to remediate them.  
**M1017:**  User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
**M1018:**  User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
**M1020:**  SSL/TLS Inspection - Break and inspect SSL/TLS sessions to look at encrypted web traffic for adversary activity.  
**M1021:**  Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
**M1022:**  Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
**M1024:**  Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
**M1025:**  Privileged Process Integrity - Protect processes with high privileges that can be used to interact with critical system components through use of protected process light, anti-process injection defenses, or other process integrity enforcement measures.  
**M1026:**  Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
**M1027:**  Password Policies - Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.  
**M1028:**  Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
**M1030:**  Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
**M1031:**  Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
**M1032:**  Multi-factor Authentication - Use two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate to a system; such as username and password in addition to a token from a physical smart card or token generator.  
**M1033:**  Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
**M1035:**  Limit Access to Resource Over Network - Prevent access to file shares, remote access to systems, unnecessary services. Mechanisms to limit access may include use of network concentrators, RDP gateways, etc.  
**M1037:**  Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
**M1038:**  Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
**M1040:**  Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
**M1041:**  Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
**M1042:**  Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
**M1043:**  Credential Access Protection - Use capabilities to prevent successful credential access by adversaries; including blocking forms of credential dumping.  
**M1044:**  Restrict Library Loading - Prevent abuse of library loading mechanisms in the operating system and software to load untrusted code by configuring appropriate library loading mechanisms and investigating potential vulnerable software.  
**M1045:**  Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
**M1046:**  Boot Integrity - Use secure methods to boot a system and verify the integrity of the operating system and loading mechanisms.  
**M1047:**  Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
**M1048:**  Application Isolation and Sandboxing - Restrict execution of code to a virtual environment on or in transit to an endpoint system.  
**M1049:**  Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
**M1050:**  Exploit Protection - Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.  
**M1051:**  Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
**M1052:**  User Account Control - Configure Windows User Account Control to mitigate risk of adversaries obtaining elevated process access.  
**M1054:**  Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
**M1056:**  Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.  
**M1057:**  Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: BlackSoul Delivered By ReconHellcat
QuoIntelligence reports on a new malware package, BlackSoul, that is being distributed by a threat-actor called ReconHellcat. The targeted campaign appears be using spear-phishing as a delivery mechanism.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Threat-Actor, Spear-Phishing, RAT



# Overview

QuoIntelligence reports on what appears to be a targeted campaign, possibly spread through the use of spear-phishing emails with a weaponized CAB file attachment. The CAB's file name is patterned after the file names one would expect in a download from the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST). The threat-actor is attempting to gain access to victims by installing the remote access Trojan, BlackSoul, on the victim system. The attachment is actually a loader that uses obfuscation techniques previously used by ReconHellcat to deliver the BlackWater malware. The loader downloads an executable and a DLL from the C2 server and then displays a legitimate document from NIST as a decoy. BlackSoul is a minimalistic RAT that accepts only a few commands. Although QuoIntelligence was unable to determine the exact targets of this campaign, they suspect, from the NIST-themed lure, the intended targets may be government related. For full technical details, please refer to the link in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/35719522/BlackSoul%20Delivered%20By%20ReconHellcat%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1610048685752&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://quointelligence.eu/2021/01/reconhellcat-uses-nist-theme-as-lure-to-deliver-new-blacksoul-malware/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: New Version of DanaBot
DanaBot briefly declined in activity after June 2020, but in October 2020 Proofpoint researchers observed its return with a new version.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Stealer




# Overview

Proofpoint has published a blog post analyzing a new version of DanaBot that appeared in October 2020, which they believe is version 4 of the malware. The sample they obtained was being distributed via crack websites that offer premium software that has supposedly been cracked to allow free access. Downloading a program from this site provides a ZIP file containing a password-protected archive, which, in turn, contains the dropper payload. This dropper is an executable that drops a stealer component that provides victim system information to the attacker. A second-stage payload is then downloaded that installs an AutoIT cryptominer and the DanaBot payload to the system. The DanaBot payload includes hardcoded configuration information, including the affiliate ID (two of which were discovered by Proofpoint), a version number, embedded hash values, C2 IPs and ports, and a Tor C2 domain. The malware can run in several alternative modes including a TOR mode, process injection mode, and a module mode. Proofpoint's analysis focuses on running mode 0, which is the main component. Available commands from the C2 response include those to get an updated list of C2 addresses, enable a stealer, change to Tor-based C2 communications, exfiltrate arbitrary information from the victim system, obtain a command shell, download and execute additional modules, and more. For more information, see the Proofpoint blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.proofpoint.com/us/blog/threat-insight/new-year-new-version-danabot>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Another LILIN DVR 0-day Used to Spread Mirai
Previously targeted by various botnets, a new 0-day vulnerability has been identified in LILIN DVR devices. 360 Netlab discovered this 0-day as part of Mirai activity and their recent blog post discusses the technical details of the vulnerability.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Exploit, Botnet




# Overview

360 Netlab published a blog post analyzing a 0-day vulnerability in LILIN DVR that was discovered being exploited by Mirai samples. Based on their findings, almost 7,000 devices remain vulnerable to this 0-day, which has since been patched by Merit LILIN. The exploit used by Mirai is leveraged in combination with default credentials for infection. Specifically, the vulnerability allows for remote code execution based on a web service that runs a command line program against provided parameters. However, one of the passed parameters is not validated, so it can be leveraged to pass a shell command of the attacker's choice that will be executed in shared memory. The patch released by Merit LILIN ensures that this vulnerable parameter includes the expected content type. It is recommended that LILIN DVR/NVR users update their devices and ensure strong login credentials are configured. For more information, see the 360 Netlab blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.netlab.360.com/another-lilin-dvr-0-day-being-used-to-spread-mirai-en/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: LogoKit Phishing Kit
Phishing kits provide an easy-to-use method of attackers to carry out phishing campaigns. RiskIQ has discovered a new phishing kit that they have dubbed "LogoKit."

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

RiskIQ has published their analysis of a new phishing kit dubbed "LogoKit." This phishing kit uses a unique methodology as compared to other phishing kits. It uses JavaScript functions that interact within the DOM to allow content and HTML form data to be dynamically altered without user interaction. It can either be used to integrate with existing HTML templates or to build fake forms. A victim is sent an email containing a customized URL. The content of the site is built using the company's logo, which is obtained from a third-party service. An AJAX request is used to exfiltrate entered credentials, at which point the victim is either redirected to the legitimate company site or is asked to provide their password again so that the attackers can perform new actions on the data. LogoKit is fully modularized and been used to target a variety of sectors with various templates, such as SharePoint, Adobe, and Microsoft login pages. By using legitimate services such as Google Firebase or Amazon's object storage to load page content, it is more difficult to block the phishing page content. Riskiq identified over 700 domains infected with LogoKit over the past month. For more information, see the RiskIQ blog post in the Reference section.

# Recommendations

  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.riskiq.com/blog/external-threat-management/logokit-phishing/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Fake COVID-19 Survey Hides Ransomware
The Threat Intelligence Team at MalwarebytesLabs recently observed phishing attacks conducted by the APT group, Silent Librarian; targeting universities and colleges worldwide. An attack against the University of British Columbia (UBC) by Silent Librarian, unusually, involved ransomware.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Fake COVID-19 Survey Hides Ransomware
The Threat Intelligence Team at MalwarebytesLabs recently observed phishing attacks conducted by the APT group, Silent Librarian; targeting universities and colleges worldwide. An attack against the University of British Columbia (UBC) by Silent Librarian, unusually, involved ransomware.

# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

The APT group, Silent Librarian are well known for targeting educational facilities with phishing campaigns used to obtain user credentials. In an attack against the University of British Columbia (UBC) which MalwarebytesLabs attributes to Silent Librarian, instead of attempting to obtain user credentials, the goal was to install the Vaggen ransomware. The attackers leveraged mailproof.com services to create legitimate email accounts that were then used to register accounts in Box.net and Dropbox. The emails sent to victims contained a link to a malicious document hosted on the free services. Analysis revealed that the malicious phishing document utilized template injection to download and execute a remote template that contained a malicious macro; as well as notified via the canarytokens.com website. The final payload was the Vaggen ransomware that encrypts user’s files and drops a ransom note on the Desktop, demanding a payment equivalent to $80 USD to be paid in Bitcoin. For more information, see the blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.malwarebytes.com/cybercrime/2020/10/fake-covid-19-survey-hides-ransomware-in-canadian-university-attack/>
